The main drawback of the planned preventive maintenance system is its poor cost-effectiveness. With fixed maintenance cycles and scopes, it often leads to unnecessary repairs of certain components—what’s known as over-maintenance. During the maintenance process, repairs are categorized into several levels and types based on the depth and breadth of the work required, including major overhauls, mid-level repairs, minor repairs, item-specific repairs, retrofits, and unplanned maintenance tasks—all determined by the scale and nature of the repair workload. (1) Overhaul: A comprehensive or fundamental restoration of the functionality of mechanical and electrical equipment, typically carried out by specialized maintenance teams within factories and mines—or at repair centers established in regions with a high concentration of industrial facilities. During an overhaul, the equipment is either fully or extensively disassembled, with a focus on repairing critical components, replacing or refurbishing parts that have lost their function or are on the verge of doing so. After the repairs, the equipment’s precision is restored to nearly its original factory specifications, while also receiving a fresh cosmetic overhaul to enhance its appearance. (2) Intermediate Overhaul. This is a level of maintenance that falls between major and minor overhauls, serving as a balanced approach to upkeep. (3) Minor Repair. This involves replacing or repairing components that have significantly worn out or are nearing failure within the maintenance interval, without addressing any underlying structural issues. It is a troubleshooting-based repair aimed at restoring functionality. The three levels—major overhaul, mid-term repair, and minor repair—objectively reflect the chronological progression of机电 equipment, making them ideally suited for implementing time-based planned preventive maintenance, a practice widely adopted by most organizations. However, these levels still require complementary repair tiers to address unforeseen maintenance needs effectively. (4) Item-based maintenance. Based on condition monitoring of mechanical and electrical equipment, this involves proactively planning repairs specifically for components or technical items that are about to fail. Item-based maintenance is conducted between major, medium, and minor overhauls—it’s a non-periodic, planned maintenance level that doesn’t follow a fixed cycle. (5) Retrofitting. This involves making localized modifications to existing mechanical and electrical equipment using new technologies, materials, structures, and processes, with the goal of enhancing its precision, functionality, productivity, and reliability. Such repairs are classified as improvement-oriented, and the extent of the work required depends on how well the original equipment’s design accommodates the retrofitting process—as well as on the specific level of performance enhancement desired for the equipment. Retrofitting is also referred to as modernization or upgrading. (6) Unscheduled Maintenance. This is a level of maintenance required for mechanical and electrical equipment due to sudden breakdowns and accidents. The fewer the number and scope of unscheduled maintenance activities, the higher the level of management.
5. Improve Maintenance Improvement maintenance, also known as corrective maintenance, refers to a type of repair that enhances the technical performance of mechanical and electrical equipment to prevent recurring failures. It involves integrating maintenance activities with technological upgrades, ensuring that after repairs, key aspects such as precision, performance, and efficiency of the equipment are improved. Rate. During operation, mechanical and electrical equipment often has certain weak links, which necessitates technical improvements and structural modifications to specific devices or components. These enhancements aim to boost reliability and elevate the overall technological level of the equipment, ultimately leading to better economic outcomes. A key feature of improvement-based maintenance is its integrated approach, frequently combined with major overhauls and targeted repairs in actual production settings. When implementing such improvement maintenance, it’s essential to systematically address and refine the mechanisms of the equipment, as well as enhance the diagnostic and repair capabilities of electromechanical systems—based on thorough inspection and analysis of component failures. 10
6 The procedure for equipment failure management is outlined below. (1) Conduct thorough education and awareness campaigns to ensure that operators and maintenance personnel voluntarily comply with relevant rules and regulations regarding operation, maintenance, inspection, etc., properly use and carefully maintain equipment, and diligently record, compile statistics, and analyze any equipment malfunctions. (2) Based on the company’s actual production conditions, equipment status, and specific features, determine the key areas for equipment failure management. (3) Use monitoring instruments and diagnostic techniques to systematically monitor critical equipment, enabling timely detection of fault indicators and deterioration. Information on equipment condition. Typically, equipment can undergo daily inspections, routine patrols, and periodic checks (including precision assessments), as well as integrity assessments—using human senses and common diagnostic tools—to closely monitor the technical status and any unusual signs in components, mechanisms, and areas prone to failure. At the same time, inspection standards should be established to clearly define the boundaries between normal operation, abnormalities, and equipment failures. (4) To quickly locate the fault location and its cause, in addition to providing training to ensure that maintenance and operational staff acquire a solid understanding of electrical and hydraulic technologies, it is also essential to compile common equipment failure symptoms, analysis procedures, and troubleshooting methods into a fault-finding logic flowchart. This will enable operators to swiftly identify the source and root cause of any malfunction after it occurs, allowing for timely diagnosis, repair, and restoration of equipment functionality. (5) Improve the fault recording system. Fault records serve as the foundational data for effective fault management and also provide the original basis for conducting fault analysis and troubleshooting. Records must be complete and accurate. After on-site inspections and fault repairs, maintenance personnel should follow the "Equipment Carefully complete the  "Equipment Failure Repair Form " and submit monthly statistical analyses to the equipment management department. (6) Conduct timely statistics and analysis of equipment failures. In addition to monitoring failure situations on a daily basis, staff members should compile  "Failure Repair Forms " and maintenance records on a monthly basis. By systematically collecting, organizing, and analyzing failure data, it’s possible to calculate the failure frequency and mean time between failures for each type of equipment. Furthermore, this process allows for an in-depth analysis of individual equipment failure trends and identifies key root causes, helping to pinpoint recurring patterns. Armed with this insight, teams can prioritize their response strategies effectively. Finally, the compiled and analyzed failure information should be shared back with the planning department, enabling them to schedule preventive maintenance or implement improvement measures. This data can also serve as a valuable reference for adjusting the intervals, content, and standards of routine inspections. (7) Implement different countermeasures based on the nature of the failure, the type of fault, and the specific characteristics of the equipment. For newly acquired equipment, strengthen management during the initial phase of use—carefully monitor and document the equipment’s precision, performance, and any emerging defects from the outset. During operation, emphasize routine maintenance, regular patrol inspections, and periodic checks to promptly identify early warning signs and take appropriate adjustment or troubleshooting actions. For critical equipment, conduct condition monitoring and diagnostics. Establish a flexible and responsive maintenance team equipped with advanced technical expertise, employing rapid repair techniques such as component-by-component fixes or group-based replacements. Ensure timely availability of high-quality spare parts, leverage production downtime for equipment overhauls, and apply measures like retrofitting or replacing components when wear patterns have been thoroughly understood. (8) Carry out routine maintenance tasks effectively to control equipment failures. Utilize status information and early warning signs of potential issues gathered during daily rounds by regional maintenance workers, as well as scheduled equipment condition checks, along with relevant records and analysis data. Based on the specific characteristics of each type of equipment and the general defects already identified, the workshop’s equipment mechanic (technician) or maintenance team leader should promptly schedule routine repairs—ideally during production downtime or weekend slots—to proactively address problems before they escalate, thereby minimizing breakdowns. For certain failure indicators or hidden risks that exceed the scope of routine maintenance, these should be reported back to the planning department for scheduling dedicated, planned maintenance activities instead. (9) Establish a rational fault information management flowchart.
1.2.4 Use of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment During operation, equipment's technical condition changes—and its performance gradually declines—due to various forces acting upon it, as well as factors such as environmental conditions, usage methods, operational guidelines, and the duration of use. To effectively manage these changes in technical condition and slow down the decline in equipment performance, the most critical measure is to ensure the equipment is used properly and correctly. Maintenance of mechanical and electrical equipment is a crucial method for improving utilization and ensuring its functionality—it consists of two forms: daily maintenance and periodic maintenance. Daily maintenance is primarily carried out by operators of mechanical and electrical equipment—conducting pre-shift inspections and post-shift cleaning to ensure that the equipment remains in optimal technical condition. Regular maintenance, also known as Level 1 care, is carried out by operators with assistance from maintenance personnel. It’s similar to minor repairs and is covered in Chapter 1 of the  "Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. " 13
28 Determine the form and compensation method for the error compensation环节, ensuring assembly accuracy among all components—such as parallelism, coaxiality, perpendicularity, and the required meshing precision of the transmission. 3) Post-Repair Acceptance Phase All equipment that has undergone repair, assembly, and adjustment must be subjected to comprehensive precision checks and tests—such as geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluations—in accordance with the relevant prescribed accuracy standards or the precision criteria established prior to repair. These measures ensure a thorough assessment of the repaired equipment’s quality, restored precision, and overall performance. After equipment maintenance, record the modifications made to the original technical documentation and document any lessons learned during the repair process. Prepare a thorough post-repair summary and file it alongside the original documents for future reference during the next maintenance task. 2. Determining the Equipment Maintenance Plan Major equipment overhauls must not only meet the predetermined technical requirements but also strive to enhance economic efficiency. Therefore, before starting repairs, it’s essential to thoroughly assess the equipment’s technical condition, develop a practical and feasible repair plan, and ensure comprehensive preparation—both technically and in terms of production readiness. During the repair process, actively incorporate new technologies, materials, processes, and modern management techniques, while diligently managing technical, financial, and organizational aspects to guarantee high-quality workmanship, minimize downtime, and reduce overall maintenance costs. A pre-inspection must be conducted to thoroughly assess the equipment's technical condition before repairs, identify the main defects present, and analyze the product-specific process requirements that influence the equipment's technical specifications—allowing for the immediate development of a repair plan. 3. Technical Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment—along with developing the overall maintenance production schedule. Pre-inspection survey preparation work To gain a comprehensive understanding of the specific condition of equipment degradation, schedule a shutdown inspection before the major overhaul—this is referred to as a pre-inspection. Before conducting the equipment pre-inspection, ensure the following preparatory investigations are completed. (1) Review the following equipment records: factory inspection reports; precision and performance verification records from equipment installation acceptance tests; details of all past equipment incidents, malfunctions, and repairs, including any remaining issues after repairs; records of all previous maintenance activities, including replaced or repaired components, as well as any unresolved problems left behind after servicing; and operational status monitoring logs and comprehensive equipment inspection records.

reference: The primary disadvantage of planned preventive maintenance systems is their poor cost-effectiveness. This inefficiency stems from the system's reliance on fixed maintenance cycles and predetermined scopes of work, which frequently results in unnecessary repairs of components that are still functional鈥攁 phenomenon known as over-maintenance. This approach can lead to increased operational costs without corresponding benefits in equipment reliability or longevity.
answer: The main drawback of the planned preventive maintenance system is its poor cost-effectiveness.

1.2 Basics of Equipment Maintenance 1.2.1 Maintenance Method The method of equipment maintenance carries the meaning of a maintenance strategy. Modern equipment management emphasizes applying different maintenance approaches to various types of equipment, underscoring that equipment repair should align with the objective principles governing the physical lifecycle of machinery and materials. This approach ensures production continuity while optimizing the efficient use of maintenance resources, ultimately achieving the most cost-effective outcome over the equipment's entire lifespan. Commonly used maintenance methods for electromechanical equipment include the following: Reactive Maintenance Post-failure maintenance, also known as breakdown maintenance, damage repair, or unplanned maintenance, refers to repairs carried out after mechanical and electrical equipment has malfunctioned—essentially, "if it breaks, we fix it." For certain critical equipment, post-failure maintenance should be minimized whenever possible; however, for devices that have minimal impact on production or are backed up by redundant units, opting for post-failure maintenance is often the most cost-effective approach. Preventive Maintenance Maintenance performed before mechanical and electrical equipment fails is called preventive maintenance. Its main benefits include reducing unexpected equipment failures, ensuring continuous production, integrating equipment upkeep and repair tasks into a structured plan—thereby minimizing unplanned disruptions in production—and ultimately improving equipment utilization, lowering maintenance costs, and extending the equipment's natural lifespan. Preventive maintenance is categorized into two basic forms: Regular maintenance Regular maintenance is also known as planned maintenance or time-based preventive maintenance. It involves carrying out preventive maintenance activities at predetermined intervals and follows a cyclical pattern. This type of maintenance is based on the wear patterns of components, with specific guidelines for setting maintenance intervals, defining maintenance categories, outlining maintenance tasks, and estimating the associated workload. However, this approach to maintenance can lead to certain challenges: First, when equipment is still in good technical condition and fully capable of continuing operation, it may undergo major over-maintenance simply because the scheduled interval has arrived—resulting in unnecessary repairs. Second, if a machine’s technical condition has already deteriorated to the point where it can no longer meet production requirements, but the prescribed maintenance interval hasn’t yet been reached, no repair plan will be implemented, leading to under-maintenance. This method is particularly well-suited for process-oriented production equipment or power systems where the wear patterns are well understood, and operations are stable and continuous—such as large-scale assembly line equipment or key machinery operating on automated production lines. Currently, China primarily implements two main types of equipment maintenance systems: the Planned Preventive Maintenance System and the Planned Warranty System. (1) Planned Preventive Maintenance System (referred to as Planned Pre-Maintenance). This system involves maintaining, inspecting, and repairing equipment according to its wear patterns, adhering to predetermined maintenance cycles and procedures, to ensure that the equipment consistently remains in optimal technical condition. Its key features are outlined below. ① Perform daily cleaning, inspection, lubrication, tightening, and adjustments on equipment as required to minimize wear and ensure proper operation. ② Conduct regular inspections and adjustments of the equipment's operational status and wear levels according to the prescribed schedule, ensuring that potential issues are promptly addressed. This allows you to monitor changes in the equipment's technical condition and adequately prepare the necessary resources for scheduled maintenance. ③ Conduct preventive maintenance on equipment in a planned and prepared manner. (2) The Planned Maintenance System (also known as the Maintenance and Repair System) is a equipment maintenance approach that combines routine upkeep with scheduled inspections and repairs. Its key features are outlined below. ① Based on the equipment's characteristics and condition, different maintenance categories and intervals are specified according to operational hours (such as production output and mileage).
2) Condition Monitoring and Maintenance This is a preventive maintenance approach based on the equipment's technical condition, carried out precisely when needed. It relies on condition monitoring and advanced diagnostic techniques to track the gradual deterioration of equipment over time. By leveraging highly predictive insights, this method allows for timely scheduling of preventive maintenance activities, which is why it’s also referred to as "predictive maintenance." At its core, this maintenance strategy integrates comprehensive data from various sources—such as inspections, routine upkeep, operational use, and repair activities—especially insights gained from diagnostics and monitoring. Through rigorous statistical analysis, it accurately assesses the extent of equipment degradation, identifies specific areas where failures may occur (or are likely to occur), and predicts trends in the equipment’s overall technical condition. Armed with this information, operators can then determine the most appropriate type of maintenance intervention. By doing so, organizations gain full control over maintenance activities, ensuring thorough preparation before repairs begin. Moreover, this approach enables seamless coordination with production schedules, maximizing equipment utilization while simultaneously extending the lifespan of critical components. However, this method does come with some drawbacks: it tends to be more expensive and requires sophisticated diagnostic capabilities. Additionally, it demands highly skilled technicians who can interpret complex data and make informed decisions. This approach is particularly well-suited for critical, high-value equipment, key assets on production lines, machinery that cannot be easily disassembled for inspection (such as precision machine tools), and systems whose failure could lead to significant environmental or public health concerns.
Material details, etc. 6. Maintenance-Free Design Maintenance-free design is the ideal goal for equipment maintenance—it refers to implementing improvement measures during the design phase of new machinery and electrical equipment to address common failures encountered during maintenance, aiming to minimize maintenance efforts or even eliminate the need for repairs altogether. 1.2.2 Maintenance Method Selection The purpose of maintenance is to ensure the reliable operation of equipment—specifically, to guarantee the dependable fulfillment of its intended use—and, at the same time, minimize maintenance costs. Therefore, the fundamental requirements for maintenance decisions are: ① Reliability must not fall below the permissible minimum value [R], meaning that ()[] R ≥ R(t); ② Maintenance costs (KI) must be kept as low as possible—or, alternatively, must not exceed a predetermined maintenance cost limit (KImin), i.e., K ≤ KImin. To optimize maintenance decisions, the first step should be to choose an appropriate maintenance approach. The six maintenance methods mentioned above each have a specific scope of applicability; however, their effectiveness can vary depending on how appropriately they are applied. To maximize equipment efficiency, minimize downtime-related losses, and reduce maintenance costs, it’s essential to select the most suitable approach based on the characteristics of mechatronic systems and the conditions under which they are used. Looking ahead, the trend in maintenance practices is shifting from routine preventive maintenance toward planned, periodic inspections—and then, based on inspection findings, scheduling timely condition-based repairs. As the technological sophistication of factory equipment continues to rise, with increasingly complex system designs and broader adoption of mechatronic solutions, production activities are becoming more reliant on equipment performance and reliability. Consequently, the traditional static approach to maintenance management is evolving into a more dynamic model, gradually moving toward advanced strategies such as reliability-centered maintenance and quality-focused repair practices. Mechatronic equipment comes in a wide variety of types and is widely applied, making it essential to select one or a combination of maintenance methods tailored to the specific situation. When choosing a maintenance approach for mechatronic systems, reliability typically becomes the primary focus. For critical components, implementing condition-based monitoring allows for timely preventive measures. Meanwhile, for equipment at quality control points, it’s crucial to closely track changes in product quality during the manufacturing process and promptly address any detected anomalies through quality repairs. Additionally, it’s important to equip teams with personnel who are well-versed in microelectronics technology, providing them with supervision and guidance while fostering the development of skilled, integrated mechatronics technicians. Regular inspections and logical fault analysis should be conducted on CNC and other mechatronic systems, and any failed components identified must be promptly replaced and properly adjusted to ensure optimal performance. 1.2.3 Maintenance System Maintenance work is not only a technical task but also a managerial one. A maintenance system refers to a set of guidelines established under specific maintenance theories and principles, encompassing elements such as maintenance plans, categories, methods, timing, scope, levels, organizational structures, and performance evaluation metrics. Implementing a rational maintenance system helps optimize the allocation of human, material, and financial resources, enabling timely preparation before maintenance tasks, ensuring repairs are carried out appropriately, meeting operational requirements, enhancing the technical condition, reliability, and service life of机电 equipment, reducing downtime, and minimizing maintenance costs and production losses due to equipment shutdowns. Meanwhile, maintenance systems are continuously evolving and improving—currently, the main approaches include the following: Planned Preventive Maintenance System It is based on a thorough understanding of the wear and failure patterns of mechanical and electrical equipment, applying the principle of prevention being better than cure—and addressing potential issues before they escalate—by systematically organizing maintenance and repairs according to the rate of wear and expected service life of each component. This approach helps prevent premature wear, compensates for natural degradation, minimizes or avoids failures altogether, extends equipment lifespan, and ultimately saves time spent on repairs, thereby enhancing operational efficiency and boosting economic returns. The practical implementation of planned preventive maintenance can be summarized as "regular inspections, timely upkeep, and scheduled repairs," making it particularly suitable for Chapter 1 of this guide: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment. 11 Macro-level management. ③ Having well-equipped maintenance facilities organized according to functional divisions and strategically located for optimal efficiency. The main drawback of the planned preventive maintenance system is its poor cost-effectiveness. With fixed maintenance cycles and scopes, it often leads to unnecessary repairs of certain components—what’s known as over-maintenance. During the maintenance process, repairs are categorized into several levels and types based on the depth and breadth of the work required, including major overhauls, mid-level repairs, minor repairs, item-specific repairs, retrofits, and unplanned maintenance tasks—all determined by the scale and nature of the repair workload. (1) Overhaul: A comprehensive or fundamental restoration of the functionality of mechanical and electrical equipment, typically carried out by specialized maintenance teams within factories and mines—or at repair centers established in regions with a high concentration of industrial facilities. During an overhaul, the equipment is either fully or extensively disassembled, with a focus on repairing critical components, replacing or refurbishing parts that have lost their function or are on the verge of doing so. After the repairs, the equipment’s precision is restored to nearly its original factory specifications, while also receiving a fresh cosmetic overhaul to enhance its appearance. (2) Intermediate Overhaul. This is a level of maintenance that falls between major and minor overhauls, serving as a balanced approach to upkeep. (3) Minor Repair. This involves replacing or repairing components that have significantly worn out or are nearing failure within the maintenance interval, without addressing any underlying structural issues. It is a troubleshooting-based repair aimed at restoring functionality. The three levels—major overhaul, mid-term repair, and minor repair—objectively reflect the chronological progression of机电 equipment, making them ideally suited for implementing time-based planned preventive maintenance, a practice widely adopted by most organizations. However, these levels still require complementary repair tiers to address unforeseen maintenance needs effectively. (4) Item-based maintenance. Based on condition monitoring of mechanical and electrical equipment, this involves proactively planning repairs specifically for components or technical items that are about to fail. Item-based maintenance is conducted between major, medium, and minor overhauls—it’s a non-periodic, planned maintenance level that doesn’t follow a fixed cycle. (5) Retrofitting. This involves making localized modifications to existing mechanical and electrical equipment using new technologies, materials, structures, and processes, with the goal of enhancing its precision, functionality, productivity, and reliability. Such repairs are classified as improvement-oriented, and the extent of the work required depends on how well the original equipment’s design accommodates the retrofitting process—as well as on the specific level of performance enhancement desired for the equipment. Retrofitting is also referred to as modernization or upgrading. (6) Unscheduled Maintenance. This is a level of maintenance required for mechanical and electrical equipment due to sudden breakdowns and accidents. The fewer the number and scope of unscheduled maintenance activities, the higher the level of management.
12 As a basis for determining equipment condition; it requires close collaboration between the design, manufacturing, and maintenance departments to develop a comprehensive maintenance plan for mechanical and electrical equipment, along with access to necessary testing methods and standards. 3. Targeted Maintenance System This maintenance system is based on comprehensive management principles and reliability-centered maintenance thinking, adopting a practical approach tailored to the specific characteristics of mechanical and electrical equipment—such as their design, performance, and operating conditions. Building upon the implementation of a condition-based inspection system, it strategically incorporates various maintenance methods, including predictive maintenance, preventive maintenance, and corrective maintenance. By leveraging advanced decision-making tools, computer technologies, as well as state monitoring and fault diagnosis techniques, the system ensures that maintenance activities are conducted in a scientifically sound manner. Ultimately, this approach aims to minimize the total lifecycle costs of equipment while maximizing overall operational efficiency and profitability. The characteristics of the targeted maintenance system are as follows: (1) It adopts and refines the classification management approach, strengthening maintenance management for key mechanical and electrical equipment as well as critical areas. Moreover, it implements tailored maintenance strategies based on the specific characteristics and current condition of each asset, maximizing their respective suitability and effectiveness to achieve optimal maintenance outcomes. (2) Among various maintenance approaches, condition monitoring and predictive maintenance should be promoted as the primary methods. Implement a systematic inspection system that embodies reliability-centered thinking, focusing maintenance efforts on routine upkeep while striving for targeted, proactive interventions whenever possible. (3) Emphasize the role of information, leverage computer technology for dynamic management, and make timely decisions to ensure that maintenance efforts are truly targeted and effective. The content of the targeted maintenance system includes: ① implementing a periodic inspection system, categorizing mechanical and electrical equipment, and applying various maintenance methods in a targeted manner; ② enhancing planned preventive maintenance by adopting maintenance type decisions for equipment equipped with condition-monitoring systems, allowing for tailored corrective or major overhauls; ③ establishing a set of maintenance and inspection standards, along with standardized work-hour quotas; ④ introducing computer-aided dynamic management, including decision-support systems for all relevant processes. 4. Operation and Maintenance System This is a standardized requirement for personnel behavior, serving as an essential software engineering practice in机电 equipment management, and it primarily consists of five disciplines and four key requirements. Five disciplines: ① Implement operator-specific machine assignments; ② Maintain cleanliness of mechanical and electrical equipment, ensuring proper lubrication and maintenance; ③ Follow safety operating procedures and the shift handover system; ④ Properly manage tools and accessories; ⑤ Immediately stop and inspect the machine upon detecting any malfunction. Four requirements: ① Neatness; ② Cleanliness; ③ Lubrication; ④ Safety.

user_input: What is condition-based maintenance and how does it differ from traditional maintenance?
reference_contexts: ['Condition-Based Maintenance System It is based on reliability theory, condition monitoring, and fault diagnosis, determining the timing and scope of maintenance based on actual technical condition assessments of mechanical and electrical equipment.', 'Given that many complex mechanical and electrical systems typically experience only early or occasional failures鈥攚ithout a wear-out phase鈥攔egular, scheduled maintenance often proves ineffective against such faults.', 'This approach ensures that equipment remains reliably operational while maximizing the lifespan of its components鈥攎aking it far more efficient and cost-effective than traditional planned preventive maintenance strategies.']
reference: Condition-based maintenance is a maintenance strategy that determines maintenance timing and scope through actual technical condition assessments of equipment, utilizing reliability theory, condition monitoring, and fault diagnosis. Unlike traditional scheduled maintenance, which proves ineffective for systems experiencing only early or occasional failures without a wear-out phase, condition-based maintenance focuses on the actual equipment condition rather than fixed time intervals. This approach is significantly more efficient and cost-effective than traditional planned preventive maintenance because it maximizes component lifespan while ensuring reliable equipment operation by addressing issues based on real-time condition data rather than predetermined schedules.
answer: Condition-based maintenance is a system based on reliability theory, condition monitoring, and fault diagnosis that determines the timing and scope of maintenance based on actual technical condition assessments, characterized by flexible decision-making regarding maintenance cycles, procedures, and scopes, and it differs from traditional maintenance such as regular planned or time-based preventive maintenance which operates on rigid schedules and can lead to over-maintenance or under-maintenance, with the overall trend shifting from routine preventive maintenance toward planned inspections followed by condition-based repairs.

Context:  
Condition-Based Maintenance System It is based on reliability theory, condition monitoring, and fault diagnosis, determining the timing and scope of maintenance based on actual technical condition assessments of mechanical and electrical equipment. Given that many complex mechanical and electrical systems typically experience only early or occasional failures—without a wear-out phase—regular, scheduled maintenance often proves ineffective against such faults. Moreover, in modern mechanical and electrical systems, only a small number of component failures pose safety risks; thus, maintenance tasks should be tailored specifically to the functional requirements of each part, considering potential functional failures, their root causes, and their consequences. This maintenance approach is characterized by flexible decision-making regarding maintenance cycles, procedures, and scopes—adapting dynamically to the actual conditions of the equipment. It shifts the focus of maintenance activities from routine repairs and upkeep to proactive inspections, underpinned by the implementation of a systematic inspection system. Not only does this inspection process provide critical information for determining optimal maintenance timing and scope, but it also allows certain maintenance tasks to be carried out incrementally and efficiently. By conducting daily, periodic, and precision inspections of mechanical and electrical equipment, combined with thorough analysis of condition-monitoring and fault-diagnosis data, operators can accurately assess the degree of degradation and proactively address issues before they escalate into full-blown failures. This approach ensures that equipment remains reliably operational while maximizing the lifespan of its components—making it far more efficient and cost-effective than traditional planned preventive maintenance strategies. To successfully implement condition-based maintenance, several prerequisites must be met: robust reliability testing data and comprehensive documentation are essential for effectively managing the mechanical and electrical systems. Commonly used maintenance methods for electromechanical equipment include the following: Reactive Maintenance Post-failure maintenance, also known as breakdown maintenance, damage repair, or unplanned maintenance, refers to repairs carried out after mechanical and electrical equipment has malfunctioned—essentially, "if it breaks, we fix it." Preventive Maintenance Maintenance performed before mechanical and electrical equipment fails is called preventive maintenance. Preventive maintenance is categorized into two basic forms: Regular maintenance Regular maintenance is also known as planned maintenance or time-based preventive maintenance. It involves carrying out preventive maintenance activities at predetermined intervals and follows a cyclical pattern. This type of maintenance is based on the wear patterns of components, with specific guidelines for setting maintenance intervals, defining maintenance categories, outlining maintenance tasks, and estimating the associated workload. However, this approach to maintenance can lead to certain challenges: First, when equipment is still in good technical condition and fully capable of continuing operation, it may undergo major over-maintenance simply because the scheduled interval has arrived—resulting in unnecessary repairs. Second, if a machine’s technical condition has already deteriorated to the point where it can no longer meet production requirements, but the prescribed maintenance interval hasn’t yet been reached, no repair plan will be implemented, leading to under-maintenance. Looking ahead, the trend in maintenance practices is shifting from routine preventive maintenance toward planned, periodic inspections—and then, based on inspection findings, scheduling timely condition-based repairs.

reference: The targeted maintenance system is a comprehensive approach based on management principles and reliability-centered maintenance thinking, specifically designed for mechanical and electrical equipment according to their design, performance, and operating conditions. Its main characteristics include: (1) implementing classification management to strengthen maintenance of key equipment and critical areas, with tailored strategies based on each asset's specific characteristics and condition to maximize suitability and effectiveness; (2) promoting condition monitoring and predictive maintenance as primary methods through a systematic inspection system that focuses on routine upkeep and proactive interventions; and (3) emphasizing information utilization and computer technology for dynamic management and timely decision-making to ensure maintenance efforts are precisely targeted and effective.
answer: The targeted maintenance system is a maintenance system based on comprehensive management principles and reliability-centered maintenance thinking that adopts a practical approach tailored to specific equipment characteristics, strategically incorporates predictive, preventive, and corrective maintenance methods, leverages advanced decision-making tools and technologies, and aims to minimize total lifecycle costs while maximizing operational efficiency and profitability. Its main characteristics are that it adopts and refines a classification management approach, promotes condition monitoring and predictive maintenance as primary methods, and emphasizes the role of information and computer technology for dynamic management.

user_input: What are the key components of the operation and maintenance system for mechanical and electrical equipment?
reference_contexts: ['This is a standardized requirement for personnel behavior, serving as an essential software engineering practice in鏈虹數 equipment management, and it primarily consists of five disciplines and four key requirements.', 'Five disciplines: 鈶?Implement operator-specific machine assignments; 鈶?Maintain cleanliness of mechanical and electrical equipment, ensuring proper lubrication and maintenance; 鈶?Follow safety operating procedures and the shift handover system; 鈶?Properly manage tools and accessories; 鈶?Immediately stop and inspect the machine upon detecting any malfunction.', 'Four requirements: 鈶?Neatness; 鈶?Cleanliness; 鈶?Lubrication; 鈶?Safety.']
reference: The operation and maintenance system consists of standardized behavioral requirements organized into five disciplines and four key requirements. The five disciplines are: (1) implementing operator-specific machine assignments, (2) maintaining equipment cleanliness with proper lubrication and maintenance, (3) following safety procedures and shift handover systems, (4) properly managing tools and accessories, and (5) immediately stopping and inspecting machines upon detecting malfunctions. The four key requirements are: (1) neatness, (2) cleanliness, (3) lubrication, and (4) safety, which together form the essential framework for personnel behavior in mechanical and electrical equipment management.
answer: The key components of the operation and maintenance system are the five disciplines and the four key requirements.

6) Use correctly Under normal operating conditions, mechanical equipment follows its own failure patterns; however, when operating conditions change, these failure patterns also shift accordingly. The primary operating conditions include the following: (1) Load. The primary causes of wear and fatigue failure in mechanical equipment are the wear of components and their fatigue-induced damage. Under specified operating conditions, the rate of component wear over a given period is directly proportional to the magnitude of the load applied. Meanwhile, fatigue damage to components occurs only under certain types of cyclic loading and intensifies as the load increases. Thus, both wear and fatigue are functions of the applied load. Exceeding the design-rated load levels can lead to severe failure, which is unacceptable. (2) Environment. The environment includes the effects of climate, corrosive media, and other harmful substances, as well as the condition of the working object itself. Increased temperatures accelerate wear and corrosion, while excessively high humidity and corrosive agents present in the air can lead to both corrosion and corrosive wear. Additionally, excessive dust levels in the air and harsh operating conditions often contribute to equipment failures. However, the environment is an objective factor, and in certain situations, measures can be taken manually to improve it. (3) Maintenance and Operation. Establishing a sound maintenance system and strictly adhering to technical maintenance guidelines and operational procedures are crucial for ensuring the reliable performance of mechanical equipment and extending its service life. Additionally, it is essential to provide training for personnel to enhance their skills and expertise.

Cultivate a culture and habit of consciously caring for equipment, ensuring it remains regularly clean, safe, and in optimal technical condition. 1.2.5 Maintenance and保养 of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 1) Principles of Operation and Maintenance Procedures Mechanical and electrical equipment maintenance refers to the tasks performed to eliminate inevitable abnormal technical conditions that arise during operation (such as loose parts, dry friction, or unusual noises). Overall, maintaining mechanical and electrical equipment requires meeting four fundamental criteria: neatness, cleanliness, lubrication, and safety. Developing clear equipment operation and maintenance procedures is a crucial step in ensuring that all subsequent operations are carried out systematically and efficiently. The principles for creating these operational and maintenance guidelines are outlined below. (1) General guidelines should list precautions according to the equipment operation sequence, as well as before, during, and after shifts—aiming for concise, clear, and practical content. (2) List the structural features, processing range, operational precautions, maintenance requirements, and more separately by equipment category, making it easier for operators to grasp the key points and ensure proper implementation. (3) Common elements across various types of mechanical and electrical equipment can be used to develop a unified, standard general procedure. (4) Key equipment, high-precision, large and medium-sized, as well as rare and critical electromechanical devices, must have operation and maintenance procedures prepared separately. Also, post prominent signage near the machine tool, clearly indicating that operators should pay special attention and strictly adhere to the guidelines. 2) Basic Content of Operation and Maintenance Procedures
The basic content of operation and maintenance procedures generally includes the following aspects. (1) Operators must wear appropriate personal protective equipment as required during operation. When inspecting or approaching the equipment, they should avoid wearing loose-fitting clothing. Female employees are not permitted to wear long hair loose. (2) Before starting work, clear the workspace. Before turning on the equipment, inspect each operating handle and control device according to the items specified in the daily inspection checklist to ensure they are in the off position. Check whether any components show signs of severe wear, damage requiring replacement, or loose connections posing safety risks. Verify that all safety protection devices are intact and securely fastened. Also, confirm that the power supply is functioning properly and keep a detailed inspection record. If any issues are found that fail to meet safety standards, promptly submit safety improvement suggestions or solutions to the workshop supervisor to prevent the equipment from operating while faulty. (3) Check whether the wires and control cabinets are damaged, whether the surrounding environment is reliable, and whether the equipment's grounding or earthing facilities are safe. If any issues are detected, take protective measures immediately. (4) Check the oil quality and level in lubrication and hydraulic systems; replenish oil according to the lubrication chart, ensuring the oil remains clean, the oil lines are unobstructed, and lubrication is optimal. Proper lubrication not only guarantees effective cooling and heat dissipation but also provides sealing and protective functions. Additionally, it plays a significant role in cleaning away contaminants and reducing wear. (5) After confirming that all components are functioning correctly, you may first run the machine at low speed for 3–5 minutes with no load. Ensure that all parts operate smoothly and are well-lubricated before proceeding with actual work. Never exceed the recommended load or use the equipment outside of specified guidelines. (6) While the equipment is running, it is strictly prohibited to adjust the workpiece by hand or to perform lubrication, remove debris, or wipe down the machine. When leaving the machine tool, always turn off the power supply. During operation, closely monitor the condition of all components; if any abnormalities are detected, immediately stop the machine and address the issue. (7) When maintaining, servicing, or cleaning equipment and instruments, ensure that the equipment and instruments are powered down and the power supply is completely turned off. Additionally, clearly display or hang warning signs at the work site to indicate that the equipment is undergoing maintenance or repair, or that personnel are present for ongoing work. (8) Before maintenance and servicing, personnel should be aware of the precautions specific to this task and follow the proper maintenance procedures. During maintenance, staff must remain fully focused, wear appropriate safety gear, and ensure their standing position is secure. (9) When maintaining equipment, use disassembly tools correctly; unauthorized assembly or disassembly is strictly prohibited. Do not remove or alter the equipment's Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance at will. 15 Safety protection device: When positioning or assembling the equipment, never insert your hands into the mating surfaces or use your fingers to align holes. (10) After completing maintenance, repair, and other operational tasks, equipment should be removed from the work area, and the workspace along with machinery must be thoroughly cleaned. Every component of the equipment’s instruments and gauges should be carefully inspected, ensuring that no tools or other items are left behind—either on the equipment or inside it. Additionally, the workshop should conduct regular maintenance, upkeep, and repairs to ensure the smooth operation of all machinery. (11) Instructions, safety signs, and signage located within the workshop and on machinery must be strictly followed at all times. (12) It is strictly prohibited to use flammable or volatile substances for wiping equipment. Oil-soaked rags must not be left on the equipment, and no flammable or explosive materials are allowed to be stored near the equipment. (13) When working in flammable and explosive hazard areas, appropriate safety measures must be taken beforehand and approved by the production safety department and management before proceeding. Additionally, when welding or grinding containers or pipelines containing flammable, explosive, or toxic materials, these must first be properly purged and thoroughly cleaned—and all openings must be fully opened—before work can begin. (14) The work area should be dry and clean. Used oil and waste rags must not be discarded randomly on the floor. Raw materials, semi-finished products, and finished goods must be neatly stacked, and blocking passageways is strictly prohibited. (15) Regularly maintain the cleanliness of lubrication and hydraulic systems. Keep the tank lid securely closed, ensuring no water, dust, metal chips, or other contaminants enter the oil tank or electrical equipment. (16) After finishing work and before leaving for the day, clean the machine tools and equipment thoroughly, ensuring they remain tidy. Return operating handles, buttons, and other controls to their non-working positions, turn off the power supply, and complete the handover procedures with the next shift. 3) Classification of Maintenance and Servicing Tasks Depending on the depth, scope, and volume of work involved in equipment maintenance and upkeep, maintenance tasks can be categorized into the following types. (1) Daily Maintenance (Routine Maintenance). Its main tasks include: inspecting and lubricating the equipment; strictly following the equipment operation procedures. Cheng uses the equipment to tighten any loose parts; cleans and wipes down the equipment, checks its operational status, and records the condition in the shift handover log. This type of maintenance is relatively simple, with most tasks performed on the equipment's surface. Daily maintenance should be carried out by the operating person. (2) First-Level Maintenance (Monthly Maintenance). The main tasks include: disassembling specified components such as the housing cover and protective shields, thoroughly cleaning and wiping both the inside and outside of the equipment; inspecting and adjusting clearance gaps between parts, tightening any loose components, and replacing individual wear-and-tear parts; clearing oil passages, cleaning filters, and replacing coolant while also flushing the coolant tank; cleaning guideways and sliding surfaces, removing burrs and scratches; and inspecting and adjusting electrical wiring and related devices. This first-level maintenance is performed after the equipment has been running for 1 to 2 months (under a two-shift system), primarily by operational staff with support from maintenance technicians. (3) Second-Level Maintenance (Annual Maintenance). In addition to the tasks included in first-level maintenance, second-level maintenance also involves repairing or replacing worn parts, adjusting clearances in components such as guides, maintaining the electrical system, and inspecting and fine-tuning equipment accuracy. This type of maintenance is carried out once a year after the equipment has been in operation, primarily by maintenance technicians with the participation of operators.

user_input: What are the two forms of maintenance for mechanical and electrical equipment?
reference_contexts: ['Maintenance of mechanical and electrical equipment is a crucial method for improving utilization and ensuring its functionality鈥攊t consists of two forms: daily maintenance and periodic maintenance.']
reference: The two forms of maintenance for mechanical and electrical equipment are daily maintenance and periodic maintenance. Daily maintenance involves pre-shift inspections and post-shift cleaning performed by operators to keep the equipment in optimal technical condition. Periodic maintenance, also referred to as Level 1 care, is conducted by operators with assistance from maintenance personnel and is similar to minor repairs, as detailed in Chapter 1 of 'Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance'.
answer: The two forms of maintenance for mechanical and electrical equipment are daily maintenance and periodic maintenance.

3) By the rate at which the fault develops (1) Sudden failures. These failures occur unexpectedly and spontaneously, typically independent of the equipment’s usage time. They are often preceded by no obvious warning signs, making them difficult to predict even through early-stage testing or trials. Such failures usually result from a combination of inherent adverse factors within the process system and unpredictable external influences. (2) Gradual failure. These failures develop slowly and typically occur during the later stages of an electromechanical device's useful life. Their likelihood of occurrence is closely tied to the equipment's usage time, and they can often be predicted through early-stage testing or monitoring. Such failures usually result from the gradual progression of issues like corrosion, wear, fatigue, and material aging in the components. 4) By the cause of fault formation (1) Failures caused by operational or management errors, such as using机电 equipment under conditions that deviate from the original design specifications, leading to improper equipment usage. (2) Failures caused by inherent system factors. These typically arise from defects left over from system design or manufacturing—such as residual stresses or localized weak points—or from latent flaws within the materials themselves. Such failures are unpredictable and represent a major cause of sudden, unexpected breakdowns. (3) Natural failures. During the operational and maintenance period, mechanical and electrical equipment may experience failures caused by various external or internal natural factors—such as wear, fracture, corrosion, deformation, creep, aging, and other forms of damage that occur under normal conditions. 5) By the consequences caused by the failure (1) Critical Failure: A failure that endangers personal safety, results in injury or death, causes the scrapping of机电 equipment, or leads to significant financial losses. Examples include frame or body separation, wheel detachment, and complete engine assembly failure. (2) Minor faults. These are issues that affect the normal operation of mechanical and electrical equipment but can be resolved within a relatively short time. Examples include broken drive belts, damaged control handles, cracks or loose welds in sheet metal components, faulty electrical switches, minor leaks, and loose general fasteners. 6) By the period when the fault occurred (1) Early-stage failures. These faults may arise from design, manufacturing, or material defects and typically become apparent shortly after the equipment is first put into operation. Alternatively, certain components—such as gear pairs in gearboxes or other friction-based assemblies—often require an initial "running-in" period before their performance gradually improves. Once these early-stage issues are identified, addressed, and optimized, the failure rate tends to decline over time. (2) Failure during the useful life. This refers to failures that occur within a product's effective lifespan, caused by unpredictable, random factors related to both external loads (such as operational conditions) and intrinsic system characteristics (including internal factors like component failures or structural damage). Since equipment typically operates in this condition for most of its lifetime, the failure rate during this period remains relatively constant. Therefore, monitoring and diagnosing failures during this phase is critically important. (3) Late-stage failures (dissipation-phase failures). These typically occur during the latter part of a device's lifespan, often after the equipment has been in use for an extended period—or even beyond its intended service life. Such failures arise due to gradual wear, fatigue, and aging of the equipment's components, leading to a decline in system functionality. Ultimately, this can result in sudden, hazardous, and potentially widespread system breakdowns. During this phase, the failure rate of the equipment tends to increase steadily. To prevent accidents, it’s crucial to monitor and diagnose the system regularly, promptly replacing any identified failing components before they cause a major incident. As illustrated by the classification of these failures, mechanical and electrical equipment malfunctions are often interconnected and can evolve over time—shifting from one type of failure to another. Ultimately, every type of machinery and equipment failure will manifest as a specific issue, underscoring the importance of comprehensive diagnostic and maintenance strategies. 5
6 The procedure for equipment failure management is outlined below. (1) Conduct thorough education and awareness campaigns to ensure that operators and maintenance personnel voluntarily comply with relevant rules and regulations regarding operation, maintenance, inspection, etc., properly use and carefully maintain equipment, and diligently record, compile statistics, and analyze any equipment malfunctions. (2) Based on the company’s actual production conditions, equipment status, and specific features, determine the key areas for equipment failure management. (3) Use monitoring instruments and diagnostic techniques to systematically monitor critical equipment, enabling timely detection of fault indicators and deterioration. Information on equipment condition. Typically, equipment can undergo daily inspections, routine patrols, and periodic checks (including precision assessments), as well as integrity assessments—using human senses and common diagnostic tools—to closely monitor the technical status and any unusual signs in components, mechanisms, and areas prone to failure. At the same time, inspection standards should be established to clearly define the boundaries between normal operation, abnormalities, and equipment failures. (4) To quickly locate the fault location and its cause, in addition to providing training to ensure that maintenance and operational staff acquire a solid understanding of electrical and hydraulic technologies, it is also essential to compile common equipment failure symptoms, analysis procedures, and troubleshooting methods into a fault-finding logic flowchart. This will enable operators to swiftly identify the source and root cause of any malfunction after it occurs, allowing for timely diagnosis, repair, and restoration of equipment functionality. (5) Improve the fault recording system. Fault records serve as the foundational data for effective fault management and also provide the original basis for conducting fault analysis and troubleshooting. Records must be complete and accurate. After on-site inspections and fault repairs, maintenance personnel should follow the "Equipment Carefully complete the  "Equipment Failure Repair Form " and submit monthly statistical analyses to the equipment management department. (6) Conduct timely statistics and analysis of equipment failures. In addition to monitoring failur e situations on a daily basis, staff members should compile  "Failure Repair Forms " and maintenance records on a monthly basis. By systematically collecting, organizing, and analyzing failure data, it’s possible to calculate the failure frequency and mean time b etween failures for each type of equipment. Furthermore, this process allows for an in-depth analysis of individual equipment failure trends and identifies key root causes, helping  to pinpoint recurring patterns. Armed with this insight, teams can prioritize their response strategies effectively. Finally, the compiled and analyzed failure information should  be shared back with the planning department, enabling them to schedule preventive maintenance or implement improvement measures. This data can also serve as a valuable reference fo r adjusting the intervals, content, and standards of routine inspections. (7) Implement different countermeasures based on the nature of the failure, the type of fault, and the spe cific characteristics of the equipment. For newly acquired equipment, strengthen management during the initial phase of use—carefully monitor and document the equipment’s precision , performance, and any emerging defects from the outset. During operation, emphasize routine maintenance, regular patrol inspections, and periodic checks to promptly identify early  warning signs and take appropriate adjustment or troubleshooting actions. For critical equipment, conduct condition monitoring and diagnostics. Establish a flexible and responsive  maintenance team equipped with advanced technical expertise, employing rapid repair techniques such as component-by-component fixes or group-based replacements. Ensure timely avai lability of high-quality spare parts, leverage production downtime for equipment overhauls, and apply measures like retrofitting or replacing components when wear patterns have bee n thoroughly understood. (8) Carry out routine maintenance tasks effectively to control equipment failures. Utilize status information and early warning signs of potential issues g athered during daily rounds by regional maintenance workers, as well as scheduled equipment condition checks, along with relevant records and analysis data. Based on the specific c haracteristics of each type of equipment and the general defects already identified, the workshop’s equipment mechanic (technician) or maintenance team leader should promptly sched ule routine repairs—ideally during production downtime or weekend slots—to proactively address problems before they escalate, thereby minimizing breakdowns. For certain failure ind icators or hidden risks that exceed the scope of routine maintenance, these should be reported back to the planning department for scheduling dedicated, planned maintenance activit ies instead. (9) Establish a rational fault information management flowchart.
1.2.4 Use of Mechanical and Elect rical Equipment During operation, equipment's technical condition changes—and its performance gradually declines—due to various forces acting upon it, as well as factors such as en vironmental conditions, usage methods, operational guidelines, and the duration of use. To effectively manage these changes in technical condition and slow down the decline in equi pment performance, the most critical measure is to ensure the equipment is used properly and correctly. Maintenance of mechanical and electrical equipment is a crucial method for i mproving utilization and ensuring its functionality—it consists of two forms: daily maintenance and periodic maintenance. Daily maintenance is primarily carried out by operators of  mechanical and electrical equipment—conducting pre-shift inspections and post-shift cleaning to ensure that the equipment remains in optimal technical condition. Regular maintenan ce, also known as Level 1 care, is carried out by operators with assistance from maintenance personnel. It’s similar to minor repairs and is covered in Chapter 1 of the  "Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. " 13
6. Develop effective operating procedures, establish a sound e quipment usage accountability system, and strictly adhere to them during operation. Establishing and adhering to operating procedures is one of the key measures to ensure the safe  operation of equipment. Leaders at all levels within the enterprise, as well as equipment management departments, production team leaders, and production workers, all bear correspo nding responsibilities in ensuring the proper use of equipment. Practical experience has shown that many equipment failures can be significantly reduced simply by following establi shed operating procedures. 7. Pre-employment Training for Operators Operators must be thoroughly familiar with and proficient in the equipment’s performance, structure, processing  capabilities, and maintenance procedures. New operators are required to undergo a technical assessment before operating the machine; only those who pass can independently perform s etup tasks. For precision, complex, or critical production equipment, designated operators with specialized expertise should be assigned—adhering to the principle of  "designated personnel for specific machines, operating only with proper certification. " Additionally, employees should receive ongoing education and training on the proper use and care of equipment. The level of care operators demonstrate toward machinery directly i mpacts the equipment’s lifespan and operational efficiency. Therefore, companies must regularly provide employees with both ideological guidance and technical training, equipping t hem with the skills needed to diagnose and troubleshoot mechanical and electrical system failures effectively. 14
1.2.7 Patterns of Failure Occurrence Mechanical and electrical equipment failures exhibit two notable characteristics: first, the likelihood of failure increases as the equipment ages; second, failures occur randomly, making it difficult to predict the exact timing of any given failure. Consequently, over the equipment's lifespan, the probability of a failure can be expressed using statistical methods. The failure rate, denoted by ( \lambda(t) ), represents the conditional probability that a failure will occur within the infinitesimal time interval ( dt ), given that no failure has yet happened up to time ( t ). user_input: How should the equipment be maintained when not in active use?
reference_contexts: ['Even when no machining tasks are scheduled, ensure the equipment remains powered on regularly鈥攊deally, running it once or twice a week for about an hour each time under no-load conditions. This practice leverages the heat generated by the equipment itself to lower humidity levels inside, preventing moisture buildup that could damage electronic components.']
reference: When the equipment is not in active use, it should be powered on regularly鈥攊deally once or twice a week for about an hour each time under no-load conditions. This practice generates heat from the equipment, which helps lower internal humidity levels, preventing moisture buildup that could otherwise damage sensitive electronic components and ensuring longevity.
answer: When equipment is not in active use, it should undergo preventive maintenance, which includes regular planned maintenance and condition monitoring, with daily maintenance tasks such as cleaning, inspection, lubrication, and tightening performed by operators to ensure it remains in optimal technical condition and to extend its stable wear phase.
