1.1.5 Key Factors Influencing Failure Generation The more complex the mechanical and electrical equipment, the more diverse the potential causes of failure. The main factors influencing these failures include the following aspects. 1) Design Planning In the design planning phase, accurate estimates of the equipment's future operating conditions are essential, and potential variations should be thoroughly considered. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 7 Consideration: Imperfect design solutions and inadequate review of design drawings and technical documents are major causes of failures. 2) Material Selection In design, manufacturing, and maintenance, it is essential to correctly select materials based on the nature and characteristics of the part’s function. Improper material selection, failure to meet specified material standards, or the use of inappropriate substitutes are major causes of phenomena such as wear, corrosion, excessive deformation, fatigue, cracking, and aging. Additionally, during manufacturing and repair processes, many materials undergo various fabrication steps, including casting, forging, welding, and heat treatment. Throughout these processes, the microstructure and mechanical/physical properties of the materials often undergo significant changes—among which the effects of heating and cooling are particularly critical. 3) Manufacturing Quality Errors exist in every step of the manufacturing process. The variability in process conditions and material properties inevitably leads to differences among parts during casting, Stress concentrations, local defects, and microscopic cracks—such as those arising during forging, welding, heat treatment, and machining—are common issues. These flaws are often overlooked during process inspections. As a result, the manufacturing quality of parts frequently fails to meet requirements, which is a major reason behind the short lifespan of mechanical equipment. 4) Assembly Quality First, there must be proper fit requirements. The tolerance limits for the clearance include the initial clearance that remains after assembly and running-in. If the initial clearance is too large, the effective service life will be shortened. Additionally, the positional accuracy between individual components during assembly is critical—failure to meet these specifications can lead to additional stresses, uneven wear, and ultimately accelerate component failure. 5) Proper Maintenance
When designing, it's essential to consider not only the strength of the parts but also their stiffness, as well as issues related to manufacturing, assembly, usage, disassembly, and maintenance. (1) Select materials carefully, paying attention to their process properties—such as casting fluidity and shrinkage, forging ductility and cold-heading capability, weldability characteristics like susceptibility to cold and hot cracking, machinability for ease of cutting, and heat-treatment properties including hardenability and resistance to cold brittleness. (2) Properly arrange the parts to optimize their stress distribution. Select appropriate structural dimensions, ensuring uniform wall thicknesses as much as possible, and minimize deformation during hot working processes. For instance, avoid sharp corners by replacing them with rounded or chamfered edges; for areas with significant thickness variations, consider adding process holes or reinforcing excessively thin sections. Additionally, carefully position any existing holes—transforming blind holes into through-holes where feasible. For parts with complex geometries, whenever possible, opt for modular or assembled designs to further enhance stress management. (3) In the design process, ensure the application of new technologies, processes, and materials to minimize internal stresses and deformation during manufacturing. 2) Manufacturing In the rough casting manufacturing process, it is important to address deformation issues and implement various process measures to minimize residual stresses in the blank. After the raw parts are produced and during subsequent machining processes, it is essential to incorporate sufficient steps for relieving internal stresses, aiming to minimize residual stresses within the components. One effective method to eliminate these residuals is through aging treatment, which can be either natural or artificial. Natural aging involves leaving the finished raw parts exposed outdoors for 1 to 2 years. This approach leverages the material’s inherent property of gradually releasing internal stresses over a period of 12 to 20 months—making it particularly effective—but the main drawback is the excessively long aging cycle. On the other hand, artificial aging accelerates the stress-relief process by subjecting the parts to high-temperature annealing followed by controlled cooling at a slow pace. Alternatively, vibrational techniques can also be employed to achieve artificial aging. For high-precision components, artificial aging must be integrated into the final machining stages to ensure optimal dimensional accuracy and stability. During machining and repair processes, minimize the number of datum shifts, preserving the original machining datums for use during maintenance, thereby reducing repair time. Errors caused by inconsistent benchmarks during machining. For parts that have undergone heat treatment, be sure to allow sufficient machining allowances and adjust the machining dimensions accordingly. Pre-applying controlled deformation is crucial—once the deformation patterns of the part are understood, you can counteract them in advance by introducing an equal but opposite amount of deformation. Alternatively, you can pre-stress the part or carefully manage the generation and evolution of stresses, ensuring that the final deformation aligns with specifications and effectively minimizes distortion. 3) Maintenance Aspects During maintenance, it is essential to not only meet the technical requirements—such as restoring part dimensions, ensuring proper fit tolerances, and achieving high surface quality—but also to inspect and correct any shape or positional errors in critical components. To minimize stress and deformation of parts during repair, standardized guidelines and maintenance procedures specifically addressing deformation issues should be established. Additionally, simple, reliable, and user-friendly specialized measuring tools and fixtures should be designed. Finally, it’s important to actively promote "three new" technologies, particularly innovative repair techniques like brush plating and bonding. 4) Usage Instructions
1.4.1 Preparations Before Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Electromechanical equipment occupies a critically important position in the production and operational activities of modern industrial enterprises. To ensure smooth equipment operation and safe production, implementing planned preventive maintenance is an essential component of equipment management and repair practices in industrial companies. This section will cover the detailed process of major equipment overhauls, the determination of equipment repair plans, as well as the technical and material preparations required prior to equipment maintenance. 1. Equipment Major Overhaul Process To ensure the precision and operational performance of mechanical and electrical equipment, preventive scheduled maintenance must be carried out in addition to routine upkeep. Among these preventive measures, major overhauls stand out as a critical task aimed at restoring the equipment's accuracy. Within the category of preventive maintenance, major overhauls—often referred to simply as "overhauls"—represent the most extensive and time-consuming type of repair. An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit. The ultimate goal is to thoroughly eliminate any pre-existing defects and restore the equipment to its specified performance standards. The purpose of precision and performance. The major steps involved in the overhaul of mechanical and electrical equipment typically include: pre-disassembly unit inspection, component removal, component inspection, necessary component disassembly, parts cleaning and examination, component repair and assembly, final assembly, no-load trial operation, load testing, overall machine precision verification, and final acceptance. In practice, these tasks should be carried out according to the overhaul work plan, while also ensuring effective job scheduling, quality control during operations, and thorough completion acceptance. The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment is typically divided into three stages: pre-repair preparation, the repair process itself, and post-repair acceptance. Pre-repair preparation phase To ensure the repair work proceeds smoothly and accurately, maintenance personnel should carefully listen to operators' requirements for equipment repairs and thoroughly understand the issues affecting the equipment being serviced—such as loss of precision, the extent of wear on major mechanical components, the accuracy of the transmission system, and any visible defects. They should also identify which parts need improvement or modification to meet the equipment’s operational specifications. Additionally, they should review relevant technical documentation, equipment manuals, and previous maintenance records to become familiar with the device’s structural features, transmission system, and original design precision standards. This preparation will enable them to propose comprehensive pre-inspection tasks. Following the pre-inspection, specific repair methods for critical and large components can be determined, allowing for the preparation of specialized tools and precision measuring instruments. Finally, the team must define the post-repair precision testing procedures and establish clear acceptance criteria for trial runs, ensuring all technical preparations are fully in place before proceeding with the complete overhaul of the equipment.
Particularly important
General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment

user_input: What is fracture in mechanical parts and why is it significant?
reference_contexts: ['Fracture refers to the phenomenon where a mechanical component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under the influence of certain factors.', 'It is one of the primary modes of mechanical component failure鈥攐nce a part fractures, it not only completely loses its functionality but can also lead to significant economic losses and even cause accidents resulting in injuries or fatalities.', 'Particularly as modern manufacturing systems continue to evolve toward higher power levels and faster rotational speeds, the operating conditions for components have changed dramatically, increasing the likelihood of fracture-related failures.']
reference: Fracture in mechanical parts is the phenomenon where a component develops localized cracks or splits into several pieces due to various influencing factors. It is a primary mode of mechanical failure because once fracture occurs, the part loses all functionality entirely. This can result in substantial economic losses and may even cause accidents leading to injuries or fatalities. The significance of fracture has increased with modern manufacturing systems evolving toward higher power outputs and faster rotational speeds, which dramatically alter component operating conditions and raise the probability of fracture-related failures. Additionally, the fracture surface that forms after breaking provides a detailed record of the failure process. Analyzing this surface helps identify the root cause of the fracture, offering critical insights for improving design specifications and facilitating effective repair strategies.
answer: Fracture in mechanical parts is the phenomenon where a component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under certain factors, and it is a primary mode of mechanical component failure. It is significant because once a part fractures, it completely loses its functionality and can lead to significant economic losses and accidents causing injuries or fatalities, and by analyzing the fracture surface, the cause can be identified to help refine designs and enable effective repairs.

Context:  
1.3.4 Fracture of Mechanical Parts Fracture refers to the phenomenon where a mechanical component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under the influence of certain factors. It is one of the primary modes of mechanical component failure—once a part fractures, it not only completely loses its functionality but can also lead to significant economic losses and even cause accidents resulting in injuries or fatalities. Particularly as modern manufacturing systems continue to evolve toward higher power levels and faster rotational speeds, the operating conditions for components have changed dramatically, increasing the likelihood of fracture-related failures. As a result, fracture failure has become a hot topic of research today. The fracture surface formed after a part breaks can accurately capture the dynamic evolution of the failure process. By analyzing the fracture surface, it is possible to identify the primary cause of the fracture, providing valuable insights that help refine designs and enable effective repairs. Based on the cause of failure, fractures can be categorized into types such as brittle fracture and fatigue fracture. Brittle Fracture Before fracturing, the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation; this type of fracture, which develops extremely rapidly, is known as brittle fracture.  Brittle fracture occurs without any prior warning signs, making it a sudden and highly dangerous form of failure. Metal parts may become brittle—and thus prone to sudden fracture— due to improper manufacturing processes, exposure to corrosive media during use, or adverse environmental conditions. For instance, the penetration of hydrogen or hydrides into met al materials can lead to  "hydrogen embrittlement, " while chloride ions infiltrating austenitic stainless steel may cause  "chloride stress corrosion cracking. " Similarly, nitrate ions entering carbon steel can trigger  "nitrate embrittlement, " and steel in contact with alkaline substances might suffer from  "alkali embrittlement. " Additionally, copper components exposed to ammonia can experience  "ammonia-induced embrittlement. " Furthermore, at ambient temperatures between 10°C and 15°C, medium- to low-strength carbon steels are particularly susceptible to  "cold embrittlement " (often caused by elevated phosphorus content in the steel). Meanwhile, aluminum-containing alloys, if not carefully temperature-controlled during heat treatment, can easily overh eat—even with only a slight deviation from the optimal range—leading to severe embrittlement. The hazards posed by brittle fracture in metals are significant, second only to those  associated with fatigue failure. Fatigue Fracture The fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses is known as fatigue failure. In fact, 80% of fractures in mechanical components during use are caused by fatigue. Typically, fatigue failure progresses through three distinct stages: the initiation phase of fatigue cracks; the propagation phase of fatigue cracks; and finally, catastrophic failure—the unstable, rapid growth phase of the fatigue crack. Below, we will analyze the fracture surfaces associated with fatigue failure. A typical fatigue fracture typically exhibits 3 distinct features based on the fracture process. Regions with distinct characteristics: fatigue core zone, fatigue crack propagation Zone and transient zone, as shown in Figure 1.4. Fatigue Core Zone It is the source region of fatigue fracture, visible to the naked eye or under low magnification. A magnifying glass can pinpoint the location of the fatigue core on the fracture surface—it typically does. Appearing in the area with the lowest intensity, highest stress, and closest to the surface Position. But if there are defects inside the material, this fatigue core... It could also occur at the defect site. Scratches left behind during the machining, storage, transportation, and assembly processes are highly likely to become fatigue nuclei, as these marks not only cause stress concentrations but also remain vulnerable to corrosion damage from air and other environmental factors. Figure 1.4: Schematic Diagram of Fatigue Fracture Features (Uniaxial Bending)
4. Measures to Reduce Fracture Failure Fracture failure is one of the most dangerous forms of failure, and most metal parts fail due to various factors arising from metallurgy and part manufacturing processes. Because all of them contain cracks of varying sizes and characteristics, ranging from atomic-level dislocations to macroscopic cracks visible to the naked eye. However, a part with cracks doesn’t necessarily fail immediately—there’s typically a period during which these cracks undergo subcritical propagation. Moreover, under certain conditions, cracks may even remain stable without expanding at all. Therefore, by implementing effective measures, it’s possible to ensure that parts containing cracks do not ultimately fracture. Strategies to minimize fracture failures can be considered from the following perspectives. 1) Optimize the shape and structural design of parts, and carefully select appropriate materials for the components. Both geometric discontinuities in part shapes and material imperfections can lead to stress concentration. Geometric discontinuities are commonly referred to as notches, such as fillets at shoulders, grooves, oil holes, keyways, threads, and machining marks. Material-related discontinuities are typically called material defects, including shrinkage porosity, shrinkage cavities, non-metallic inclusions, and welding flaws. These areas prone to stress concentration are particularly susceptible to crack initiation and propagation under cyclic or impact loading, ultimately leading to fracture. Therefore, in part design, it’s crucial to minimize stress-concentration zones while carefully considering the part’s operating environment—such as the presence of corrosive media, temperature variations, and applied loads—and selecting appropriate materials accordingly. This approach helps effectively reduce the risk of fatigue failure. 2) Properly select the part machining method During various machining, welding, and heat treatment processes, residual stresses remain inside components due to factors such as plastic deformation, thermal expansion and contraction, and phase transformations occurring during these operations. Residual stresses are categorized into two types: residual tensile stress and residual compressive stress. While residual tensile stress is detrimental to component performance, residual compressive stress can significantly enhance the fatigue life of the part. Therefore, it is advisable to prioritize processes like carburizing, nitriding, shot peening, and surface rolling—methods known for generating beneficial compressive stresses—in component manufacturing. By inducing compressive stresses on the component’s surface, these techniques help counteract some of the tensile stresses caused by external loads, thereby improving the overall durability and longevity of the part. 3) Installation and Usage Instructions

user_input: What are brittle fracture and fatigue fracture, and how do they differ?
reference_contexts: ['Based on the cause of failure, fractures can be categorized into types such as brittle fracture and fatigue fracture.', 'Brittle Fracture Before fracturing, the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation; this type of fracture, which develops extremely rapidly, is known as brittle fracture. Brittle fracture occurs without any prior warning signs, making it a sudden and highly dangerous form of failure.', 'Fatigue Fracture The fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses is known as fatigue failure. In fact, 80% of fractures in mechanical components during use are caused by fatigue.']
reference: Brittle fracture and fatigue fracture are two primary categories of mechanical part failures based on their causes. Brittle fracture is characterized by the absence of noticeable plastic deformation before fracturing; it develops extremely rapidly and occurs without warning, making it sudden and highly dangerous. This type of failure can result from improper manufacturing processes, exposure to corrosive media, or adverse environmental conditions, leading to phenomena like hydrogen embrittlement, chloride stress corrosion cracking, nitrate embrittlement, alkali embrittlement, ammonia-induced embrittlement, or cold embrittlement. In contrast, fatigue fracture occurs in metal parts after they have been subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses. It is the most common cause of fractures, accounting for 80% of failures in mechanical components during use. Fatigue failure progresses through distinct stages: initiation of fatigue cracks, propagation of these cracks, and finally catastrophic failure due to unstable, rapid crack growth. Unlike brittle fracture, fatigue involves gradual damage accumulation under repetitive stress, often with visible features on the fracture surface such as a fatigue core zone and propagation zone, allowing for analysis and prevention.
answer: Brittle fracture is a type of fracture where the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation before fracturing and develops extremely rapidly, making it sudden and dangerous. Fatigue fracture is a fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses, and it typically progresses through three distinct stages: initiation, propagation, and catastrophic failure. They differ in their causes and characteristics: brittle fracture occurs suddenly with no prior plastic warning, often due to factors like improper manufacturing or environmental embrittlement, while fatigue fracture results from cyclic loading, progresses through stages leaving identifiable surface features like a fatigue core zone and crack propagation zone, and accounts for the majority of fractures in mechanical components during use.

Context:  
1.3.4 Fracture of Mechanical Parts Fracture refers to the phenomenon where a mechanical component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under the influence of certain factors. It is one of the primary modes of mechanical component failure—once a part fractures, it not only completely loses its functionality but can also lead to significant economic losses and even cause accidents resulting in injuries or fatalities. Particularly as modern manufacturing systems continue to evolve toward higher power levels and faster rotational speeds, the operating conditions for components have changed dramatically, increasing the likelihood of fracture-related failures. As a result, fracture failure has become a hot topic of research today. The fracture surface formed after a part breaks can accurately capture the dynamic evolution of the failure process. By analyzing the fracture surface, it is possible to identify the primary cause of the fracture, providing valuable insights that help refine designs and enable effective repairs. Based on the cause of failure, fractures can be categorized into types such as brittle fracture and fatigue fracture. Brittle Fracture Before fracturing, the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation; this type of fracture, which develops extremely rapidly, is known as brittle fracture.  Brittle fracture occurs without any prior warning signs, making it a sudden and highly dangerous form of failure. Metal parts may become brittle—and thus prone to sudden fracture— due to improper manufacturing processes, exposure to corrosive media during use, or adverse environmental conditions. For instance, the penetration of hydrogen or hydrides into met al materials can lead to  "hydrogen embrittlement, " while chloride ions infiltrating austenitic stainless steel may cause  "chloride stress corrosion cracking. " Similarly, nitrate ions entering carbon steel can trigger  "nitrate embrittlement, " and steel in contact with alkaline substances might suffer from  "alkali embrittlement. " Additionally, copper components exposed to ammonia can experience  "ammonia-induced embrittlement. " Furthermore, at ambient temperatures between 10°C and 15°C, medium- to low-strength carbon steels are particularly susceptible to  "cold embrittlement " (often caused by elevated phosphorus content in the steel). Meanwhile, aluminum-containing alloys, if not carefully temperature-controlled during heat treatment, can easily overh eat—even with only a slight deviation from the optimal range—leading to severe embrittlement. The hazards posed by brittle fracture in metals are significant, second only to those  associated with fatigue failure. Fatigue Fracture The fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses is known as fatigue failure. In fact, 80% of fractures in mechanical components during use are caused by fatigue. Typically, fatigue failure progresses through three distinct stages: the initiation phase of fatigue cracks; the propagation phase of fatigue cracks; and finally, catastrophic failure—the unstable, rapid growth phase of the fatigue crack. Below, we will analyze the fracture surfaces associated with fatigue failure. A typical fatigue fracture typically exhibits 3 distinct features based on the fracture process. Regions with distinct characteristics: fatigue core zone, fatigue crack propagation Zone and transient zone, as shown in Figure 1.4. Fatigue Core Zone It is the source region of fatigue fracture, visible to the naked eye or under low magnification. A magnifying glass can pinpoint the location of the fatigue core on the fracture surface—it typically does. Appearing in the area with the lowest intensity, highest stress, and closest to the surface Position. But if there are defects inside the material, this fatigue core... It could also occur at the defect site. Scratches left behind during the machining, storage, transportation, and assembly processes are highly likely to become fatigue nuclei, as these marks not only cause stress concentrations but also remain vulnerable to corrosion damage from air and other environmental factors. Figure 1.4: Schematic Diagram of Fatigue Fracture Features (Uniaxial Bending)
2) Fatigue Crack Propagation Zone This region is the most critical feature area on the fracture surface, often appearing shell-like or resembling beach ripples. Each individual line marks the trace left behind after a single crack extension event—typically corresponding to a change in applied load, such as when a machine starts up or shuts down. These lines radiate outward from the fatigue core, advancing perpendicularly to the direction of crack propagation. The smoother the crack propagation zone on the fatigue fracture surface, the more load cycles the component endured prior to failure. Conversely, the denser the shell-like lines near the instantaneous fracture zone indicate lower load magnitudes. On the other hand, if this area appears rougher, it suggests that the crack propagated rapidly under relatively high loading conditions. 3) Transient Break Zone Commonly referred to as the "static fracture surface," it is the fracture region formed when a fatigue crack rapidly propagates upon reaching a critical size. Its macroscopic features closely resemble the radial zone and shear lips typically observed in fast-fracture areas of static tensile fractures. The location and size of the instantaneous fracture zone are directly influenced by the applied load—specifically, the greater the load, the closer the final fracture area moves toward the center of the fracture surface. Conversely, a smaller fracture area indicates that the component was subjected to a lower load. 3. Fracture Failure Analysis  
Shot peening enhances a material's resistance to fatigue fracture, preventing fatigue failure, plastic deformation, and brittle fracture while extending its fatigue life.

user_input: How does the instantaneous fracture zone relate to applied load and what are its features?
reference_contexts: ["Commonly referred to as the 'static fracture surface,' it is the fracture region formed when a fatigue crack rapidly propagates upon reaching a critical size.", 'Its macroscopic features closely resemble the radial zone and shear lips typically observed in fast-fracture areas of static tensile fractures.', 'The location and size of the instantaneous fracture zone are directly influenced by the applied load鈥攕pecifically, the greater the load, the closer the final fracture area moves toward the center of the fracture surface.']
reference: The instantaneous fracture zone, also known as the 'static fracture surface,' forms when a fatigue crack rapidly propagates after reaching a critical size. Its macroscopic features resemble the radial zone and shear lips found in fast-fracture areas of static tensile fractures. The zone's location and size are directly determined by the applied load: greater loads cause the final fracture area to move closer to the center of the fracture surface, while smaller fracture areas indicate the component was subjected to lower loads.
answer: The instantaneous fracture zone's location and size are directly influenced by the applied load, with a greater load moving the final fracture area closer to the center of the fracture surface and a smaller fracture area indicating a lower load, and its macroscopic features resemble the radial zone and shear lips of static tensile fractures.

user_input: What are the initial steps in fracture failure analysis after a major equipment accident?
reference_contexts: ['On-site recording and photography After a major equipment accident occurs, promptly investigate and understand all circumstances before and after the incident, and take photographs or videos if necessary.', 'Unless there are casualties requiring immediate attention, efforts should be made to preserve the scene as much as possible.']
reference: The initial steps involve on-site recording and photography. Immediately after a major equipment accident occurs, investigators must promptly investigate and understand all circumstances before and after the incident. Photographs or videos should be taken if necessary to document the scene. Unless there are casualties requiring immediate attention, every effort should be made to preserve the accident scene in its original state to maintain evidence integrity.
answer: The initial steps in fracture failure analysis after a major equipment accident are on-site recording and photography, analyzing the dominant failure component, and identifying the dominant crack on that component.

(Identify the dominant crack, is step, fracture failure analysis) — This directly states the third step in the analysis process.

Context:  
The steps for fracture failure analysis are generally as follows. 1) On-site recording and photography After a major equipment accident occurs, promptly investigate and understand all circumstances before and after the incident, and take photographs or videos if necessary. Unless there are casualties requiring immediate attention, efforts should be made to preserve the scene as much as possible. 2) Analyze the dominant failure component When a critical component fails due to fracture, it often leads to the failure of other related parts and structural elements. In such cases, it’s essential to carefully determine the sequence of events and accurately identify the primary fracture-causing component—otherwise, the analysis results could be misleading. 3) Identify the dominant crack on the primary failure component The dominant failure component may already be fragmented; therefore, the remaining fragments should be collected, carefully pieced together, and analyzed to identify which crack initiated first—this crack is the dominant one. 4) Identifying the Failure Source Area Once the dominant crack is identified, you can then examine the corresponding fracture surface to locate the crack initiation zone. 5) Fracture Surface Treatment If further microscopic analysis of the fracture surface is required, or if it’s necessary to preserve evidence, the fracture surface should be cleaned. Typically, clean with compressed air or alcohol, then dry thoroughly afterward. If long-term storage is required, apply rust-preventive oil or grease and store in a sealed container equipped with a desiccant. 6) Determine the cause of failure
When determining the failure cause of a part, consider the material properties, manufacturing process, load conditions, assembly quality, and years of use. Carefully examine and analyze factors such as the medium and temperature in the working environment, as well as the usage conditions of similar parts, before combining this information with the macroscopic and microscopic features of the fracture surface to make an accurate assessment and identify the primary and secondary causes of the failure. 7) Identify Failure Countermeasures Once the cause of failure is identified, targeted solutions are proposed to effectively leverage existing conditions and prevent fracture incidents from occurring.

user_input: How should fracture surfaces be treated for microscopic analysis or long-term storage?
reference_contexts: ["Fracture Surface Treatment If further microscopic analysis of the fracture surface is required, or if it's necessary to preserve evidence, the fracture surface should be cleaned.", 'Typically, clean with compressed air or alcohol, then dry thoroughly afterward.', 'If long-term storage is required, apply rust-preventive oil or grease and store in a sealed container equipped with a desiccant.']
reference: Fracture surfaces require specific treatment procedures depending on the intended use. For microscopic analysis or evidence preservation, the fracture surface must be cleaned first - typically using compressed air or alcohol, followed by thorough drying. For long-term storage requirements, additional protective measures are necessary: rust-preventive oil or grease should be applied to the surface, and the component should be stored in a sealed container that includes a desiccant to prevent moisture damage and corrosion.
answer: For microscopic analysis, the fracture surface should be cleaned with compressed air or alcohol and dried thoroughly; for long-term storage, apply rust-preventive oil or grease and store it in a sealed container with a desiccant.

user_input: What factors should be considered when determining the failure cause of a part?
reference_contexts: ['When determining the failure cause of a part, consider the material properties, manufacturing process, load conditions, assembly quality, and years of use.', 'Carefully examine and analyze factors such as the medium and temperature in the working environment, as well as the usage conditions of similar parts, before combining this information with the macroscopic and microscopic features of the fracture surface to make an accurate assessment and identify the primary and secondary causes of the failure.']
reference: To determine the failure cause of a part, several factors must be considered. These include the material properties of the part, the manufacturing process used to create it, the load conditions it was subjected to, the quality of its assembly, and the number of years it has been in use. Additionally, it is essential to examine and analyze the medium and temperature in the working environment, as well as the usage conditions of similar parts. This information should then be combined with an analysis of the macroscopic and microscopic features of the fracture surface. This comprehensive approach allows for an accurate assessment, helping to identify both the primary and secondary causes of the failure.
answer: When determining the failure cause of a part, factors to consider include material properties, manufacturing process, load conditions, assembly quality, years of use, the medium and temperature in the working environment, the usage conditions of similar parts, and the macroscopic and microscopic features of the fracture surface, as well as key influencing factors such as design planning, material selection, manufacturing quality, assembly quality, and proper maintenance.

(1) The defined object. This refers to a single machine, a system composed of several individual machines, or a specific component on the equipment. Different objects may experience varying failure conditions at the same time. For instance, on an automated production line, the failure of a single machine can be enough to disable the entire system; however, in a workshop with a clustered machine layout, the failure of one machine would not necessarily be linked to a breakdown affecting the entire workshop. (2) Time-to-failure. This refers to the fact that the probability of a failure increases as time goes on. In addition to using direct units like years, months, days, or hours, time can also be measured by the number of equipment operations, mileage, or cycles. For instance, vehicles typically use total miles driven as their unit of measurement, while gears might be measured by the number of load-bearing cycles they endure. (3) The specified conditions. These refer to the operational and maintenance conditions during equipment operation, the skill level of personnel, environmental factors, and more. Different conditions will lead to different types of failures. (4) The specified function. It depends on the particular issue at hand. For example, in a lathe operating in the same state, damage to the feed screw would be considered a malfunction when it comes to threading operations—but not when machining end faces, since the two scenarios require different functional capabilities from the lathe. (5) A certain degree of failure. This refers to assessing the severity of functional loss from a quantitative perspective. In production practice, to encompass all possible events, a broad definition of failure has been established: "A failure is an unqualified state." 1.1.2 Classification of Failures Mechanical and electrical equipment failures can be categorized from various perspectives, with each classification method highlighting a different aspect of the fault. The purpose of categorizing failures is to assess the severity of the incident, analyze its root causes, and ultimately enable more effective, tailored responses to address the specific types of malfunctions. By examining factors such as failure nature, underlying causes, and distinctive characteristics, faults can be grouped into the following categories. By fault nature (1) Intermittent failures. The equipment temporarily loses certain functions, with the faults often caused by external factors affecting the mechanical and electrical systems—such as operator error, climate changes, or inadequate environmental conditions. Once the external interference is removed or the equipment undergoes minor repairs and adjustments, its functionality typically resumes. (2) Permanent failure. Once this type of failure occurs, it can only be restored through manual repair; otherwise, the fault will persist indefinitely. Such failures are typically caused by damage to specific components. 2) By Severity of the Fault (1) Localized failure. A specific part of the机电 equipment is malfunctioning, causing that particular component to lose its functionality while other parts continue to operate as intended—essentially, a partial functional breakdown. (2) Systemic Failure. A failure that results in the complete loss of system functionality—though it may initially appear as a malfunction in a specific component, it ultimately prevents the device from performing its intended function altogether. 1.1.5 Key Factors Influencing Failure Generation The more complex the mechanical and electrical equipment, the more diverse the potential causes of failure. The main factors influencing these failures include the following aspects. 1) Design Planning In the design planning phase, accurate estimates of the equipment's future operating conditions are essential, and potential variations should be thoroughly considered. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 7 Consideration: Imperfect design solutions and inadequate review of design drawings and technical documents are major causes of failures. 2) Material Selection In design, manufacturing, and maintenance, it is essential to correctly select materials based on the nature and characteristics of the part’s function. Improper material selection, failure to meet specified material standards, or the use of inappropriate substitutes are major causes of phenomena such as wear, corrosion, excessive deformation, fatigue, cracking, and aging. Additionally, during manufacturing and repair processes, many materials undergo various fabrication steps, including casting, forging, welding, and heat treatment. Throughout these processes, the microstructure and mechanical/physical properties of the materials often undergo significant changes—among which the effects of heating and cooling are particularly critical. 3) Manufacturing Quality Errors exist in every step of the manufacturing process. The variability in process conditions and material properties inevitably leads to differences among parts during casting, Stress concentrations, local defects, and microscopic cracks—such as those arising during forging, welding, heat treatment, and machining—are common issues. These flaws are often overlooked during process inspections. As a result, the manufacturing quality of parts frequently fails to meet requirements, which is a major reason behind the short lifespan of mechanical equipment. 4) Assembly Quality First, there must be proper fit requirements. The tolerance limits for the clearance include the initial clearance that remains after assembly and running-in. If the initial clearance is too large, the effective service life will be shortened. Additionally, the positional accuracy between individual components during assembly is critical—failure to meet these specifications can lead to additional stresses, uneven wear, and ultimately accelerate component failure. 5) Proper Maintenance

16 1. Equipment Fault Diagnosis Process Equipment fault diagnosis encompasses three key areas: condition monitoring, analytical diagnosis, and fault prediction. The specific implementation process can be summarized into the following four steps. 1) Signal Acquisition During operation, equipment inevitably experiences changes in various quantities such as force, heat, vibration, and energy, generating a wide range of distinct information. Depending on specific diagnostic needs, it is crucial to select signals that accurately reflect the equipment's operational status—such as vibration, pressure, or temperature—since these signals are typically captured using different types of sensors. 2) Signal Processing This is the process of classifying and processing the collected signals to extract features that accurately represent the machine's characteristics—also known as feature extraction. For example, transforming a vibration signal from the time domain to the frequency domain for spectral analysis is part of this process. 3) State Recognition The device's characteristic parameters, obtained after signal processing, are compared with the specified allowable or discriminant parameters to determine the device's condition. The current status—whether a fault exists, and if so, its type and nature. To address this, appropriate identification criteria and diagnostic strategies should be carefully developed. 4) Diagnostic Decision-making
The steps for fracture failure analysis are generally as follows. 1) On-site recording and photography After a major equipment accident occurs, promptly investigate and understand all circumstances before and after the incident, and take photographs or videos if necessary. Unless there are casualties requiring immediate attention, efforts should be made to preserve the scene as much as possible. 2) Analyze the dominant failure component When a critical component fails due to fracture, it often leads to the failure of other related parts and structural elements. In such cases, it’s essential to carefully determine the sequence of events and accurately identify the primary fracture-causing component—otherwise, the analysis results could be misleading. 3) Identify the dominant crack on the primary failure component The dominant failure component may already be fragmented; therefore, the remaining fragments should be collected, carefully pieced together, and analyzed to identify which crack initiated first—this crack is the dominant one. 4) Identifying the Failure Source Area Once the dominant crack is identified, you can then examine the corresponding fracture surface to locate the crack initiation zone. 5) Fracture Surface Treatment If further microscopic analysis of the fracture surface is required, or if it’s necessary to preserve evidence, the fracture surface should be cleaned. Typically, clean with compressed air or alcohol, then dry thoroughly afterward. If long-term storage is required, apply rust-preventive oil or grease and store in a sealed container equipped with a desiccant. 6) Determine the cause of failure

user_input: What measures can be taken to reduce fracture failure in metal parts?
reference_contexts: ['Strategies to minimize fracture failures can be considered from the following perspectives.', '1) Optimize the shape and structural design of parts, and carefully select appropriate materials for the components.', 'Both geometric discontinuities in part shapes and material imperfections can lead to stress concentration.']
reference: To reduce fracture failure in metal parts, two primary measures should be implemented. First, optimize the shape and structural design of parts while carefully selecting appropriate materials. This involves minimizing stress-concentration zones, which are areas prone to crack initiation and propagation under cyclic or impact loading. Geometric discontinuities (notches) such as fillets at shoulders, grooves, oil holes, keyways, threads, and machining marks should be reduced. Material defects like shrinkage porosity, shrinkage cavities, non-metallic inclusions, and welding flaws must also be considered. The part's operating environment鈥攊ncluding corrosive media, temperature variations, and applied loads鈥攕hould guide material selection to effectively reduce fatigue failure risk. Second, properly select the machining method to manage residual stresses. Processes like carburizing, nitriding, shot peening, and surface rolling are recommended because they generate beneficial compressive stresses on the component's surface. These compressive stresses counteract tensile stresses from external loads, significantly enhancing fatigue life and improving overall part durability and longevity.
answer: Measures to reduce fracture failure in metal parts include optimizing the shape and structural design of parts to minimize stress concentration zones and carefully selecting appropriate materials considering the operating environment, and properly selecting the part machining method by prioritizing processes like carburizing, nitriding, shot peening, and surface rolling to induce beneficial residual compressive stresses on the component's surface.

4. Measures to Reduce Fracture Failure Fracture failure is one of the most dangerous forms of failure, and most metal parts fail due to various factors arising from metallurgy and part manufacturing processes. Because all of them contain cracks of varying sizes and characteristics, ranging from atomic-level dislocations to macroscopic cracks visible to the naked eye. However, a part with cracks doesn’t necessarily fail immediately—there’s typically a period during which these cracks undergo subcritical propagation. Moreover, under certain conditions, cracks may even remain stable without expanding at all. Therefore, by implementing effective measures, it’s possible to ensure that parts containing cracks do not ultimately fracture. Strategies to minimize fracture failures can be considered from the following perspectives. 1) Optimize the shape and structural design of parts, and carefully select appropriate materials for the components. Both geometric discontinuities in part shapes and material imperfections can lead to stress concentration. Geometric discontinuities are commonly referred to as notches, such as fillets at shoulders, grooves, oil holes, keyways, threads, and machining marks. Material-related discontinuities are typically called material defects, including shrinkage porosity, shrinkage cavities, non-metallic inclusions, and welding flaws. These areas prone to stress concentration are particularly susceptible to crack initiation and propagation under cyclic or impact loading, ultimately leading to fracture. Therefore, in part design, it’s crucial to minimize stress-concentration zones while carefully considering the part’s operating environment—such as the presence of corrosive media, temperature variations, and applied loads—and selecting appropriate materials accordingly. This approach helps effectively reduce the risk of fatigue failure. 2) Properly select the part machining method During various machining, welding, and heat treatment processes, residual stresses remain inside components due to factors such as plastic deformation, thermal expansion and contraction, and phase transformations occurring during these operations. Residual stresses are categorized into two types: residual tensile stress and residual compressive stress. While residual tensile stress is detrimental to component performance, residual compressive stress can significantly enhance the fatigue life of the part. Therefore, it is advisable to prioritize processes like carburizing, nitriding, shot peening, and surface rolling—methods known for generating beneficial compressive stresses—in component manufacturing. By inducing compressive stresses on the component’s surface, these techniques help counteract some of the tensile stresses caused by external loads, thereby improving the overall durability and longevity of the part. 3) Installation and Usage Instructions

1.3.4 Fracture of Mechanical Parts Fracture refers to the phenomenon where a mechanical component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under the influence of certain factors. It is one of the primary modes of mechanical component failure—once a part fractures, it not only completely loses its functionality but can also lead to significant economic losses and even cause accidents resulting in injuries or fatalities. Particularly as modern manufacturing systems continue to evolve toward higher power levels and faster rotational speeds, the operating conditions for components have changed dramatically, increasing the likelihood of fracture-related failures. As a result, fracture failure has become a hot topic of research today. The fracture surface formed after a part breaks can accurately capture the dynamic evolution of the failure process. By analyzing the fracture surface, it is possible to identify the primary cause of the fracture, providing valuable insights that help refine designs and enable effective repairs. Based on the cause of failure, fractures can be categorized into types such as brittle fracture and fatigue fracture. Brittle Fracture Before fracturing, the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation; this type of fracture, which develops extremely rapidly, is known as brittle fracture.  Brittle fracture occurs without any prior warning signs, making it a sudden and highly dangerous form of failure. Metal parts may become brittle—and thus prone to sudden fracture— due to improper manufacturing processes, exposure to corrosive media during use, or adverse environmental conditions. For instance, the penetration of hydrogen or hydrides into met al materials can lead to  "hydrogen embrittlement, " while chloride ions infiltrating austenitic stainless steel may cause  "chloride stress corrosion cracking. " Similarly, nitrate ions entering carbon steel can trigger  "nitrate embrittlement, " and steel in contact with alkaline substances might suffer from  "alkali embrittlement. " Additionally, copper components exposed to ammonia can experience  "ammonia-induced embrittlement. " Furthermore, at ambient temperatures between 10°C and 15°C, medium- to low-strength carbon steels are particularly susceptible to  "cold embrittlement " (often caused by elevated phosphorus content in the steel). Meanwhile, aluminum-containing alloys, if not carefully temperature-controlled during heat treatment, can easily overh eat—even with only a slight deviation from the optimal range—leading to severe embrittlement. The hazards posed by brittle fracture in metals are significant, second only to those  associated with fatigue failure. Fatigue Fracture The fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses is known as fatigue failure. In fact, 80% of fractures in mechanical components during use are caused by fatigue. Typically, fatigue failure progresses through three distinct stages: the initiation phase of fatigue cracks; the propagation phase of fatigue cracks; and finally, catastrophic failure—the unstable, rapid growth phase of the fatigue crack. Below, we will analyze the fracture surfaces associated with fatigue failure. A typical fatigue fracture typically exhibits 3 distinct features based on the fracture process. Regions with distinct characteristics: fatigue core zone, fatigue crack propagation Zone and transient zone, as shown in Figure 1.4. Fatigue Core Zone It is the source region of fatigue fracture, visible to the naked eye or under low magnification. A magnifying glass can pinpoint the location of the fatigue core on the fracture surface—it typically does. Appearing in the area with the lowest intensity, highest stress, and closest to the surface Position. But if there are defects inside the material, this fatigue core... It could also occur at the defect site. Scratches left behind during the machining, storage, transportation, and assembly processes are highly likely to become fatigue nuclei, as these marks not only cause stress concentrations but also remain vulnerable to corrosion damage from air and other environmental factors.

1.4 Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Procedures and Implementation With the continuous advancement of new materials, processes, and technologies, repairing mechanical parts has evolved beyond simply restoring them to their original condition. Many advanced techniques now not only revive components but also enhance their performance and extend their service life. For instance, methods such as electroplating, surfacing welding, application of wear-resistant coatings, thermal spraying and flame spraying, adhesive bonding, and various surface-hardening treatments allow for the precise deposition of small amounts of high-performance materials onto part surfaces—at relatively low costs—while significantly boosting wear resistance. As a result, in the maintenance of electromechanical equipment, fully leveraging these repair techniques and carefully selecting appropriate processes can reduce downtime, cut maintenance expenses, and ultimately lead to substantial improvements in a company’s economic efficiency. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Repair for Electromechanical Equipment 27
2) Condition Monitoring and Maintenance This is a preventive maintenance approach based on the equipment's technical condition, carried out precisely when needed. It relies on condition monitoring and advanced diagnostic techniques to track the gradual deterioration of equipment over time. By leveraging highly predictive insights, this method allows for timely scheduling of preventive maintenance activities, which is why it’s also referred to as "predictive maintenance." At its core, this maintenance strategy integrates comprehensive data from various sources—such as inspections, routine upkeep, operational use, and repair activities—especially insights gained from diagnostics and monitoring. Through rigorous statistical analysis, it accurately assesses the extent of equipment degradation, identifies specific areas where failures may occur (or are likely to occur), and predicts trends in the equipment’s overall technical condition. Armed with this information, operators can then determine the most appropriate type of maintenance intervention. By doing so, organizations gain full control over maintenance activities, ensuring thorough preparation before repairs begin. Moreover, this approach enables seamless coordination with production schedules, maximizing equipment utilization while simultaneously extending the lifespan of critical components. However, this method does come with some drawbacks: it tends to be more expensive and requires sophisticated diagnostic capabilities. Additionally, it demands highly skilled technicians who can interpret complex data and make informed decisions. This approach is particularly well-suited for critical, high-value equipment, key assets on production lines, machinery that cannot be easily disassembled for inspection (such as precision machine tools), and systems whose failure could lead to significant environmental or public health concerns.

Improve Maintenance Improvement maintenance, also known as corrective maintenance, refers to a type of repair that enhances the technical performance of mechanical and electrical equipment to prevent recurring failures. It involves integrating maintenance activities with technological upgrades, ensuring that after repairs, key aspects such as precision, performance, and efficiency of the equipment are improved. Rate. During operation, mechanical and electrical equipment often has certain weak links, which necessitates technical improvements and structural modifications to specific devices or components. A key feature of improvement-based maintenance is its integrated approach, frequently combined with major overhauls and targeted repairs in actual production settings. Overall, maintaining mechanical and electrical equipment requires meeting four fundamental criteria: neatness, cleanliness, lubrication, and saf ety. Developing clear equipment operation and maintenance procedures is a crucial step in ensuring that all subsequent operations are carried out systematically and efficiently. (2) List the structural features, processing range, operational precautions, main tenance requirements, and more separately by equipment category, making it easier for operators to grasp the key points and ensure proper implementation. (3) Common elements across  various types of mechanical and electrical equipment can be used to develop a unified, standard general procedure. Also, post prominent signage near the machine tool, clearly i ndicating that operators should pay special attention and strictly adhere to the guidelines. 2) Basic Content of Operation and Maintenance Procedures
4Fe + 3O₂ → 2Fe₂O₃ 3Fe + 2O₂ → Fe₃O₄ Corrosion products such as Fe₂O₃ or Fe₃O₄ typically form a protective film that coats the metal surface. During friction, Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 21 After the surface oxide film is worn away, the friction surface quickly reacts with the oxidizing medium, forming a new oxide layer that is subsequently removed during the friction  process. This cyclical process ultimately leads to metal corrosion. A key characteristic of oxidative wear is the presence of uniform, fine grooves aligned along the sliding direc tion on the friction surface, accompanied by reddish-brown flaky Fe₂O₃ or grayish-black filamentous Fe₃O₄ debris. Debris is generated. The primary factors influencing oxidative wea r are the density and integrity of the oxide film, as well as how firmly it adheres to the substrate. If the oxide film is dense, intact, free of pores, and strongly bonded to the  metal substrate, it exhibits excellent wear resistance, resists being worn away easily, and effectively helps prevent corrosion of the metal surface. 2. Electrochemical Corrosion o f Metal Parts Electrochemical corrosion is a complex physical and chemical process of corrosion. It can be defined as the continuous, charge-driven chemical corrosion that occurs w hen two metal electrodes with a potential difference are immersed in an electrolyte solution. This type of corrosion happens when metals come into contact with electrolytic substan ces, and its key distinction from ordinary chemical corrosion lies in the fact that it involves the flow of electric current during the process. The fundamental conditions necessar y for electrochemical corrosion to occur are: ① the presence of two or more objects with differing electrode potentials—or, within a single object, regions exhibiting different ele ctrode potentials—that act as positive and negative electrodes; ② a conductive pathway connecting the electrodes, either through a conductor or direct contact, allowing charges in  the corrosion zone to flow freely; and ③ the simultaneous presence of an electrolyte solution. Common forms of electrochemical corrosion include the following: (1) Uniform corrosio n. When a metal part or component exhibits a uniform corrosion pattern across its surface, it is referred to as uniform corrosion. This type of corrosion can occur in liquids, the  atmosphere, or soil. Among mechanical equipment, the most common form of uniform corrosion is atmospheric corrosion. In industrial areas, the atmosphere often contains higher conce ntrations of corrosive gases such as CO₂, SO₂, H₂S, NO₂, and Cl₂. Additionally, airborne dust particles may carry acidic, alkaline, or saline micro-particles, which, when adhering  to the surface of components, can absorb moisture from the air and form an electrolyte, ultimately leading to corrosion on the part's surface. (2) Pitting corrosion. On most surfac es of metal components, corrosion either doesn’t occur at all or is very mild; however, localized areas develop small corrosion pits that penetrate deeply into the material. This t ype of corrosion is known as pitting corrosion. Because metals used in industry often contain extremely tiny microelectrodes, they are highly susceptible to pitting corrosion when  exposed to aqueous solutions or humid environments. In the case of steel components, when pitting corrosion occurs alongside uniform corrosion, the corrosion spots can easily becom e obscured by the porous structure formed during uniform corrosion, making them difficult to detect and identify. As a result, pitting corrosion is one of the most dangerous forms  of corrosion. (3) Crevice corrosion. In机电 equipment, gaps exist between various connected components—typically ranging from 0.025 to 0.1 mm. When corrosive media enter these gaps a nd remain trapped, localized corrosion can occur precisely at the crevices. For instance, this type of crevice corrosion often happens at flange faces where pipes are connected, as  well as at the riveted joints of metal rivets. (4) Corrosion Fatigue. When metallic components subjected to cyclic stress experience reduced fatigue strength or shortened fatigue  life—and ultimately fail—due to the presence of a corrosive environment, this phenomenon is known as corrosion fatigue or corrosion fatigue fracture. Corrosion fatigue can cause me tal components to fracture even under very low levels of cyclic (pulsating) stress, and often there is no clear fatigue limit. As a result, damage caused by corrosion fatigue tends  to be more severe than that resulting from pure mechanical fatigue alone. To prevent and reduce corrosion failures, as well as minimize their harmful effects on equipment, special  attention must be paid during the manufacturing process to correctly selecting materials for components and thoughtfully designing various structural elements. Additionally, for p arts operating in corrosive environments, advanced anti-corrosion measures such as surface coating technologies, electrochemical protection techniques, and the addition of corrosio n inhibitors should be employed to ensure that these components remain protected—or at least minimally affected—by corrosive agents.
When designing, it's essential to consider not only the strength of the parts but also their stiffness, as well as issues related to manufacturing, assembly, usage, disassembly, and maintenance. (1) Select materials carefully, paying attention to their process properties—such as casting fluidity and shrinkage, forging ductility and cold-heading capability, weldability characteristics like susceptibility to cold and hot cracking, machinability for ease of cutting, and heat-treatment properties including hardenability and resistance to cold brittleness. (2) Properly arrange the parts to optimize their stress distribution. Select appropriate structural dimensions, ensuring uniform wall thicknesses as much as possible, and minimize deformation during hot working processes. For instance, avoid sharp corners by replacing them with rounded or chamfered edges; for areas with significant thickness variations, consider adding process holes or reinforcing excessively thin sections. Additionally, carefully position any existing holes—transforming blind holes into through-holes where feasible. For parts with complex geometries, whenever possible, opt for modular or assembled designs to further enhance stress management. (3) In the design process, ensure the application of new technologies, processes, and materials to minimize internal stresses and deformation during manufacturing. 2) Manufacturing In the rough casting manufacturing process, it is important to address deformation issues and implement various process measures to minimize residual stresses in the blank. After the raw parts are produced and during subsequent machining processes, it is essential to incorporate sufficient steps for relieving internal stresses, aiming to minimize residual stresses within the components. One effective method to eliminate these residuals is through aging treatment, which can be either natural or artificial. Natural aging involves leaving the finished raw parts exposed outdoors for 1 to 2 years. This approach leverages the material’s inherent property of gradually releasing internal stresses over a period of 12 to 20 months—making it particularly effective—but the main drawback is the excessively long aging cycle. On the other hand, artificial aging accelerates the stress-relief process by subjecting the parts to high-temperature annealing followed by controlled cooling at a slow pace. Alternatively, vibrational techniques can also be employed to achieve artificial aging. For high-precision components, artificial aging must be integrated into the final machining stages to ensure optimal dimensional accuracy and stability. During machining and repair processes, minimize the number of datum shifts, preserving the original machining datums for use during maintenance, thereby reducing repair time. Errors caused by inconsistent benchmarks during machining. For parts that have undergone heat treatment, be sure to allow sufficient machining allowances and adjust the machining dimensions accordingly. Pre-applying controlled deformation is crucial—once the deformation patterns of the part are understood, you can counteract them in advance by introducing an equal but opposite amount of deformation. Alternatively, you can pre-stress the part or carefully manage the generation and evolution of stresses, ensuring that the final deformation aligns with specifications and effectively minimizes distortion. 3) Maintenance Aspects During maintenance, it is essential to not only meet the technical requirements—such as restoring part dimensions, ensuring proper fit tolerances, and achieving high surface quality—but also to inspect and correct any shape or positional errors in critical components. To minimize stress and deformation of parts during repair, standardized guidelines and maintenance procedures specifically addressing deformation issues should be established. Additionally, simple, reliable, and user-friendly specialized measuring tools and fixtures should be designed. Finally, it’s important to actively promote "three new" technologies, particularly innovative repair techniques like brush plating and bonding. 4) Usage Instructions
1.4.1 Preparations Before Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Electromechanical equipment occupies a critically important position in the production and operational activities of modern industrial enterprises. To ensure smooth equipment operation and safe production, implementing planned preventive maintenance is an essential component of equipment management and repair practices in industrial companies. This section will cover the detailed process of major equipment overhauls, the determination of equipment repair plans, as well as the technical and material preparations required prior to equipment maintenance. 1. Equipment Major Overhaul Process To ensure the precision and operational performance of mechanical and electrical equipment, preventive scheduled maintenance must be carried out in addition to routine upkeep. Among these preventive measures, major overhauls stand out as a critical task aimed at restoring the equipment's accuracy. Within the category of preventive maintenance, major overhauls—often referred to simply as "overhauls"—represent the most extensive and time-consuming type of repair. An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit. The ultimate goal is to thoroughly eliminate any pre-existing defects and restore the equipment to its specified performance standards. The purpose of precision and performance. The major steps involved in the overhaul of mechanical and electrical equipment typically include: pre-disassembly unit inspection, component removal, component inspection, necessary component disassembly, parts cleaning and examination, component repair and assembly, final assembly, no-load trial operation, load testing, overall machine precision verification, and final acceptance. In practice, these tasks should be carried out according to the overhaul work plan, while also ensuring effective job scheduling, quality control during operations, and thorough completion acceptance. The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment is typically divided into three stages: pre-repair preparation, the repair process itself, and post-repair acceptance. Pre-repair preparation phase To ensure the repair work proceeds smoothly and accurately, maintenance personnel should carefully listen to operators' requirements for equipment repairs and thoroughly understand the issues affecting the equipment being serviced—such as loss of precision, the extent of wear on major mechanical components, the accuracy of the transmission system, and any visible defects. They should also identify which parts need improvement or modification to meet the equipment’s operational specifications. Additionally, they should review relevant technical documentation, equipment manuals, and previous maintenance records to become familiar with the device’s structural features, transmission system, and original design precision standards. This preparation will enable them to propose comprehensive pre-inspection tasks. Following the pre-inspection, specific repair methods for critical and large components can be determined, allowing for the preparation of specialized tools and precision measuring instruments. Finally, the team must define the post-repair precision testing procedures and establish clear acceptance criteria for trial runs, ensuring all technical preparations are fully in place before proceeding with the complete overhaul of the equipment.

During the maintenance process, repairs are categorized into several levels and types based on the depth and breadth of the work required, including major overhauls, mi d-level repairs, minor repairs, item-specific repairs, retrofits, and unplanned maintenance tasks—all determined by the scale and nature of the repair workload. (1) Overhaul: A com prehensive or fundamental restoration of the functionality of mechanical and electrical equipment, typically carried out by specialized maintenance teams within factories and mines —or at repair centers established in regions with a high concentration of industrial facilities.
