2) Maintenance Process Stage Once the maintenance process begins, the first step is to disassemble the equipment—following a sequence and approach that reverses the original assembly order, adhering to the principle of "top-down and outside-in." This systematic method carefully releases the components from their interlocking and fixed positions within the machine. After removal, each part should undergo a secondary pre-inspection. Based on the findings from this second check, any additional repair parts required will be identified. Furthermore, the availability of replacement and repaired components, along with their current status, will help establish a rough schedule for the maintenance tasks. This ensures that the repair work progresses methodically and according to plan, preventing delays caused by poor coordination in organizational efforts. The precision and performance achievable during equipment maintenance depend on factors such as the technical expertise available for repair work, the number of major overhauls the equipment has undergone, and its pre-repair technical condition. Generally speaking, for machinery undergoing its first major overhaul, both its precision and performance should ideally meet the original factory standards. However, after two or more major overhauls, the equipment’s post-repair precision and performance typically fall short of those of a new unit. That said, if the equipment was in relatively good technical condition prior to the last overhaul, it will likely be easier to restore its quality closer to the original factory standards this time around. Conversely, if the previous overhaul left the equipment in suboptimal condition, it may create significant challenges for the next major repair—and in some cases, the resulting quality might even fail to meet the original factory standards, making further repairs impractical altogether. The assembly of the complete equipment is carried out according to acceptance criteria. During assembly, appropriate reference surfaces should be selected for accurate mechanical and electrical system fault diagnosis and maintenance case studies.

Conversely, if the equipment was left in suboptimal condition after a previous overhaul, it creates significant challenges for the next major repair. In such cases, the resulting quality may fail to meet the original factory standards, and further repairs could become impractical.
answer: The pre-repair technical condition directly affects the precision and performance outcome of a major overhaul, where a good condition enables restoration closer to original standards while a poor condition creates challenges for the repair and can lead to substandard results that may fail to meet original standards.

28 Determine the form and compensation method for the error compensation环节, ensuring assembly accuracy among all components—such as parallelism, coaxiality, perpendicularity, and the required meshing precision of the transmission. 3) Post-Repair Acceptance Phase All equipment that has undergone repair, assembly, and adjustment must be subjected to comprehensive precision checks and tests—such as geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluations—in accordance with the relevant prescribed accuracy standards or the precision criteria established prior to repair. These measures ensure a thorough assessment of the repaired equipment’s quality, restored precision, and overall performance. After equipment maintenance, record the modifications made to the original technical documentation and document any lessons learned during the repair process. Prepare a thorough post-repair summary and file it alongside the original documents for future reference during the next maintenance task. 2. Determining the Equipment Maintenance Plan Major equipment overhauls must not only meet the predetermined technical requirements but also strive to enhance economic efficiency. Therefore, before starting repairs, it’s essential to thoroughly assess the equipment’s technical condition, develop a practical and feasible repair plan, and ensure comprehensive preparation—both technically and in terms of production readiness. During the repair process, actively incorporate new technologies, materials, processes, and modern management techniques, while diligently managing technical, financial, and organizational aspects to guarantee high-quality workmanship, minimize downtime, and reduce overall maintenance costs. A pre-inspection must be conducted to thoroughly assess the equipment's technical condition before repairs, identify the main defects present, and analyze the product-specific process requirements that influence the equipment's technical specifications—allowing for the immediate development of a repair plan. 3. Technical Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment—along with developing the overall maintenance production schedule. Pre-inspection survey preparation work To gain a comprehensive understanding of the specific condition of equipment degradation, schedule a shutdown inspection before the major overhaul—this is referred to as a pre-inspection. Before conducting the equipment pre-inspection, ensure the following preparatory investigations are completed. (1) Review the following equipment records: factory inspection reports; precision and performance verification records from equipment installation acceptance tests; details of all past equipment incidents, malfunctions, and repairs, including any remaining issues after repairs; records of all previous maintenance activities, including replaced or repaired components, as well as any unresolved problems left behind after servicing; and operational status monitoring logs and comprehensive equipment inspection records.
5. Improve Maintenance Improvement maintenance, also known as corrective maintenance, refers to a type of repair that enhances the technical performance of mechanical and electrical equipment to prevent recurring failures. It involves integrating maintenance activities with technological upgrades, ensuring that after repairs, key aspects such as precision, performance, and efficiency of the equipment are improved. Rate. During operation, mechanical and electrical equipment often has certain weak links, which necessitates technical improvements and structural modifications to specific devices or components. These enhancements aim to boost reliability and elevate the overall technological level of the equipment, ultimately leading to better economic outcomes. A key feature of improvement-based maintenance is its integrated approach, frequently combined with major overhauls and targeted repairs in actual production settings. When implementing such improvement maintenance, it’s essential to systematically address and refine the mechanisms of the equipment, as well as enhance the diagnostic and repair capabilities of electromechanical systems—based on thorough inspection and analysis of component failures. 10
③ Having well-equipped maintenance facilities organized according to functional divisions and strategically located for optimal efficiency. The main drawback of the planned preven tive maintenance system is its poor cost-effectiveness. With fixed maintenance cycles and scopes, it often leads to unnecessary repairs of certain components—what’s known as over-m aintenance. During the maintenance process, repairs are categorized into several levels and types based on the depth and breadth of the work required, including major overhauls, mi d-level repairs, minor repairs, item-specific repairs, retrofits, and unplanned maintenance tasks—all determined by the scale and nature of the repair workload. (1) Overhaul: A com prehensive or fundamental restoration of the functionality of mechanical and electrical equipment, typically carried out by specialized maintenance teams within factories and mines —or at repair centers established in regions with a high concentration of industrial facilities. During an overhaul, the equipment is either fully or extensively disassembled, with  a focus on repairing critical components, replacing or refurbishing parts that have lost their function or are on the verge of doing so. After the repairs, the equipment’s precisi on is restored to nearly its original factory specifications, while also receiving a fresh cosmetic overhaul to enhance its appearance. (2) Intermediate Overhaul. This is a level o f maintenance that falls between major and minor overhauls, serving as a balanced approach to upkeep. (3) Minor Repair. This involves replacing or repairing components that have si gnificantly worn out or are nearing failure within the maintenance interval, without addressing any underlying structural issues. It is a troubleshooting-based repair aimed at rest oring functionality. The three levels—major overhaul, mid-term repair, and minor repair—objectively reflect the chronological progression of机电 equipment, making them ideally suited  for implementing time-based planned preventive maintenance, a practice widely adopted by most organizations. However, these levels still require complementary repair tiers to addr ess unforeseen maintenance needs effectively. (4) Item-based maintenance. Based on condition monitoring of mechanical and electrical equipment, this involves proactively planning r epairs specifically for components or technical items that are about to fail. Item-based maintenance is conducted between major, medium, and minor overhauls—it’s a non-periodic, pl anned maintenance level that doesn’t follow a fixed cycle. (5) Retrofitting. This involves making localized modifications to existing mechanical and electrical equipment using new  technologies, materials, structures, and processes, with the goal of enhancing its precision, functionality, productivity, and reliability. Such repairs are classified as improveme nt-oriented, and the extent of the work required depends on how well the original equipment’s design accommodates the retrofitting process—as well as on the specific level of perfo rmance enhancement desired for the equipment. Retrofitting is also referred to as modernization or upgrading. (6) Unscheduled Maintenance. This is a level of maintenance required f or mechanical and electrical equipment due to sudden breakdowns and accidents. The fewer the number and scope of unscheduled maintenance activities, the higher the level of managem ent.
2) Maintenance Process Stage Once the maintenance process begins, the first step is to disassemble the equipment—following a sequence and approach that reverses the original assembly order, adhering to the principle of "top-down and outside-in." This systematic method carefully releases the components from their interlocking and fixed positions within the machine. After removal, each part should undergo a secondary pre-inspection. Based on the findings from this second check, any additional repair parts required will be identified. Furthermore, the availability of replacement and repaired components, along with their current status, will help establish a rough schedule for the maintenance tasks. This ensures that the repair work progresses methodically and according to plan, preventing delays caused by poor coordination in organizational efforts. The precision and performance achievable during equipment maintenance depend on factors such as the technical expertise available for repair work, the number of major overhauls the equipment has undergone, and its pre-repair technical condition. Generally speaking, for machinery undergoing its first major overhaul, both its precision and performance should ideally meet the original factory standards. However, after two or more major overhauls, the equipment’s post-repair precision and performance typically fall short of those of a new unit. That said, if the equipment was in relatively good technical condition prior to the last overhaul, it will likely be easier to restore its quality closer to the original factory standards this time around. Conversely, if the previous overhaul left the equipment in suboptimal condition, it may create significant challenges for the next major repair—and in some cases, the resulting quality might even fail to meet the original factory standards, making further repairs impractical altogether. The assembly of the complete equipment is carried out according to acceptance criteria. During assembly, appropriate reference surfaces should be selected for accurate mechanical and electrical system fault diagnosis and maintenance case studies.

This ensures a thorough assessment of the equipment's quality, restored precision, and overall performance. 1.4.1 Preparations Before Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Electromechanical equipment occupies a critically important position in the production and operational activities of modern industrial enterprises. To ensure smooth equipment operation and safe production, implementing planned preventive maintenance is an essential component of equipment management and repair practices in industrial companies. This section will cover the detailed process of major equipment overhauls, the determination of equipment repair plans, as well as the technical and material preparations required prior to equipment maintenance. 1. Equipment Major Overhaul Process To ensure the precision and operational performance of mechanical and electrical equipment, preventive scheduled maintenance must be carried out in addition to routine upkeep. Among these preventive measures, major overhauls stand out as a critical task aimed at restoring the equipment's accuracy. Within the category of preventive maintenance, major overhauls—often referred to simply as "overhauls"—represent the most extensive and time-consuming type of repair. An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit. The ultimate goal is to thoroughly eliminate any pre-existing defects and restore the equipment to its specified performance standards. The purpose of precision and performance. The major steps involved in the overhaul of mechanical and electrical equipment typically include: pre-disassembly unit inspection, component removal, component inspection, necessary component disassembly, parts cleaning and examination, component repair and assembly, final assembly, no-load trial operation, load testing, overall machine precision verification, and final acceptance. In practice, these tasks should be carried out according to the overhaul work plan, while also ensuring effective job scheduling, quality control during operations, and thorough completion acceptance. The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment is typically divided into three stages: pre-repair preparation, the repair process itself, and post-repair acceptance. Pre-repair preparation phase To ensure the repair work proceeds smoothly and accurately, maintenance personnel should carefully listen to operators' requirements for equipment repairs and thoroughly understand the issues affecting the equipment being serviced—such as loss of precision, the extent of wear on major mechanical components, the accuracy of the transmission system, and any visible defects. They should also identify which parts need improvement or modification to meet the equipment’s operational specifications. Additionally, they should review relevant technical documentation, equipment manuals, and previous maintenance records to become familiar with the device’s structural features, transmission system, and original design precision standards. This preparation will enable them to propose comprehensive pre-inspection tasks. Following the pre-inspection, specific repair methods for critical and large components can be determined, allowing for the preparation of specialized tools and precision measuring instruments. Finally, the team must define the post-repair precision testing procedures and establish clear acceptance criteria for trial runs, ensuring all technical preparations are fully in place before proceeding with the complete overhaul of the equipment.
28 Determine the form and compensation method for the error compensation环节, ensuring assembly accuracy among all components—such as parallelism, coaxiality, perpendicularity, and the required meshing precision of the transmission. 3) Post-Repair Acceptance Phase All equipment that has undergone repair, assembly, and adjustment must be subjected to comprehensive precision checks and tests—such as geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluations—in accordance with the relevant prescribed accuracy standards or the precision criteria established prior to repair. These measures ensure a thorough assessment of the repaired equipment’s quality, restored precision, and overall performance. After equipment maintenance, record the modifications made to the original technical documentation and document any lessons learned during the repair process. Prepare a thorough post-repair summary and file it alongside the original documents for future reference during the next maintenance task.

user_input: What are the key aspects of preparation for equipment maintenance?
reference_contexts: ['Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness.', 'The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation.', 'Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment鈥攁long with developing the overall maintenance production schedule.']
reference: Preparation for equipment maintenance consists of two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. Technical preparation, managed by the lead technician, includes pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Production readiness, handled by spare parts, materials, and tools personnel along with maintenance unit production planners, involves ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment, as well as developing the overall maintenance production schedule.
answer: The key aspects of preparation for equipment maintenance include establishing a basis and considerations for the plan, gathering information such as technical condition data and production schedules, preparing a draft plan aligned with production needs, conducting a balanced approval process with input from various departments, and formally issuing the plan for execution. Additionally, specific pre-repair preparations involve thoroughly understanding equipment issues, reviewing technical documentation, determining repair methods and preparing tools, and defining testing and acceptance criteria.

2) Basis for preparing the maintenance plan, as well as considerations and key steps to be addressed.
④ Equipment maintenance cycles and maintenance intervals. (2) The following issues should be considered when preparing the maintenance plan. ① Equipment critical to production needs, impacting product quality, and essential to key processes should be prioritized. ② Single critical equipment on the production line should, whenever possible, be scheduled for maintenance during holidays to minimize downtime. ③ Equipment for continuous or periodic production (thermal and power equipment) must be properly scheduled according to their specific characteristics, ensuring that equipment maintenance is closely integrated with production tasks. ④ Special requirements for precision equipment maintenance. ⑤ The balance of maintenance workload should be considered to ensure that repair activities are evenly distributed throughout the year. Prioritize and schedule maintenance tasks for equipment based on their urgency and importance. ⑥ The workload and timeline for pre-repair production technology preparation should be taken into account. ⑦ Arrange similar equipment continuously whenever possible. ⑧ Comprehensively consider the availability of technology, materials, labor, and funding sources required for equipment maintenance. (3) Preparation of the Annual Maintenance Plan. The five steps involved in compiling the annual maintenance plan are outlined below. ① Thoroughly assess the actual technical condition of the equipment requiring maintenance, and analyze the ease or difficulty of performing repairs.
⑤ Propose solutions to address the contradictions that have emerged in the above 4 steps. (4) Typically, the equipment maintenance plan for the following year is prepared in September each year. The preparation process follows these 4 steps: ① Gather information. Before drafting the plan, thorough data collection and analysis must be conducted. This primarily involves two key areas: first, technical condition data of the equipment, such as original documentation, equipment inspection forms, product process requirements, and quality-related information, to determine the appropriate maintenance category; and second, the annual production schedule, equipment maintenance quotas, relevant technical specifications for the equipment, and current inventory levels of spare parts. ② Prepare the draft. When drafting, fully consider how the annual production plan impacts equipment requirements, ensuring that maintenance schedules are aligned with production plans. This will help prevent both under-maintenance and over-maintenance of equipment. Before formally submitting the draft annual maintenance plan, the equipment management department, under the leadership of the chief plant manager, should organize a comprehensive technical and economic analysis and evaluation involving departments such as process engineering, technology, operations, and production—aiming to achieve well-balanced, rational objectives. ③ Balanced Approval. After the draft plan is completed, it is distributed to the production, planning, engineering, technical, finance, and user departments for discussion. Participants are invited to propose modifications, such as adding or removing items, adjusting maintenance downtime durations, setting machine-off delivery dates, and revising maintenance categories. Once these inputs are comprehensively evaluated and balanced, the final maintenance plan is formally prepared and submitted to senior management for approval. The maintenance plan must be filled out on the prescribed form, including details such as: the equipment’s basic information (user department, asset number, name, and model), the repair complexity factor, the type or scope of the repair work, time quotas, downtime duration, planned schedule, and the responsible maintenance contractor. Additionally, a plan description should be prepared, highlighting key priorities, identifying potential weak links, and outlining critical issues that need attention. Finally, preliminary measures and recommendations should be proposed to address these crucial challenges effectively. ④ Issue for execution. Before December each year, the enterprise's production planning department will issue the equipment maintenance plan for the following year, serving as the basis for the company's operations.

user_input: What should be checked during the inspection of the machine tool's operational condition?
reference_contexts: ["Check the machine tool's operational condition: Verify whether the control system responds sensitively and reliably during movement; ensure that all movements meet the specified values; and confirm that the motion is smooth, without vibrations, noise, or stick-slip phenomena."]
reference: During the inspection of the machine tool's operational condition, several aspects must be verified. First, the control system should be checked to ensure it responds sensitively and reliably during movement. Second, all movements must meet the specified values as required. Finally, the motion should be confirmed to be smooth, without any vibrations, noise, or stick-slip phenomena, indicating proper mechanical function and alignment.
answer: Before starting work, inspect each operating handle and control device to ensure they are in the off position, check components for severe wear, damage, or loose connections, verify all safety protection devices are intact and securely fastened, confirm the power supply is functioning properly, check wires and control cabinets for damage, verify the equipment grounding or earthing facilities are safe, and check the oil quality and level in lubrication and hydraulic systems according to the lubrication chart; after confirming all components are correct, run the machine at low speed for 3–5 minutes with no load to ensure smooth operation and good lubrication; during operation, monitor all components for abnormalities.

Context:  
The basic content of operation and maintenance procedures generally includes the following aspects. (1) Operators must wear appropriate personal protective equipment as required during operation. When inspecting or approaching the equipment, they should avoid wearing loose-fitting clothing. Female employees are not permitted to wear long hair loose. (2) Before starting work, clear the workspace. Before turning on the equipment, inspect each operating handle and control device according to the items specified in the daily inspection checklist to ensure they are in the off position. Check whether any components show signs of severe wear, damage requiring replacement, or loose connections posing safety risks. Verify that all safety protection devices are intact and securely fastened. Also, confirm that the power supply is functioning properly and keep a detailed inspection record. If any issues are found that fail to meet safety standards, promptly submit safety improvement suggestions or solutions to the workshop supervisor to prevent the equipment from operating while faulty. (3) Check whether the wires and control cabinets are damaged, whether the surrounding environment is reliable, and whether the equipment's grounding or earthing facilities are safe. If any issues are detected, take protective measures immediately. (4) Check the oil quality and level in lubrication and hydraulic systems; replenish oil according to the lubrication chart, ensuring the oil remains clean, the oil lines are unobstructed, and lubrication is optimal. Proper lubrication not only guarantees effective cooling and heat dissipation but also provides sealing and protective functions. Additionally, it plays a significant role in cleaning away contaminants and reducing wear. (5) After confirming that all components are functioning correctly, you may first run the machine at low speed for 3–5 minutes with no load. Ensure that all parts operate smoothly and are well-lubricated before proceeding with actual work. Never exceed the recommended load or use the equipment outside of specified guidelines. (6) While the equipment is running, it is strictly prohibited to adjust the workpiece by hand or to perform lubrication, remove debris, or wipe down the machine. When leaving the machine tool, always turn off the power supply. During operation, closely monitor the condition of all components; if any abnormalities are detected, immediately stop the machine and address the issue. (7) When maintaining, servicing, or cleaning equipment and instruments, ensure that the equipment and instruments are powered down and the power supply is completely turned off. Additionally, clearly display or hang warning signs at the work site to indicate that the equipment is undergoing maintenance or repair, or that personnel are present for ongoing work. (8) Before maintenance and servicing, personnel should be aware of the precautions specific to this task and follow the proper maintenance procedures. During maintenance, staff must remain fully focused, wear appropriate safety gear, and ensure their standing position is secure. (9) When maintaining equipment, use disassembly tools correctly; unauthorized assembly or disassembly is strictly prohibited. Do not remove or alter the equipment's Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance at will. 15 Safety protection device: When positioning or assembling the equipment, never insert your hands into the mating surfaces or use your fingers to align holes. (10) After completing maintenance, repair, and other operational tasks, equipment should be removed from the work area, and the workspace along with machinery must be thoroughly cleaned. Every component of the equipment’s instruments and gauges should be carefully inspected, ensuring that no tools or other items are left behind—either on the equipment or inside it. Additionally, the workshop should conduct regular maintenance, upkeep, and repairs to ensure the smooth operation of all machinery. (11) Instructions, safety signs, and signage located within the workshop and on machinery must be strictly followed at all times. (12) It is strictly prohibited to use flammable or volatile substances for wiping equipment. Oil-soaked rags must not be left on the equipment, and no flammable or explosive materials are allowed to be stored near the equipment. (13) When working in flammable and explosive hazard areas, appropriate safety measures must be taken beforehand and approved by the production safety department and management before proceeding. Additionally, when welding or grinding containers or pipelines containing flammable, explosive, or toxic materials, these must first be properly purged and thoroughly cleaned—and all openings must be fully opened—before work can begin. (14) The work area should be dry and clean. Used oil and waste rags must not be discarded randomly on the floor. Raw materials, semi-finished products, and finished goods must be neatly stacked, and blocking passageways is strictly prohibited. (15) Regularly maintain the cleanliness of lubrication and hydraulic systems. Keep the tank lid securely closed, ensuring no water, dust, metal chips, or other contaminants enter the oil tank or electrical equipment. (16) After finishing work and before leaving for the day, clean the machine tools and equipment thoroughly, ensuring they remain tidy. Return operating handles, buttons, and other controls to their non-working positions, turn off the power supply, and complete the handover procedures with the next shift. 3) Classification of Maintenance and Servicing Tasks Depending on the depth, scope, and volume of work involved in equipment maintenance and upkeep, maintenance tasks can be categorized into the following types. (1) Daily Maintenance (Routine Maintenance). Its main tasks include: inspecting and lubricating the equipment; strictly following the equipment operation procedures. Cheng uses the equipment to tighten any loose parts; cleans and wipes down the equipment, checks its operational status, and records the condition in the shift handover log. This type of maintenance is relatively simple, with most tasks performed on the equipment's surface. Daily maintenance should be carried out by the operating personnel. (2) First-Level Maintenance (Monthly Maintenance). The main tasks include: disassembling specified components such as the housing cover and protective shields, thoroughly cleaning and wiping both the inside and outside of the equipment; inspecting and adjusting clearance gaps between parts, tightening any loose components, and replacing individual wear-and-tear parts; clearing oil passages, cleaning filters, and replacing coolant while also flushing the coolant tank; cleaning guideways and sliding surfaces, removing burrs and scratches; and inspecting and adjusting electrical wiring and related devices. This first-level maintenance is performed after the equipment has been running for 1 to 2 months (under a two-shift system), primarily by operational staff with support from maintenance technicians. (3) Second-Level Maintenance (Annual Maintenance). In addition to the tasks included in first-level maintenance, second-level maintenance also involves repairing or replacing worn parts, adjusting clearances in components such as guides, maintaining the electrical system, and inspecting and fine-tuning equipment accuracy. This type of maintenance is carried out once a year after the equipment has been in operation, primarily by maintenance technicians with the participation of operators. 1.2.6 Equipment Fault Diagnosis Technology When equipment malfunctions, certain characteristics change accordingly, leading to variations in mechanical, thermal, acoustic, and electromagnetic physical and chemical parameters—each carrying distinct types of information. By capturing these altered indicators, detecting the underlying signals and patterns, and analyzing their causes and anomalies, fault diagnosis technology enables us to pinpoint the location, nature, and severity of the failure, as well as forecast future issues, assess damage conditions, make informed decisions, eliminate potential hazards, and ultimately prevent accidents from occurring. This is precisely what fault diagnosis technology aims to achieve. Mechatronic System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Studies Tutorial

Through pre-inspection, we can comprehensively and thoroughly assess the deterioration of equipment conditions, gain a clearer understanding of how product processes affect the equipment’s precision and performance, thereby identifying which parts need to be replaced or repaired. This information then allows us to create detailed drawings or verify existing ones for these parts, ensuring they meet the requirements for manufacturing and repair work. (2) Pre-inspection content: Typically, the pre-inspection content is determined based on the equipment type and the pre-repair investigation. (3) Inspect geometric and operational accuracy item by item, according to the equipment manufacturer's precision standards and inspection methods for each country or enterprise. Precision Inspection of Mechanical Equipment Maintenance After major overhauls of mechanical equipment, acceptance checks are conducted according to established standards, with each type of equipment having its own specific acceptance criteria and inspection methods. Take metal cutting machine tools as an example: the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established various precision testing standards for different types of machine tools, along with general guidelines for machine tool accuracy verification. Similarly, China has developed its own standards that are either equivalent to or closely aligned with international benchmarks. These standards specify the inspection items, criteria, methods, and tolerances for machine tool accuracy—serving as the fundamental basis for conducting precision tests. Currently, machine tool maintenance is carried out based on both geometric and operational precision standards during acceptance procedures. Inspection of Machine Tool Geometric Accuracy Geometric accuracy of machine tools refers to the precision of the components that ultimately affect the machine's operational accuracy. It encompasses individual accuracies of basic structural elements, positional accuracy between various parts, as well as motion accuracy, positioning accuracy, indexing accuracy, and transmission chain accuracy. Typically, geometric accuracy checks are performed while the machine tool is stationary. Before conducting these inspections, it’s essential to first ensure proper installation and leveling. Follow the machine tool’s instruction manual carefully to install the equipment on a suitable foundation and achieve precise leveling. The primary goal of leveling is to guarantee the machine’s static stability, which facilitates accurate measurements during testing—especially those related to the straightness of machine components. Additionally, national standards have standardized methods for inspecting both geometric and operational accuracy of machine tools, providing a reliable reference for conducting geometric accuracy tests. Machine Tool Testing Since the geometric accuracy of machine tools is checked under static conditions, it cannot fully reflect the quality of machine tool maintenance. To determine whether a machine tool can maintain its original geometric accuracy under operational conditions and load applications, it must be evaluated through various machine tool tests. The key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. (1) No-load operation test of the machine tool. The purpose of the no-load operation test is to further verify the correct functioning of each component of the machine tool. Sex, reliability, ease and normality of operation, as well as whether the temperature rise and noise levels of each moving component are within acceptable limits. The primary focus of the machine tool's no-load running test is to simultaneously check the operational status of relevant parts while testing the spindle and feed speeds. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 35 Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required quality standards. Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points. It is crucial to note: Only after completing all necessary preparations in accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used. (2) Machine Tool Load Testing. The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machine’s main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design, as well as checks if all machine components are functioning properly under these conditions, whether there are any positional changes between parts, and if such changes remain within the permissible limits. Additionally, it ensures that vibrations, noise levels, and temperature rise remain within normal operating ranges. The machine tool load test primarily involves performing a cutting-load test, where tools and cutting parameters are selected according to specified requirements to machine the surface of test specimens made from a particular material and in a specific size. During the load test, the spindle speed and feed rate are allowed to deviate by no more than 5% compared to the theoretical values. (3) Machine Tool Working Accuracy Test. The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machine’s various components during the machining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured. Before the test, its geometric accuracy must be rechecked. The machine tool working accuracy test involves machining the surface of a specified test piece using cutting tools and appropriate cutting parameters, as outlined in the machine tool accuracy testing standards for working precision requirements. The geometric accuracy of the machined workpiece surface must fall within the tolerance range specified by the precision standards of the machine tool used, and the surface roughness value should not

user_input: What are the key elements included in the equipment maintenance technical specification?
reference_contexts: ['The equipment maintenance technical specification should include the following content. 鈶?The technical condition of the equipment before major overhaul. 鈶?Key maintenance activities include detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection of components to identify parts that require repair or replacement; briefly outlining the repair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that must be thoroughly inspected and adjusted, as well as other areas requiring attention; and highlighting specific parts and aspects that can be improved during the overhaul process. 鈶?Maintenance quality requirements: Specify the names and numbers of the general technical standards applicable to each quality inspection during major equipment overhauls, and attach the content of any specialized technical standards to the back of the task specification.']
reference: The equipment maintenance technical specification includes three main elements. First, it documents the technical condition of the equipment before the major overhaul, providing a baseline for assessment. Second, it outlines key maintenance activities, such as detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection processes to identify parts needing repair or replacement; briefly describing repair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that require thorough inspection and adjustment; and highlighting areas for potential improvement during the overhaul. Third, it defines maintenance quality requirements by listing the names and numbers of applicable general technical standards for each quality inspection and attaching any specialized technical standards to the specification for reference.
answer: The equipment maintenance technical specification includes the technical condition of the equipment before major overhaul, key maintenance activities, and maintenance quality requirements.

Management of Maintenance Technical Documentation Equipment maintenance technical documentation primarily comes from the technical materials provided as part of the equipment purchase; materials acquired during use from equipment manufacturers, relevant organizations, scientific bookstores, and more; as well as documents designed, surveyed, and compiled in-house. Management is as described below. (1) Specification standards, including relevant international standards, national standards, departmentally issued standards, as well as applicable laws and regulations. (2) Drawing materials, including instruction manuals for mechanical power equipment within the company, partial equipment manufacturing drawings, maintenance and assembly diagrams, spare parts catalogues, and related technical documentation. (3) Layout Diagram of Power Station Equipment and Power Pipeline Network Diagram. (4) Process documentation, including maintenance procedures, parts repair processes, critical component manufacturing techniques, and drawings for specialized tools and fixtures, etc. (5) Maintenance Quality Standards and Equipment Testing Procedures. (6) General technical files, including equipment manuals, research reports, experimental data, calculation notes, cost analyses, claim reports, standard technical materials, patent documents, and relevant literature, among others. (7) Samples and books, including domestic and international samples, books, periodicals, electronic publications, CDs, floppy disks, photographs, and slides, among others. 2) Management Program Maintenance technical documentation is primarily intended for use within the equipment management system and should generally be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room. The management process should encompass the entire lifecycle of the materials—covering collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution. Effective management of technical documentation requires prioritization: key equipment manuals, along with relevant assembly drawings, electrical schematics, and other critical documents, should be clearly marked for enhanced oversight. Importantly, these priority documents are typically not available for external loan. To facilitate compilation and retrieval, it is necessary to establish a coded indexing system for the data and implement computer-based management. The equipment maintenance manual serves as a comprehensive collection of specialized technical documentation for equipment repair, providing maintenance personnel with essential resources for troubleshooting, diagnosing faults, developing repair strategies, and even manufacturing spare parts when needed. The equipment maintenance manuals are compiled separately for each equipment model, and the manuals should include the following content. (1) Features and Feature Diagrams. The features and feature diagrams include an outline diagram, lifting diagram, installation foundation drawing, and Chapter 1—Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. 51
② Inspection, maintenance, and assembly procedures for key components, as well as the technical specifications to be achieved. ③ The overall assembly procedure and the precision requirements, technical specifications, and inspection/measurement methods that the assembly process must meet. ④ Adjustment processes for critical components  and the corresponding technical specifications to be achieved. ⑤ Test run procedures, specifications, and technical requirements to be achieved after final assembly. ⑥ Detailed list of general or specialized tools, inspection and testing equipment, research fixtures, and measuring instruments required during major equipment overhauls, with specific notes indicating items that are custom-made. ⑦ Safety measures during major overhaul operations, etc. (3) Major Maintenance Quality Standards. When accepting the repair of mechanical equipment, reference can be made to general technical specifications for major equipment repairs established and issued by national and ministerial authorities, such as the General Technical Specifications for Major Repairs of Metal Cutting Machine Tools and the General Technical Specifications for Major Repairs of Forging and Pressing Equipment. Industries and enterprises may also develop their own specialized quality standards for major equipment repairs based on these relevant general technical guidelines. A Practical Guide to Fault Diagnosis and Repair Cases in Mechatronic Systems 30
6) Use correctly Under normal operating conditions, mechanical equipment follows its own failure patterns; however, when operating conditions change, these failure patterns also shift accordingly. The primary operating conditions include the following: (1) Load. The primary causes of wear and fatigue failure in mechanical equipment are the wear of components and their fatigue-induced damage. Under specified operating conditions, the rate of component wear over a given period is directly proportional to the magnitude of the load applied. Meanwhile, fatigue damage to components occurs only under certain types of cyclic loading and intensifies as the load increases. Thus, both wear and fatigue are functions of the applied load. Exceeding the design-rated load levels can lead to severe failure, which is unacceptable. (2) Environment. The environment includes the effects of climate, corrosive media, and other harmful substances, as well as the condition of the working object itself. Increased temperatures accelerate wear and corrosion, while excessively high humidity and corrosive agents present in the air can lead to both corrosion and corrosive wear. Additionally, excessive dust levels in the air and harsh operating conditions often contribute to equipment failures. However, the environment is an objective factor, and in certain situations, measures can be taken manually to improve it. (3) Maintenance and Operation. Establishing a sound maintenance system and strictly adhering to technical maintenance guidelines and operational procedures are crucial for ensuring the reliable performance of mechanical equipment and extending its service life. Additionally, it is essential to provide training for personnel to enhance their skills and expertise.
The degree is very high. Choose a reasonable running-in load, relative motion speed, and lubrication. Slip conditions and other parameters are key to shortening the break-in period. 2) Stable Wear Phase AB The wear characteristic of this stage is a low and stable wear rate, which is why the duration of this phase is relatively long. But by mid- Figure 1.3: Wear Characteristic Curve –  Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 19 Later on, the wear rate becomes relatively faster, but the equipment can still function for a while. When the wear amount reaches point B, the wear rate sharply accelerates, marking the onset of the severe wear phase. Proper usage, along with regular maintenance and upkeep of the equipment, is key to extending this critical stage. 3) Rapid Wear Phase BC Once this stage is reached, significant changes in friction conditions occur, such as altered lubrication or shifts in the geometric dimensions of components. Changes, such as increased clearance between mating parts and the generation of impact loads, can cause wear rates to rise sharply. At this point, mechanical efficiency noticeably declines, and precision deteriorates—conditions that, if left unaddressed, could lead to equipment failure or even unexpected accidents. Therefore, promptly identifying and repairing components that are about to enter this stage is critically important. According to wear results, wear is categorized into pitting wear, adhesive wear, abrasive wear, and more; while based on wear mechanisms, it is classified into abrasive wear, fatigue wear, adhesive wear, fretting wear, and others. Abrasive wear occurs when a hard protruding part on one surface of a friction pair comes into contact with the other surface, or when abrasive particles are present between the two rubbing surfaces. Wear occurs when hard particulates—such as dust in the air or metal particles generated by abrasion—cause material transfer from one surface to another, or even simultaneous material loss on both surfaces, during relative motion. Among the many wear failure modes, abrasive wear is not only the most common but also the most severe type of failure. Fretting wear refers to a type of wear where localized areas on the surfaces of friction pairs develop fatigue cracks under cyclic contact stresses, leading to the detachment of micro-sheets or particles. Depending on the nature of contact and relative motion between the friction pairs, fretting wear can be categorized into two main forms: rolling-contact fatigue wear and sliding-contact fatigue wear. In practical applications, pure rolling-contact fatigue wear is relatively rare; most often, it occurs as a combination of rolling and sliding motions. Adhesive wear occurs when, at the points of contact between mating surfaces, "cold welding" takes place, causing material from one surface to transfer to the other during relative sliding. Micro-motion wear is a type of wear that occurs when two contacting objects undergo relative vibrations with very small amplitudes. It happens on two closely matched surfaces that appear nominally stationary but actually experience cyclic, minute-scale relative sliding—typically at the micrometer level (2–20 μm). For instance, this phenomenon can be observed at interference or transition-fit interfaces between shafts and holes, on keyway surfaces, or in threaded fasteners. Wear occurring on working surfaces, such as the working surface of the rivet, and other similar areas. Fretting wear not only reduces mating accuracy, loosens tight-fitting components, and degrades the quality of the mating surfaces, but can also lead to the formation of fatigue cracks, significantly diminishing the fatigue strength of the part. 2. Measures to Prevent or Reduce Wear

(4) Check the machine tool's operational condition: Verify whether the control system responds sensitively and reliably during movement; ensure that all movements meet the specified values; and confirm that the motion is smooth, without vibrations, noise, or stick-slip phenomena. (5) Inspect the machine tool guideways, lead screws, and racks for wear, and measure the extent of the wear. (6) Inspect the hydraulic, pneumatic, and lubrication systems: Verify that movements are accurate, check for any component damage or leaks, and if leaks are present, identify the cause. (7) Inspect the electrical system: Check whether electrical components are aged or malfunctioning. (8) Inspect safety protection devices: Verify that all limit switches and interlock mechanisms are sensitive and reliable, and check whether any of the indicator instruments or protective guards are damaged. (9) Inspect the equipment's appearance and accessories: Check for chipped paint, damage to any handles, ensure all labels are present, and verify that accessories are complete and free from wear or damage. (10) Partial disassembly inspection to determine whether parts need replacement or repair based on their wear condition. During the pre-inspection, especially large and complex castings and forgings, high-precision critical components, and purchased parts must be checked one by one to determine whether they need replacement or repair. Preparing overhaul technical documentation By conducting a pre-inspection to assess the equipment's condition and determine whether repairs or component replacements are necessary, we can then proceed to analyze, develop a repair plan, and prepare the corresponding technical documentation. These technical documents serve as the foundation for major equipment overhauls. Commonly used technical documents for equipment overhauls include the following types: (1) Prepare the equipment maintenance technical specification. The equipment maintenance technical specification should include the following content. ① The technical condition of the equipment before major overhaul. ② Key maintenance activities include detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection of components to identify parts that require repair or replacement; briefly outlining the repair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that must be thoroughly inspected and adjusted, as well as other areas requiring attention; and highlighting specific parts and aspects that can be improved during the overhaul process. ③ Maintenance quality requirements: Specify the names and numbers of the general technical standards applicable to each quality inspection during major equipment overhauls, and attach the content of any specialized technical standards to the back of the task specification. (2) Preparing Maintenance Procedures. The maintenance procedures for mechanical equipment are the technical documents that must be carefully followed and implemented during major overhauls. When developing overhaul procedures, it’s essential to consider the actual conditions, ensuring both technical feasibility and economic viability. Mechanical equipment overhaul procedures can be categorized into two types: standard maintenance procedures and specialized maintenance procedures. The overhaul procedures for mechanical equipment typically include the following elements. ① Disassembly procedures and methods for the complete machine and its components, as well as the data to be monitored and precautions to observe during the disassembly process.

(5) Preparing the Overhaul Work Plan. The overhaul work plan is prepared by the planning personnel in the maintenance department, who are responsible for equipment management. Personnel, chief technicians, and maintenance foremen (team leaders) review it together. The overhaul work plan includes: work procedures, the number of workers required for each phase and stage of the job, along with the corresponding duration in days; requirements for seamless coordination between individual work phases; and details on projects that need to be outsourced to external partners, including specific timeframes. A general overhaul work plan can be presented using a "bar chart" format, supplemented by necessary explanatory text. For overhauls of complex, high-precision, large-scale, and critical equipment, network scheduling techniques should be employed to ensure efficient resource utilization, shorten project timelines, and enhance overall economic benefits. 4. Material Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Material preparation before equipment maintenance is a critically important task, serving as the essential logistical foundation for successful repairs. In practice, delays often occur due to insufficient availability of spare parts and components, disrupting the normal flow of maintenance work, prolonging downtime, and ultimately leading to inefficiencies and production losses. Therefore, it is imperative to strengthen material preparation efforts prior to equipment maintenance. After the lead maintenance technician has prepared detailed lists of replacement parts and materials, they should promptly hand these over to the responsible personnel managing spare parts and supplies. Once the inventory has been verified, these managers will place orders accordingly. Meanwhile, after finalizing the repair procedures, the lead maintenance technician must immediately provide the tool management team with detailed lists and drawings of specialized tools, inspection devices, and testing equipment. The tool management staff will then cross-check the existing inventory and forward any necessary items—such as specialized tools, inspection devices, or testing equipment—to the relevant departments for evaluation. Based on the evaluation results, if repairs are indeed required, the departments will arrange for the necessary maintenance activities. Additionally, the tool management team will initiate new procurement requests for any additional specialized tools, inspection devices, or testing equipment that may be needed. 1.4.2 General Process for Mechanical Equipment Maintenance
28 Determine the form and compensation method for the error compensation环节, ensuring assembly accuracy among all components—such as parallelism, coaxiality, perpendicularity, and the required meshing precision of the transmission. 3) Post-Repair Acceptance Phase All equipment that has undergone repair, assembly, and adjustment must be subjected to comprehensive precision checks and tests—such as geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluations—in accordance with the relevant prescribed accuracy standards or the precision criteria established prior to repair. These measures ensure a thorough assessment of the repaired equipment’s quality, restored precision, and overall performance. After equipment maintenance, record the modifications made to the original technical documentation and document any lessons learned during the repair process. Prepare a thorough post-repair summary and file it alongside the original documents for future reference during the next maintenance task. 2. Determining the Equipment Maintenance Plan Major equipment overhauls must not only meet the predetermined technical requirements but also strive to enhance economic efficiency. Therefore, before starting repairs, it’s essential to thoroughly assess the equipment’s technical condition, develop a practical and feasible repair plan, and ensure comprehensive preparation—both technically and in terms of production readiness. During the repair process, actively incorporate new technologies, materials, processes, and modern management techniques, while diligently managing technical, financial, and organizational aspects to guarantee high-quality workmanship, minimize downtime, and reduce overall maintenance costs. A pre-inspection must be conducted to thoroughly assess the equipment's technical condition before repairs, identify the main defects present, and analyze the product-specific process requirements that influence the equipment's technical specifications—allowing for the immediate development of a repair plan. 3. Technical Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment—along with developing the overall maintenance production schedule. Pre-inspection survey preparation work To gain a comprehensive understanding of the specific condition of equipment degradation, schedule a shutdown inspection before the major overhaul—this is referred to as a pre-inspection. Before conducting the equipment pre-inspection, ensure the following preparatory investigations are completed. (1) Review the following equipment records: factory inspection reports; precision and performance verification records from equipment installation acceptance tests; details of all past equipment incidents, malfunctions, and repairs, including any remaining issues after repairs; records of all previous maintenance activities, including replaced or repaired components, as well as any unresolved problems left behind after servicing; and operational status monitoring logs and comprehensive equipment inspection records.

user_input: What are the general technical requirements for part processing quality in major machine tool repairs?
reference_contexts: ['The processing quality of replaced or repaired workpieces must meet the requirements specified in the drawing.', 'The tooth ends of sliding gears should have chamfers. The portion of the first thread on lead screws, worm gears, and similar components where the end thickness is less than 1 mm must be removed.', 'The scraped surface should not have any traces of machining or noticeable tool marks, and the scraping points must be evenly distributed. When inspected using the coloring method, within each 25 mm 脳 25 mm area, the number of contact points must not be less than the values specified in Table 1.1.']
reference: The general technical requirements for part processing quality in major machine tool repairs include three key aspects. First, all replaced or repaired workpieces must strictly conform to the dimensional and specification requirements outlined in their respective engineering drawings. Second, specific machining details must be observed: sliding gears require chamfers on their tooth ends, and lead screws, worm gears, and similar components must have the first thread portion removed if its end thickness is less than 1 mm. Third, scraped surfaces must be free of machining traces or visible tool marks, with evenly distributed scraping points that meet minimum contact point requirements per 25 mm 脳 25 mm area as defined in Table 1.1 when inspected via the coloring method.
answer: The processing quality of replaced or repaired workpieces must meet the requirements specified in the drawing; the tooth ends of sliding gears should have chamfers and the portion of the first thread on lead screws and worm gears where the end thickness is less than 1 mm must be removed; the scraped surface should not have any traces of machining or noticeable tool marks, and the scraping points must be evenly distributed with the number of contact points within each 25 mm × 25 mm area not being less than the values specified in Table 1.1.

③ Having well-equipped maintenance facilities organized according to functional divisions and strategically located for optimal efficiency. The main drawback of the planned preventive maintenance system is its poor cost-effectiveness. With fixed maintenance cycles and scopes, it often leads to unnecessary repairs of certain components—what’s known as over-maintenance. During the maintenance process, repairs are categorized into several levels and types based on the depth and breadth of the work required, including major overhauls, mid-level repairs, minor repairs, item-specific repairs, retrofits, and unplanned maintenance tasks—all determined by the scale and nature of the repair workload. (1) Overhaul: A comprehensive or fundamental restoration of the functionality of mechanical and electrical equipment, typically carried out by specialized maintenance teams within factories and mines —or at repair centers established in regions with a high concentration of industrial facilities. During an overhaul, the equipment is either fully or extensively disassembled, with a focus on repairing critical components, replacing or refurbishing parts that have lost their function or are on the verge of doing so. After the repairs, the equipment’s precision is restored to nearly its original factory specifications, while also receiving a fresh cosmetic overhaul to enhance its appearance. (2) Intermediate Overhaul. This is a level of maintenance that falls between major and minor overhauls, serving as a balanced approach to upkeep. (3) Minor Repair. This involves replacing or repairing components that have significantly worn out or are nearing failure within the maintenance interval, without addressing any underlying structural issues. It is a troubleshooting-based repair aimed at restoring functionality. The three levels—major overhaul, mid-term repair, and minor repair—objectively reflect the chronological progression of机电 equipment, making them ideally suited for implementing time-based planned preventive maintenance, a practice widely adopted by most organizations. However, these levels still require complementary repair tiers to address unforeseen maintenance needs effectively. (4) Item-based maintenance. Based on condition monitoring of mechanical and electrical equipment, this involves proactively planning repairs specifically for components or technical items that are about to fail. Item-based maintenance is conducted between major, medium, and minor overhauls—it’s a non-periodic, planned maintenance level that doesn’t follow a fixed cycle. (5) Retrofitting. This involves making localized modifications to existing mechanical and electrical equipment using new technologies, materials, structures, and processes, with the goal of enhancing its precision, functionality, productivity, and reliability. Such repairs are classified as improvement-oriented, and the extent of the work required depends on how well the original equipment’s design accommodates the retrofitting process—as well as on the specific level of performance enhancement desired for the equipment. Retrofitting is also referred to as modernization or upgrading. (6) Unscheduled Maintenance. This is a level of maintenance required for mechanical and electrical equipment due to sudden breakdowns and accidents. The fewer the number and scope of unscheduled maintenance activities, the higher the level of management.
When designing, it's essential to consider not only the strength of the parts but also their stiffness, as well as issues related to manufacturing, assembly, usage, disassembly, and maintenance. (1) Select materials carefully, paying attention to their process properties—such as casting fluidity and shrinkage, forging ductility and cold-heading capability, weldability characteristics like susceptibility to cold and hot cracking, machinability for ease of cutting, and heat-treatment properties including hardenability and resistance to cold brittleness. (2) Properly arrange the parts to optimize their stress distribution. Select appropriate structural dimensions, ensuring uniform wall thicknesses as much as possible, and minimize deformation during hot working processes. For instance, avoid sharp corners by replacing them with rounded or chamfered edges; for areas with significant thickness variations, consider adding process holes or reinforcing excessively thin sections. Additionally, carefully position any existing holes—transforming blind holes into through-holes where feasible. For parts with complex geometries, whenever possible, opt for modular or assembled designs to further enhance stress management. (3) In the design process, ensure the application of new technologies, processes, and materials to minimize internal stresses and deformation during manufacturing. 2) Manufacturing In the rough casting manufacturing process, it is important to address deformation issues and implement various process measures to minimize residual stresses in the blank. After the raw parts are produced and during subsequent machining processes, it is essential to incorporate sufficient steps for relieving internal stresses, aiming to minimize residual stresses within the components. One effective method to eliminate these residuals is through aging treatment, which can be either natural or artificial. Natural aging involves leaving the finished raw parts exposed outdoors for 1 to 2 years. This approach leverages the material’s inherent property of gradually releasing internal stresses over a period of 12 to 20 months—making it particularly effective—but the main drawback is the excessively long aging cycle. On the other hand, artificial aging accelerates the stress-relief process by subjecting the parts to high-temperature annealing followed by controlled cooling at a slow pace. Alternatively, vibrational techniques can also be employed to achieve artificial aging. For high-precision components, artificial aging must be integrated into the final machining stages to ensure optimal dimensional accuracy and stability. During machining and repair processes, minimize the number of datum shifts, preserving the original machining datums for use during maintenance, thereby reducing repair time. Errors caused by inconsistent benchmarks during machining. For parts that have undergone heat treatment, be sure to allow sufficient machining allowances and adjust the machining dimensions accordingly. Pre-applying controlled deformation is crucial—once the deformation patterns of the part are understood, you can counteract them in advance by introducing an equal but opposite amount of deformation. Alternatively, you can pre-stress the part or carefully manage the generation and evolution of stresses, ensuring that the final deformation aligns with specifications and effectively minimizes distortion. 3) Maintenance Aspects During maintenance, it is essential to not only meet the technical requirements—such as restoring part dimensions, ensuring proper fit tolerances, and achieving high surface quality—but also to inspect and correct any shape or positional errors in critical components. To minimize stress and deformation of parts during repair, standardized guidelines and maintenance procedures specifically addressing deformation issues should be established. Additionally, simple, reliable, and user-friendly specialized measuring tools and fixtures should be designed. Finally, it’s important to actively promote "three new" technologies, particularly innovative repair techniques like brush plating and bonding. 4) Usage Instructions
② Inspection, maintenance, and assembly procedures for key components, as well as the technical specifications to be achieved. ③ The overall assembly procedure and the precision requirements, technical specifications, and inspection/measurement methods that the assembly process must meet. ④ Adjustment processes for critical components and the corresponding technical specifications to be achieved. ⑤ Test run procedures, specifications, and technical requirements to be achieved after final assembly. ⑥ Detailed list of general or specialized tools, inspection and testing equipment, research fixtures, and measuring instruments required during major equipment overhauls, with specific notes indicating items that are custom-made. ⑦ Safety measures during major overhaul operations, etc. (3) Major Maintenance Quality Standards. When accepting the repair of mechanical equipment, reference can be made to general technical specifications for major equipment repairs established and issued by national and ministerial authorities, such as the General Technical Specifications for Major Repairs of Metal Cutting Machine Tools and the General Technical Specifications for Major Repairs of Forging and Pressing Equipment. Industries and enterprises may also develop their own specialized quality standards for major equipment repairs based on these relevant general technical guidelines. ⑤ Propose solutions to address the contradictions that have emerged in the above 4 steps. (4) Typically, the equipment maintenance plan for the following year is prepared in September each year. The preparation process follows these 4 steps: ① Gather information. Before drafting the plan, thorough data collection and analysis must be conducted. This primarily involves two key areas: first, technical condition data of the equipment, such as original documentation, equipment inspection forms, product process requirements, and quality-related information, to determine the appropriate maintenance category; and second, the annual production schedule, equipment maintenance quotas, relevant technical specifications for the equipment, and current inventory levels of spare parts. ② Prepare the draft. When drafting, fully consider how the annual production plan impacts equipment requirements, ensuring that maintenance schedules are aligned with production plans. This will help prevent both under-maintenance and over-maintenance of equipment. Before formally submitting the draft annual maintenance plan, the equipment management department, under the leadership of the chief plant manager, should organize a comprehensive technical and economic analysis and evaluation involving departments such as process engineering, technology, operations, and production—aiming to achieve well-balanced, rational objectives. ③ Balanced Approval. After the draft plan is completed, it is distributed to the production, planning, engineering, technical, finance, and user departments for discussion. Participants are invited to propose modifications, such as adding or removing items, adjusting maintenance downtime durations, setting machine-off delivery dates, and revising maintenance categories. Once these inputs are comprehensively evaluated and balanced, the final maintenance plan is formally prepared and submitted to senior management for approval. The maintenance plan must be filled out on the prescribed form, including details such as: the equipment’s basic information (user department, asset number, name, and model), the repair complexity factor, the type or scope of the repair work, time quotas, downtime duration, planned schedule, and the responsible maintenance contractor. Additionally, a plan description should be prepared, highlighting key priorities, identifying potential weak links, and outlining critical issues that need attention. Finally, preliminary measures and recommendations should be proposed to address these crucial challenges effectively. ④ Issue for execution. Before December each year, the enterprise's production planning department will issue the equipment maintenance plan for the following year, serving as the basis for the company's operations. It serves as an important component for evaluating production and business plans.
