For machine tools that do not undergo a load test, accuracy verification should be performed after the no-load running test. 2. Precision Inspection of Mechanical Equipment Maintenance After major overhauls of mechanical equipment, acceptance checks are conducted according to established standards, with each type of equipment having its own specific acceptance criteria and inspection methods. Take metal cutting machine tools as an example: the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established various precision testing standards for different types of machine tools, along with general guidelines for machine tool accuracy verification. Similarly, China has developed its own standards that are either equivalent to or closely aligned with international benchmarks. These standards specify the inspection items, criteria, methods, and tolerances for machine tool accuracy—serving as the fundamental basis for conducting precision tests. Currently, machine tool maintenance is carried out based on both geometric and operational precision standards during acceptance procedures. Inspection of Machine Tool Geometric Accuracy Geometric accuracy of machine tools refers to the precision of the components that ultimately affect the machine's operational accuracy. It encompasses individual accuracies of basic structural elements, positional accuracy between various parts, as well as motion accuracy, positioning accuracy, indexing accuracy, and transmission chain accuracy. Typically, geometric accuracy checks are performed while the machine tool is stationary. Before conducting these inspections, it’s essential to first ensure proper installation and leveling. Follow the machine tool’s instruction manual carefully to install the equipment on a suitable foundation and achieve precise leveling. The primary goal of leveling is to guarantee the machine’s static stability, which facilitates accurate measurements during testing—especially those related to the straightness of machine components. Additionally, national standards have standardized methods for inspecting both geometric and operational accuracy of machine tools, providing a reliable reference for conducting geometric accuracy tests. Machine Tool Testing Since the geometric accuracy of machine tools is checked under static conditions, it cannot fully reflect the quality of machine tool maintenance. To determine  whether a machine tool can maintain its original geometric accuracy under operational conditions and load applications, it must be evaluated through various machine tool tests. Th e key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. (1) No-load operation test of the machine tool. The pur pose of the no-load operation test is to further verify the correct functioning of each component of the machine tool. Sex, reliability, ease and normality of operation, as well as  whether the temperature rise and noise levels of each moving component are within acceptable limits. The primary focus of the machine tool's no-load running test is to simultaneou sly check the operational status of relevant parts while testing the spindle and feed speeds. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Mai ntenance 35 Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required qua lity standards. Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points. It is crucial to note: Only after completing all necessary preparations in  accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used. (2 ) Machine Tool Load Testing. The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machine’s main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design, as well a s checks if all machine components are functioning properly under these conditions, whether there are any positional changes between parts, and if such changes remain within the pe rmissible limits. Additionally, it ensures that vibrations, noise levels, and temperature rise remain within normal operating ranges. The machine tool load test primarily involves  performing a cutting-load test, where tools and cutting parameters are selected according to specified requirements to machine the surface of test specimens made from a particular  material and in a specific size. During the load test, the spindle speed and feed rate are allowed to deviate by no more than 5% compared to the theoretical values. (3) Machine Too l Working Accuracy Test. The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machine’s various components during the m achining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured. Before the test, its geometric accuracy must be rechecked. The machine tool working accuracy test  involves machining the surface of a specified test piece using cutting tools and appropriate cutting parameters, as outlined in the machine tool accuracy testing standards for wor king precision requirements. The geometric accuracy of the machined workpiece surface must fall within the tolerance range specified by the precision standards of the machine tool  used, and the surface roughness value should not exceed the prescribed standard.
2.3.2 Installation and Maintenance of Sliding Bearings Sliding bearings are characterized by their reliable operation, smooth performance, quietness, strong vibration absorption due to the lubricating oil film, and ability to withstand significant impact loads. Sliding bearings can be categorized into various structural types, such as integral and split designs, as shown in Figure 2.3. Figure 2.3: Sliding Bearing Basic Requirements for Sliding Bearing Installation (1) Before installation, burrs and sharp edges on the parts of the sliding bearing should be removed, and the contact surfaces must be smooth and clean. (2) When installing the bearing housing, the bearing or bushing should be fitted onto the housing and aligned according to the center position of the bushing or shaft sleeve. All bearings on the same transmission shaft must lie on a single axis, with their coaxial error remaining within the specified tolerance range. The bottom surface of the bearing housing must also be properly aligned with the machine components. The contact surfaces should make even, tight contact, and the fixed connections must be secure. During operation, there should be no signs of loosening or shifting. (3) The contact condition between the bearing and the shaft surface can be checked using the dye-penetration method, and the number of contact points must meet the specified requirements. (4) When the axis is rotating, no rotation of the bearing bush or shaft sleeve is permitted. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial
7. System Leak Fault Diagnosis and Repair System leaks are categorized into internal and external leaks, and depending on the severity of the  leak, they can manifest in various forms, such as oil film scraping, seepage, dripping, and spraying. Oil film scraping occurs between relatively moving components, like sliding o r reciprocating pairs in rotating parts. Seepage typically happens at the junctions of end covers and valve plates. Dripping is most common around pipe fittings and connections. Sp raying, on the other hand, often results from broken pipes or improperly installed seals. The underlying causes of these failures are as follows: (1) Sealing failure can occur due to poor seal quality, incorrect assembly, damage, prolonged aging and deterioration over time, or incompatibility with the working medium.

reference: After repairing or replacing hydraulic components (tie rods, pistons, cylinders, valves), working surfaces must be scratch-free. The system must operate without vibrations at any speed, and without noise, impact, stalling, or creeping. Pressure gauges must be sensitive and reliable with clear markings, and pressure safety devices must be dependable per manual instructions. During operation, no foam should form in the oil tank, and oil temperature should not exceed 60掳C normally, or 70掳C during 4-hour continuous operation if ambient temperature exceeds 35掳C.
answer: After repair or part replacement, hydraulic systems must be operated with correctly selected working fluids, proper maintenance practices, and strict control of contaminants in the hydraulic oil to prevent failures.

28 Determine the form and compensation method for the error compensation环节, ensuring assembly accuracy among all components—such as parallelism, coaxiality, perpendicularity, and the required meshing precision of the transmission. 3) Post-Repair Acceptance Phase All equipment that has undergone repair, assembly, and adjustment must be subjected to comprehensive precision checks and tests—such as geometric accuracy inspections, no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision evaluations—in accordance with the relevant prescribed accuracy standards or the precision criteria established prior to repair. These measures ensure a thorough assessment of the repaired equipment’s quality, restored precision, and overall performance. After equipment maintenance, record the modifications made to the original technical documentation and document any lessons learned during the repair process. Prepare a thorough post-repair summary and file it alongside the original documents for future reference during the next maintenance task. 2. Determining the Equipment Maintenance Plan Major equipment overhauls must not only meet the predetermined technical requirements but also strive to enhance economic efficiency. Therefore, before starting repairs, it’s essential to thoroughly assess the equipment’s technical condition, develop a practical and feasible repair plan, and ensure comprehensive preparation—both technically and in terms of production readiness. During the repair process, actively incorporate new technologies, materials, processes, and modern management techniques, while diligently managing technical, financial, and organizational aspects to guarantee high-quality workmanship, minimize downtime, and reduce overall maintenance costs. A pre-inspection must be conducted to thoroughly assess the equipment's technical condition before repairs, identify the main defects present, and analyze the product-specific process requirements that influence the equipment's technical specifications—allowing for the immediate development of a repair plan. 3. Technical Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment—along with developing the overall maintenance production schedule. Pre-inspection survey preparation work To gain a comprehensive understanding of the specific condition of equipment degradation, schedule a shutdown inspection before the major overhaul—this is referred to as a pre-inspection. Before conducting the equipment pre-inspection, ensure the following preparatory investigations are completed. (1) Review the following equipment records: factory inspection reports; precision and performance verification records from equipment installation acceptance tests; details of all past equipment incidents, malfunctions, and repairs, including any remaining issues after repairs; records of all previous maintenance activities, including replaced or repaired components, as well as any unresolved problems left behind after servicing; and operational status monitoring logs and comprehensive equipment inspection records.
3.1.2 Analysis  of Failure Causes in the Hydraulic System Hydraulic systems can experience a wide range of failures during operation, with the primary causes rooted in issues related to design, m anufacturing, usage practices, and hydraulic oil contamination. Among hydraulic component failures, the hydraulic pump accounts for the highest failure rate—approximately 30% of al l hydraulic component malfunctions—making it essential to pay close attention to this issue. Additionally, many hydraulic system failures are also caused by improper selection of w orking fluids or inadequate maintenance practices. In fact, 70% to 80% of all hydraulic system failures are directly linked to contaminants present in the hydraulic oil, and among these oil-related failures, about 90% are attributed to impurities. Another significant cause of failure stems from natural wear, aging, and degradation that occur under normal operating conditions. Impurities pose a serious threat to hydraulic systems, as they can accelerate component wear, increase leakage, impair system performance, and shorten component lifespan—even leading to equipment damage or complete system failure. The following sections will focus on analyzing failures caused by improper design, manufacturing processes, incorrect usage practices, and hydraulic oil contamination.

user_input: What are the key components of machine tool maintenance testing?
reference_contexts: ['The key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests.', 'The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machine鈥檚 main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design, as well as checks if all machine components are functioning properly under these conditions, whether there are any positional changes between parts, and if such changes remain within the permissible limits.', 'The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machine鈥檚 various components during the machining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured.']
reference: Machine tool maintenance testing consists of three key components: no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. The no-load running test verifies the correct functioning, reliability, and operational normality of each machine component while checking temperature rise and noise levels. The load test evaluates whether the main motion system can achieve the designed maximum torque and power, checks component functionality under load conditions, monitors positional changes between parts, and ensures vibrations, noise, and temperature rise remain within acceptable limits. The working accuracy test determines if the positional accuracy between machine components during machining meets part precision requirements, typically involving machining test pieces with specified tools and parameters according to established standards.
answer: The key components of machine tool maintenance testing are no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests.

The steps for fracture failure analysis are generally as follows. 1) On-site recording and photography After a major equipment accident occurs, promptly investigate and understand all circumstances before and after the incident, and take photographs or videos if necessary. In such cases, it’s essential to carefully determine the sequence of events and accurately identify the primary fracture-causing component—otherwise, the analysis results could be misleading. 3) Identify the dominant crack on the primary failure component The dominant failure component may already be fragmented; therefore, the remaining fragments should be collected, carefully pieced together, and analyzed to identify which crack initiated first—this crack is the dominant one. 4) Identifying the Failure Source Area Once the dominant crack is identified, you can then examine the corresponding fracture surface to locate the crack initiation zone. 5) Fracture Surface Treatment If further microscopic analysis of the fracture surface is required, or if it’s necessary to preserve evidence, the fracture surface should be cleaned. 1.4.1 Preparations Before Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Electromechanical equipment occupies a critically important position in the production and operational activities of modern industrial enterprises. To ensure smooth equipment operation and safe production, implementing planned preventive maintenance is an essential component of equipment management and repair practices in industrial companies. This section will cover the detailed process of major equipment overhauls, the determination of equipment repair plans, as well as the technical and material preparations required prior to equipment maintenance. 1. Equipment Major Overhaul Process To ensure the precision and operational performance of mechanical and electrical equipment, preventive scheduled maintenance must be carried out in addition to routine upkeep. Among these preventive measures, major overhauls stand out as a critical task aimed at restoring the equipment's accuracy. Within the category of preventive maintenance, major overhauls—often referred to simply as "overhauls"—represent the most extensive and time-consuming type of repair. An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit. The ultimate goal is to thoroughly eliminate any pre-existing defects and restore the equipment to its specified performance standards. The purpose of precision and performance. The major steps involved in the overhaul of mechanical and electrical equipment typically include: pre-disassembly unit inspection, component removal, component inspection, necessary component disassembly, parts cleaning and examination, component repair and assembly, final assembly, no-load trial operation, load testing, overall machine precision verification, and final acceptance. In practice, these tasks should be carried out according to the overhaul work plan, while also ensuring effective job scheduling, quality control during operations, and thorough completion acceptance. The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment is typically divided into three stages: pre-repair preparation, the repair process itself, and post-repair acceptance. Pre-repair preparation phase To ensure the repair work proceeds smoothly and accurately, maintenance personnel should carefully listen to operators' requirements for equipment repairs and thoroughly understand the issues affecting the equipment being serviced—such as loss of precision, the extent of wear on major mechanical components, the accuracy of the transmission system, and any visible defects. They should also identify which parts need improvement or modification to meet the equipment’s operational specifications. Additionally, they should review relevant technical documentation, equipment manuals, and previous maintenance records to become familiar with the device’s structural features, transmission system, and original design precision standards. This preparation will enable them to propose comprehensive pre-inspection tasks. Following the pre-inspection, specific repair methods for critical and large components can be determined, allowing for the preparation of specialized tools and precision measuring instruments. Finally, the team must define the post-repair precision testing procedures and establish clear acceptance criteria for trial runs, ensuring all technical preparations are fully in place before proceeding with the complete overhaul of the equipment.

Precision Inspection of Mechanical Equipment Maintenance After major overhauls of mechanical equipment, acceptance checks are conducted according to established standards, with each type of equipment having its own specific acceptance criteria and inspection methods. Take metal cutting machine tools as an example: the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established various precision testing standards for different types of machine tools, along with general guidelines for machine tool accuracy verification. Similarly, China has developed its own standards that are either equivalent to or closely aligned with international benchmarks. These standards specify the inspection items, criteria, methods, and tolerances for machine tool accuracy—serving as the fundamental basis for conducting precision tests. Currently, machine tool maintenance is carried out based on both geometric and operational precision standards during acceptance procedures. Inspection of Machine Tool Geometric Accuracy Geometric accuracy of machine tools refers to the precision of the components that ultimately affect the machine's operational accuracy. It encompasses individual accuracies of basic structural elements, positional accuracy between various parts, as well as motion accuracy, positioning accuracy, indexing accuracy, and transmission chain accuracy. Typically, geometric accuracy checks are performed while the machine tool is stationary. Before conducting these inspections, it’s essential to first ensure proper installation and leveling. Follow the machine tool’s instruction manual carefully to install the equipment on a suitable foundation and achieve precise leveling. The primary goal of leveling is to guarantee the machine’s static stability, which facilitates accurate measurements during testing—especially those related to the straightness of machine components. Additionally, national standards have standardized methods for inspecting both geometric and operational accuracy of machine tools, providing a reliable reference for conducting geometric accuracy tests. Machine Tool Testing Since the geometric accuracy of machine tools is checked under static conditions, it cannot fully reflect the quality of machine tool maintenance. To determine  whether a machine tool can maintain its original geometric accuracy under operational conditions and load applications, it must be evaluated through various machine tool tests. Th e key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. (1) No-load operation test of the machine tool. The pur pose of the no-load operation test is to further verify the correct functioning of each component of the machine tool. Sex, reliability, ease and normality of operation, as well as  whether the temperature rise and noise levels of each moving component are within acceptable limits. The primary focus of the machine tool's no-load running test is to simultaneou sly check the operational status of relevant parts while testing the spindle and feed speeds. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Mai ntenance 35 Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required qua lity standards. Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points. It is crucial to note: Only after completing all necessary preparations in  accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used. (2 ) Machine Tool Load Testing. The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machine’s main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design, as well a s checks if all machine components are functioning properly under these conditions, whether there are any positional changes between parts, and if such changes remain within the pe rmissible limits. Additionally, it ensures that vibrations, noise levels, and temperature rise remain within normal operating ranges. The machine tool load test primarily involves  performing a cutting-load test, where tools and cutting parameters are selected according to specified requirements to machine the surface of test specimens made from a particular  material and in a specific size. During the load test, the spindle speed and feed rate are allowed to deviate by no more than 5% compared to the theoretical values. (3) Machine Too l Working Accuracy Test. The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machine’s various components during the m achining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured. Before the test, its geometric accuracy must be rechecked. The machine tool working accuracy test  involves machining the surface of a specified test piece using cutting tools and appropriate cutting parameters, as outlined in the machine tool accuracy testing standards for wor king precision requirements. The geometric accuracy of the machined workpiece surface must fall within the tolerance range specified by the precision standards of the machine tool  used, and the surface roughness value should not exceed the prescribed standard.
Management of Maintenance Technical Documentation Equipment maintenance technical documentation primarily comes from the technical materials provided as part of the equipment purchase; materials acquired during use from equipment manufacturers, relevant organizations, scientific bookstores, and more; as well as documents designed, surveyed, and compiled in-house. Management is as described below. (1) Specification standards, including relevant international standards, national standards, departmentally issued standards, as well as applicable laws and regulations. (2) Drawing materials, including instruction manuals for mechanical power equipment within the company, partial equipment manufacturing drawings, maintenance and assembly diagrams, spare parts catalogues, and related technical documentation. (7) Samples and books, including domestic and international samples, books, periodicals, electronic publications, CDs, floppy disks, photographs, and slides, among others. 2) Management Program Maintenance technical documentation is primarily intended for use within the equipment management system and should generally be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room. The management process should encompass the entire lifecycle of the materials—covering collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution. Effective management of technical documentation requires prioritization: key equipment manuals, along with relevant assembly drawings, electrical schematics, and other critical documents, should be clearly marked for enhanced oversight. Importantly, these priority documents are typically not available for external loan. To facilitate compilation and retrieval, it is necessary to establish a coded indexing system for the data and implement computer-based management. Based on the actual conditions of your enterprise, adopt relatively mature new processes and materials to gradually replace outdated techniques. Develop systems and measures for learning, researching, testing, and implementing advanced maintenance technologies, continuously enhancing the company's equipment repair expertise and process capabilities. 3. Quality Management of Equipment Maintenance To ensure the quality of equipment maintenance, quality management should be implemented for equipment repairs. 1) The content of equipment maintenance and quality management (1) Establish quality standards for equipment maintenance. (2) Develop equipment maintenance procedures. (3) Inspection and evaluation of equipment maintenance quality. (4) Strengt hen quality management during the maintenance process. Establish quality control points for critical procedures and encourage participation in grassroots quality management team ac tivities, ensuring thorough implementation of the maintenance process plan. (5) Conduct post-repair customer service and quality feedback activities. (6) Strengthen technical train ing efforts to enhance both technical and managerial skills. 2) Inspection of Equipment Repair Quality Enterprises should establish organizations and assign personnel responsible f or inspecting and evaluating the quality of equipment maintenance. The main aspects of equipment maintenance quality inspection include: ① incoming inspection of purchased spare pa rts and materials; ② process quality control and final inspection of self-made spare parts and repaired components; ③ quality checks on components and assemblies during the equipme nt repair process; ④ visual inspection, trial runs, accuracy assessments, and performance tests conducted after repairs are completed. 3) Quality Assurance System for Equipment Mai ntenance The planning, management, spare parts handling, production oversight, technical administration, financial control, and supply of maintenance materials for equipment repair  form an integrated whole. By effectively organizing and coordinating these various aspects of management, we can establish robust systems—complete with management regulations, ope rational standards, workflow processes, and performance evaluation methods—ultimately creating a comprehensive quality assurance system for equipment maintenance. This ensures high -quality repairs while continuously enhancing our overall maintenance expertise. 1.5.5 Spare Parts Management The process by which enterprises, based on economic and practical prin ciples, determine standard limits for spare parts inventory—such as the quantity of spares to keep in stock, the amount of capital allocated to inventory, and the optimal reserve d uration—after gathering relevant data and conducting both calculations and real-world statistical analysis, is known as  "reserve quotas. " Effective spare parts inventory control requires establishing these precise reserve quotas. There is a wide variety of maintenance spare parts, and the prices, demand, inventory  levels, and stockholding durations of these parts vary significantly. Different inventory control methods should be applied to spare parts of varying types and characteristics, as  inventory management must also focus on key priorities. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 53 The ABC analysis categoriz es inventory spare parts into 3 classes. (1) Class A Spare Parts. Class A spare parts are a small but critical subset of components, characterized by their high importance, challen ging procurement and manufacturing processes, elevated costs, and extended lead times for stockpiling. Although these parts account for approximately 10% of all spare part types, t hey consume around 80% of the total budget allocated to spare parts. Therefore, Class A items require stringent control measures. Employing inventory theory, carefully determine op timal stock levels and ordering schedules, while maintaining minimal safety stock levels. Additionally, strive to reduce order cycles by increasing the frequency of purchases, ther eby accelerating the turnover of spare parts inventory funds. In warehouse management, ensure meticulous recording of all incoming and outgoing spare parts, conduct thorough statis tical analysis and calculations of inventory levels, and rigorously implement preventive measures to protect components against corrosion and rust. (2) Category B spare parts. Thes e have a wider variety than Category A spare parts, accounting for about 25% of the total product range, but they require less capital investment—typically around 15% of the total  funds allocated to spare parts. Category B spare parts usually maintain a higher safety stock level, though their reserves can be managed more flexibly. Additionally, based on main tenance needs, the ordering cycle can be appropriately extended to reduce the frequency of purchases. (3) Category C spare parts. These account for approximately 65% of all part va rieties but represent only about 5% of the total funds allocated to spare parts. For Category C items, inventory levels can be maintained at a slightly higher level based on mainte nance needs, and order lead times can be extended accordingly. The focus of spare parts management should be placed on managing Class A and Class B spare parts.

user_input: What preparations are required before conducting a machine tool's no-load operation test?
reference_contexts: ['Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required quality standards.', 'Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points.', 'Only after completing all necessary preparations in accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used.']
reference: Before conducting a machine tool's no-load operation test, several critical preparations must be completed. First, all major overhaul tasks must be finished, with each repair meeting the required quality standards. Second, all oil reservoirs must be filled with appropriate lubricant, and all lubrication points must be properly greased to ensure adequate lubrication during operation. Finally, all necessary preparations must be completed in strict accordance with safety operating procedures. Only after these steps are fulfilled can the no-load tests proceed according to the precision inspection standards specific to that particular machine tool, ensuring safe and accurate testing conditions.
answer: Before conducting the no-load operation test, ensure all major overhaul tasks are completed and meet quality standards, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points, and complete all necessary preparations in accordance with safety operating procedures.

Context:  
Rolling bearing: 70°C vs. 40°C (3) The machine tool's feed mechanism should undergo no-load tests at low, medium, and high feed speeds, while the rapid traverse mechanism should be tested under no-load conditions at its maximum rapid-speed setting. (4) During the machine tool's operational test, all mechanisms undergo startup, stopping, braking, automatic motion, gear-shift transitions, and rapid movements. All should be flexible and reliable. (5) All hydraulic, lubrication, and cooling systems must be free of leaks. (6) The pneumatic system and piping must not have any air leaks. (7) The machine tool's safety guards and protective devices must be complete, secure, and function reliably and sensitively. (8) The machine tool's accuracy must be checked both before and after the load test. For machine tools that do not undergo a load test, accuracy verification should be performed after the no-load running test. 2. Precision Inspection of Mechanical Equipment Maintenance After major overhauls of mechanical equipment, acceptance checks are conducted according to established standards. Take metal cutting machine tools as an example: the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established various precision testing standards for different types of machine tools, along with general guidelines for machine tool accuracy verification. These standards specify the inspection items, criteria, methods, and tolerances for machine tool accuracy—serving as the fundamental basis for conducting precision tests. Machine Tool Testing Since the geometric accuracy of machine tools is checked under static conditions, it cannot fully reflect the quality of machine tool maintenance. Th e key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. (1) No-load operation test of the machine tool. The pur pose of the no-load operation test is to further verify the correct functioning of each component of the machine tool. Sex, reliability, ease and normality of operation, as well as  whether the temperature rise and noise levels of each moving component are within acceptable limits. The primary focus of the machine tool's no-load running test is to simultaneou sly check the operational status of relevant parts while testing the spindle and feed speeds. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Mai ntenance 35 Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required qua lity standards. Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points. It is crucial to note: Only after completing all necessary preparations in  accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used. (2 ) Machine Tool Load Testing. The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machine’s main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design. (3) Machine Too l Working Accuracy Test. The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machine’s various components during the m achining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured.

user_input: What are the general principles and requirements for mechanical equipment disassembly?
reference_contexts: ['The primary purpose of dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance workload.', 'Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, it鈥檚 essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment.', 'This way, the dismantling can proceed methodically鈥攆ollowing a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines.']
reference: The general principles for mechanical equipment disassembly emphasize careful planning and methodical execution to support high-quality repairs. Disassembly primarily serves to enable inspection and repair of components, representing approximately 20% of total maintenance work. Key requirements include anticipating challenges beforehand and following a structured approach with specific rules and guidelines to ensure the process is efficient and maintains equipment integrity.
answer: The general principles for mechanical equipment disassembly include selecting a logical disassembly sequence based on structural characteristics, rational disassembly to avoid unnecessary disassembly, and using disassembly tools and equipment correctly. The requirements include preparations before disassembly such as selection and cleanup of the disassembly site, draining the oil before disassembly, and understanding the equipment's structure and principles, along with precautions during disassembly such as ensuring thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts, storing parts by category, and protecting the machined surfaces of removed parts.

Context:  
1.4.3 General Principles and Requirements for Mechanical Equipment Disassembly Any piece of machinery is assembled from numerous components. When machinery requires maintenance, it must first be disassembled so that faulty parts can be repaired or replaced. The primary purpose of dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance workload. Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, it’s essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment. This way, the dismantling can proceed methodically—following a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines. Preparations Before Disassembly (1) Selection and Cleanup of the Disassembly Site. Before disassembly, choose an appropriate work area—avoid locations prone to windblown sand or dust. The workspace should be kept free from frequent unauthorized access by unrelated personnel to prevent unnecessary disruptions or accidents. Additionally, ensure that the ground in the work area remains clean, free from dirt, oil, or other contaminants. Prior to entering the disassembly site, all machinery must undergo an external cleaning process to guarantee that the disassembly procedure does not compromise the equipment’s precision. (2) Protective Measures: Before cleaning the exterior of mechanical equipment, electrical devices should be either removed or properly protected to prevent moisture damage. Additionally, parts prone to oxidation and rust should promptly undergo appropriate protective and maintenance measures. (3) Draining the oil before disassembly. Whenever possible, drain the lubricating oil from the machinery while it’s still hot prior to disassembly, ensuring smoother and more efficient removal work. (4) Understand the structure, performance, and operating principles of mechanical equipment. To avoid unnecessary disassembly and ensure the smooth progress of maintenance work, thoroughly assess all aspects of the machinery before dismantling. Familiarize yourself with the structural features of each component, the transmission system, as well as the specific design characteristics and interrelationships of individual parts. Clearly identify their intended functions and how they interact with one another, enabling you to plan the disassembly process logically and select the appropriate tools or equipment for the job.
General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose.
2) Key Points for Process Specification Work (1) Disassembly process. When repairing mechanical equipment, the first step is to partially disassemble and take it apart. However, each time a machine is disassembled, its performance and precision inevitably suffer some degree of damage. Improper disassembly of precision equipment can even lead to complete报废 of the device. Therefore, it is crucial to approach this process with utmost care and expertise. Key and precision equipment should have dismantling process specifications developed. The general principles and precautions for disassembly will be introduced in Chapter 2 and can serve as a reference when developing the disassembly process. Additionally, please keep the following points in mind. ① Safety comes first during disassembly. Before starting, ensure the power supply is disconnected, remove any hazardous materials—such as toxic or flammable substances—from both inside and outside the machinery and equipment, set up reliable supports, and select appropriate lifting equipment and tools. ② Disassembly for service and maintenance. Do not disassemble components that are unnecessary or prohibited. For parts with tight fits, establish a proper disassembly method and use appropriate tools to avoid damaging critical surfaces. ③ Disassembly serves assembly. When the machine structure is complex and the drawing documentation is incomplete, disassemble while simultaneously documenting details and sketching preliminary diagrams, ultimately compiling a complete assembly drawing.
(1) The work area for disassembly and cleaning must be kept clean; dusty environments or outdoor locations are prohibited. If it is necessary to carry out the work outdoors, dust-control measures must be implemented. (2) Before disassembly, you must familiarize yourself with the drawings. Proceed step-by-step according to the diagrams, and mark the mating components clearly, ensuring that the markings are consistent, unambiguous, and easily visible. If the components already have existing marks, verify them thoroughly before proceeding with disassembly. When disassembling identical yet numerous components, provide a schematic diagram and mark them according to the numbers shown on the diagram. (3) Removed parts must be stored properly and protected from moisture, damage, or loss.

reference: Several critical preparations are required before disassembling mechanical equipment. First, select and prepare an appropriate disassembly site by choosing a location not prone to windblown sand or dust, keeping it free from unauthorized access to prevent disruptions, and ensuring the ground is clean without dirt, oil, or contaminants. All machinery must undergo external cleaning before entering the site to protect equipment precision. Protective measures include removing or safeguarding electrical devices against moisture during cleaning and applying protective maintenance to oxidation- and rust-prone parts. Additionally, drain lubricating oil while it is still hot to facilitate smoother disassembly. Finally, thoroughly understand the equipment's structure, performance, operating principles, component features, transmission system, design characteristics, part interrelationships, and functions to plan disassembly logically and select proper tools.
answer: Before disassembling mechanical equipment, preparations include selecting and cleaning the disassembly site to ensure it is free from dust and contaminants, protecting electrical devices and oxidation-prone parts from damage, draining the lubricating oil while it is still hot, thoroughly understanding the equipment's structure, performance, and operating principles, and familiarizing oneself with the relevant drawings to plan the disassembly sequence and mark components properly.

To ensure effective repairs and enhance overall efficiency, it’s essential to select the appropriate repair solution and develop a detailed maintenance process procedure. These procedures are typically documented in the form of process cards, which provide more specifics than standard manufacturing process cards yet remain simpler than operation-specific cards. A typical maintenance process card usually includes the following information: ① Part name, drawing number, material and properties, part defect indication diagram, and explanations regarding the defects.

(7) After cleaning, mechanical equipment components that cannot be assembled immediately should be properly stored to prevent dust from entering. user_input: How is the gear pair disassembled to maintain precision during reassembly?
reference_contexts: ['To improve the precision of the transmission chain, the gear pair with a transmission ratio of 1 is assembled using an error-compensation method: specifically, the tooth space at the point of maximum radial runout on one external gear is engaged with the tooth space at the point of minimum radial runout on the other gear.', 'To prevent errors introduced during reassembly from remaining unresolved, a mark is made at the mating points of the two gears during disassembly, ensuring that the original precision can be restored during reassembly.']
reference: The gear pair is disassembled with careful attention to preserving its precision characteristics. During disassembly, a mark is made at the mating points where the two gears engage. This marking is crucial because the gear pair uses an error-compensation assembly method where the tooth space at the point of maximum radial runout on one external gear engages with the tooth space at the point of minimum radial runout on the other gear. By marking these specific engagement points during disassembly, technicians ensure that the gears can be reassembled in exactly the same orientation, restoring the original precision and maintaining the error-compensation benefits of the transmission system.
answer: To maintain precision during reassembly, the gear pair assembled using an error-compensation method is disassembled by first making a mark at the mating points of the two gears, then removing axial positioning parts such as set screws, locknuts, spring washers, and retaining springs from the shaft, while also following general principles for disassembling threaded connections with the correct wrench and for interference-fit components with an appropriate removal method.

(axial positioning parts, are removed from, shaft) — Directly answers part of the "how" in disassembling the gear pair by specifying components to remove.  
(threaded connections, require, correct wrench) — Provides a general disassembly principle relevant to removing fasteners on the gear assembly.

Context:  
Disassembly of the Gear Pair To improve the precision of the transmission chain, the gear pair with a transmission ratio of 1 is assembled using an error-compensation method: specifically, the tooth space at the point of maximum radial runout on one external gear is engaged with the tooth space at the point of minimum radial runout on the other gear. To prevent errors introduced during reassembly from remaining unresolved, a mark is made at the mating points of the two gears during disassembly, ensuring that the original precision can be restored during reassembly. Removing Axially Positioned Parts
When disassembling shaft components from the gearbox, it is essential to first determine the direction of the shaft's steps, which will dictate the movement direction during removal. Next, remove the shaft caps at both ends, along with any axial positioning parts on the shaft, such as set screws, locknuts, spring washers, and retaining springs. Disassembling Threaded Connections In mechanical equipment, threaded connections are the most widely used method of joining components. They offer advantages such as simple structure, convenient adjustment, and the ability to be repeatedly disassembled and reassembled. While these connections are relatively easy to dismantle, improper handling—such as insufficient attention, incorrect tool selection, or improper dismantling techniques—often leads to damage. Therefore, when removing threaded fasteners, it’s crucial to use the right wrench or screwdriver; always avoid using adjustable wrenches whenever possible. For particularly tough-to-remove threaded joints, first determine the direction of the thread rotation, and never force the connection by twisting randomly or applying excessive leverage with an overly long extension bar. When removing double-ended studs, always use a specialized wrench designed specifically for this purpose. Disassembling Interference-Fit Components When disassembling interference-fit components, select the appropriate removal method, tools, and equipment based on the part's fit dimensions and the size of the interference. Suitable options include pullers, presses, and other specialized tools. Avoid directly striking components with a steel hammer to prevent damage. If no dedicated tools are available, you can use a wooden mallet, copper mallet, or plastic hammer, or alternatively, tap gently using a wooden (or block-shaped) or copper (or block-shaped) rod as a cushion against the steel hammer. Disassembling rolling bearings falls under the category of removing interference-fit components; this process is particularly versatile due to the unique characteristics of these bearings. Therefore, when disassembling, you must not only follow the key points for removing interference-fit components but also take into account their unique characteristics.

reference: The disassembly of shaft components from a gearbox involves two critical steps. First, you must determine the direction of the shaft's steps, as this dictates the correct movement direction for removal to avoid damage. Second, you need to remove the shaft caps located at both ends of the shaft, as well as all axial positioning parts attached to the shaft. These parts include set screws, locknuts, spring washers, and retaining springs, which secure the shaft in place and must be carefully detached to allow safe removal.

Context:  
When disassembling shaft components from the gearbox, it is essential to first determine the direction of the shaft's steps, which will dictate the movement direction during removal. Next, remove the shaft caps at both ends, along with any axial positioning parts on the shaft, such as set screws, locknuts, spring washers, and retaining springs. Disassembling Interference-Fit Components When disassembling interference-fit components, select the appropriate removal method, tools, and equipment based on the part's fit dimensions and the size of the interference. Suitable options include pullers, presses, and other specialized tools. Avoid directly striking components with a steel hammer to prevent damage. 2.1.2 Methods for Disassembling Shaft-Type Components
Removal Method (1) Striking and Disengaging. Striking involves using the force of a hammer to create relative movement between mating parts, allowing them to separate and achieve disassembly. This is a straightforward method suitable for simpler structures or when dealing with robust, non-critical components. (2) Press and pull disassembly. Press and pull methods are superior to impact disassembly because they apply force more evenly, allowing precise control over both the magnitude and direction of the force. As a result, these techniques reduce the risk of part misalignment or damage. This method is particularly suitable for dismantling larger components or parts with significant interference fits. (3) Hot disassembly. Hot disassembly leverages the thermal expansion properties of metals to separate parts, preventing issues like parts getting stuck or damaged—something that can occur with methods like impact or press disassembly. This technique is commonly used when the interference fit is significant (exceeding 0.1 mm), the components are large in size, or traditional disassembly methods prove impractical. In summary, choose the appropriate removal method based on how the parts fit together.

Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment

Customers are responsible for preparing operation and maintenance manuals in the appropriate language, as well as changing the display language, when shipping, transferring, or exporting robots to foreign countries—and must also ensure compliance with local laws and regulations. New users, without reading the operation manual, may perform improper or unsafe actions, potentially leading to accidents. 1.3 Abandoned Robots Do not disassemble, heat, or incinerate the batteries used in control devices and the robot body, as this may cause fire, rupture, or combustion. After disassembly, do not discard the control unit's baseplate and components directly, as sharp edges from cracks, cuts, or other damaged areas, along with exposed wires, could cause injury. Please remove the cables and external circuit wires from the connectors and junction boxes, then discard them directly—no further disassembly is required. Otherwise, operators could risk cuts to their hands or eyes from sharp conductors or other objects. Please exercise caution during the disposal process to avoid pinching or getting injured. Discarded items should be disposed of safely. 6. Disassembly of Non-Detachable Fasteners Non-detachable fasteners include welded and riveted components, among others. Welding and riveting are considered permanent connections and are typically not disassembled during maintenance. For dismantling welded components, methods such as sawing, plasma cutting, or first drilling small pilot holes with a drill bit before sawing can be used. Alternatively, oxy-acetylene flame cutting is also effective. As for riveted components, the rivet heads can be removed by chiseling, sawing, or gas cutting, or the rivets themselves can be drilled out using a drill. When performing these operations, care should be taken to avoid damaging the base parts. 1.4.5 Factors to Consider When Repairing Mechanical Part Failures

user_input: What factors should be considered when selecting a repair technique for mechanical parts?
reference_contexts: ['When repairing damage or defects in mechanical parts, several methods and techniques may be available, but determining the best approach depends on considering the following factors.', '(1) Consider the compatibility of the selected repair technique with the part material.', '(2) Consider the patching layer thicknesses that each repair technique can provide.']
reference: Two primary factors must be considered when selecting a repair technique for mechanical parts. First, the compatibility between the repair technique and the part material must be evaluated to ensure the method is suitable for the specific material. Second, the patching layer thickness that each technique can provide should be assessed, as different parts experience varying degrees of wear and require different thicknesses to compensate for that wear effectively.
answer: When selecting a repair technique for mechanical parts, one must consider the compatibility of the technique with the part material, the patching layer thickness it can provide, the mechanical properties of the repair layer, the operating conditions and requirements of the part, the production feasibility including existing workshop equipment and expertise, and the cost-effectiveness which combines repair cost with extended service life.

Context:  
During operation,机电设备 inevitably experience gradual wear, deformation, fracture, corrosion, and other forms of failure in their components. As a result, the equipment's precision, performance, and productivity decline, potentially leading to malfunctions, accidents, or even complete报废 (scrapping). This underscores the critical need for timely maintenance and repairs. In restorative maintenance, all measures are aimed at restoring the equipment as quickly and cost-effectively as possible. Effectively eliminate failures to enhance the equipment's overall utilization rate. Additionally, implementing repair techniques to restore failed components can efficiently achieve this goal. When repairing damage or defects in mechanical parts, several methods and techniques may be available, but determining the best approach depends on considering the following factors. (1) Consider the compatibility of the selected repair technique with the part material. When choosing a repair method, the first step should be to determine whether the technique is suitable for the material of the component being repaired. For instance, manual arc welding is ideal for low-carbon steel, medium-carbon steel, and alloy structural steels—A Case Study Guide for Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Mechanical and Electrical Systems. 38 And stainless steel. Arc surfacing under a flux layer is suitable for low-carbon and medium-carbon steels. Chrome plating technology works well with carbon structural steels, alloy structural steels, stainless steels, and gray cast iron. Bonded repair methods can firmly join parts made of various metallic and non-metallic materials. Spray coating has a broad applicability—almost any type of metal part, including carbon steel, alloy steel, cast iron components, and the vast majority of non-ferrous metal parts, can be coated. However, among metals, only a few non-ferrous materials pose challenges for spraying, such as pure copper; additionally, materials primarily composed of tungsten or molybdenum are also difficult to coat effectively. (2) Consider the patching layer thicknesses that each repair technique can provide. Since the degree of wear varies across different parts, the required thickness of the repair layer to compensate for wear will also differ. Therefore, when selecting a repair technique, it’s important to understand the maximum patching layer thickness achievable by each method.
(3) The mechanical properties of the repair layer—such as its strength and hardness—as well as the bond strength between the repair layer and the component, and the changes in surface strength of the part after repair—are critical indicators for evaluating repair quality and serve as the basis for selecting the appropriate restoration technique. (4) Consider the operating conditions and requirements of the mechanical parts. When selecting a repair technique, the working condition of the part should be taken into account. For example, For example, when mechanical parts operate under rolling conditions, the contact surfaces between the two components experience high contact stresses, making repair techniques like chrome plating, spray welding, and overlay welding particularly suitable. In contrast, when mechanical parts function under sliding conditions—where contact stresses are lower—the range of applicable repair technologies becomes much broader. When selecting a repair technique, it’s important to consider whether the mechanical part can still meet operational requirements after restoration. For instance, if the chosen repair method involves high temperatures during application—such as gas welding or electric welding—it may cause annealing of the mechanical component, compromising the original surface’s heat-treated properties and increasing thermal deformation and residual stresses. Techniques like patch welding or buildup welding, which involve high-temperature processes, are therefore best suited only for non-quenched parts, components that undergo post-weld machining or reshaping, or parts requiring subsequent heat treatment after welding. (5) Consider production feasibility. When selecting repair technologies, it’s essential to take into account the practicality of production, aligning the choice with the existing equipment in the company’s repair workshop, the current level of repair expertise, and the efficiency of the repair production management system. (6) Consider cost-effectiveness. When selecting a repair technique, economic factors should be taken into account. The repair cost of the part and the extended service life after repair should be combined to comprehensively evaluate and measure the economic viability of the chosen repair method. When selecting a parts repair process, it’s essential to consider multiple factors comprehensively rather than focusing on just one aspect. On one hand, you must evaluate the technical requirements of the part being repaired; on the other hand, you should assess the specific characteristics of the repair process itself. Additionally, it’s crucial to align the chosen method with your company’s existing repair capabilities and technical expertise. By doing so, you can ensure the process is both technically sound, economically viable, and practically feasible—ultimately leading to the optimal repair solution.

Additionally, arc surfacing under a flux layer is also suitable for low-carbon and medium-carbon steels, providing another viable option for repairing components made from low-carbon steel.

By doing so, you can ensure the process is both technically sound, economically viable, and practically feasible—ultimately leading to the optimal repair solution. 1.4.6 Methods for Repairing Mechanical Parts 1. Repair Dimension Method For certain mating dimensions, wear and other factors can alter the nature of the fit, leading to component failure. In such cases, cutting processes or other methods can be employed to restore the shape accuracy, positional accuracy, surface roughness, and other technical specifications of the worn areas on the primary part. Meanwhile, the complementary, simpler component—whether a new part manufactured to the correct dimensions while maintaining its original fit characteristics, or a repaired version—is produced accordingly. The dimension obtained after this reconditioning process is referred to as the "repair size." This approach is economically advantageous and ensures consistent quality since it involves machining directly on the existing component. However, it does reduce the strength and rigidity of the part, and it also necessitates replacing or repairing the mating component, thereby complicating the interchangeability of parts. The repair dimensioning method is primarily used to restore parts with relatively complex structures, while the corresponding complementary part is typically simpler—such as journal bearings, transmission threads, keyways, or sliding guides. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 39 2. Inlaying Component Method After localized wear of a part, and provided the structure and strength allow, add a component to compensate for the portion removed due to wear or repair, thereby restoring the original dimensions and precision. 3. Local Repair and Replacement Method The localized repair and replacement method restores a part's functionality by addressing worn or damaged areas through techniques such as local repairs, adjustments, repositioning, or partial replacements. 4. Plastic Deformation Method By leveraging the plastic deformation properties of metallic materials, this method allows excess material from non-functional areas of a part to be redistributed onto worn regions under specific external forces, thereby restoring the part’s original shape and dimensions. This approach not only alters the part’s geometry but also modifies its mechanical properties and microstructure. The primary techniques include upsetting, extrusion, expansion, and thermal straightening. When repairing low-carbon steel or non-ferrous metal parts that have not undergone heat treatment, plastic deformation can be performed without heating. For medium- and high-carbon steel parts or alloy steel parts, heating is required during plastic deformation repair. In the case of quenched parts undergoing plastic deformation repair, they must first be subjected to high-temperature tempering or annealing. 5. Metal Riveting Method This method uses specially designed connectors made from metal materials to mechanically and securely rejoin cracked or broken machine components into a single unit. It is characterized by being operated at room temperature, preventing thermal deformation and avoiding stress concentrations. The equipment is simple, and the process is easy to perform. Primarily, this technique is used to repair cracks or fractures in large castings—but it is not recommended for thin-walled castings smaller than 8 mm in thickness. There are strong-buckle bonding, tight-buckle bonding, premium-buckle bonding, and thermal-buckle bonding methods. For the specific processes of each bonding method, please refer to the relevant references. 6. Weld Repair Method The process of welding—where two or more materials (either identical or different) are joined permanently by heating, applying pressure, or combining both methods to achieve atomic-level bonding—is known as welding. At its core, this technique involves repairing damaged parts such as those with cracks or fractures, as well as building up wear-resistant and corrosion-resistant weld layers onto the surfaces of failed components. Its primary purpose is to restore most metal parts that have suffered damage due to wear, breakage, cracking, pitting, or other forms of deterioration. The advantages of the welding repair method include high bonding strength, simple welding equipment, mature technology, no limitations on part size, low cost, high efficiency, and great flexibility. The downside is that, due to the high welding temperature, it can easily cause changes in the microstructure, leading to stress and deformation. Additionally, it’s not suitable for repairing parts that require high precision, are slender, or relatively thin, as these components are prone to defects such as porosity, slag inclusion, and cracking. Welding techniques are primarily applied to metallic base materials, with commonly used methods including arc welding, argon arc welding, CO2 shielded welding, oxy-acetylene welding, laser welding, and more. Non-metallic materials like plastics can also be welded using specialized techniques. Future welding processes will focus on developing new welding methods, equipment, and materials to further enhance welding quality, safety, and reliability. This includes improving existing welding energy sources such as arc, plasma arc, electron beam, and laser technologies. Additionally, advancements in electronics and control technologies will be leveraged to optimize the process performance of arcs, while also enabling the development of reliable, lightweight arc-tracking systems. On the other hand, efforts will be made to elevate the level of welding mechanization and automation. For instance, welders will increasingly feature program-controlled or digitally controlled systems. Specialized automated welding machines capable of handling the entire process—from preparation and welding to quality monitoring—will be developed. Moreover, on automated welding production lines, numerically controlled welding manipulators and robots will be widely adopted and scaled up, boosting overall welding productivity while significantly improving workplace hygiene and safety conditions.
