Operators must always keep the following warnings in  mind: High-speed, high-temperature spray jets can cause injury to both people and equipment; spray dust is harmful to health—so ensure proper dust control and adequate ventilation ; loud spray noise may damage hearing—always wear ear protection; and radiation from the spray arc can harm your eyesight—make sure to wear safety goggles. Spray Welding Repair Technology If the thermal spray coating is further heated until both the coating and the substrate surface reach a molten state, allowing them to fuse together through metallurgical bonding and forming a robust working layer, this technique is known as spray welding repair technology. The materials used in spray welding can include various metals, alloys, or even non-metals, while the substrate material itself can also be made from a wide range of metals, alloys, or non-metals. The thickness of the spray-welded coating typically ranges from 0.5 mm to several millimeters, and the resulting coating structure is porous, which helps retain oil, leading to excellent lubrication and wear resistance. The spray welding process itself is straightforward. Single, short repair cycles, high productivity, and low costs. The spray welding repair technique can effectively enhance and improve the performance of part surfaces, such as oxidation resistance, electrical conductivity, insulation properties, and thermal insulation. However, the bond strength of the sprayed coating is relatively low, so caution should be exercised during application. Spray welding repair can restore the dimensions of worn components, such as machine tool spindles, crankshafts, camshaft journals, motor rotor shafts, machine tool guides, and slides. It can also be used to repair defects in castings, like sand holes and porosity. Additionally, applying a wear-resistant material—such as phosphor bronze or aluminum bronze—to areas requiring enhanced durability can significantly improve the component's resistance to wear. Meanwhile, spraying protective coatings onto specific areas can boost the part's corrosion resistance and other performance characteristics. Bonding and Coating Repair Techniques The method of joining parts made of the same or different materials into a single unit using adhesives, or of repairing worn or damaged compon ents, is known as bonding and repair bonding. Bonding can be used to fix broken parts, replacing screw connections when installing guide rail plates. It can also involve applying a dhesive to the worn areas of components—such as shafts or holes—followed by machining to restore their dimensions and geometric accuracy. Additionally, adhesives are employed to se al the mating surfaces between housings and lids, as well as pipe joints, ensuring both a tight seal and secure locking of threaded connections. Furthermore, adhesives can fill def ects like sand holes, air pockets, and porosity in castings, effectively preventing leaks and other issues. The bonding process has several advantages: First, it offers strong adhe sive strength and can bond a wide range of materials—everything from various metals to non-metallic substances. First, it provides strong adhesion and can bond dissimilar materials  together. Second, the process operates at relatively low temperatures, preventing thermal deformation of the bonded materials. Third, after bonding, the integrity and surface fini sh of the original components remain intact, with no stress concentrations formed. Additionally, the adhesive joint exhibits excellent chemical stability, insulation properties, an d sealing performance. Finally, the bonding process is simple, cost-effective, and allows for quick repair times. The drawback of the bonding process is that it lacks high-temperat ure resistance—organic adhesives typically can only withstand long-term operation up to 150°C. Inorganic adhesives can withstand high temperatures of up to 700°C; however, they exh ibit poor impact resistance and aging performance. Compared to welding, their bonding strength is relatively low. Nowadays, plastic components are increasingly used in engineering  applications. Plastics are broadly categorized into two types: thermoplastics and thermosets. For bonding thermoplastic parts, both hot-melt adhesive bonding and solvent-based adhe sive bonding methods can be employed. The specific procedures are outlined below. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 43 (1) Hot-melt bonding method. The surfaces to be bonded are heated and melted using electric heat, hot air, or frictional heat, then pressed together under sufficient pressure u ntil they cool and solidify. For most thermoplastic materials, heating the surface to 150–230°C is sufficient for bonding. (2) Solvent bonding method. Apply the appropriate solvent  to the bonding area, allow it to soften the plastic, and then bring the surfaces together while applying pressure. Force ensures strong adhesion once the solvent has evaporated, s uch as when polyethylene dissolves in xylene. If the solvent is chosen appropriately, the results are even better—however, thermosetting plastics remain insoluble in the solvent. Surface Enhancement Technologies Surface enhancement technology refers to a process that modifies the microstructure and properties of a part's surface, making them distinct from those of the base material. This technique can significantly improve the surface’s hardness, strength, wear resistance, and corrosion resistance. Specifically, it includes several methods such as surface mechanical strengthening, surface heat treatment strengthening, chemical heat treatment strengthening, laser surface treatment, and electrical discharge machining-based surface enhancement. Surface Mechanical Strengthening Surface mechanical strengthening involves inducing compressive deformation in the metal surface of a part through methods such as shot peening, roll forming, and internal extrusion, creating a hardened layer measuring 0.3 to 1.5 mm in thickness on the surface. Shot peening involves blasting high-velocity projectiles onto a component's surface, inducing intense plastic deformation in the metal material and creating a cold-worked layer with elevated residual stresses—known as the shot-peened layer. Shot peening enhances a material's resistance to fatigue fracture, preventing fatigue failure, plastic deformation, and brittle fracture while extending its fatigue life. It is suitable for use in a wide range of industries, including machinery, aerospace, marine applications, petroleum, mining, railways, transportation, heavy machinery, and military equipment. Rolling enhancement involves using a diamond or other type of rolling head to apply a specific rolling force onto the surface of a part. A method that induces hardening of the rolled surface through strain-induced strengthening, thereby enhancing the mechanical properties of the component's surface. Surface Heat Treatment Strengthening and Chemical Heat Treatment Strengthening (1) Surface heat treatment strengthening. Surface heat treatment is a metal heat treatment process that involves heating only the surface layer of a workpiece to alter its mechanical properties. To heat only the surface of the workpiece without allowing excessive heat to penetrate into its interior, the heat source used must have a high energy density—meaning it delivers significant thermal energy over a small area of the workpiece, enabling the surface or specific regions to reach extremely high temperatures in a short or even instantaneous time. The main methods of surface heat treatment include flame quenching and induction heating, while common heat sources include flames such as oxy-acetylene or oxy-propane, as well as induced currents, lasers, and electron beams. (2) Surface chemical heat treatment strengthening. Surface chemical heat treatment is a metal heat treatment process that alters the chemical composition, microstructure, and properties of a workpiece's surface layer. Unlike surface heat treatment, which primarily modifies the material's surface properties through temperature changes, surface chemical heat treatment specifically targets the chemical composition of the surface layer. Chemical heat treatment involves heating a workpiece in a medium containing carbon, nitrogen, or other alloying elements—such as gas, liquid, or solid—and holding it at that temperature for an extended period. This process allows elements like carbon, nitrogen, boron, and chromium to diffuse into the surface of the workpiece. After diffusion, additional heat treatment processes, such as quenching and tempering, may be carried out as needed. The main methods of chemical heat treatment include carburizing, nitriding, and metal impregnation. 3) Laser Surface Treatment Heating is achieved using a laser beam, which rapidly melts a thin layer of the workpiece surface to a specific depth. Simultaneously, alloy elements are applied to the workpiece surface via methods such as vacuum evaporation, electroplating, or ion implantation. Under laser irradiation, these elements fully fuse with the base metal, and after solidification, a specially engineered alloy layer—ranging from 10 to 1,000 micrometers thick—is formed on the mold surface, exhibiting unique properties. The cooling rate during this process is equivalent to… Quenching with Rapid Cooling: A Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems
Shielded Metal Arc Welding Shielded metal arc welding (SMAW), also known as manual arc welding, is an arc welding process in which a welder manually controls the electrode while using the electric arc generated between the electrode and the workpiece to locally heat and melt both the electrode and the base material for joining. It remains the most widely used welding method today. The advantages of this method include: simple equipment that’s easy to maintain, flexible operation, and the ability to weld seams in any spatial position—essentially anywhere the electrode can reach—making it highly versatile across a wide range of applications. The drawbacks are: high requirements for welders, poor working conditions, and low production efficiency. The equipment used in shielded metal arc welding is an arc welder, which has a simple structure and mainly consists of two parts: the arc welding power source and the welding clamp. Welding electrode arc welding equipment should be used with the following precautions. (1) Check that the wiring is correct and ensure the equipment casing is properly grounded. If a welder experiences electric shock, first disconnect the power supply before administering first aid. (2) When operating the power switch, always wear dry gloves and avoid standing directly in front of it to prevent facial burns caused by arc sparks. (3) Welding cables must not be placed near the welding machine or on hot metal welds, and they should also be protected from collisions and abrasion.
Gas welding A welding method that uses the flame generated by the combustion of a flammable gas mixed with an oxidizing gas as a heat source, melting both the workpiece and the filler material to achieve atomic-level bonding. The primary oxidizing gas is oxygen, while common flammable gases include acetylene, liquefied petroleum gas, and others. Oxygen-acetylene gas welding equipment primarily includes oxygen cylinders, acetylene cylinders (if acetylene is used as the combustible gas), pressure regulators, welding torches, and hoses. Since the gas cylinders used to store these flammable and explosive gases are pressure vessels, this method is one of the most hazardous among all welding techniques. Advantages of gas welding: simple equipment, flexible use; excellent adaptability for welding cast iron and certain non-ferrous metals; and a valuable option when welding is needed in areas with insufficient power supply. Drawbacks of gas welding: lower production efficiency; significant workpiece deformation and a larger heat-affected zone after welding; and greater difficulty in achieving automation. The flame temperature typically ranges from 2,700 to 3,300°C, making it suitable for welding various materials. It is virtually compatible with almost all metallic materials, particularly well-suited for thin sections less than 6 mm thick. Additionally, it excels in welding aluminum, aluminum alloys, copper, and copper alloys. The thickness can be thicker.

user_input: What is brazing and how does it work?
reference_contexts: ["Use a metal material with a melting point lower than that of the base material as the brazing filler metal, and heat the workpieces鈥攚here the filler metal has been placed鈥攖o a temperature above the filler metal's melting point but below the base material's melting point.", 'The method of joining components by using a liquid brazing filler metal that wets the base material at its melting point, fills the joint gap, and then diffuses into the base material to form a strong bond is called brazing.']
reference: Brazing is a method of joining components by using a brazing filler metal that has a lower melting point than the base material. The process involves placing the filler metal between the workpieces and heating them to a temperature above the filler metal's melting point but below that of the base material. This causes the filler metal to melt, wet the base material, fill the joint gap through capillary action, and then diffuse into the base material to form a strong bond.
answer: Brazing is a method of joining components that uses a brazing filler metal with a melting point lower than the base material, where the workpieces are heated to a temperature above the filler metal's melting point but below the base material's melting point, causing the liquid filler metal to wet the base material, fill the joint gap via capillary action, and then diffuse into the base material to form a bond.

Context:  
Use a metal material with a melting point lower than that of the base material as the brazing filler metal, and heat the workpieces—where the filler metal has been placed—to a temperature above the filler metal's melting point but below the base material's melting point. The method of joining components by using a liquid brazing filler metal that wets the base material at its melting point, fills the joint gap, and then diffuses into the base material to form a strong bond is called brazing. Brazing is divided into hard brazing and soft brazing. Brazing performed using filler metals with melting points above 450°C is commonly referred to as hard brazing, examples include copper brazing and silver brazing; while brazing conducted with filler metals having melting points below 450°C is typically called soft brazing, such as tin soldering and lead soldering. Brazing has the following characteristics: ① It requires lower heating temperatures, resulting in minimal changes to the microstructure and mechanical properties of the workpiece. ② The molten braze filler metal fills the gaps between the metals being joined via capillary action, leading to excellent gas-tightness in the weld. ③ The workpiece experiences little deformation, producing smooth and even joints. ④ Can join dissimilar materials. ⑤ Low weld strength. Brazing methods can technically be divided into two types: soldering iron brazing and flame brazing. (1) Soldering with a soldering iron. The solder and the area to be welded are heated using an electric soldering iron, making it suitable for soft soldering applications where temperatures remain below 300°C—such as with tin-lead or lead-based solders. When soldering thin or small components, a flux is typically required. The power rating of the soldering iron should be selected based on the type of solder, the material of the workpiece, and the shape and size of the component. (2) Flame brazing. This method uses a flame to heat the braze alloy and the area to be joined, making it suitable for hard brazing applications where temperatures exceed 300°C. It is particularly ideal for workpieces whose shape, size, or equipment constraints make other brazing methods impractical. Commonly used brazing alloys include copper-zinc, copper-phosphorus, silver-based, aluminum-based, and zinc-aluminum alloys, enabling the joining of materials such as steel, stainless steel, cemented carbides, cast iron, copper, silver, aluminum, and their respective alloys. Since brazed joints typically exhibit lower strength compared to other welding techniques, brazing is generally recommended for repairing cracks and fractures in components that do not require high structural integrity. Additionally, designing and selecting an appropriate joint configuration is crucial to enhance the overall strength of the assembly. Brazing is especially well-suited for addressing localized defects—such as abrasions or scratches—on low-speed moving parts.

user_input: What are the differences between hard brazing and soft brazing?
reference_contexts: ['Brazing is divided into hard brazing and soft brazing. Brazing performed using filler metals with melting points above 450掳C is commonly referred to as hard brazing, examples include copper brazing and silver brazing; while brazing conducted with filler metals having melting points below 450掳C is typically called soft brazing, such as tin soldering and lead soldering.']
reference: Hard brazing and soft brazing are distinguished by the melting point of the filler metal used. Hard brazing employs filler metals with melting points above 450掳C, such as copper or silver brazing alloys, and is used for higher-temperature applications. Soft brazing uses filler metals with melting points below 450掳C, like tin-lead or lead-based solders, and is suitable for lower-temperature joining processes.
answer: The primary difference between hard brazing and soft brazing is the melting point of the filler metal: hard brazing uses filler metals with melting points above 450°C, such as copper brazing and silver brazing, and is suitable for methods like flame brazing, while soft brazing uses filler metals with melting points below 450°C, such as tin soldering and lead soldering, and is suitable for methods like soldering iron brazing.

user_input: What are the advantages of the spray welding repair process?
reference_contexts: ['The process is flexible, requires few operational steps, allows for quick repairs, and reduces machining time.', 'Highly adaptable, generally unrestricted by workpiece size or site conditions.', 'Coating thickness can be controlled.']
reference: The spray welding repair process offers several key advantages: It is highly flexible and adaptable, with few operational steps, making it efficient and straightforward to perform. This adaptability means it is generally not restricted by workpiece size or site conditions, allowing for versatile application. The process enables quick repairs with short cycles, high productivity, and low costs, reducing overall machining time. Coating thickness can be precisely controlled, and the base material is heated to a lower temperature, which minimizes workpiece deformation and results in only slight changes to microstructure and mechanical properties. Additionally, it can use various substrate materials to create a wide range of protective and functional coatings on nearly all solid material surfaces, enhancing properties like oxidation resistance, electrical conductivity, insulation, and thermal insulation.

1.4 Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Procedures and Implementation With the continuous advancement of new materials, processes, and technologies, repairing mechanical parts has evolved beyond simply restoring them to their original condition. Many advanced techniques now not only revive components but also enhance their performance and extend their service life. For instance, methods such as electroplating, surfacing welding, application of wear-resistant coatings, thermal spraying and flame spraying, adhesive bonding, and various surface-hardening treatments allow for the precise deposition of small amounts of high-performance materials onto part surfaces—at relatively low costs—while significantly boosting wear resistance. As a result, in the maintenance of electromechanical equipment, fully leveraging these repair techniques and carefully selecting appropriate processes can reduce downtime, cut maintenance expenses, and ultimately lead to substantial improvements in a company’s economic efficiency. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Repair for Electromechanical Equipment 27
If none of the above standards apply, refer to the equipment manufacturer's technical specifications. (4) Preparation of spare parts, materials, and specialized tools, inspection equipment, and research fixtures. The lead technical personnel should promptly provide the management team with detailed lists of replacement parts, material specifications, as well as lists of specialized tools, inspection equipment, and research fixtures, along with relevant drawings. After verifying the inventory, the management team will place orders or arrange for manufacturing to ensure that these items are available on time for use during major equipment overhauls. (5) Preparing the Overhaul Work Plan. The overhaul work plan is prepared by the planning personnel in the maintenance department, who are responsible for equipment management. Personnel, chief technicians, and maintenance foremen (team leaders) review it together. The overhaul work plan includes: work procedures, the number of workers required for each phase and stage of the job, along with the corresponding duration in days; requirements for seamless coordination between individual work phases; and details on projects that need to be outsourced to external partners, including specific timeframes. A general overhaul work plan can be presented using a "bar chart" format, supplemented by necessary explanatory text. For overhauls of complex, high-precision, large-scale, and critical equipment, network scheduling techniques should be employed to ensure efficient resource utilization, shorten project timelines, and enhance overall economic benefits. 4. Material Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Material preparation before equipment maintenance is a critically important task, serving as the essential logistical foundation for successful repairs. In practice, delays often occur due to insufficient availability of spare parts and components, disrupting the normal flow of maintenance work, prolonging downtime, and ultimately leading to inefficiencies and production losses. Therefore, it is imperative to strengthen material preparation efforts prior to equipment maintenance. After the lead maintenance technician has prepared detailed lists of replacement parts and materials, they should promptly hand these over to the responsible personnel managing spare parts and supplies. Once the inventory has been verified, these managers will place orders accordingly. Meanwhile, after finalizing the repair procedures, the lead maintenance technician must immediately provide the tool management team with detailed lists and drawings of specialized tools, inspection devices, and testing equipment. The tool management staff will then cross-check the existing inventory and forward any necessary items—such as specialized tools, inspection devices, or testing equipment—to the relevant departments for evaluation. Based on the evaluation results, if repairs are indeed required, the departments will arrange for the necessary maintenance activities. Additionally, the tool management team will initiate new procurement requests for any additional specialized tools, inspection devices, or testing equipment that may be needed. 1.4.2 General Process for Mechanical Equipment Maintenance
(2) The process is flexible, requires few operational steps, allows for quick repairs, and reduces machining time. (3) Highly adaptable, generally unrestricted by workpiece size or site conditions. (4) Coating thickness can be controlled. (5) Apart from spray welding, the base material is heated to a lower temperature, resulting in minimal workpiece deformation and only slight changes in microstructure and mechanical properties. (6) Components made from various substrate materials can be used to prepare a wide range of protective and functional coatings on nearly all solid material surfaces. However, it’s important to remember that spray painting is an extremely hazardous task. Operators must always keep the following warnings in mind: High-speed, high-temperature spray jets can cause injury to both people and equipment; spray dust is harmful to health—so ensure proper dust control and adequate ventilation; loud spray noise may damage hearing—always wear ear protection; and radiation from the spray arc can harm your eyesight—make sure to wear safety goggles. Spray Welding Repair Technology If the thermal spray coating is further heated until both the coating and the substrate surface reach a molten state, allowing them to fuse together through metallurgical bonding and forming a robust working layer, this technique is known as spray welding repair technology. The materials used in spray welding can include various metals, alloys, or even non-metals, while the substrate material itself can also be made from a wide range of metals, alloys, or non-metals. The thickness of the spray-welded coating typically ranges from 0.5 mm to several millimeters, and the resulting coating structure is porous, which helps retain oil, leading to excellent lubrication and wear resistance. The spray welding process itself is straightforward. Single, short repair cycles, high productivity, and low costs. The spray welding repair technique can effectively enhance and improve the performance of part surfaces, such as oxidation resistance, electrical conductivity, insulation properties, and thermal insulation. However, the bond strength of the sprayed coating is relatively low, so caution should be exercised during application. Spray welding repair can restore the dimensions of worn components, such as machine tool spindles, crankshafts, camshaft journals, motor rotor shafts, machine tool guides, and slides. It can also be used to repair defects in castings, like sand holes and porosity. Additionally, applying a wear-resistant material—such as phosphor bronze or aluminum bronze—to areas requiring enhanced durability can significantly improve the component's resistance to wear. Meanwhile, spraying protective coatings onto specific areas can boost the part's corrosion resistance and other performance characteristics. Bonding and Coating Repair Techniques The method of joining parts made of the same or different materials into a single unit using adhesives, or of repairing worn or damaged components, is known as bonding and repair bonding. Bonding can be used to fix broken parts, replacing screw connections when installing guide rail plates. It can also involve applying adhesive to the worn areas of components—such as shafts or holes—followed by machining to restore their dimensions and geometric accuracy. Additionally, adhesives are employed to seal the mating surfaces between housings and lids, as well as pipe joints, ensuring both a tight seal and secure locking of threaded connections. Furthermore, adhesives can fill defects like sand holes, air pockets, and porosity in castings, effectively preventing leaks and other issues. The bonding process has several advantages: First, it offers strong adhesive strength and can bond a wide range of materials—everything from various metals to non-metallic substances. First, it provides strong adhesion and can bond dissimilar materials together. Second, the process operates at relatively low temperatures, preventing thermal deformation of the bonded materials. Third, after bonding, the integrity and surface finish of the original components remain intact, with no stress concentrations formed. Additionally, the adhesive joint exhibits excellent chemical stability, insulation properties, and sealing performance. Finally, the bonding process is simple, cost-effective, and allows for quick repair times. The drawback of the bonding process is that it lacks high-temperature resistance—organic adhesives typically can only withstand long-term operation up to 150°C. Inorganic adhesives can withstand high temperatures of up to 700°C; however, they exhibit poor impact resistance and aging performance. Compared to welding, their bonding strength is relatively low. Nowadays, plastic components are increasingly used in engineering applications. Plastics are broadly categorized into two types: thermoplastics and thermosets. For bonding thermoplastic parts, both hot-melt adhesive bonding and solvent-based adhesive bonding methods can be employed. The specific procedures are outlined below. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 43 (1) Hot-melt bonding method. The surfaces to be bonded are heated and melted using electric heat, hot air, or frictional heat, then pressed together under sufficient pressure until they cool and solidify. For most thermoplastic materials, heating the surface to 150–230°C is sufficient for bonding. (2) Solvent bonding method. Apply the appropriate solvent to the bonding area, allow it to soften the plastic, and then bring the surfaces together while applying pressure. Force ensures strong adhesion once the solvent has evaporated, such as when polyethylene dissolves in xylene. If the solvent is chosen appropriately, the results are even better—however, thermosetting plastics remain insoluble in the solvent. Surface Enhancement Technologies Surface enhancement technology refers to a process that modifies the microstructure and properties of a part's surface, making them distinct from those of the base material. This technique can significantly improve the surface’s hardness, strength, wear resistance, and corrosion resistance. Specifically, it includes several methods such as surface mechanical strengthening, surface heat treatment strengthening, chemical heat treatment strengthening, laser surface treatment, and electrical discharge machining-based surface enhancement. Surface Mechanical Strengthening Surface mechanical strengthening involves inducing compressive deformation in the metal surface of a part through methods such as shot peening, roll forming, and internal extrusion, creating a hardened layer measuring 0.3 to 1.5 mm in thickness on the surface. Shot peening involves blasting high-velocity projectiles onto a component's surface, inducing intense plastic deformation in the metal material and creating a cold-worked layer with elevated residual stresses—known as the shot-peened layer. Shot peening enhances a material's resistance to fatigue fracture, preventing fatigue failure, plastic deformation, and brittle fracture while extending its fatigue life. It is suitable for use in a wide range of industries, including machinery, aerospace, marine applications, petroleum, mining, railways, transportation, heavy machinery, and military equipment. Rolling enhancement involves using a diamond or other type of rolling head to apply a specific rolling force onto the surface of a part. A method that induces hardening of the rolled surface through strain-induced strengthening, thereby enhancing the mechanical properties of the component's surface. Surface Heat Treatment Strengthening and Chemical Heat Treatment Strengthening (1) Surface heat treatment strengthening. Surface heat treatment is a metal heat treatment process that involves heating only the surface layer of a workpiece to alter its mechanical properties. To heat only the surface of the workpiece without allowing excessive heat to penetrate into its interior, the heat source used must have a high energy density—meaning it delivers significant thermal energy over a small area of the workpiece, enabling the surface or specific regions to reach extremely high temperatures in a short or even instantaneous time. The main methods of surface heat treatment include flame quenching and induction heating, while common heat sources include flames such as oxy-acetylene or oxy-propane, as well as induced currents, lasers, and electron beams. (2) Surface chemical heat treatment strengthening. Surface chemical heat treatment is a metal heat treatment process that alters the chemical composition, microstructure, and properties of a workpiece's surface layer. Unlike surface heat treatment, which primarily modifies the material's surface properties through temperature changes, surface chemical heat treatment specifically targets the chemical composition of the surface layer. Chemical heat treatment involves heating a workpiece in a medium containing carbon, nitrogen, or other alloying elements—such as gas, liquid, or solid—and holding it at that temperature for an extended period. This process allows elements like carbon, nitrogen, boron, and chromium to diffuse into the surface of the workpiece. After diffusion, additional heat treatment processes, such as quenching and tempering, may be carried out as needed. The main methods of chemical heat treatment include carburizing, nitriding, and metal impregnation. 3) Laser Surface Treatment Heating is achieved using a laser beam, which rapidly melts a thin layer of the workpiece surface to a specific depth. Simultaneously, alloy elements are applied to the workpiece surface via methods such as vacuum evaporation, electroplating, or ion implantation. Under laser irradiation, these elements fully fuse with the base metal, and after solidification, a specially engineered alloy layer—ranging from 10 to 1,000 micrometers thick—is formed on the mold surface, exhibiting unique properties. The cooling rate during this process is equivalent to… Quenching with Rapid Cooling: A Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems
1) Categories of Equipment Maintenance Plans The time-phased plans include: ① The annual maintenance plan, which encompasses all major, medium, and minor repair schedules for the enterprise throughout the year, as well as regular equipment maintenance and upgrade/installation plans. This plan should be completed by the end of the previous year. ② The quarterly maintenance plan, derived from the annual plan, further breaks down the yearly objectives into more detailed tasks. It also allows for timely adjustments and additions to project timelines and sequences based on actual conditions, typically finalized during the last month of the preceding quarter. ③ The monthly maintenance plan, which is even more specific and meticulous than the quarterly plan, serves as the operational blueprint for executing maintenance activities. Critical tasks such as routine upkeep, periodic inspections, and scheduled diagnostics must all be incorporated into the monthly plan. Additionally, any issues identified during the previous month’s routine checks will be addressed by scheduling minor repairs this month. Plans categorized by maintenance type usually consist of the annual major overhaul plan and the annual equipment preventive maintenance schedule. The budget is primarily intended for corporate finance departments to prepare funds for major repairs and control major repair expenses. Some companies also prepare budgets for itemized repairs and minor maintenance tasks. Detailed schedule for maintenance, preventive testing, and regular precision adjustments.

This technique alters the surface properties of the base material by integrating the applied conductive material through spark-induced melting and fusion.

Context:  
1.5.1 The Significance of Equipment Management Strengthening equipment management and ensuring proper maintenance will keep machinery consistently in excellent condition, thereby extending its lifespan. This not only plays a critical role in boosting production volume and variety, enhancing labor productivity, reducing consumption, lowering costs, and safeguarding worker safety—but also significantly contributes to upgrading the company’s overall production technology, accelerating industrial growth, and protecting productive capacity. Equipment management is an extremely important task—only by effectively managing equipment can organizations achieve optimal economic results with minimal human, financial, and material resources. This, in turn, allows for the full realization of equipment potential, enabling businesses to better meet production goals. Especially in modern manufacturing, prioritizing sound equipment management is a fundamental principle that must be followed. Equipment maintenance management is an important component of enterprise management. Its primary tasks include: maximizing Effectively collecting and utilizing equipment information resources allows for the strategic management of manpower, materials, funds, equipment, and technology within the maintenance system, ensuring that maintenance operations achieve optimal quality and maximum efficiency. The key components of maintenance management include maintenance information management, maintenance planning, maintenance technology, process and quality control, spare parts management, and maintenance economic management. In modern enterprises, management is inseparable from technology, while the effective application of engineering technologies relies on sound management practices. Equipment engineering technicians, who are well-versed in equipment maintenance management principles and methods, should seamlessly integrate technical expertise with managerial skills. To this end, this section will outline the key aspects, methodologies, and practical applications of equipment maintenance management. 1.5.2 Information Management for Equipment Maintenance In corporate equipment maintenance activities, it is often necessary to make various technical and economic decisions, and the basis for these decisions is information. Breath. Without a systematic and reliable information system, effective management becomes difficult to implement. Therefore, the task of equipment maintenance information management is to establish a comprehensive information system that collects, stores, and organizes all types of equipment-related data, while also enabling data processing, output, and feedback—ultimately supporting informed economic and technical decision-making for equipment management. 1. Classification of Equipment Maintenance Information Equipment maintenance information can be complex, but it can generally be categorized using the following methods. 1) Categorized by equipment in the early versus later stages This classification method divides equipment information into two major systems—early-stage and later-stage—and further breaks them down into numerous subsystems. Within these subsystems, various types of equipment are grouped, ultimately leading to a detailed breakdown for each individual device. The approach is straightforward and clear, making it easy to process, organize, and access the information. 2) Categorized by equipment management objectives and performance indicators
Usage guidelines include strengthening equipment management, establishing and rigorously enforcing operating procedures, enhancing inspection and maintenance of mechanical equipment, avoiding overloading, and preventing localized overloads or overheating. Case Study Tutorial on Diagnosis and Repair of Electromechanical System Failures 24
Component Repair Method By treating equipment components as the primary focus of maintenance—replacing entire components during repairs—the process allows for disassembly, reassembly of parts, and even manufacturing tasks to be carried out after the component has been replaced. This approach significantly reduces downtime during maintenance. However, the component-based repair method requires maintaining a certain inventory of spare parts, which ties up some working capital. For companies that own large numbers of similar equipment, this method is particularly well-suited. Component Repair Method Some machinery and equipment experience heavy production loads, making it difficult to schedule ample time for major overhauls. In such cases, the sectional maintenance method can be employed. This approach involves repairing different components of the equipment at separate times—rather than all at once—by systematically and sequentially addressing each independent part of the machine, focusing on just one section at a time. The key advantage of sectional maintenance is that it allows organizations to take advantage of holidays Repairs are carried out during non-production hours to maximize machine uptime and improve equipment utilization. The sectional repair method is suitable for machinery with structurally independent components, as well as equipment requiring lengthy maintenance periods—such as modular machine tools and heavy-duty transportation equipment. 3) Synchronized Maintenance Method The synchronized maintenance method involves arranging several pieces of equipment, which are interconnected in the production process, to undergo maintenance simultaneously, thereby achieving synchronized upkeep and minimizing downtime associated with decentralized repairs. This approach is commonly applied to equipment on assembly lines, particularly to main units, auxiliary machines, and supporting systems within integrated production lines. The implementation of the single-equipment maintenance plan involves the following steps: (1) Delivery for Repair. The equipment user unit shall deliver the equipment to the repair unit on the date specified in the maintenance plan. During the handover, a thorough inspection and verification must be conducted, and the "Equipment Handover Form" should be completed in duplicate, with each party retaining one copy. After the equipment completion and acceptance, both parties shall count the equipment as per the "Equipment Handover Form," along with the accompanying accessories and specialized tools that were transferred together. (2) Maintenance and Construction. During the maintenance process, the following key steps should generally be carefully managed: ① Dismantling Inspection: After the equipment is disassembled, the lead technician and maintenance workers will promptly inspect the components for wear and failure. Special attention should be paid to identifying any issues that were either undetected or unforeseen prior to the repair process. Additionally, the following technical documents and drawings should be issued as soon as possible: a detailed list of parts to be repaired or replaced, based on inspection findings; an updated and supplemented bill of materials; revised and supplementary sections of the maintenance technical specification sheet; and temporary manufacturing drawings for any custom-made components. Planning and scheduling personnel, together with the maintenance team leader, will revise and adjust the maintenance work plan based on the actual situation, then post it at the construction site so that all involved personnel can stay informed about the project progress. ② Production scheduling. The maintenance team leader must daily monitor the actual progress of repair work on each component and mark it clearly with a red line on the work schedule. If a task is found to be delayed, the team leader can reallocate resources based on the time buffers indicated in the network plan to get the project back on track. Planning and scheduling personnel should daily review the progress of work plans, paying close attention to the pace of tasks on critical paths. They should collaborate with technicians, workers, and team leaders to promptly address any issues arising during construction. Additionally, emphasis should be placed on ensuring smooth coordination among different trades to prevent idle time, material shortages, and delays that could impact project timelines. ③ Process Quality Inspection: After maintenance personnel complete each process and pass their own self-inspection, the work must be inspected by a quality control inspector. Only after confirmation of compliance can it proceed to the next process. For critical processes that pass inspection, a label should be affixed. ④ Progress in manufacturing temporary components. The progress of manufacturing temporary parts often becomes the primary factor delaying repair work. To address this, meticulously schedule processing steps for each critical component and implement measures to ensure they remain ready for use without delay. 1.1.4 Management of Failures Equipment failure management is a critical component of overall equipment maintenance. Effectively leveraging the fault information generated during equipment operation—by analyzing data from multiple perspectives and predicting potential failures—and subsequently implementing proactive measures to minimize equipment-related losses are essential for enhancing overall equipment management practices. Establishing a procedure for managing enterprise equipment failures is the first step in building an accident early-warning mechanism, and correctly developing such a procedure is of great significance. To effectively manage equipment failures, it’s essential to thoroughly understand the root causes of breakdowns, systematically collect data and information on common and typical failures, conduct in-depth failure analyses, emphasize research into failure patterns and mechanisms, and strengthen routine maintenance, inspections, and preventive repairs. The purpose of equipment failure management is to monitor and diagnose equipment conditions before failures occur, enabling operators to identify any signs of degradation. This proactive approach aims to detect early warning indicators and potential risks, allowing for timely preventive maintenance to effectively control the occurrence of failures. After a failure does happen, the process involves promptly analyzing the root cause, developing targeted solutions, and implementing measures to either resolve the issue or improve the equipment—ultimately preventing future occurrences. Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechatronic Systems
Equipment maintenance technology and process management refer to the scientific administration of all technical and operational activities involved in the maintenance system and the repair process. Equipment maintenance quality management involves a series of managerial practices aimed at ensuring the high quality of equipment repairs. These three areas of management play a crucial role in successfully completing equipment maintenance tasks. Management of Basic Maintenance Technical Tasks

To facilitate statistical analysis, equipment information can be categorized into five main types: investment planning data, asset and spare parts information, technical condition data, maintenance schedule details, and personnel information. Each category can further be broken down into numerous sub-items and specific evaluation metrics, making it easier to conduct comprehensive classification-based analysis. 3) Categorized from a maintenance perspective Equipment information can be categorized into equipment status information, equipment maintenance information, equipment failure or accident information, repair work information, repair material information, repair personnel information, repair cost information, and related information, among others. 2. Functions of the Computer Repair Information System In modern enterprises, a computer maintenance information system can either serve as a subsystem within the company's management system or operate as an independent system altogether. The functionality of a computer maintenance information system is closely tied to the configuration of both the hardware and software components of computers. Currently, several versatile equipment management software solutions have already been integrated into the system software. The computer maintenance information system offers the following key functions in equipment repair and management: 1) Process Control Function The process control function can be used to monitor equipment operating conditions and detect key performance parameters such as vibration, noise, ultrasound, temperature rise, cooling status, lubrication condition, and environmental factors, providing critical information to guide maintenance activities. 2) Engineering Design and Calculation Functionality The engineering design and calculation function enables mechanical analysis and computations for various equipment and maintenance tooling, as well as supports computer-aided design and drafting, along with diverse optimization processes. 3) Information Processing Function The information processing function handles various types of data in maintenance management, covering the following 5 aspects: (1) Equipment Ledger Management. Store the original data and documentation for all company equipment in a computer system, allowing you to generate workshop equipment ledgers and equipment lists by model—in various formats—as needed. (2) Equipment classification, sorting, querying, and retrieval. Categorize and sort equipment supply information available in the market, storing it in the system to provide insights when companies update or add new equipment. (3) Equipment Maintenance Planning Management. When determining equipment maintenance plans, you can refer to equipment records, maintenance information, and diagnostic data stored in the computer system, and, based on actual conditions, use the computer to develop annual, quarterly, and monthly equipment maintenance schedules. (4) Maintenance Spare Parts Management. By entering the enterprise equipment maintenance spare parts’ demand information, inventory details, and inbound/outbound records into the computer system, users can instantly access real-time inventory status and generate statistical reports. Additionally, an alert notification can be automatically triggered when the current stock level drops below the predefined warning threshold. (5) Other functions. The computer system can also provide service functionalities to the maintenance system, including personnel management, financial management, and technical and process management.

Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 45 Repair costs, equipment integrity rate, maintenance expenses per 10,000 yuan of equipment value, and more. To facilitate statistical analysis, equipment information can be categorized into five main types: investment planning data, asset and spare parts information, technical condition data, maintenance schedule details, and personnel information. Each category can further be broken down into numerous sub-items and specific evaluation metrics, making it easier to conduct comprehensive classification-based analysis. 3) Categorized from a maintenance perspective Equipment information can be categorized into equipment status information, equipment maintenance information, equipment failure or accident information, repair work information, repair material information, repair personnel information, repair cost information, and related information, among others. 2. Functions of the Computer Repair Information System In modern enterprises, a computer maintenance information system can either serve as a subsystem within the company's management system or operate as an independent system altogether. The functionality of a computer maintenance information system is closely tied to the configuration of both the hardware and software components of computers. Currently, several versatile equipment management software solutions have already been integrated into the system software. The computer maintenance information system offers the following key functions in equipment repair and management: 1) Process Control Function The process control function can be used to monitor equipment operating conditions and detect key performance parameters such as vibration, noise, ultrasound, temperature rise, cooling status, lubrication condition, and environmental factors, providing critical information to guide maintenance activities. 2) Engineering Design and Calculation Functionality The engineering design and calculation function enables mechanical analysis and computations for various equipment and maintenance tooling, as well as supports computer-aided design and drafting, along with diverse optimization processes. 3) Information Processing Function The information processing function handles various types of data in maintenance management, covering the following 5 aspects: (1) Equipment Ledger Management. Store the original data and documentation for all company equipment in a computer system, allowing you to generate workshop equipment ledgers and equipment lists by model—in various formats—as needed. (2) Equipment classification, sorting, querying, and retrieval. Categorize and sort equipment supply information available in the market, storing it in the system to provide insights when companies update or add new equipment. (3) Equipment Maintenance Planning Management. When determining equipment maintenance plans, you can refer to equipment records, maintenance information, and diagnostic data stored in the computer system, and, based on actual conditions, use the computer to develop annual, quarterly, and monthly equipment maintenance schedules. (4) Maintenance Spare Parts Management. By entering the enterprise equipment maintenance spare parts’ demand information, inventory details, and inbound/outbound records into the computer system, users can instantly access real-time inventory status and generate statistical reports. Additionally, an alert notification can be automatically triggered when the current stock level drops below the predefined warning threshold. (5) Other functions. The computer system can also provide service functionalities to the maintenance system, including personnel management, financial management, and technical and process management. 1.5.3 Equipment Maintenance Plan Management The enterprise's equipment management department conducts planned, appropriately scaled maintenance on its equipment. When carrying out specific maintenance tasks, it’s also essential to organize resources effectively to ensure the progress, quality, and efficiency of the repairs. This planning and organizational process is known as Maintenance Planning Management. It comprises two key components: first, a macro-level maintenance plan (including annual, quarterly, and monthly schedules); and second, a detailed tutorial on micro-level mechanical and electrical system fault diagnosis and repair cases. 46 The work plan refers to a specific operational process, such as a major overhaul schedule for a machine, and is characterized by its closer relationship to process technology. Standard Workload for Equipment Maintenance The equipment maintenance work quotas serve as the basis for developing equipment maintenance plans and organizing repair operations. Accurately establishing these maintenance quotas enhances the scientific rigor and predictive capability of maintenance planning, facilitates thorough preparation before repairs begin, and ensures that maintenance activities are conducted in a more cost-effective and rational manner. Before drafting mechanical and electrical equipment maintenance plans, it is essential to first define various maintenance quotas. The main equipment maintenance quotas include: equipment maintenance complexity factor, maintenance labor-hour quota, maintenance downtime quota, maintenance cycle and interval period, and maintenance cost quota. 1) Equipment Maintenance Complexity Factor The equipment maintenance complexity factor, also known as the maintenance complexity unit or simply the maintenance unit, is a hypothetical measure used to assess the intricacy of equipment repair tasks, determine the associated workload, and establish standard benchmarks for various metrics. This assumed unit represents the maintenance effort required for a specific type of machinery, with its value determined by factors such as the equipment's structural design, dimensions, size, and precision levels. In general, the more complex the equipment's structure, the larger its physical dimensions, and the higher the machining accuracy demanded, the greater its maintenance complexity factor will be. For instance, in metal-cutting machine tools, the C620 lathe—typically featuring a maximum workpiece diameter of 400 mm and a maximum workpiece length of 1,000 mm—is often used as the benchmark machine. Its maintenance complexity factor is standardized at 10. As for electrical equipment, the focus shifts to… A protected cage-type synchronous motor with a rated power of 0.6 kW is standard equipment, and its maintenance complexity factor is specified as 1. For other machinery and equipment, the maintenance complexity factor can be determined by comparing their structure, size, precision, and other characteristics to those of the standard unit. Once a labor quota for one maintenance unit (represented by "R") has been established, the maintenance workload for any other type of machine can be calculated based on this unit. Additionally, maintenance downtime quotas and cost estimates can also be derived using the maintenance unit as a benchmark. The enterprise's supervisory authority has determined the maintenance complexity factors for various types of equipment and machine tools (establishing separate complexity factors for mechanical and electrical systems), and formulated these into company standards for use during equipment maintenance activities.
1.5.1 The Significance of Equipment Management Strengthening equipment management and ensuring proper maintenance will keep machinery consistently in excellent condition, thereby extending its lifespan. This not only plays a critical role in boosting production volume and variety, enhancing labor productivity, reducing consumption, lowering costs, and safeguarding worker safety—but also significantly contributes to upgrading the company’s overall production technology, accelerating industrial growth, and protecting productive capacity. Equipment management is an extremely important task—only by effectively managing equipment can organizations achieve optimal economic results with minimal human, financial, and material resources. This, in turn, allows for the full realization of equipment potential, enabling businesses to better meet production goals. Especially in modern manufacturing, prioritizing sound equipment management is a fundamental principle that must be followed. Equipment maintenance management is an important component of enterprise management. Its primary tasks include: maximizing Effectively collecting and utilizing equipment information resources allows for the strategic management of manpower, materials, funds, equipment, and technology within the maintenance system, ensuring that maintenance operations achieve optimal quality and maximum efficiency. The key components of maintenance management include maintenance information management, maintenance planning, maintenance technology, process and quality control, spare parts management, and maintenance economic management. In modern enterprises, management is inseparable from technology, while the effective application of engineering technologies relies on sound management practices. Equipment engineering technicians, who are well-versed in equipment maintenance management principles and methods, should seamlessly integrate technical expertise with managerial skills. To this end, this section will outline the key aspects, methodologies, and practical applications of equipment maintenance management. 1.5.2 Information Management for Equipment Maintenance In corporate equipment maintenance activities, it is often necessary to make various technical and economic decisions, and the basis for these decisions is information. Breath. Without a systematic and reliable information system, effective management becomes difficult to implement. Therefore, the task of equipment maintenance information management is to establish a comprehensive information system that collects, stores, and organizes all types of equipment-related data, while also enabling data processing, output, and feedback—ultimately supporting informed economic and technical decision-making for equipment management. 1. Classification of Equipment Maintenance Information Equipment maintenance information can be complex, but it can generally be categorized using the following methods. 1) Categorized by equipment in the early versus later stages This classification method divides equipment information into two major systems—early-stage and later-stage—and further breaks them down into numerous subsystems. Within these subsystems, various types of equipment are grouped, ultimately leading to a detailed breakdown for each individual device. The approach is straightforward and clear, making it easy to process, organize, and access the information. 2) Categorized by equipment management objectives and performance indicators
3. Reliability Maintenance Also known as Reliability-Centered Maintenance (RCM), this approach emerged in the U.S. civil aviation industry during the 1960s and is now widely implemented in industries with particularly high demands for equipment operational reliability, such as the nuclear and military sectors. While the time it takes for a potential failure in operating equipment to evolve into a functional failure can vary, all failure patterns eventually reveal detectable trends through systematic monitoring. This technique leverages these predictable patterns to implement proactive maintenance measures—making it a reliability-focused maintenance strategy aimed at enhancing equipment dependability. Rooted in reliability theory, RCM involves detailed analysis and experimentation of factors influencing system reliability, followed by the application of logical decision-making processes. This approach enables the scientific development of tailored maintenance plans, the optimal selection of repair methods, and the precise determination of equipment lifespan—all designed to maintain and restore the inherent reliability of assets while minimizing costs. Reliability-based maintenance is advancing equipment repair work toward greater scientific rigor and modernization, making it worthy of further attention and research. 4. Quality Maintenance This is an equipment maintenance procedure developed with a focus on ensuring product quality, aiming to keep all critical quality characteristics of product components and parts in optimal condition. To achieve this goal, the method manages key factors influencing quality—such as people, machines, and materials—and places particular emphasis on the relationship between equipment performance and product quality. It employs tools from Total Quality Management, including graphical techniques like Pareto charts, as well as statistical analysis methods. By closely monitoring product quality conditions, the process identifies problematic production steps, pinpointing faulty equipment areas and their root causes, and then systematically categorizes and organizes this information. Based on the severity of each issue, critical problems are prioritized, analyzed one by one, and targeted recovery measures are formulated. For chronic quality issues where the root cause remains unclear, PM analysis (Process-Machine Phenomenon Analysis) is utilized to investigate further. Perform a root cause analysis to identify the reasons and solutions, and establish a management system to prevent future failures.
Material details, etc. 6. Maintenance-Free Design Maintenance-free design is the ideal goal for equipment maintenance—it refers to implementing improvement measures during the design phase of new machinery and electrical equipment to address common failures encountered during maintenance, aiming to minimize maintenance efforts or even eliminate the need for repairs altogether. 1.2.2 Maintenance Method Selection The purpose of maintenance is to ensure the reliable operation of equipment—specifically, to guarantee the dependable fulfillment of its intended use—and, at the same time, minimize maintenance costs. Therefore, the fundamental requirements for maintenance decisions are: ① Reliability must not fall below the permissible minimum value [R], meaning that ()[] R ≥ R(t); ② Maintenance costs (KI) must be kept as low as possible—or, alternatively, must not exceed a predetermined maintenance cost limit (KImin), i.e., K ≤ KImin. To optimize maintenance decisions, the first step should be to choose an appropriate maintenance approach. The six maintenance methods mentioned above each have a specific scope of applicability; however, their effectiveness can vary depending on how appropriately they are applied. To maximize equipment efficiency, minimize downtime-related losses, and reduce maintenance costs, it’s essential to select the most suitable approach based on the characteristics of mechatronic systems and the conditions under which they are used. Looking ahead, the trend in maintenance practices is shifting from routine preventive maintenance toward planned, periodic inspections—and then, based on inspection findings, scheduling timely condition-based repairs. As the technological sophistication of factory equipment continues to rise, with increasingly complex system designs and broader adoption of mechatronic solutions, production activities are becoming more reliant on equipment performance and reliability. Consequently, the traditional static approach to maintenance management is evolving into a more dynamic model, gradually moving toward advanced strategies such as reliability-centered maintenance and quality-focused repair practices. Mechatronic equipment comes in a wide variety of types and is widely applied, making it essential to select one or a combination of maintenance methods tailored to the specific situation. When choosing a maintenance approach for mechatronic systems, reliability typically becomes the primary focus. For critical components, implementing condition-based monitoring allows for timely preventive measures. Meanwhile, for equipment at quality control points, it’s crucial to closely track changes in product quality during the manufacturing process and promptly address any detected anomalies through quality repairs. Additionally, it’s important to equip teams with personnel who are well-versed in microelectronics technology, providing them with supervision and guidance while fostering the development of skilled, integrated mechatronics technicians. Regular inspections and logical fault analysis should be conducted on CNC and other mechatronic systems, and any failed components identified must be promptly replaced and properly adjusted to ensure optimal performance. 1.2.3 Maintenance System Maintenance work is not only a technical task but also a managerial one. A maintenance system refers to a set of guidelines established under specific maintenance theories and principles, encompassing elements such as maintenance plans, categories, methods, timing, scope, levels, organizational structures, and performance evaluation metrics. Implementing a rational maintenance system helps optimize the allocation of human, material, and financial resources, enabling timely preparation before maintenance tasks, ensuring repairs are carried out appropriately, meeting operational requirements, enhancing the technical condition, reliability, and service life of机电 equipment, reducing downtime, and minimizing maintenance costs and production losses due to equipment shutdowns. Meanwhile, maintenance systems are continuously evolving and improving—currently, the main approaches include the following: Planned Preventive Maintenance System It is based on a thorough understanding of the wear and failure patterns of mechanical and electrical equipment, applying the principle of pre vention being better than cure—and addressing potential issues before they escalate—by systematically organizing maintenance and repairs according to the rate of wear and expected  service life of each component. This approach helps prevent premature wear, compensates for natural degradation, minimizes or avoids failures altogether, extends equipment lifespan , and ultimately saves time spent on repairs, thereby enhancing operational efficiency and boosting economic returns. The practical implementation of planned preventive maintenance  can be summarized as  "regular inspections, timely upkeep, and scheduled repairs, " making it particularly suitable for Chapter 1 of this guide: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment. 11 Macro-level management. I mplementing a planned preventive maintenance system requires the following conditions: ① Determining the maintenance intervals for assemblies and key components through statistical analysis, measurements, and experimental studies, and rationally categorizing mainten ance tasks;
The degree is very high. Choose a reasonable running-in load, relative motion speed, and lubrication. Slip conditions and other parameters are key to shortening the break-in period. 2) Stable Wear Phase AB The wear characteristic of this stage is a low and stable wear rate, which is why the duration of this phase is relatively long. But by mid- Figure 1.3: Wear Characteristic Curve –  Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 19 Later on, the wear rate becomes relatively faster, but the equipment can still fu nction for a while. When the wear amount reaches point B, the wear rate sharply accelerates, marking the onset of the severe wear phase. Proper usage, along with regular maintenanc e and upkeep of the equipment, is key to extending this critical stage. 3) Rapid Wear Phase BC Once this stage is reached, significant changes in friction conditions occur, such as  altered lubrication or shifts in the geometric dimensions of components. Changes, such as increased clearance between mating parts and the generation of impact loads, can cause we ar rates to rise sharply. At this point, mechanical efficiency noticeably declines, and precision deteriorates—conditions that, if left unaddressed, could lead to equipment failure  or even unexpected accidents. Therefore, promptly identifying and repairing components that are about to enter this stage is critically important. According to wear results, wear  is categorized into pitting wear, adhesive wear, abrasive wear, and more; while based on wear mechanisms, it is classified into abrasive wear, fatigue wear, adhesive wear, fretting  wear, and others. Abrasive wear occurs when a hard protruding part on one surface of a friction pair comes into contact with the other surface, or when abrasive particles are pres ent between the two rubbing surfaces. Wear occurs when hard particulates—such as dust in the air or metal particles generated by abrasion—cause material transfer from one surface t o another, or even simultaneous material loss on both surfaces, during relative motion. Among the many wear failure modes, abrasive wear is not only the most common but also the mo st severe type of failure. Fretting wear refers to a type of wear where localized areas on the surfaces of friction pairs develop fatigue cracks under cyclic contact stresses, lead ing to the detachment of micro-sheets or particles. Depending on the nature of contact and relative motion between the friction pairs, fretting wear can be categorized into two mai n forms: rolling-contact fatigue wear and sliding-contact fatigue wear. In practical applications, pure rolling-contact fatigue wear is relatively rare; most often, it occurs as a  combination of rolling and sliding motions. Adhesive wear occurs when, at the points of contact between mating surfaces,  "cold welding " takes place, causing material from one surface to transfer to the other during relative sliding. Micro-motion wear is a type of wear that occurs when two contacting objects under go relative vibrations with very small amplitudes. It happens on two closely matched surfaces that appear nominally stationary but actually experience cyclic, minute-scale relative  sliding—typically at the micrometer level (2–20 μm). For instance, this phenomenon can be observed at interference or transition-fit interfaces between shafts and holes, on keyway  surfaces, or in threaded fasteners. Wear occurring on working surfaces, such as the working surface of the rivet, and other similar areas. Fretting wear not only reduces mating ac curacy, loosens tight-fitting components, and degrades the quality of the mating surfaces, but can also lead to the formation of fatigue cracks, significantly diminishing the fatig ue strength of the part. 2. Measures to Prevent or Reduce Wear

reference_contexts: ['The equipment maintenance complexity factor, also known as the maintenance complexity unit or simply the maintenance unit, is a hypothetical measure used to assess the intricacy of equipment repair tasks, determine the associated workload, and establish standard benchmarks for various metrics.', "This assumed unit represents the maintenance effort required for a specific type of machinery, with its value determined by factors such as the equipment's structural design, dimensions, size, and precision levels. In general, the more complex the equipment's structure, the larger its physical dimensions, and the higher the machining accuracy demanded, the greater its maintenance complexity factor will be.", 'For instance, in metal-cutting machine tools, the C620 lathe鈥攖ypically featuring a maximum workpiece diameter of 400 mm and a maximum workpiece length of 1,000 mm鈥攊s often used as the benchmark machine. Its maintenance complexity factor is standardized at 10. As for electrical equipment, the focus shifts to鈥?A protected cage-type synchronous motor with a rated power of 0.6 kW is standard equipment, and its maintenance complexity factor is specified as 1.']
reference: The equipment maintenance complexity factor, also referred to as the maintenance complexity unit or maintenance unit, is a hypothetical standardized measure designed to evaluate the complexity of equipment repair tasks, quantify associated workloads, and set benchmarks for maintenance metrics. Its value is determined by specific equipment characteristics including structural design, dimensions, physical size, and precision requirements鈥攇enerally, more complex structures, larger dimensions, and higher precision demands result in a higher complexity factor. For example, in metal-cutting machine tools, the C620 lathe (with a maximum workpiece diameter of 400 mm and length of 1,000 mm) serves as the benchmark with a standardized factor of 10, while for electrical equipment, a protected cage-type synchronous motor rated at 0.6 kW is the standard with a factor of 1. Other machinery is assessed by comparing their structural, size, and precision attributes to these standard units. Once the labor quota for one maintenance unit (denoted as "R") is defined, it enables calculation of maintenance workloads for any machine type. Furthermore, the maintenance unit serves as a basis for deriving maintenance downtime quotas and cost estimates. Enterprises establish these factors for different equipment and machine tools, with separate values for mechanical and electrical systems, and formalize them into company standards to guide maintenance activities.
answer: The equipment maintenance complexity factor is a hypothetical measure used to assess the intricacy of equipment repair tasks, determine the associated workload, and establish standard benchmarks for various metrics; it is used to assess workload, establish standard benchmarks, calculate maintenance workload, downtime quotas, and cost estimates, and serves as a benchmark for planning and resource allocation.

(C620 lathe, has a maintenance complexity factor of, 10) — This provides a concrete example of the factor's value for a standard machine.  
(0.6 kW protected cage-type synchronous motor, has a maintenance complexity factor of, 1) — This provides a concrete example for electrical equipment.
