Context:  
Equipment maintenance technology and process management refer to the scientific administration of all technical and operational activities involved in the maintenance system and the repair process. Equipment maintenance quality management involves a series of managerial practices aimed at ensuring the high quality of equipment repairs. These three areas of management play a crucial role in successfully completing equipment maintenance tasks. Management of Basic Maintenance Technical Tasks
3. Reliability Maintenance Also known as Reliability-Centered Maintenance (RCM), this approach emerged in the U.S. civil aviation industry during the 1960s and is now widely implemented in industries with particularly high demands for equipment operational reliability, such as the nuclear and military sectors. While the time it takes for a potential failure in operating equipment to evolve into a functional failure can vary, all failure patterns eventually reveal detectable trends through systematic monitoring. This technique leverages these predictable patterns to implement proactive maintenance measures—making it a reliability-focused maintenance strategy aimed at enhancing equipment dependability. Rooted in reliability theory, RCM involves detailed analysis and experimentation of factors influencing system reliability, followed by the application of logical decision-making processes. This approach enables the scientific development of tailored maintenance plans, the optimal selection of repair methods, and the precise determination of equipment lifespan—all designed to maintain and restore the inherent reliability of assets while minimizing costs. Reliability-based maintenance is advancing equipment repair work toward greater scientific rigor and modernization, making it worthy of further attention and research. 4. Quality Maintenance This is an equipment maintenance procedure developed with a focus on ensuring product quality, aiming to keep all critical quality characteristics of product components and parts in optimal condition. To achieve this goal, the method manages key factors influencing quality—such as people, machines, and materials—and places particular emphasis on the relationship between equipment performance and product quality. It employs tools from Total Quality Management, including graphical techniques like Pareto charts, as well as statistical analysis methods. By closely monitoring product quality conditions, the process identifies problematic production steps, pinpointing faulty equipment areas and their root causes, and then systematically categorizes and organizes this information. Based on the severity of each issue, critical problems are prioritized, analyzed one by one, and targeted recovery measures are formulated. For chronic quality issues where the root cause remains unclear, PM analysis (Process-Machine Phenomenon Analysis) is utilized to investigate further. Perform a root cause analysis to identify the reasons and solutions, and establish a management system to prevent future failures.
1.5.1 The Significance of Equipment Management Strengthening equipment management and ensuring proper maintenance will keep machinery consistently in excellent condition, thereby extending its lifespan. This not only plays a critical role in boosting production volume and variety, enhancing labor productivity, reducing consumption, lowering costs, and safeguarding worker safety—but also significantly contributes to upgrading the company’s overall production technology, accelerating industrial growth, and protecting productive capacity. Equipment management is an extremely important task—only by effectively managing equipment can organizations achieve optimal economic results with minimal human, financial, and material resources. This, in turn, allows for the full realization of equipment potential, enabling businesses to better meet production goals. Especially in modern manufacturing, prioritizing sound equipment management is a fundamental principle that must be followed. Equipment maintenance management is an important component of enterprise management. Its primary tasks include: maximizing Effectively collecting and utilizing equipment information resources allows for the strategic management of manpower, materials, funds, equipment, and technology within the maintenance system, ensuring that maintenance operations achieve optimal quality and maximum efficiency. The key components of maintenance management include maintenance information management, maintenance planning, maintenance technology, process and quality control, spare parts management, and maintenance economic management. In modern enterprises, management is inseparable from technology, while the effective application of engineering technologies relies on sound management practices. Equipment engineering technicians, who are well-versed in equipment maintenance management principles and methods, should seamlessly integrate technical expertise with managerial skills. To this end, this section will outline the key aspects, methodologies, and practical applications of equipment maintenance management.

Context:  
Management of Maintenance Technical Documentation Equipment maintenance technical documentation primarily comes from the technical materials provided as part of the equipment purchase; materials acquired during use from equipment manufacturers, relevant organizations, scientific bookstores, and more; as well as documents designed, surveyed, and compiled in-house. Management is as described below. (1) Specification standards, including relevant international standards, national standards, departmentally issued standards, as well as applicable laws and regulations. (2) Drawing materials, including instruction manuals for mechanical power equipment within the company, partial equipment manufacturing drawings, maintenance and assembly diagrams, spare parts catalogues, and related technical documentation. (3) Layout Diagram of Power Station Equipment and Power Pipeline Network Diagram. (4) Process documentation, including maintenance procedures, parts repair processes, critical component manufacturing techniques, and drawings for specialized tools and fixtures, etc. (5) Maintenance Quality Standards and Equipment Testing Procedures. (6) General technical files, including equipment manuals, research reports, experimental data, calculation notes, cost analyses, claim reports, standard technical materials, patent documents, and relevant literature, among others. (7) Samples and books, including domestic and international samples, books, periodicals, electronic publications, CDs, floppy disks, photographs, and slides, among others.

user_input: How should maintenance technical documentation be managed and what are the key priorities?
reference_contexts: ['Maintenance technical documentation is primarily intended for use within the equipment management system and should generally be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room.', 'The management process should encompass the entire lifecycle of the materials鈥攃overing collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution.', 'Effective management of technical documentation requires prioritization: key equipment manuals, along with relevant assembly drawings, electrical schematics, and other critical documents, should be clearly marked for enhanced oversight.']
reference: Maintenance technical documentation should be centrally managed in a dedicated documentation room for use within the equipment management system. The management process covers the complete lifecycle including collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution. Key priorities include clearly marking critical documents such as key equipment manuals, assembly drawings, and electrical schematics for enhanced oversight, with these priority documents typically restricted from external loan. Additionally, effective management requires establishing a coded indexing system and implementing computer-based management to facilitate compilation and retrieval of documentation.
answer: Maintenance technical documentation should be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room, encompassing the entire lifecycle of the materials including collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction, storage, retrieval, and distribution. Context:  
Management of Maintenance Technical Documentation Equipment maintenance technical documentation primarily comes from the technical materials provided as part of the equipment purchase; materials acquired during use from equipment manufacturers, relevant organizations, scientific bookstores, and more; as well as documents designed, surveyed, and compiled in-house. Management is as described below. (1) Specification standards, including relevant international standards, national standards, departmentally issued standards, as well as applicable laws and regulations. (2) Drawing materials, including instruction manuals for mechanical power equipment within the company, partial equipment manufacturing drawings, maintenance and assembly diagrams, spare parts catalogues, and related technical documentation. (3) Layout Diagram of Power Station Equipment and Power Pipeline Network Diagram. (4) Process documentation, including maintenance procedures, parts repair processes, critical component manufacturing techniques, and drawings for specialized tools and fixtures, etc. (5) Maintenance Quality Standards and Equipment Testing Procedures. (6) General technical files, including equipment manuals, research reports, experimental data, calculation notes, cost analyses, claim reports, standard technical materials, patent documents, and relevant literature, among others. (7) Samples and books, including domestic and international samples, books, periodicals, electronic publications, CDs, floppy disks, photographs, and slides, among others. 2) Management Program Maintenance technical documentation is primarily intended for use within the equipment management system and should generally be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room. The management process should encompass the entire lifecycle of the materials—covering collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution. Effective management of technical documentation requires prioritization: key equipment manuals, along with relevant assembly drawings, electrical schematics, and other critical documents, should be clearly marked for enhanced oversight. Importantly, these priority documents are typically not available for external loan. To facilitate compilation and retrieval, it is necessary to establish a coded indexing system for the data and implement computer-based management. The equipment maintenance manual serves as a comprehensive collection of specialized technical documentation for equipment repair, providing maintenance personnel with essential resources for troubleshooting, diagnosing faults, developing repair strategies, and even manufacturing spare parts when needed. The equipment maintenance manuals are compiled separately for each equipment model, and the manuals should include the following content. (1) Features and Feature Diagrams. The features and feature diagrams include an outline diagram, lifting diagram, installation foundation drawing, and Chapter 1—Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. 51

(4) Check the machine tool's operational condition: Verify whether the control system responds sensitively and reliably during movement; ensure that all movements meet the specified values; and confirm that the motion is smooth, without vibrations, noise, or stick-slip phenomena. (5) Inspect the machine tool guideways, lead screws, and racks for wear, and measure the extent of the wear. (6) Inspect the hydraulic, pneumatic, and lubrication systems: Verify that movements are accurate, check for any component damage or leaks, and if leaks are present, identify the cause. (7) Inspect the electrical system: Check whether electrical components are aged or malfunctioning. (8) Inspect safety protection devices: Verify that all limit switches and interlock mechanisms are sensitive and reliable, and check whether any of the indicator instruments or protective guards are damaged. (9) Inspect the equipment's appearance and accessories: Check for chipped paint, damage to any handles, ensure all labels are present, and verify that accessories are complete and free from wear or damage. (10) Partial disassembly inspection to determine whether parts need replacement or repair based on their wear condition. During the pre-inspection, especially large and complex castings and forgings, high-precision critical components, and purchased parts must be checked one by one to determine whether they need replacement or repair. Preparing overhaul technical documentation By conducting a pre-inspection to assess the equipment's condition and determine whether repairs or component replacements are necessary, we can then proceed to analyze, develop a repair plan, and prepare the corresponding technical documentation. These technical documents serve as the foundation for major equipment overhauls. Commonly used technical documents for equipment overhauls include the following types: (1) Prepare the equipment maintenance technical specification. The equipment maintenance technical specification should include the following content. ① The technical condition of the equipment before major overhaul. ② Key maintenance activities include detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection of components to identify parts that require repair or replacement; briefly outlining the repair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that must be thoroughly inspected and adjusted, as well as other areas requiring attention; and highlighting specific parts and aspects that can be improved during the overhaul process. ③ Maintenance quality requirements: Specify the names and numbers of the general technical standards applicable to each quality inspection during major equipment overhauls, and attach the content of any specialized technical standards to the back of the task specification. (2) Preparing Maintenance Procedures. The maintenance procedures for mechanical equipment are the technical documents that must be carefully followed and implemented during major overhauls. When developing overhaul procedures, it’s essential to consider the actual conditions, ensuring both technical feasibility and economic viability. Mechanical equipment overhaul procedures can be categorized into two types: standard maintenance procedures and specialized maintenance procedures. The overhaul procedures for mechanical equipment typically include the following elements. ① Disassembly procedures and methods for the complete machine and its components, as well as the data to be monitored and precautions to observe during the disassembly process.
6 The procedure for equipment failure management is outlined below. (1) Conduct thorough education and awareness campaigns to ensure that operators and maintenance personnel voluntarily comply with relevant rules and regulations regarding operation, maintenance, inspection, etc., properly use and carefully maintain equipment, and diligently record, compile statistics, and analyze any equipment malfunctions. (2) Based on the company’s actual production conditions, equipment status, and specific features, determine the key areas for equipment failure management. (3) Use monitoring instruments and diagnostic techniques to systematically monitor critical equipment, enabling timely detection of fault indicators and deterioration. Information on equipment condition. Typically, equipment can undergo daily inspections, routine patrols, and periodic checks (including precision assessments), as well as integrity assessments—using human senses and common diagnostic tools—to closely monitor the technical status and any unusual signs in components, mechanisms, and areas prone to failure. At the same time, inspection standards should be established to clearly define the boundaries between normal operation, abnormalities, and equipment failures. (4) To quickly locate the fault location and its cause, in addition to providing training to ensure that maintenance and operational staff acquire a solid understanding of electrical and hydraulic technologies, it is also essential to compile common equipment failure symptoms, analysis procedures, and troubleshooting methods into a fault-finding logic flowchart. This will enable operators to swiftly identify the source and root cause of any malfunction after it occurs, allowing for timely diagnosis, repair, and restoration of equipment functionality. (5) Improve the fault recording system. Fault records serve as the foundational data for effective fault management and also provide the original basis for conducting fault analysis and troubleshooting. Records must be complete and accurate. After on-site inspections and fault repairs, maintenance personnel should follow the "Equipment Carefully complete the "Equipment Failure Repair Form" and submit monthly statistical analyses to the equipment management department. (6) Conduct timely statistics and analysis of equipment failures. In addition to monitoring failure situations on a daily basis, staff members should compile "Failure Repair Forms" and maintenance records on a monthly basis. By systematically collecting, organizing, and analyzing failure data, it’s possible to calculate the failure frequency and mean time between failures for each type of equipment. Furthermore, this process allows for an in-depth analysis of individual equipment failure trends and identifies key root causes, helping to pinpoint recurring patterns. Armed with this insight, teams can prioritize their response strategies effectively. Finally, the compiled and analyzed failure information should be shared back with the planning department, enabling them to schedule preventive maintenance or implement improvement measures. This data can also serve as a valuable reference for adjusting the intervals, content, and standards of routine inspections. (7) Implement different countermeasures based on the nature of the failure, the type of fault, and the specific characteristics of the equipment. For newly acquired equipment, strengthen management during the initial phase of use—carefully monitor and document the equipment’s precision, performance, and any emerging defects from the outset. During operation, emphasize routine maintenance, regular patrol inspections, and periodic checks to promptly identify early warning signs and take appropriate adjustment or troubleshooting actions. For critical equipment, conduct condition monitoring and diagnostics. Establish a flexible and responsive maintenance team equipped with advanced technical expertise, employing rapid repair techniques such as component-by-component fixes or group-based replacements. Ensure timely availability of high-quality spare parts, leverage production downtime for equipment overhauls, and apply measures like retrofitting or replacing components when wear patterns have been thoroughly understood. (8) Carry out routine maintenance tasks effectively to control equipment failures. Utilize status information and early warning signs of potential issues gathered during daily rounds by regional maintenance workers, as well as scheduled equipment condition checks, along with relevant records and analysis data. Based on the specific characteristics of each type of equipment and the general defects already identified, the workshop’s equipment mechanic (technician) or maintenance team leader should promptly schedule routine repairs—ideally during production downtime or weekend slots—to proactively address problems before they escalate, thereby minimizing breakdowns. For certain failure indicators or hidden risks that exceed the scope of routine maintenance, these should be reported back to the planning department for scheduling dedicated, planned maintenance activities instead. (9) Establish a rational fault information management flowchart.

Manufacturers typically do not provide complete assembly drawings for components, subassemblies, and the finished machine. Whenever possible, you should gather these drawings or, during equipment maintenance, create detailed sketches of critical components or the entire machine. (3) Spare parts, wear-and-tear component drawings and bills of materials, along with a list of purchased components. (4) Other content. For power equipment, as-built drawings, piping or wiring network diagrams, and similar documents should also be provided. 3) Maintenance Technical Preparation Work Technical preparation work before equipment maintenance is also an important foundational task, primarily involving a pre-maintenance technical condition assessment and the preparation of maintenance-related technical documents. 2. Standardization of Maintenance Procedures To ensure repair quality, enhance repair efficiency, and prevent resource waste, it is necessary to standardize the various procedural practices involved in the repair process. 1) Maintenance Procedures (1) Typical maintenance procedures. A typical maintenance procedure refers to the repair process developed for common wear-and-tear scenarios affecting parts of a specific equipment type and structural design—parts that are identical across such equipment. While these procedures offer broad guidance, they often lack specificity when applied to a particular piece of equipment. (2) Dedicated maintenance procedures. Dedicated maintenance procedures refer to processes specifically developed by a company for a particular model of equipment, tailored to address its actual wear-and-tear conditions. Moreover, the maintenance procedure prepared for a specific repair of this equipment still holds significant reference value for future repairs and should be adjusted and updated as needed, based on actual wear conditions and technological advancements.
(1) Basis for preparing the maintenance plan. ① The technical condition of equipment refers to its actual state in terms of technical performance, load capacity, transmission mechanisms, and operational safety. Key indicators reflecting the quality of a company’s equipment—including equipment integrity rate, failure downtime rate, and the extent to which equipment impacts balanced production—provide a clear picture of the overall technical condition. Information on equipment’s technical status is primarily gathered through comprehensive surveys and assessments of equipment conditions, as well as from original documentation. Typically, companies conduct equipment surveys during the third quarter of each year, with the main objective of identifying existing issues, proposing corrective measures, and completing the Equipment Technical Condition Survey Form, which then serves as the foundation for developing maintenance plans. Original records include daily inspections, routine checks, condition-monitoring logs, repair histories, and other primary documents, along with comprehensive analytical data. Equipment showing signs of deteriorating technical conditions and requiring maintenance should be included as items in the annual maintenance plan application. ② Requirements for equipment based on production processes and product quality. If the actual technical condition of the equipment fails to meet the process and quality standards for the product, the process department will submit a request to schedule planned maintenance.

Spare parts and wear-and-tear component drawings, bills of materials, and lists of purchased components are also essential. For power equipment, as-built drawings, piping or wiring network diagrams, and similar documents must be provided to ensure comprehensive maintenance preparation.

For power equipment, as-built drawings, piping or wiring network diagrams, and similar documents should also be provided. 3) Maintenance Technical Preparation Work Technical preparation work before equipment maintenance is also an important foundational task, primarily involving a pre-maintenance technical condition assessment and the preparation of maintenance-related technical documents. 2. Standardization of Maintenance Procedures To ensure repair quality, enhance repair efficiency, and prevent resource waste, it is necessary to standardize the various procedural practices involved in the repair process. 1) Maintenance Procedures (1) Typical maintenance procedures. A typical maintenance procedure refers to the repair process developed for common wear-and-tear scenarios affecting parts of a specific equipment type and structural design—parts that are identical across such equipment. While these procedures offer broad guidance, they often lack specificity when applied to a particular piece of equipment. (2) Dedicated maintenance procedures. Dedicated maintenance procedures refer to processes specifically developed by a company for a particular model of equipment, tailored to address its actual wear-and-tear conditions. Moreover, the maintenance procedure prepared for a specific repair of this equipment still holds significant reference value for future repairs and should be adjusted and updated as needed, based on actual wear conditions and technological advancements.
Management of Maintenance Technical Documentation Equipment maintenance technical documentation primarily comes from the technical materials provided as part of the equipment purchase; materials acquired during use from equipment manufacturers, relevant organizations, scientific bookstores, and more; as well as documents designed, surveyed, and compiled in-house. Management is as described below. (1) Specification standards, including relevant international standards, national standards, departmentally issued standards, as well as applicable laws and regulations. (2) Drawing materials, including instruction manuals for mechanical power equipment within the company, partial equipment manufacturing drawings, maintenance and assembly diagrams, spare parts catalogues, and related technical documentation. (3) Layout Diagram of Power Station Equipment and Power Pipeline Network Diagram. (4) Process documentation, including maintenance procedures, parts repair processes, critical component manufacturing techniques, and drawings for specialized tools and fixtures, etc. (5) Maintenance Quality Standards and Equipment Testing Procedures. (6) General technical documents, including equipment manuals, research reports, experimental data, calculation notes, cost analyses, claim reports, standard technical materials, patent documents, and relevant literature, among others. (7) Samples and books, including domestic and international samples, books, periodicals, electronic publications, CDs, floppy disks, photographs, and slides, among others. 2) Management Program Maintenance technical documentation is primarily intended for use within the equipment management system and should generally be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room. The management process should encompass the entire lifecycle of the materials—covering collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution. Effective management of technical documentation requires prioritization: key equipment manuals, along with relevant assembly drawings, electrical schematics, and other critical documents, should be clearly marked for enhanced oversight. Importantly, these priority documents are typically not available for external loan. To facilitate compilation and retrieval, it is necessary to establish a coded indexing system for the data and implement computer-based management. The equipment maintenance manual serves as a comprehensive collection of specialized technical documentation for equipment repair, providing maintenance personnel with essential resources for troubleshooting, diagnosing faults, developing repair strategies, and even manufacturing spare parts when needed. The equipment maintenance manuals are compiled separately for each equipment model, and the manuals should include the following content. (1) Features and Feature Diagrams. The features and feature diagrams include an outline diagram, lifting diagram, installation foundation drawing, and Chapter 1—Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance.

user_input: What are the differences between typical and dedicated maintenance procedures?
reference_contexts: ['Typical maintenance procedures. A typical maintenance procedure refers to the repair process developed for common wear-and-tear scenarios affecting parts of a specific equipment type and structural design鈥攑arts that are identical across such equipment. While these procedures offer broad guidance, they often lack specificity when applied to a particular piece of equipment.', 'Dedicated maintenance procedures. Dedicated maintenance procedures refer to processes specifically developed by a company for a particular model of equipment, tailored to address its actual wear-and-tear conditions. Moreover, the maintenance procedure prepared for a specific repair of this equipment still holds significant reference value for future repairs and should be adjusted and updated as needed, based on actual wear conditions and technological advancements.']
reference: Typical maintenance procedures are generalized repair processes designed for common wear-and-tear scenarios in parts that are identical across a specific equipment type and structural design. They provide broad guidance but often lack specificity for individual equipment instances. In contrast, dedicated maintenance procedures are specifically developed by a company for a particular model of equipment, tailored to its actual wear-and-tear conditions. These procedures are more precise and relevant, and they retain significant reference value for future repairs, allowing for adjustments and updates based on actual wear conditions and technological advancements to ensure ongoing effectiveness and efficiency.
answer: Typical maintenance procedures are developed for common wear-and-tear scenarios on a specific equipment type and offer broad guidance but lack specificity, while dedicated maintenance procedures are specifically developed for a particular model of equipment and are tailored to its actual wear-and-tear conditions.

(5) Inspect the machine tool guideways, lead screws, and racks for wear, and measure the extent of the wear. (6) Inspect the hydraulic, pneumatic, and lubrication systems: Verify that movements are accurate, check for any component damage or leaks, and if leaks are present, identify the cause. Preparing overhaul technical documentation By conducting a pre-inspection to assess the equipment's condition and determine whether repairs or component replacements are necessary, we can then proceed to analyze, develop a repair plan, and prepare the corresponding technical documentation. These technical documents serve as the foundation for major equipment overhauls. Commonly used technical documents for equipment overhauls include the following types: (1) Prepare the equipment maintenance technical specification. The equipment maintenance technical specification should include the following content. ① The technical condition of the equipment before major overhaul. ② Key maintenance activities include detailing the disassembly, cleaning, and inspection of components to identify parts that require repair or replacement; briefly outlining the r epair methods for basic and critical components; specifying mechanisms that must be thoroughly inspected and adjusted, as well as other areas requiring attention; and highlighting  specific parts and aspects that can be improved during the overhaul process. ③ Maintenance quality requirements: Specify the names and numbers of the general technical standards ap plicable to each quality inspection during major equipment overhauls, and attach the content of any specialized technical standards to the back of the task specification. (2) Prepa ring Maintenance Procedures. The maintenance procedures for mechanical equipment are the technical documents that must be carefully followed and implemented during major overhauls.  When developing overhaul procedures, it’s essential to consider the actual conditions, ensuring both technical feasibility and economic viability. Mechanical equipment overhaul pr ocedures can be categorized into two types: standard maintenance procedures and specialized maintenance procedures. The overhaul procedures for mechanical equipment typically inclu de the following elements. ① Disassembly procedures and methods for the complete machine and its components, as well as the data to be monitored and precautions to observe during t he disassembly process.

user_input: What are the key points to consider during the disassembly process in mechanical equipment repair?
reference_contexts: ['When repairing mechanical equipment, the first step is to partially disassemble and take it apart. However, each time a machine is disassembled, its performance and precision inevitably suffer some degree of damage. Improper disassembly of precision equipment can even lead to complete鎶ュ簾 of the device.', 'Safety comes first during disassembly. Before starting, ensure the power supply is disconnected, remove any hazardous materials鈥攕uch as toxic or flammable substances鈥攆rom both inside and outside the machinery and equipment, set up reliable supports, and select appropriate lifting equipment and tools.', 'Do not disassemble components that are unnecessary or prohibited. For parts with tight fits, establish a proper disassembly method and use appropriate tools to avoid damaging critical surfaces.']
reference: During the disassembly process in mechanical equipment repair, several key points must be strictly followed to prevent damage and ensure safety. First, safety is paramount: disconnect the power supply, remove hazardous materials (toxic or flammable substances) from inside and outside the equipment, set up reliable supports, and use appropriate lifting equipment and tools. Second, avoid disassembling unnecessary or prohibited components; for tightly fitted parts, establish a proper disassembly method with suitable tools to prevent damage to critical surfaces. Third, if the machine structure is complex and drawings are incomplete, document details and sketch preliminary diagrams during disassembly to eventually create a complete assembly drawing. This careful approach minimizes performance and precision degradation, which is inevitable with each disassembly, and prevents complete鎶ュ簾 (scrapping) of precision equipment due to improper handling.
answer: The key points to consider during the disassembly process in mechanical equipment repair are that safety comes first, disassembly serves assembly, and preparations include selecting and cleaning the site and draining the oil, while general principles include selecting a logical sequence, rational disassembly to avoid unnecessary work, and using tools correctly, and precautions include verifying or marking parts, storing parts by category, and protecting machined surfaces.

Context:  
2) Key Points for Process Specification Work (1) Disassembly process. When repairing mechanical equipment, the first step is to partially disassemble and take it apart. However, each time a machine is disassembled, its perfor mance and precision inevitably suffer some degree of damage. Improper disassembly of precision equipment can even lead to complete报废 of the device. Therefore, it is crucial to appr oach this process with utmost care and expertise. Key and precision equipment should have dismantling process specifications developed. The general principles and precautions for d isassembly will be introduced in Chapter 2 and can serve as a reference when developing the disassembly process. Additionally, please keep the following points in mind. ① Safety co mes first during disassembly. Before starting, ensure the power supply is disconnected, remove any hazardous materials—such as toxic or flammable substances—from both inside and ou tside the machinery and equipment, set up reliable supports, and select appropriate lifting equipment and tools. ② Disassembly for service and maintenance. Do not disassemble compo nents that are unnecessary or prohibited. For parts with tight fits, establish a proper disassembly method and use appropriate tools to avoid damaging critical surfaces. ③ Disassem bly serves assembly. When the machine structure is complex and the drawing documentation is incomplete, disassemble while simultaneously documenting details and sketching prelimina ry diagrams, ultimately compiling a complete assembly drawing. (2) Parts cleaning process. The cleaning process should include details such as the cleaning method, cleaning procedu re, type or formulation of the cleaning agent, cleaning parameters, cleaning quality, and important precautions during cleaning. (3) Repair Processes for Typical Components. In equ ipment maintenance, certain critical parts—such as machine beds, housings, worktables, and large rotating components—often require restoration. To ensure effective repairs and enha nce overall efficiency, it’s essential to select the appropriate repair solution and develop a detailed maintenance process procedure. These procedures are typically documented in  the form of process cards, which provide more specifics than standard manufacturing process cards yet remain simpler than operation-specific cards. A typical maintenance process ca rd usually includes the following information: ① Part name, drawing number, material and properties, part defect indication diagram, and explanations regarding the defects.
1.4.3 General Principles and Requirements for Mechanical Equipment Disassembly Any piece of machine ry is assembled from numerous components. When machinery requires maintenance, it must first be disassembled so that faulty parts can be repaired or replaced. The primary purpose o f dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance wor kload. Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, it’s essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment. This way,  the dismantling can proceed methodically—following a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines. Preparations Before Disassembly (1) Selection and Cleanup of the Disassembly Site. Before disassembly, choose an appropriate work area—avoid locations prone to windblown sand or dust. The workspace should be kept free from frequent unauthorized access by unrelated personnel to prevent unnecessary disruptions or accidents. Additionally, ensure that the ground in the work area remains clean, free from dirt, oil, or other contaminants. Prior to entering the disassembly site, all machinery must undergo an external cleaning process to guarantee that the disassembly procedure does not compromise the equipment’s precision. (2) Protective Measures: Before cleaning the exterior of mechanical equipment, electrical devices should be either removed or properly protected to prevent moisture damage. Additionally, parts prone to oxidation and rust should promptly undergo appropriate protective and maintenance measures. (3) Draining the oil before disassembly. Whenever possible, drain the lubricating oil from the machinery while it’s still hot prior to disassembly, ensuring smoother and more efficient removal work. (4) Understand the structure, performance, and operating principles of mechanical equipment. To avoid unnecessary disassembly and ensure the smooth progress of maintenance work, thoroughly assess all aspects of the machinery before dismantling. Familiarize yourself with the structural features of each component, the transmission system, as well as the specific design characteristics and interrelationships of individual parts. Clearly identify their intended functions and how they interact with one another, enabling you to plan the disassembly process logically and select the appropriate tools or equipment for the job. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial
General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations.

user_input: What information is typically included in a maintenance process card for equipment repair?
reference_contexts: ['These procedures are typically documented in the form of process cards, which provide more specifics than standard manufacturing process cards yet remain simpler than operation-specific cards.', 'A typical maintenance process card usually includes the following information: 鈶?Part name, drawing number, material and properties, part defect indication diagram, and explanations regarding the defects.']
reference: A maintenance process card for equipment repair typically includes detailed information to guide effective repairs. It contains the part name, drawing number, material and properties of the component, a part defect indication diagram, and explanations regarding the defects. These cards are more specific than standard manufacturing process cards but simpler than operation-specific cards, ensuring clarity and efficiency in the repair process while documenting essential details for restoration work.
answer: A maintenance process card typically includes material details, the first step of disassembling the equipment, specific technical procedures such as using an error-compensation method for disassembling a gear pair, and steps like removing axially positioned parts.

Maintenance-Free Design Maintenance-free design is the ideal goal for equipment maintenance—it refers to implementing improvement measures during the design phase of new machinery and electrical equipment to address common failures encountered during maintenance, aiming to minimize maintenance efforts or even eliminate the need for repairs altogether. 1.2.2 Maintenance Method Selection The purpose of maintenance is to ensure the reliable operation of equipment—specifically, to guarantee the dependable fulfillment of its intended use—and, at the same time, minimize maintenance costs. Therefore, the fundamental requirements for maintenance decisions are: ① Reliability must not fall below the permissible minimum value [R], meaning that ()[] R ≥ R(t); ② Maintenance costs (KI) must be kept as low as possible—or, alternatively, must not exceed a predetermined maintenance cost limit (KImin), i.e., K ≤ KImin. To optimize maintenance decisions, the first step should be to choose an appropriate maintenance approach. The six maintenance methods mentioned above each have a specific scope of applicability; however, their effectiveness can vary depending on how appropriately they are applied. To maximize equipment efficiency, minimize downtime-related losses, and reduce maintenance costs, it’s essential to select the most suitable approach based on the characteristics of mechatronic systems and the conditions under which they are used. Looking ahead, the trend in maintenance practices is shifting from routine preventive maintenance toward planned, periodic inspections—and then, based on inspection findings, scheduling timely condition-based repairs. As the technological sophistication of factory equipment continues to rise, with increasingly complex system designs and broader adoption of mechatronic solutions, production activities are becoming more reliant on equipment performance and reliability. Consequently, the traditional static approach to maintenance management is evolving into a more dynamic model, gradually moving toward advanced strategies such as reliability-centered maintenance and quality-focused repair practices. Mechatronic equipment comes in a wide variety of types and is widely applied, making it essential to select one or a combination of maintenance methods tailored to the specific situation. When choosing a maintenance approach for mechatronic systems, reliability typically becomes the primary focus. For critical components, implementing condition-based monitoring allows for timely preventive measures. Meanwhile, for equipment at quality control points, it’s crucial to closely track changes in product quality during the manufacturing process and promptly address any detected anomalies through quality repairs. Additionally, it’s important to equip teams with personnel who are well-versed in microelectronics technology, providing them with supervision and guidance while fostering the development of skilled, integrated mechatronics technicians. Regular inspections and logical fault analysis should be conducted on CNC and other mechatronic systems, and any failed components identified must be promptly replaced and properly adjusted to ensure optimal performance. 1.2.3 Maintenance System Maintenance work is not only a technical task but also a managerial one. A maintenance system refers to a set of guidelines established under specific maintenance theories and principles, encompassing elements such as maintenance plans, categories, methods, timing, scope, levels, organizational structures, and performance evaluation metrics. Implementing a rational maintenance system helps optimize the allocation of human, material, and financial resources, enabling timely preparation before maintenance tasks, ensuring repairs are carried out appropriately, meeting operational requirements, enhancing the technical condition, reliability, and service life of机电 equipment, reducing downtime, and minimizing maintenance costs and production losses due to equipment shutdowns. Meanwhile, maintenance systems are continuously evolving and improving—currently, the main approaches include the following: Planned Preventive Maintenance System It is based on a thorough understanding of the wear and failure patterns of mechanical and electrical equipment, applying the principle of pre vention being better than cure—and addressing potential issues before they escalate—by systematically organizing maintenance and repairs according to the rate of wear and expected  service life of each component. This approach helps prevent premature wear, compensates for natural degradation, minimizes or avoids failures altogether, extends equipment lifespan , and ultimately saves time spent on repairs, thereby enhancing operational efficiency and boosting economic returns. The practical implementation of planned preventive maintenance  can be summarized as  "regular inspections, timely upkeep, and scheduled repairs, " making it particularly suitable for Chapter 1 of this guide: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment. 11 Macro-level management. I mplementing a planned preventive maintenance system requires the following conditions: ① Determining the maintenance intervals for assemblies and key components through statistical analysis, measurements, and experimental studies, and rationally categorizing mainten ance tasks;
2) Maintenance Process Stage Once the maintenance process begins, the first step is to disassemble the equipment—following a sequence and approach that reverses the original assembly order, adhering to the principle of "top-down and outside-in." This systematic method carefully releases the components from their interlocking and fixed positions within the machine. After removal, each part should undergo a secondary pre-inspection. Based on the findings from this second check, any additional repair parts required will be identified. Furthermore, the availability of replacement and repaired components, along with their current status, will help establish a rough schedule for the maintenance tasks. This ensures that the repair work progresses methodically and according to plan, preventing delays caused by poor coordination in organizational efforts. The precision and performance achievable during equipment maintenance depend on factors such as the technical expertise available for repair work, the number of major overhauls the equipment has undergone, and its pre-repair technical condition. Generally speaking, for machinery undergoing its first major overhaul, both its precision and performance should ideally meet the original factory standards. However, after two or more major overhauls, the equipment’s post-repair precision and performance typically fall short of those of a new unit. That said, if the equipment was in relatively good technical condition prior to the last overhaul, it will likely be easier to restore its quality closer to the original factory standards this time around. Conversely, if the previous overhaul left the equipment in suboptimal condition, it may create significant challenges for the next major repair—and in some cases, the resulting quality might even fail to meet the original factory standards, making further repairs impractical altogether. The assembly of the complete equipment is carried out according to acceptance criteria. During assembly, appropriate reference surfaces should be selected for accurate mechanical and electrical system fault diagnosis and maintenance case studies.
Disassembly of the Gear Pair To improve the precision of the transmission chain, the gear pair with a transmission ratio of 1 is assembled using an error-compensation method: specifically, the tooth space at the point of maximum radial runout on one external gear is engaged with the tooth space at the point of minimum radial runout on the other gear. To prevent errors introduced during reassembly from remaining unresolved, a mark is made at the mating points of the two gears during disassembly, ensuring that the original precision can be restored during reassembly. 1.5.1 The Significance of Equipment Management Strengthening equipment management and ensuring proper maintenance will keep machinery consistently in excellent condition, thereby extending its lifespan. This not only plays a critical role in boosting production volume and variety, enhancing labor productivity, reducing consumption, lowering costs, and safeguarding worker safety—but also significantly contributes to upgrading the company’s overall production technology, accelerating industrial growth, and protecting productive capacity. Equipment management is an extremely important task—only by effectively managing equipment can organizations achieve optimal economic results with minimal human, financial, and material resources. This, in turn, allows for the full realization of equipment potential, enabling businesses to better meet production goals. Especially in modern manufacturing, prioritizing sound equipment management is a fundamental principle that must be followed. Equipment maintenance management is an important component of enterprise management. Its primary tasks include: maximizing Effectively collecting and utilizing equipment information resources allows for the strategic management of manpower, materials, funds, equipment, and technology within the maintenance system, ensuring that maintenance operations achieve optimal quality and maximum efficiency. The key components of maintenance management include maintenance information management, maintenance planning, maintenance technology, process and quality control, spare parts management, and maintenance economic management. In modern enterprises, management is inseparable from technology, while the effective application of engineering technologies relies on sound management practices. Equipment engineering technicians, who are well-versed in equipment maintenance management principles and methods, should seamlessly integrate technical expertise with managerial skills. To this end, this section will outline the key aspects, methodologies, and practical applications of equipment maintenance management. 1.5.2 Information Management for Equipment Maintenance In corporate equipment maintenance activities, it is often necessary to make various technical and economic decisions, and the basis for these decisions is information. Breath. Without a systematic and reliable information system, effective management becomes difficult to implement. Therefore, the task of equipment maintenance information management is to establish a comprehensive information system that collects, stores, and organizes all types of equipment-related data, while also enabling data processing, output, and feedback—ultimately supporting informed economic and technical decision-making for equipment management. 1. Classification of Equipment Maintenance Information Equipment maintenance information can be complex, but it can generally be categorized using the following methods. 1) Categorized by equipment in the early versus later stages This classification method divides equipment information into two major systems—early-stage and later-stage—and further breaks them down into numerous subsystems. Within these subsystems, various types of equipment are grouped, ultimately leading to a detailed breakdown for each individual device. The approach is straightforward and clear, making it easy to process, organize, and access the information. 2) Categorized by equipment management objectives and performance indicators
Enterprise authorities, investors, and business operators all need to understand and monitor key indicators, such as output value per ten thousand yuan. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 45 Repair costs, equipment integrity rate, maintenance expenses per 10,000 yuan of equipment value, and more. To facilitate statistical analysis, equipment information can be categorized into five main types: investment planning data, asset and spare parts information, technical condition data, maintenance schedule details, and personnel information. Each category can further be broken down into numerous sub-items and specific evaluation metrics, making it easier to conduct comprehensive classification-based analysis. 3) Categorized from a maintenance perspective Equipment information can be categorized into equipment status information, equipment maintenance information, equipment failure or accident information, repair work information, repair material information, repair personnel information, repair cost information, and related information, among others. 2. Functions of the Computer Repair Information System In modern enterprises, a computer maintenance information system can either serve as a subsystem within the company's management system or operate as an independent system altogether. The functionality of a computer maintenance information system is closely tied to the configuration of both the hardware and software components of computers. Currently, several versatile equipment management software solutions have already been integrated into the system software. The computer maintenance information system offers the following key functions in equipment repair and management: 1) Process Control Function The process control function can be used to monitor equipment operating conditions and detect key performance parameters such as vibration, noise, ultrasound, temperature rise, cooling status, lubrication condition, and environmental factors, providing critical information to guide maintenance activities. 2) Engineering Design and Calculation Functionality The engineering design and calculation function enables mechanical analysis and computations for various equipment and maintenance tooling, as well as supports computer-aided design and drafting, along with diverse optimization processes. 3) Information Processing Function The information processing function handles various types of data in maintenance management, covering the following 5 aspects: (1) Equipment Ledger Management. Store the original data and documentation for all company equipment in a computer system, allowing you to generate workshop equipment ledgers and equipment lists by model—in various formats—as needed. (2) Equipment classification, sorting, querying, and retrieval. Categorize and sort equipment supply information available in the market, storing it in the system to provide insights when companies update or add new equipment. (3) Equipment Maintenance Planning Management. When determining equipment maintenance plans, you can refer to equipment records, maintenance information, and diagnostic data stored in the computer system, and, based on actual conditions, use the computer to develop annual, quarterly, and monthly equipment maintenance schedules. (4) Maintenance Spare Parts Management. By entering the enterprise equipment maintenance spare parts’ demand information, inventory details, and inbound/outbound records into the computer system, users can instantly access real-time inventory status and generate statistical reports. Additionally, an alert notification can be automatically triggered when the current stock level drops below the predefined warning threshold. (5) Other functions. The computer system can also provide service functionalities to the maintenance system, including personnel management, financial management, and technical and process management. 1.5.3 Equipment Maintenance Plan Management The enterprise's equipment management department conducts planned, appropriately scaled maintenance on its equipment. When carrying out specific maintenance tasks, it’s also essential to organize resources effectively to ensure the progress, quality, and efficiency of the repairs. This planning and organizational process is known as Maintenance Planning Management. It comprises two key components: first, a macro-level maintenance plan (including annual, quarterly, and monthly schedules); and second, a detailed tutorial on micro-level mechanical and electrical system fault diagnosis and repair cases. 46 The work plan refers to a specific operational process, such as a major overhaul schedule for a machine, and is characterized by its closer relationship to process technology. Standard Workload for Equipment Maintenance The equipment maintenance work quotas serve as the basis for developing equipment maintenance plans and organizing repair operations. Accurately establishing these maintenance quotas enhances the scientific rigor and predictive capability of maintenance planning, facilitates thorough preparation before repairs begin, and ensures that maintenance activities are conducted in a more cost-effective and rational manner. Before drafting mechanical and electrical equipment maintenance plans, it is essential to first define various maintenance quotas. The main equipment maintenance quotas include: equipment maintenance complexity factor, maintenance labor-hour quota, maintenance downtime quota, maintenance cycle and interval period, and maintenance cost quota. 1) Equipment Maintenance Complexity Factor The equipment maintenance complexity factor, also known as the maintenance complexity unit or simply the maintenance unit, is a hypothetical measure used to assess the intricacy of equipment repair tasks, determine the associated workload, and establish standard benchmarks for various metrics. This assumed unit represents the maintenance effort required for a specific type of machinery, with its value determined by factors such as the equipment's structural design, dimensions, size, and precision levels. In general, the more complex the equipment's structure, the larger its physical dimensions, and the higher the machining accuracy demanded, the greater its maintenance complexity factor will be. For instance, in metal-cutting machine tools, the C620 lathe—typically featuring a maximum workpiece diameter of 400 mm and a maximum workpiece length of 1,000 mm—is often used as the benchmark machine. Its maintenance complexity factor is standardized at 10. As for electrical equipment, the focus shifts to… A protected cage-type synchronous motor with a rated power of 0.6 kW is standard equipment, and its maintenance complexity factor is specified as 1. For other machinery and equipment, the maintenance complexity factor can be determined by comparing their structure, size, precision, and other characteristics to those of the standard unit. Once a labor quota for one maintenance unit (represented by "R") has been established, the maintenance workload for any other type of machine can be calculated based on this unit. Additionally, maintenance downtime quotas and cost estimates can also be derived using the maintenance unit as a benchmark. The enterprise's supervisory authority has determined the maintenance complexity factors for various types of equipment and machine tools (establishing separate complexity factors for mechanical and electrical systems), and formulated these into company standards for use during equipment maintenance activities.

user_input: What are the main contents of repair and assembly process specifications?
reference_contexts: ['The main contents of the repair and assembly process specifications include preparation for repair and assembly, the sequence for assembling components during repair and overall assembly, repair and assembly methods, analysis of repair dimension chains, adjustment and compensation techniques for ensuring repair assembly accuracy, as well as inspection methods.', 'Additionally, the procedures cover inspection and test runs after repair and assembly.']
reference: The repair and assembly process specifications comprehensively cover several key areas. They begin with preparation for repair and assembly, detailing the necessary preliminary steps. They then specify the sequence for assembling components during both repair operations and overall assembly processes. The specifications include detailed repair and assembly methods, along with analysis of repair dimension chains to ensure proper fit and function. Adjustment and compensation techniques are provided to guarantee repair assembly accuracy. Inspection methods are outlined to verify quality at various stages. Finally, the procedures encompass inspection and test runs conducted after the repair and assembly is complete to ensure everything functions correctly before returning the equipment to service.
answer: The main contents of repair and assembly process specifications include preparation for repair and assembly, the sequence for assembling components during repair and overall assembly, repair and assembly methods, analysis of repair dimension chains, adjustment and compensation techniques for ensuring repair assembly accuracy, as well as inspection methods, and additionally cover inspection and test runs after repair and assembly.

When accepting the repair of mechanical equipment, reference can be made to general technical specifications for major equipment repairs established and issued by national and ministerial authorities, such as the General Technical Specifications for Major Repairs of Metal Cutting Machine Tools and the General Technical Specifications for Major Repairs of Forging and Pressing Equipment. Industries and enterprises may also develop their own specialized quality standards for major equipment repairs based on these relevant general technical guidelines. A Practical Guide to Fault Diagnosis and Repair Cases in Mechatronic Systems 30
2) Key Points for Process Specification Work (1) Disassembly process. When repairing mechanical equipment, the first step is to partially disassemble and take it apart. However, each time a machine is disassembled, its performance and precision inevitably suffer some degree of damage. Improper disassembly of precision equipment can even lead to complete报废 of the device. Therefore, it is crucial to approach this process with utmost care and expertise. Key and precision equipment should have dismantling process specifications developed. The general principles and precautions for disassembly will be introduced in Chapter 2 and can serve as a reference when developing the disassembly process. Additionally, please keep the following points in mind. ① Safety comes first during disassembly. Before starting, ensure the power supply is disconnected, remove any hazardous materials—such as toxic or flammable substances—from both inside and outside the machinery and equipment, set up reliable supports, and select appropriate lifting equipment and tools. ② Disassembly for service and maintenance. Do not disassemble components that are unnecessary or prohibited. For parts with tight fits, establish a proper disassembly method and use appropriate tools to avoid damaging critical surfaces. ③ Disassembly serves assembly. When the machine structure is complex and the drawing documentation is incomplete, disassemble while simultaneously documenting details and sketching preliminary diagrams, ultimately compiling a complete assembly drawing. (2) Parts cleaning process. The cleaning process should include details such as the cleaning method, cleaning procedure, type or formulation of the cleaning agent, cleaning parameters, cleaning quality, and important precautions during cleaning. (3) Repair Processes for Typical Components. In equipment maintenance, certain critical parts—such as machine beds, housings, worktables, and large rotating components—often require restoration. To ensure effective repairs and enhance overall efficiency, it’s essential to select the appropriate repair solution and develop a detailed maintenance process procedure. These procedures are typically documented in the form of process cards, which provide more specifics than standard manufacturing process cards yet remain simpler than operation-specific cards. A typical maintenance process card usually includes the following information: ① Part name, drawing number, material and properties, part defect indication diagram, and explanations regarding the defects.
Management of Maintenance Technical Documentation Equipment maintenance technical documentation primarily comes from the technical materials provided as part of the equipment purchase; materials acquired during use from equipment manufacturers, relevant organizations, scientific bookstores, and more; as well as documents designed, surveyed, and compiled in-house. Management is as described below. (1) Specification standards, including relevant international standards, national standards, departmentally issued standards, as well as applicable laws and regulations. (2) Drawing materials, including instruction manuals for mechanical power equipment within the company, partial equipment manufacturing drawings, maintenance and assembly diagrams, spare parts catalogues, and related technical documentation. (3) Layout Diagram of Power Station Equipment and Power Pipeline Network Diagram. (4) Process documentation, including maintenance procedures, parts repair processes, critical component manufacturing techniques, and drawings for specialized tools and fixtures, etc. (5) Maintenance Quality Standards and Equipment Testing Procedures. (6) General technical files, including equipment manuals, research reports, experimental data, calculation notes, cost analyses, claim reports, standard technical materials, patent documents, and relevant literature, among others. (7) Samples and books, including domestic and international samples, books, periodicals, electronic publications, CDs, floppy disks, photographs, and slides, among others. 2) Management Program Maintenance technical documentation is primarily intended for use within the equipment management system and should generally be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room. The management process should encompass the entire lifecycle of the materials—covering collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution. Effective management of technical documentation requires prioritization: key equipment manuals, along with relevant assembly drawings, electrical schematics, and other critical documents, should be clearly marked for enhanced oversight. Importantly, these priority documents are typically not available for external loan. To facilitate compilation and retrieval, it is necessary to establish a coded indexing system for the data and implement computer-based management. The equipment maintenance manual serves as a comprehensive collection of specialized technical documentation for equipment repair, providing maintenance personnel with essential resources for troubleshooting, diagnosing faults, developing repair strategies, and even manufacturing spare parts when needed. The equipment maintenance manuals are compiled separately for each equipment model, and the manuals should include the following content. (1) Features and Feature Diagrams. The features and feature diagrams include an outline diagram, lifting diagram, installation foundation drawing, and Chapter 1—Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. 51
② Repair procedures and work steps, including operational guidelines for each step and the corresponding technical requirements to be achieved.
