Detailed and standardized repair processes and adjustment methods should also be established for the maintenance of critical, precision components, ensuring the quality of repairs. (4) Repair and Assembly Processes. The main contents of the repair and assembly process specifications include preparation for repair and assembly, the sequence for assembling components during repair and overall assembly, repair and assembly methods, analysis of repair dimension chains, adjustment and compensation techniques for ensuring repair assembly accuracy, as well as inspection methods. Additionally, the procedures cover inspection and test runs after repair and assembly. (5) Employ advanced maintenance techniques. In equipment repair, actively learn cutting-edge maintenance processes and technologies from both domestic and international sources. Based on the actual conditions of your enterprise, adopt relatively mature new processes and materials to gradually replace outdated techniques. Develop systems and measures for learning, researching, testing, and implementing advanced maintenance technologies, continuously enhancing the company's equipment repair expertise and process capabilities. 3. Quality Management of Equipment Maintenance To ensure the quality of equipment maintenance, quality management should be implemented for equipment repairs. 1) The content of equipment maintenance and quality management (1) Establish quality standards for equipment maintenance. (2) Develop equipment maintenance procedures. (3) Inspection and evaluation of equipment maintenance quality. (4) Strengthen quality management during the maintenance process. Establish quality control points for critical procedures and encourage participation in grassroots quality management team activities, ensuring thorough implementation of the maintenance process plan. (5) Conduct post-repair customer service and quality feedback activities. (6) Strengthen technical training efforts to enhance both technical and managerial skills. 2) Inspection of Equipment Repair Quality Enterprises should establish organizations and assign personnel responsible for inspecting and evaluating the quality of equipment maintenance. The main aspects of equipment maintenance quality inspection include: ① incoming inspection of purchased spare parts and materials; ② process quality control and final inspection of self-made spare parts and repaired components; ③ quality checks on components and assemblies during the equipment repair process; ④ visual inspection, trial runs, accuracy assessments, and performance tests conducted after repairs are completed. 3) Quality Assurance System for Equipment Maintenance The planning, management, spare parts handling, production oversight, technical administration, financial control, and supply of maintenance materials for equipment repair form an integrated whole. By effectively organizing and coordinating these various aspects of management, we can establish robust systems—complete with management regulations, operational standards, workflow processes, and performance evaluation methods—ultimately creating a comprehensive quality assurance system for equipment maintenance. This ensures high-quality repairs while continuously enhancing our overall maintenance expertise. 1.5.5 Spare Parts Management The process by which enterprises, based on economic and practical principles, determine standard limits for spare parts inventory—such as the quantity of spares to keep in stock, the amount of capital allocated to inventory, and the optimal reserve duration—after gathering relevant data and conducting both calculations and real-world statistical analysis, is known as "reserve quotas. " Effective spare parts inventory control requires establishing these precise reserve quotas. There is a wide variety of maintenance spare parts, and the prices, demand, inventory levels, and stockholding durations of these parts vary significantly. Different inventory control methods should be applied to spare parts of varying types and characteristics, as inventory management must also focus on key priorities. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 53 The ABC analysis categorizes inventory spare parts into 3 classes. (1) Class A Spare Parts. Class A spare parts are a small but critical subset of components, characterized by their high importance, challenging procurement and manufacturing processes, elevated costs, and extended lead times for stockpiling. Although these parts account for approximately 10% of all spare part types, they consume around 80% of the total budget allocated to spare parts. Therefore, Class A items require stringent control measures. Employing inventory theory, carefully determine optimal stock levels and ordering schedules, while maintaining minimal safety stock levels. Additionally, strive to reduce order cycles by increasing the frequency of purchases, thereby accelerating the turnover of spare parts inventory funds. In warehouse management, ensure meticulous recording of all incoming and outgoing spare parts, conduct thorough statistical analysis and calculations of inventory levels, and rigorously implement preventive measures to protect components against corrosion and rust. (2) Category B spare parts. These have a wider variety than Category A spare parts, accounting for about 25% of the total product range, but they require less capital investment—typically around 15% of the total funds allocated to spare parts. Category B spare parts usually maintain a higher safety stock level, though their reserves can be managed more flexibly. Additionally, based on maintenance needs, the ordering cycle can be appropriately extended to reduce the frequency of purchases. (3) Category C spare parts. These account for approximately 65% of all part varieties but represent only about 5% of the total funds allocated to spare parts. For Category C items, inventory levels can be maintained at a slightly higher level based on maintenance needs, and order lead times can be extended accordingly. The focus of spare parts management should be placed on managing Class A and Class B spare parts.
8—Back cover; 9—Reset spring seat; 10—Spring; 11—Stopper Figure 3.11: Structure and Operating Principle of the Solenoid Directional Control Valve – A Case Study Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Mechatronic Systems 110 The disassembly and assembly steps for the solenoid directional control valve are as follows. (1) First, disconnect the machine tool's power supply and remove the electrical components (terminals) from the solenoid directional control valve. (2) Use a Phillips screwdriver to remove the solenoid directional control valve, and then detach the side baffles. (3) After removing the springs from both ends, take out the spool of the solenoid directional control valve. 2) Electro-hydraulic directional control valve The structure and appearance of the electro-hydraulic directional control valve are shown in Figure 3.12. 1. 7—Check valve; 2. 6—Throttle valve; 3. 5—Solenoid; 4—Pilot valve spool; 8—Main valve spool Figure 3.12: Structure and Appearance of the Electro-Hydraulic Directional Control Valve The electro-hydraulic directional control valve is composed of a solenoid-operated directional valve and a hydraulically actuated directional valve combined together. The solenoid valve is responsible for switching the flow direction in the control oil circuits connected to both ends of the hydraulically actuated valve, thereby changing the working position of the valve spool—this component is referred to as the pilot valve. Meanwhile, the hydraulically actuated directional valve controls the reversing of the actuator elements within the system and is thus called the main valve. This operating mechanism allows a small electromagnetic force to manage the high-flow switching of the main oil circuit, making it ideal for hydraulic systems requiring large flow rates. As shown in Figure 3.12(a), the structure of the electro-hydraulic directional valve features a three-position, four-way Y-type solenoid valve at the top as the pilot valve, while the main valve below is a three-position, four-way O-type hydraulically actuated directional valve. The centering method for the spool of the three-position, four-way electro-hydraulic directional valve can be either spring-centered or hydraulically centered. When using spring-centering, the pilot valve should be a Y-type, three-position, four-way solenoid directional valve to ensure that, when the main spool is in the neutral position, the control oil chambers on both sides remain continuously connected to the reservoir, maintaining zero pressure. This setup allows the main spool to stay perfectly centered solely under the influence of the spring force. On the other hand, if hydraulic centering is employed, the pilot valve must be a P-type, three-position, four-way solenoid directional valve to guarantee that, in the neutral position, both control oil chambers of the main spool are always pressurized. Additionally, the electro-hydraulic directional valve offers two options for controlling the oil supply to its control circuit: internal oil supply and external oil supply. In the case of internal oil supply, the control circuit draws pressure oil directly from the main oil line via port P—this is known as internal control. For external oil supply, an independent oil source is typically required, which is referred to as external control. Similarly, the return path for the control circuit can also follow either an internal return (internal leakage) or an external return (external leakage), as illustrated in Figure 3.12(b).

user_input: What are the main failure modes of shaft-type components?
reference_contexts: ['The main failure modes include fatigue fracture due to insufficient fatigue strength, plastic deformation or brittle fracture caused by inadequate static strength, wear, deformation exceeding allowable limits, and vibration, among others.']
reference: The main failure modes of shaft-type components are fatigue fracture resulting from insufficient fatigue strength, plastic deformation or brittle fracture due to inadequate static strength, wear, deformation that exceeds allowable limits, and vibration. These failures can compromise the shaft's ability to support rotating components and transmit motion and torque effectively.
answer: The main failure modes of shaft-type components are fatigue fracture due to insufficient fatigue strength, plastic deformation or brittle fracture caused by inadequate static strength, wear, deformation exceeding allowable limits, and vibration.

Context:  
2.1.1 Main Failure Modes of Shaft-Type Components Shaft-type components are among the most critical parts in mechanical equipment, directly influencing both the operational precision and longevity of machinery. Their primary function is to support rotating components while transmitting motion and torque. Shafts can be categorized into three main types: rotating shafts (e.g., lathe spindles, shafts with pulleys), stationary shafts (e.g., train axle wheels, bicycle axles, or car front axles), and transmission shafts (e.g., leadscrews used on lathes). These shaft components are primarily designed to withstand various loads and efficiently transfer power. Structure Composition of the Shaft As shown in Figure 2.1, the shaft consists of three parts. 1—Shaft; 2, 5—Shaft ends; 3—Journal; 4—Shaft body Figure 2.1: Structural Components of the Shaft Axle head: The part that mates with transmission components or couplings and clutches. Journal: The part that fits into the bearing. Shaft body: The section connecting the shaft head and the shaft journal. Failure Modes of Shaft Components The main failure modes include fatigue fracture due to insufficient fatigue strength, plastic deformation or brittle fracture caused by inadequate static strength, wear, deformation exceeding allowable limits, and vibration, among others. Performance Requirements for Shaft Components The performance requirements for shaft-type components include sufficient tensile strength and stiffness; adequate impact toughness and high fatigue resistance; excellent machinability and hardenability; and, for friction-prone areas at the shaft journals, high hardness and wear resistance. Manufacturing Materials for Shaft Components Manufacturing materials typically include low-carbon steel, medium-carbon steel, or alloy steel, which are either forged or rolled.

answer: The performance requirements for shaft components include sufficient tensile strength and stiffness, adequate impact toughness and high fatigue resistance, excellent machinability and hardenability, and for the shaft journals, high hardness and wear resistance.

Context:  
2.1.1 Main Failure Modes of Shaft-Type Components Shaft-type components are among the most critical parts in mechanical equipment, directly influencing both the operational precision and longevity of machinery. Their primary function is to support rotating components while transmitting motion and torque. Shafts can be categorized into three main types: rotating shafts (e.g., lathe spindles, shafts with pulleys), stationary shafts (e.g., train axle wheels, bicycle axles, or car front axles), and transmission shafts (e.g., leadscrews used on lathes). These shaft components are primarily designed to withstand various loads and efficiently transfer power. Structure Composition of the Shaft As shown in Figure 2.1, the shaft consists of three parts. 1—Shaft; 2, 5—Shaft ends; 3—Journal; 4—Shaft body Figure 2.1: Structural Components of the Shaft Axle head: The part that mates with transmission components or couplings and clutches. Journal: The part that fits into the bearing. Shaft body: The section connecting the shaft head and the shaft journal. Failure Modes of Shaft Components The main failure modes include fatigue fracture due to insufficient fatigue strength, plastic deformation or brittle fracture caused by inadequate static strength, wear, deformation exceeding allowable limits, and vibration, among others. Performance Requirements for Shaft Components The performance requirements for shaft-type components include sufficient tensile strength and stiffness; adequate impact toughness and high fatigue resistance; excellent machinability and hardenability; and, for friction-prone areas at the shaft journals, high hardness and wear resistance. Manufacturing Materials for Shaft Components Manufacturing materials typically include low-carbon steel, medium-carbon steel, or alloy steel, which are either forged or rolled.

Context:  
1.4.3 General Principles and Requirements for Mechanical Equipment Disassembly Any piece of machine ry is assembled from numerous components. When machinery requires maintenance, it must first be disassembled so that faulty parts can be repaired or replaced. The primary purpose o f dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance wor kload. Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, it’s essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment. This way,  the dismantling can proceed methodically—following a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines. Preparations Before Disassembly (1) Selection and Cleanup of the Disassembly Site. Before disassembly, choose an appropriate work area—avoid locations prone to windblown sand or dust. The workspace should be kept free from frequent unauthorized access by unrelated personnel to prevent unnecessary disruptions or accidents. Additionally, ensure that the ground in the work area remains clean, free from dirt, oil, or other contaminants. Prior to entering the disassembly site, all machinery must undergo an external cleaning process to guarantee that the disassembly procedure does not compromise the equipment’s precision. (2) Protective Measures: Before cleaning the exterior of mechanical equipment, electrical devices should be either removed or properly protected to prevent moisture damage. Additionally, parts prone to oxidation and rust should promptly undergo appropriate protective and maintenance measures. (3) Draining the oil before disassembly. Whenever possible, drain the lubricating oil from the machinery while it’s still hot prior to disassembly, ensuring smoother and more efficient removal work. (4) Understand the structure, performance, and operating principles of mechanical equipment. To avoid unnecessary disassembly and ensure the smooth progress of maintenance work, thoroughly assess all aspects of the machinery before dismantling. Familiarize yourself with the structural features of each component, the transmission system, as well as the specific design characteristics and interrelationships of individual parts. Clearly identify their intended functions and how they interact with one another, enabling you to plan the disassembly process logically and select the appropriate tools or equipment for the job. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial
General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment
Phenomenon After dismantling and cleaning the equipment components, it is impossible to restore them to their original mating precision. Cause Analysis The disassembly and cleaning work did not meet the required standards; additionally, the removed parts were poorly stored, resulting in moisture damage or physical injury—and in some cases, individual parts were even lost and replaced with substitutes. Hazardousness Hazardousness refers to the decline in mechanical equipment performance, potentially leading to complete failure and rendering the equipment unusable. Prevention and Control Measures
Removal Method (1) Striking and Disengaging. Striking involves using the force of a hammer to create relative movement between mating parts, allowing them to separate and achieve disassembly. This is a straightforward method suitable for simpler structures or when dealing with robust, non-critical components. When striking, proceed with caution—improper technique could easily damage the parts. Common tools used for this method include steel hammers, copper hammers, wooden mallets, punches, as well as copper, aluminum, and wooden shims. When removing rolling bearings by striking, always tap symmetrically from both sides; never concentrate the blows on just one side, as this could lead to cracking of the bearing raceway. (2) Press and pull disassembly. Press and pull methods are superior to impact disassembly because they apply force more evenly, allowing precise control over both the magnitude and direction of the force. As a result, these techniques reduce the risk of part misalignment or damage. This method is particularly suitable for dismantling larger components or parts with significant interference fits. Commonly used tools for this process include press benches and pull molds. (3) Hot disassembly. Hot disassembly leverages the thermal expansion properties of metals to separate parts, preventing issues like parts getting stuck or damaged—something that can occur with methods like impact or press disassembly. This technique is commonly used when the interference fit is significant (exceeding 0.1 mm), the components are large in size, or traditional disassembly methods prove impractical. In summary, choose the appropriate removal method based on how the parts fit together. If it’s a transition fit, you can use a tapping method. Remove the part; if it’s a press-fit assembly, you can use either press-off or heat-based disassembly methods. After removal, place the parts on a wooden board or a low surface. Chapter 2: Troubleshooting and Repair of Commonly Used Components 57 On the platform; smaller parts such as screws, nuts, washers, pins, and others can be placed in dedicated boxes. Long, slender components like spindles and lead screws can be hung vertically to prevent bending or deformation. Disassembly of spindle components: The relative positions of parts such as the housing and spindle are ensured using an error-compensation method. To prevent improper disassembly that could compromise assembly accuracy, make sure to mark the circumferential positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and the spindle itself during disassembly. After removal, arrange the bearings and inner/outer washers separately into their respective groups—never mix them up. Additionally, keep the workbench and surrounding area thoroughly clean during disassembly, and immediately immerse removed parts in oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them precisely according to the original markings. 2.1.3 Cleaning, Inspection, and Repair After Shaft Removal
Inspect, disassemble, and replace damaged components such as needle roller bearings . Pump shaft and motor shaft, along with other components, were damaged; the coupling was adjusted to ensure that the coaxiality error is less than 0.1 mm—but this resulted in sign ificant noise. Check the suction pipe, fuel tank, filter, oil level, and lubricant for cavitation.

1.2.4 Use of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment During operation, equipment's technical condition changes—and its performance gradually declines—due to various forces acting upon it, as well as factors such as environmental conditions, usage methods, operational guidelines, and the duration of use. To effectively manage these changes in technical condition and slow down the decline in equipment performance, the most critical measure is to ensure the equipment is used properly and correctly. Maintenance of mechanical and electrical equipment is a crucial method for improving utilization and ensuring its functionality—it consists of two forms: daily maintenance and periodic maintenance. Daily maintenance is primarily carried out by operators of mechanical and electrical equipment—conducting pre-shift inspections and post-shift cleaning to ensure that the equipment remains in optimal technical condition. Regular maintenance, also known as Level 1 care, is carried out by operators with assistance from maintenance personnel. It’s similar to minor repairs and is covered in Chapter 1 of the "Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance. " 13
Cultivate a culture and habit of consciously caring for equipment, ensuring it remains regularly clean, safe, and in optimal technical condition. 1.2.5 Maintenance and保养 of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 1) Principles of Operation and Maintenance Procedures Mechanical and electrical equipment maintenance refers to the tasks performed to eliminate inevitable abnormal technical conditions that arise during operation (such as loose parts, dry friction, or unusual noises). Overall, maintaining mechanical and electrical equipment requires meeting four fundamental criteria: neatness, cleanliness, lubrication, and safety. Developing clear equipment operation and maintenance procedures is a crucial step in ensuring that all subsequent operations are carried out systematically and efficiently. The principles for creating these operational and maintenance guidelines are outlined below. (1) General guidelines should list precautions according to the equipment operation sequence, as well as before, during, and after shifts—aiming for concise, clear, and practical content. (2) List the structural features, processing range, operational precautions, maintenance requirements, and more separately by equipment category, making it easier for operators to grasp the key points and ensure proper implementation. (3) Common elements across various types of mechanical and electrical equipment can be used to develop a unified, standard general procedure. (4) Key equipment, high-precision, large and medium-sized, as well as rare and critical electromechanical devices, must have operation and maintenance procedures prepared separately. Also, post prominent signage near the machine tool, clearly indicating that operators should pay special attention and strictly adhere to the guidelines. 2) Basic Content of Operation and Maintenance Procedures
Usage guidelines include strengthening equipment management, establishing and rigorously enforcing operating procedures, enhancing inspection and maintenance of mechanical equipment, avoiding overloading, and preventing localized overloads or overheating. user_input: What is the proper procedure for cleaning machine parts?
reference_contexts: ['Machine parts are typically cleaned with kerosene, but precision components or rolling bearings must be washed again with gasoline after being thoroughly cleaned with kerosene.', 'All debris such as sediment, sand, or dirty oil inside oil holes and oil passages must be thoroughly removed, and then sealed with wooden plugs鈥攏ever use cotton yarn or cloth scraps as substitutes for the plugs.']
reference: Machine parts are typically cleaned using kerosene as the primary cleaning agent. However, for precision components or rolling bearings, an additional cleaning step is required: after thorough cleaning with kerosene, these components must be washed again with gasoline. Furthermore, all debris including sediment, sand, and dirty oil must be completely removed from oil holes and oil passages. After cleaning, these openings must be sealed using wooden plugs鈥攃otton yarn or cloth scraps are strictly prohibited as substitute sealing materials.
answer: Machine parts are typically cleaned with kerosene, but precision components or rolling bearings must be washed again with gasoline after being thoroughly cleaned with kerosene; all debris inside oil holes and oil passages must be thoroughly removed and then sealed with wooden plugs, and after cleaning, components that cannot be assembled immediately should be properly stored to prevent dust from entering, with the work area for disassembly and cleaning kept clean, prohibiting dusty environments or outdoor locations.

2) Key Points for Process Specification Work (1) Disassembly process. When repairing mechanical equipment, the first step is to partially disassemble and take it apart. However, each time a machine is disassembled, its performance and precision inevitably suffer some degree of damage. Improper disassembly of precision equipment can even lead to complete报废 of the device. Therefore, it is crucial to approach this process with utmost care and expertise. Key and precision equipment should have dismantling process specifications developed. The general principles and precautions for disassembly will be introduced in Chapter 2 and can serve as a reference when developing the disassembly process. Additionally, please keep the following points in mind. ① Safety comes first during disassembly. Before starting, ensure the power supply is disconnected, remove any hazardous materials—such as toxic or flammable substances—from both inside and outside the machinery and equipment, set up reliable supports, and select appropriate lifting equipment and tools. ② Disassembly for service and maintenance. Do not disassemble components that are unnecessary or prohibited. For parts with tight fits, establish a proper disassembly method and use appropriate tools to avoid damaging critical surfaces. ③ Disassembly serves assembly. When the machine structure is complex and the drawing documentation is incomplete, disassemble while simultaneously documenting details and sketching preliminary diagrams, ultimately compiling a complete assembly drawing. (2) Parts cleaning process. The cleaning process should include details such as the cleaning method, cleaning procedure, type or formulation of the cleaning agent, cleaning parameters, cleaning quality, and important precautions during cleaning. (3) Repair Processes for Typical Components. In equipment maintenance, certain critical parts—such as machine beds, housings, worktables, and large rotating components—often require restoration. To ensure effective repairs and enhance overall efficiency, it’s essential to select the appropriate repair solution and develop a detailed maintenance process procedure. These procedures are typically documented in the form of process cards, which provide more specifics than standard manufacturing process cards yet remain simpler than operation-specific cards. A typical maintenance process card usually includes the following information: ① Part name, drawing number, material and properties, part defect indication diagram, and explanations regarding the defects.
2. Manufacturing Cause Equipment manufacturing and component production often proceed smoothly with no issues in the overall design—but unexpected failures still tend to arise during installation and commissioning. For instance, at one company, the valve test bench of a multifunctional hydraulic component testing station failed to perform pressure tests during debugging. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the oil passages connecting the integrated block had been improperly machined, causing the pressure and return lines to inadvertently merge. As a result, sufficient pressure couldn’t be built up. After reworking the affected areas, the issue was resolved, allowing the commissioning process to proceed smoothly and successfully complete. For instance, improper clearance between the valve body and spool of a slide valve can lead to leakage or seizing. Additionally, if the mating surfaces between the valve body and the machine housing fail to meet manufacturing tolerances for flatness, deformation may occur under tightening pressure after assembly, causing the spool to become stuck inside the valve body—resulting in restricted or complete blockage of movement. Furthermore, during manufacturing, some valve bodies may not undergo reliable stress-relief treatments. As a result, residual stresses redistribute over time during operation, leading to deformation of the valve body. This not only compromises the original fit and function but also causes the slide valve to move sluggishly or even jam completely within the valve body. Some manufacturers fail to flush the hydraulic system during final assembly, opting instead to rely on cleaning components individually as they are assembled—thus skipping the critical step of flushing the system itself. This practice often leaves behind contaminants introduced during the assembly process, which can become a significant and frequently overlooked cause of system failures. Hydraulic system flushing involves using fluid flow at specific pressure and velocity levels to thoroughly clean and rinse every circuit within the entire system. However, cleaning components before assembly cannot replace the essential step of flushing the system after it has been fully assembled. During assembly, there’s always a risk of damaging seals or scratching/abrasively affecting metal parts. Additionally, adhesives, liquid sealants, or PTFE tape used when connecting pipes and components may inadvertently get pushed into the system, introducing contaminants that compromise its performance even after assembly is complete. 3. Reason for Use
(2) Fault Diagnosis and Repair. ① Improper assembly. Without applying load to the hydraulic cylinder, measure its minimum operating resistance. If the resistance is excessively high, it indicates the presence of binding. Such binding typically arises from incorrect hydraulic cylinder assembly practices. Therefore, during the assembly process, strictly follow the specified assembly procedures to ensure that the piston and piston rod move freely without being subjected to lateral forces or torsional stresses. Additionally, verify that the sealing elements maintain appropriate resistance levels and are in optimal condition. ② The reaction force from the load causes the hydraulic cylinder to become skewed. This binding phenomenon in the hydraulic cylinder, resulting from the applied load force, typically becomes noticeable only when the cylinder is pushing the load into motion. For instance, a hydraulic cylinder equipped with base mounts may experience insufficient rigidity in its feet; as a result, when the cylinder moves the load, the reaction force from the load induces flexible deformation in the foot mounts, leading to skewing of the cylinder and the onset of binding. Therefore, during installation, hydraulic cylinders must not only maintain adequate positional accuracy but also ensure sufficient structural rigidity. 2) Causes of Creep Failure Due to Seals and Maintenance Measures Hydraulic cylinders are significantly affected by seal rings when it comes to the phenomenon of creep. In most cases, the first step should be to check whether the piston rod support seals and piston seals are tightened too much. If creep occurs when the hydraulic cylinder's movement speed drops below 5 mm/s, no other solutions will work effectively. When selecting seals, care should be taken to ensure proper performance. To eliminate creeping, the seal material must have a minimal difference between its dynamic and static friction coefficients. Additionally, the sealing design itself should minimize resistance while maximizing rigidity; after being subjected to tensile forces, it should exhibit low elongation. Ideally, the sealing material would possess negative friction characteristics—meaning that as sliding speed increases, so does the resistance. For instance, seals made from leather or polytetrafluoroethylene are well-suited for low-speed applications in hydraulic cylinders. However, V-shaped seals containing only nitrile rubber are not recommended for use in low-speed scenarios. 3) Causes and Maintenance of Crawling Faults Caused by Hydraulic Component Wear

Striking and disengaging involves using hammer force to create movement between mating parts for separation, suitable for simpler structures or robust non-critical components. Press and pull disassembly applies force more evenly than impact methods, providing precise control over force magnitude and direction, reducing part misalignment or damage risks, and is ideal for larger components or parts with significant interference fits. Hot disassembly utilizes metal thermal expansion properties to separate parts, preventing sticking or damage issues that may occur with impact or press methods, and is commonly used when interference fits exceed 0.1 mm, components are large, or traditional methods are impractical.
answer: The key methods for removing parts during disassembly are Striking and Disengaging, Press and pull disassembly, and Hot disassembly.

Context:  
General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment
1.4.3 General Principles and Requirements for Mechanical Equipment Disassembly Any piece of machine ry is assembled from numerous components. When machinery requires maintenance, it must first be disassembled so that faulty parts can be repaired or replaced. The primary purpose o f dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance wor kload. Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, it’s essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment. This way,  the dismantling can proceed methodically—following a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines. Preparations Before Disassembly (1) Selection and Cleanup of the Disassembly Site. Before disassembly, choose an appropriate work area—avoid locations prone to windblown sand or dust. The workspace should be kept free from frequent unauthorized access by unrelated personnel to prevent unnecessary disruptions or accidents. Additionally, ensure that the ground in the work area remains clean, free from dirt, oil, or other contaminants. Prior to entering the disassembly site, all machinery must undergo an external cleaning process to guarantee that the disassembly procedure does not compromise the equipment’s precision. (2) Protective Measures: Before cleaning the exterior of mechanical equipment, electrical devices should be either removed or properly protected to prevent moisture damage. Additionally, parts prone to oxidation and rust should promptly undergo appropriate protective and maintenance measures. (3) Draining the oil before disassembly. Whenever possible, drain the lubricating oil from the machinery while it’s still hot prior to disassembly, ensuring smoother and more efficient removal work. (4) Understand the structure, performance, and operating principles of mechanical equipment. To avoid unnecessary disassembly and ensure the smooth progress of maintenance work, thoroughly assess all aspects of the machinery before dismantling. Familiarize yourself with the structural features of each component, the transmission system, as well as the specific design characteristics and interrelationships of individual parts. Clearly identify their intended functions and how they interact with one another, enabling you to plan the disassembly process logically and select the appropriate tools or equipment for the job. 2) Key Points for Process Specification Work (1) Disassembly process. When repairing mechanical equipment, the first step is to partially disassemble and take it apart. However, each time a machine is disassembled, its perfor mance and precision inevitably suffer some degree of damage. Improper disassembly of precision equipment can even lead to complete报废 of the device. Therefore, it is crucial to appr oach this process with utmost care and expertise. Key and precision equipment should have dismantling process specifications developed. The general principles and precautions for d isassembly will be introduced in Chapter 2 and can serve as a reference when developing the disassembly process. Before starting, ensure the power supply is disconnected, remove any hazardous materials—such as toxic or flammable substances—from both inside and ou tside the machinery and equipment, set up reliable supports, and select appropriate lifting equipment and tools. ② Disassembly for service and maintenance. Do not disassemble compo nents that are unnecessary or prohibited. When the machine structure is complex and the drawing documentation is incomplete, disassemble while simultaneously documenting details and sketching prelimina ry diagrams, ultimately compiling a complete assembly drawing. The cleaning process should include details such as the cleaning method, cleaning procedu re, type or formulation of the cleaning agent, cleaning parameters, cleaning quality, and important precautions during cleaning. (3) Repair Processes for Typical Components. In equ ipment maintenance, certain critical parts—such as machine beds, housings, worktables, and large rotating components—often require restoration. To ensure effective repairs and enha nce overall efficiency, it’s essential to select the appropriate repair solution and develop a detailed maintenance process procedure. These procedures are typically documented in  the form of process cards, which provide more specifics than standard manufacturing process cards yet remain simpler than operation-specific cards. A typical maintenance process ca rd usually includes the following information: ① Part name, drawing number, material and properties, part defect indication diagram, and explanations regarding the defects.
(1) The work area for disassembly and cleaning must be kept clean; dusty environments or outdoor locations are prohibited. If it is necessary to carry out the work outdoors, dust-control measures must be implemented. (2) Before disassembly, you must familiarize yourself with the drawings. Proceed step-by-step according to the diagrams, and mark the mating components clearly, ensuring that the markings are consistent, unambiguous, and easily visible. If the components already have existing marks, verify them thoroughly before proceeding with disassembly. When disassembling identical yet numerous components, provide a schematic diagram and mark them according to the numbers shown on the diagram. Removal Method (1) Striking and Disengaging. Striking involves using the force of a hammer to create relative movement between mating parts, allowing them to separate and achieve disassembly. This is a straightforward method suitable for simpler structures or when dealing with robust, non-critical components. When striking, proceed with caution—improper technique could easily damage the parts. Common tools used for this method include steel hammers, copper hammers, wooden mallets, punches, as well as copper, aluminum, and wooden shims. When removing rolling bearings by striking, always tap symmetrically from both sides; never concentrate the blows on just one side, as this could lead to cracking of the bearing raceway. (2) Press and pull disassembly. Press and pull methods are superior to impact disassembly because they apply force more evenly, allowing precise control over both the magnitude and direction of the force. As a result, these techniques reduce the risk of part misalignment or damage. This method is particularly suitable for dismantling larger components or parts with significant interference fits. Commonly used tools for this process include press benches and pull molds. (3) Hot disassembly. Hot disassembly leverages the thermal expansion properties of metals to separate parts, preventing issues like parts getting stuck or damaged—something that can occur with methods like impact or press disassembly. This technique is commonly used when the interference fit is significant (exceeding 0.1 mm), the components are large in size, or traditional disassembly methods prove impractical. In summary, choose the appropriate removal method based on how the parts fit together. If it’s a transition fit, you can use a tapping method. Remove the part; if it’s a press-fit assembly, you can use either press-off or heat-based disassembly methods. After removal, place the parts on a wooden board or a low surface. Chapter 2: Troubleshooting and Repair of Commonly Used Components 57 On the platform; smaller parts such as screws, nuts, washers, pins, and others can be placed in dedicated boxes. Long, slender components like spindles and lead screws can be hung vertically to prevent bending or deformation. Disassembly of spindle components: The relative positions of parts such as the housing and spindle are ensured using an error-compensation method. To prevent improper disassembly that could compromise assembly accuracy, make sure to mark the circumferential positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and the spindle itself during disassembly. After removal, arrange the bearings and inner/outer washers separately into their respective groups—never mix them up. Additionally, keep the workbench and surrounding area thoroughly clean during disassembly, and immediately immerse removed parts in oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them precisely according to the original markings. 2.1.3 Cleaning, Inspection, and Repair After Shaft Removal

reference: When removing rolling bearings using the striking method, it is crucial to tap symmetrically from both sides rather than concentrating blows on just one side. This symmetrical approach prevents uneven force distribution that could cause cracking of the bearing raceway, which would compromise the bearing's structural integrity and functionality. Proper symmetrical striking ensures the bearing separates evenly without damage to its critical components.

When designing bearing assemblies, consider the ease of installation and removal to prevent damage to the bearing and other components during these processes. Bearing installation: Small bearings can be gently and evenly tapped into place using a copper hammer to fit the retaining rings; larger bearings should be pressed in with a hydraulic press. Bearings that are large in size and tightly fitted can be heated to expand the bore before assembly. Bearing installation and removal: Specialized tools can be used; when designing the structure, ensure ease of bearing installation and removal. 1. Disassembling Rolling Bearings Disassembling rolling bearings is an essential part of mechanical maintenance. Since rolling bearings are tightly fitted to the shaft, significant force is required to remove them. If the disassembly method is improper, not only may the bearing fail to come off, but if the fit is particularly tight—with a large interference—the process could also damage the bearing and its associated components. Here, we introduce several commonly used methods for removing bearings. (1) Heating Disassembly Method. If the bearing is tightly fitted and has a significant interference fit, the bearing must be heated to induce thermal expansion, causing elastic deformation that allows for easy removal. For instance, you can wrap the shaft near the bearing with asbestos cloth and then heat the inner race of the bearing using an acetylene-oxygen flame—this method enables disassembly while heating continues. However, it’s crucial to heat slowly, keeping the temperature around 100°C to prevent damage to the bearing. (2) If the bearing has a loose fit, you can carefully tap the fitting ring of the bearing with a wooden mallet to remove it. When tapping, make sure to work evenly around the circumference—avoid focusing on just one spot repeatedly. In some cases, a steel hammer may also be used, but in this scenario, always place a wooden block between the hammer and the bearing to ensure that the force is distributed evenly across the bearing, preventing damage. (3) Select a metal material to create a sleeve, ensuring the inner diameter of the sleeve is slightly larger than the journal diameter. During removal, support the sleeve with an appropriate object. If the fit is loose, gently tap the shaft end with a hammer to detach the bearing; if the fit is tight, apply force to the shaft end using a press or jack. Alternatively, if using the sleeve proves inconvenient, you can also substitute it with two clamping plates. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Commonly Used Components 65 (4) Tensioner Disassembly Method. Use a tensioner to remove the shaft. Bearing Cleaning (1) Hot Oil Cleaning Method. For bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease, immerse them in hot motor oil heated to 100–200°C. Use pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away any oil contamination with a brush. When heated to 100–200°C, soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease will melt, allowing it to easily flush out of the bearing’s crevices. In some cases, simply shaking the bearing repeatedly in the oil is enough to dislodge the dirt and grime from between the gaps. When cleaning the radial spherical ball bearings of old or imported electric motors, the balls, retainer, and inner ring should be carefully turned horizontally out of the outer ring before being immersed in hot oil. Similarly, when cleaning short cylindrical roller bearings, the rollers, retainer, inner ring, and outer ring must first be separated from one another. When cleaning with hot oil, the oil temperature should not exceed 20°C. If using an open flame for direct heating, be careful to prevent the oil from catching fire. The bearing should be suspended inside the oil pot—immersing it completely at the bottom could cause overheating and reduce its hardness. (2) General Cleaning Method: Place the bearing in kerosene and soak it for 5–10 minutes. While holding the inner ring with one hand, gently rotate the outer ring with the other—this will cause any soft dry grease or rust-preventive paste on the bearing to fall off. Next, transfer the bearing to a container of cleaner kerosene and use a fine, soft-bristled brush to thoroughly clean away oil stains from the raceways and between the rolling elements. Finally, rinse the bearing once more in gasoline before carefully placing it onto a clean piece of paper. When cleaning spherical ball bearings and short cylindrical roller bearings, separate the balls, retainer cage, inner ring, and outer ring for individual cleaning. For bearings already mounted on a shaft, cleaning is typically done by pouring oil directly over them or using an oil gun for targeted spraying. Start with kerosene to remove easily loosened oil deposits, followed by gasoline for tougher residues. If oil stains persist, first apply hot engine oil heated to 100–200°C via pouring or spraying, then finish with gasoline. Always remember not to scrape off hardened oil buildup or rust from the bearing surfaces using sharp tools, as this could damage the smoothness of the rolling elements and raceway grooves. After cleaning, dry the bearing thoroughly with a clean cloth. 3. Inspection of Rolling Bearings For rolling bearings, focus should be placed on inspecting the inner and outer raceways. The entire working surface must be smooth, free from defects such as cracks, micropores, dents, and peeling. Similarly, the surfaces of the rolling elements themselves should be flawless, with no cracks, micropores, or dents. Additionally, the retainer must remain intact, and all rivets should be securely fastened. If clearance is detected between the inner and outer races of the bearing, avoid replacing it immediately—instead, consider adjusting it through preloading to eliminate any increased clearance caused by wear, thereby enhancing its rotational accuracy. 2.4.4 Assembly of Rolling Bearings Rolling bearings consist of an inner ring, outer ring, rolling elements, and a cage—they are the bearing components that enable relative motion between the shaft and the bearing housing through rolling friction. Rolling bearings offer advantages such as low friction coefficients, high efficiency, compact axial dimensions, and ease of assembly and disassembly, making them widely used in various types of machinery and equipment. As standardized components mass-produced by specialized factories, rolling bearings come with predetermined inner diameters, outer diameters, and axial widths at the time of manufacture. Consequently, the inner ring of a rolling bearing serves as the reference hole, while the outer ring acts as the reference shaft. Figure 2.8: Tutorial on Diagnosing and Repairing Electromechanical System Failures in Tensioners – Bearing Disassembly Case 66
4. Measures to Reduce Fracture Failure Fracture failure is one of the most dangerous forms of failure, and most metal parts fail due to various factors arising from metallurgy and part manufacturing processes. Because all of them contain cracks of varying sizes and characteristics, ranging from atomic-level dislocations to macroscopic cracks visible to the naked eye. However, a part with cracks doesn’t necessarily fail immediately—there’s typically a period during which these cracks undergo subcritical propagation. Moreover, under certain conditions, cracks may even remain stable without expanding at all. Therefore, by implementing effective measures, it’s possible to ensure that parts containing cracks do not ultimately fracture. Strategies to minimize fracture failures can be considered from the following perspectives. 1) Optimize the shape and structural design of parts, and carefully select appropriate materials for the components. Both geometric discontinuities in part shapes and material imperfections can lead to stress concentration. Geometric discontinuities are commonly referred to as notches, such as fillets at shoulders, grooves, oil holes, keyways, threads, and machining marks. Material-related discontinuities are typically called material defects, including shrinkage porosity, shrinkage cavities, non-metallic inclusions, and welding flaws. These areas prone to stress concentration are particularly susceptible to crack initiation and propagation under cyclic or impact loading, ultimately leading to fracture. Therefore, in part design, it’s crucial to minimize stress-concentration zones while carefully considering the part’s operating environment—such as the presence of corrosive media, temperature variations, and applied loads—and selecting appropriate materials accordingly. This approach helps effectively reduce the risk of fatigue failure. 2) Properly select the part machining method During various machining, welding, and heat treatment processes, residual stresses remain inside components due to factors such as plastic deformation, thermal expansion and contraction, and phase transformations occurring during these operations. Residual stresses are categorized into two types: residual tensile stress and residual compressive stress. While residual tensile stress is detrimental to component performance, residual compressive stress can significantly enhance the fatigue life of the part. Therefore, it is advisable to prioritize processes like carburizing, nitriding, shot peening, and surface rolling—methods known for generating beneficial compressive stresses—in component manufacturing. By inducing compressive stresses on the component’s surface, these techniques help counteract some of the tensile stresses caused by external loads, thereby improving the overall durability and longevity of the part. 3) Installation and Usage Instructions

user_input: What is the cleaning procedure for a shaft after removal?
reference_contexts: ['Here鈥檚 a simple cleaning procedure: 鈶?Remove the shaft from its position; 鈶?Immerse and scrub the shaft in the cleaning solution; 鈶?Rinse the thoroughly cleaned shaft to remove any remaining residue; 鈶?Use a hairdryer to dry the shaft completely (drying prevents rusting); 鈶?Apply lubricating grease to protect against dust, water, and ensure smooth operation; 鈶?Once greased, reattach the side cover before proceeding with installation.']
reference: The cleaning procedure for a shaft after removal involves six sequential steps. First, the shaft is removed from its position. Second, it is immersed and scrubbed in a cleaning solution to remove contaminants. Third, the shaft is rinsed thoroughly to eliminate any residual cleaning solution or debris. Fourth, a hairdryer is used to dry the shaft completely, which is crucial for preventing rust formation. Fifth, lubricating grease is applied to protect the shaft from dust and water ingress and to ensure smooth future operation. Finally, after greasing, the side cover is reattached before the shaft is reinstalled or further maintenance is performed.
answer: The cleaning procedure after shaft removal is to immerse and scrub the shaft in cleaning solution, rinse it to remove residue, dry it completely with a hairdryer, and then apply lubricating grease.

Cleaning After Shaft Removal Cleaning the disassembled mechanical parts is a crucial step in maintenance work. The cleaning method and the quality of removal directly impact the accuracy of parts inspection. Certainty, the quality of equipment repair, maintenance costs, and service life will all be significantly impacted. Part cleaning involves removing oil stains, scale, carbon deposits, rust layers, and old paint coatings. The tools required for cleaning include wrenches, circlip pliers, cleaning solutions, grease, a hairdryer, cloths, needles, and a container specifically designed for soaking the shaft. Here’s a simple cleaning procedure: ① Remove the shaft from its position; ② Immerse and scrub the shaft in the cleaning solution; ③ Rinse the thoroughly cleaned shaft to remove any remaining residue; ④ Use a hairdryer to dry the shaft completely (drying prevents rusting); ⑤ Apply lubricating grease to protect against dust, water, and ensure smooth operation; ⑥ Once greased, reattach the side cover before proceeding with installation. 2. The rear end of the spindle is fitted with a plug 2, which features a steel ball 3 positioned at the center hole and resting against the support plate  4. By rotating the spindle, the difference in movement indicated by the dial  gauge pointer directly reflects the coaxial error. Additionally, the circular runout error at the shoulder end face can also be measured using the dial indicator positioned at the  end face. Generally, coaxial error should be kept within 0.015, and the face runout error should be less than 0.01 mm. As for the spindle taper bore... Bearing Cleaning (1) Hot Oil Cleaning Method. For bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease, immerse them in hot motor oil heated to 100–200°C. Use pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away any oil contamination with a brush. When heated to 100–200°C, soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease will melt, allowing it to easily flush out of the bearing’s crevices. In some cases, simply shaking the bearing repeatedly in the oil is enough to dislodge the dirt and grime from between the gaps. When cleaning the radial spherical ball bearings of old or imported electric motors, the balls, retainer, and inner ring should be carefully turned horizontally out of the outer ring before being immersed in hot oil. Similarly, when cleaning short cylindrical roller bearings, the rollers, retainer, inner ring, and outer ring must first be separated from one another. When cleaning with hot oil, the oil temperature should not exceed 20°C. If using an open flame for direct heating, be careful to prevent the oil from catching fire. The bearing should be suspended inside the oil pot—immersing it completely at the bottom could cause overheating and reduce its hardness. (2) General Cleaning Method: Place the bearing in kerosene and soak it for 5–10 minutes. While holding the inner ring with one hand, gently rotate the outer ring with the other—this will cause any soft dry grease or rust-preventive paste on the bearing to fall off. Next, transfer the bearing to a container of cleaner kerosene and use a fine, soft-bristled brush to thoroughly clean away oil stains from the raceways and between the rolling elements. reference: The coaxiality of spindle journals is checked using a setup involving specific components: the spindle itself, a plug with a steel ball, a support plate, V-shaped frames, and an inspection plate. The spindle is positioned on two V-shaped supports mounted on the inspection plate. A plug fitted at the rear end of the spindle contains a steel ball that rests against the support plate to stabilize the setup. A dial indicator is used by bringing its tip into contact with the surface of each journal. As the spindle is rotated, the dial gauge pointer shows variations in movement, which directly indicate the coaxial error between journals. Acceptable coaxial error is generally within 0.015 mm, and face runout error should be less than 0.01 mm for proper spindle function.

3. Spindle Maintenance Under normal circumstances, the primary failure modes of spindles are bending deformation caused by external loads, as well as we ar on the mating surfaces. If a spindle becomes deformed, the repair method should be determined based on the extent of the deformation and the spindle's precision requirements. Fo r ordinary-precision spindles that have undergone bending deformation, straightening is an effective repair technique. However, for high-precision spindles, straightening often fai ls to restore their original accuracy, making it necessary to replace the spindle with a new one. After the spindle journal wears down, it usually needs to be restored to its origi nal dimensions. Commonly used methods include brush plating and chrome plating. The process for repairing the spindle using brush plating involves: first, inserting plugs into the  holes at both ends of the spindle; then, drilling a center hole in the plugs; next, precisely aligning the spindle on a grinding machine, using the unworn portions of the front and  rear journals as reference points; followed by grinding down the worn journal areas by 0.05 to 0.15 mm; finally, applying brush plating to the targeted outer cylindrical surfaces,  ensuring that the single-sided coating thickness is at least 0.1 mm. After brushing, the ground surfaces are carefully lapped to meet the required specifications. Additionally, th e spindle's Morse taper bore is also prone to wear, and during maintenance, its surface accuracy is often restored through grinding. If the spindle has undergone multiple rounds of  grinding, it can eventually be repaired by installing a sleeve.

reference_contexts: ['the primary failure modes of spindles are bending deformation caused by external loads, as well as wear on the mating surfaces.', "If a spindle becomes deformed, the repair method should be determined based on the extent of the deformation and the spindle's precision requirements.", 'For ordinary-precision spindles that have undergone bending deformation, straightening is an effective repair technique.']
reference: The primary failure modes of spindles are bending deformation caused by external loads and wear on the mating surfaces. For bending deformation, the repair method depends on the extent of deformation and the spindle's precision requirements. Ordinary-precision spindles can often be effectively repaired through straightening, while high-precision spindles typically require replacement as straightening cannot restore their original accuracy. For worn spindle journals, restoration to original dimensions is necessary using methods such as brush plating or chrome plating.

If a spindle becomes deformed, the repair method should be determined based on the extent of the deformation and the spindle's precision requirements. For ordinary-precision spindles that have undergone bending deformation, straightening is an effective repair technique. After brushing, the ground surfaces are carefully lapped to meet the required specifications. Additionally, the spindle's Morse taper bore is also prone to wear, and during maintenance, its surface accuracy is often restored through grinding. If the spindle has undergone multiple rounds of grinding, it can eventually be repaired by installing a sleeve. 2. user_input: What is the process for repairing a spindle journal using brush plating?
reference_contexts: ['The process for repairing the spindle using brush plating involves: first, inserting plugs into the holes at both ends of the spindle; then, drilling a center hole in the plugs; next, precisely aligning the spindle on a grinding machine, using the unworn portions of the front and rear journals as reference points; followed by grinding down the worn journal areas by 0.05 to 0.15 mm; finally, applying brush plating to the targeted outer cylindrical surfaces, ensuring that the single-sided coating thickness is at least 0.1 mm.', 'After brushing, the ground surfaces are carefully lapped to meet the required specifications.']
reference: The brush plating repair process for spindle journals involves several precise steps: First, plugs are inserted into the holes at both ends of the spindle. Then, a center hole is drilled into these plugs. Next, the spindle is precisely aligned on a grinding machine using the unworn portions of the front and rear journals as reference points. The worn journal areas are then ground down by 0.05 to 0.15 mm. Brush plating is applied to the targeted outer cylindrical surfaces with a minimum single-sided coating thickness of 0.1 mm. Finally, after brushing, the ground surfaces are carefully lapped to meet the required specifications.

Electroplating Repair Technology Electroplating is a process that uses electrolysis to deposit metal onto the surface of a part, forming a metallic coating. The electroplating repair method not only restores the dimensions of worn parts but also enhances their surface quality—particularly improving wear resistance and corrosion resistance. Electroplating repair technology is a widely used technique for restoring component dimensions under low-temperature conditions. Compared to welding repair methods, it avoids the various issues caused by localized high temperatures, while the bond strength between the electroplated layer and the substrate is nearly equivalent to that achieved with welding repairs. This technique leverages the principle of electrolysis: metal ions from the plating solution are reduced into metallic atoms, which then deposit onto the metal surface, forming a repair layer with strong adhesion and precise thickness control. Common applications include chrome plating, low-temperature iron plating, and brush plating.

user_input: What is an interference fit and what are its key characteristics?
reference_contexts: ['An interference fit involves fitting a larger component (the shaft) into a smaller one (the hole).', 'This type of connection can withstand significant axial forces, torque, and dynamic loads, while also providing high alignment accuracy and wide-ranging applications.', 'Interference fits are primarily used for tight connections between holes and shafts where relative motion is not permitted']
reference: An interference fit is a mechanical connection method where a larger component (typically a shaft) is fitted into a smaller component (the hole). This type of fit creates a tight connection that can withstand significant axial forces, torque, and dynamic loads while providing high alignment accuracy. It is specifically designed for applications where relative motion between the components is not permitted. As a fixed joint, it requires precise positioning and reliable clamping while ensuring that the assembly process maintains the strength and accuracy of the components. The interference fit finds wide-ranging applications in various industrial settings due to these robust characteristics.
answer: An interference fit is a type of fixed joint that involves fitting a larger component into a smaller one, used for tight connections where relative motion is not permitted, and its key characteristics are that it can withstand significant axial forces, torque, and dynamic loads, provides high alignment accuracy, has wide-ranging applications such as joining gears, couplings, flywheels, sprockets, and pulleys to shafts, requires assembly methods like applying pressure or thermal expansion/contraction, demands precise positioning and reliable clamping, and involves mating surfaces that can be cylindrical, conical, or other specialized shapes.

Context:  
An interference fit involves fitting a larger component (the shaft) into a smaller one (the hole). This type of connection can withstand significant axial forces, torque, and dynamic loads, while also providing high alignment accuracy and wide-ranging applications. For instance, it’s commonly used to join gears, couplings, flywheels, sprockets, pulleys, and other components to their respective shafts, as well as in the assembly of bearings with their housing sleeves. In an interference fit, since the shaft is larger in size than the hole, assembly must be carried out using methods such as applying pressure or employing thermal expansion/contraction techniques. Interference fits are primarily used for tight connections between holes and shafts where relative motion is not permitted—such as in the secure attachment of gear rims to wheel hubs in large gears. An interference fit is a type of fixed joint that not only demands precise positioning and reliable clamping but also ensures that the assembly process does not compromise the strength or accuracy of the components, while allowing for easy and rapid installation. The mating surfaces in interference connections can take various forms, including cylindrical, conical, and other specialized shapes. The assembly technical requirements for interference fit connections are as follows: (1) Accurate interference fit must be ensured to meet the design requirements after assembly. (2) The mating surface should have a low surface roughness. (3) Before assembly, ensure that the mating surfaces are clean, and make sure these surfaces are properly lubricated with oil. (4) The pressing process should be continuous, with a speed that is not too fast (typically 2.4 mm/s), and the pressing stroke must be accurately controlled. (5) During the pressing process, ensure that the axis of the shaft aligns perfectly with the axis of the hole. Regularly check using a 90° square to prevent any tilting. (6) For slender and thin-walled components, special attention should be paid to controlling the interference fit and geometric tolerances. During assembly, it's best to press them in vertically to prevent deformation of the parts.

reference_contexts: ['Press-fitting the bushing. Depending on the bushing size and the amount of interference fit, assembly is carried out either by hammering or press-fitting. reference: The assembly of a solid sliding bearing involves three main steps. First, press-fitting the bushing: depending on the bushing size and interference fit, assembly is done by hammering or press-fitting. For smaller dimensions and lighter interference, a hand hammer with a backing plate is used; for larger sizes and interference, a hydraulic press is required. If interference exceeds 0.1 mm, heating the housing or cooling the bushing is necessary to facilitate fitting. Second, fixing the bushing: after press-fitting, it is secured against rotation using screws, locating pins, or similar fasteners. Third, inspection and adjustment: post-assembly, methods like reaming, scraping, or honing are applied to ensure the clearance and contact points between the bushing and journal meet specified requirements.
answer: The steps for assembling a solid sliding bearing are press-fitting the bushing, fixed bushing, and inspection and adjustment after assembly.
