Below, we'll use a solid sliding bearing as an example to introduce its assembly method. (1) Press-fitting the bushing. Depending on the bushing size and the amount of interference fit, assembly is carried out either by hammering or press-fitting. For smaller dimensions and lighter interference fits, the bushing can be tapped into place using a hand hammer and a backing plate. When the bushing size and interference are larger, a hydraulic press should be used for assembly. If the interference exceeds 0.1 mm, the assembly process involves heating the housing or cooling the bushing to facilitate proper fitting. (2) Fixed bushing. Hard particles grinding against the shaft and bearing surfaces cause abrasive wear. (2) Scratches. Hard contour peak tips on the shaft surface scrape against the bearing, resulting in scratches. (3) Galling (adhesion). Galling occurs when temperatures rise, pressure increases, or the oil film breaks down. (4) Fatigue spalling. Repeated loading causes fatigue cracks to propagate, leading to spalling. (5) Corrosion. Oxidation of the lubricant produces acidic substances that cause corrosive damage.
2.3.2 Installation and Maintenance of Sliding Bearings Sliding bearings are characterized by their reliable operation, smooth performance, quietness, strong vibration absorption due to the lubricating oil film, and ability to withstand significant impact loads. Sliding bearings can be categorized into various structural types, such as integral and split designs, as shown in Figure 2.3. Figure 2.3: Sliding Bearing Basic Requirements for Sliding Bearing Installation (1) Before installation, burrs and sharp edges on the parts of the sliding bearing should be removed, and the contact surfaces must be smooth and clean. (2) When installing the bearing housing, the bearing or bushing should be fitted onto the housing and aligned according to the center position of the bushing or shaft sleeve. All bearings on the same transmission shaft must lie on a single axis, with their coaxial error remaining within the specified tolerance range. The bottom surface of the bearing housing must also be properly aligned with the machine components. The contact surfaces should make even, tight contact, and the fixed connections must be secure. During operation, there should be no signs of loosening or shifting. (3) The contact condition between the bearing and the shaft surface can be checked using the dye-penetration method, and the number of contact points must meet the specified requirements. (4) When the shaft is rotating, no rotation of the bearing bush or shaft sleeve is permitted. Mechatronics System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance Case Study Tutorial
An interference fit involves fitting a larger component (t he shaft) into a smaller one (the hole). This type of connection can withstand significant axial forces, torque, and dynamic loads, while also providing high alignment accuracy and  wide-ranging applications. For instance, it’s commonly used to join gears, couplings, flywheels, sprockets, pulleys, and other components to their respective shafts, as well as in  the assembly of bearings with their housing sleeves. In an interference fit, since the shaft is larger in size than the hole, assembly must be carried out using methods such as applying pressure or employing thermal expansion/contraction techniques. Interference fits are primarily used for tight connections between holes and shafts where relative motion is not permitted—such as in the secure attachment of gear rims to wheel hubs in large gears. An interference fit is a type of fixed joint that not only demands precise positioning and reliable clamping but also ensures that the assembly process does not compromise the strength or accuracy of the components, while allowing for easy and rapid installation. The mating surfaces in interference connections can take various forms, including cylindrical, conical, and other specialized shapes. The assembly technical requirements for interference fit connections are as follows: (1) Accurate interference fit must be ensured to meet the design requirements after assembly. (2) The mating surface should have a low surface roughness. (3) Before assembly, ensure that the mating surfaces are clean, and make sure these surfaces are properly lubricated with oil. (4) The pressing process should be continuous, with a speed that is not too fast (typically 2.4 mm/s), and the pressing stroke must be accurately controlled. (5) During the pressing process, ensure that the axis of the shaft aligns perfectly with the axis of the hole. Regularly check using a 90° square to prevent any tilting. (6) For slender and thin-walled components, special attention should be paid to controlling the interference fit and geometric tolerances. During assembly, it's best to press them in vertically to prevent deformation of the parts. 2.3 Maintenance and Assembly of Sliding Bearings Sliding bearings feature a simple structure, ease of manufacturing, convenient assembly and disassembly, strong load-carrying capacity, as well as excellent shock resistance and vibration-absorbing properties. It features smooth operation, stable performance, and high rotational precision, making it ideal for applications involving exceptionally high operating speeds, extremely heavy loads, stringent requirements for shaft rotational accuracy, significant shock and vibration, limited radial space dimensions, or situations requiring split-type installation (such as bearings in crankshafts), as well as environments with specialized operational conditions. The main drawbacks are high starting friction resistance and demanding lubrication and maintenance requirements. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of General-Purpose Components

Condition-Based Maintenance System It is based on reliability theory, condition monitoring, and fault diagnosis, determining the timing and scope of maintenance based on actual technical condition assessments of mechanical and electrical equipment. Given that many complex mechanical and electrical systems typically experience only early or occasional failures—without a wear-out phase—regular, scheduled maintenance often proves ineffective against such faults. Moreover, in modern mechanical and electrical systems, only a small number of component failures pose safety risks; thus, maintenance tasks should be tailored specifically to the functional requirements of each part, considering potential functional failures, their root causes, and their consequences. This maintenance approach is characterized by flexible decision-making regarding maintenance cycles, procedures, and scopes—adapting dynamically to the actual conditions of the equipment. It shifts the focus of maintenance activities from routine repairs and upkeep to proactive inspections, underpinned by the implementation of a systematic inspection system. Not only does this inspection process provide critical information for determining optimal maintenance timing and scope, but it also allows certain maintenance tasks to be carried out incrementally and efficiently. By conducting daily, periodic, and precision inspections of mechanical and electrical equipment, combined with thorough analysis of condition-monitoring and fault-diagnosis data, operators can accurately assess the degree of degradation and proactively address issues before they escalate into full-blown failures. This approach ensures that equipment remains reliably operational while maximizing the lifespan of its components—making it far more efficient and cost-effective than traditional planned preventive maintenance strategies. To successfully implement condition-based maintenance, several prerequisites must be met: robust reliability testing data and comprehensive documentation are essential for effectively managing the mechanical and electrical systems. 2.3 Maintenance and Assembly of Sliding Bearings Sliding bearings feature a simple structure, ease of manufacturing, convenient assembly and disassembly, strong load-carrying capacity, as well as excellent shock resistance and vibration-absorbing properties. 1.3.4 Fracture of Mechanical Parts Fracture refers to the phenomenon where a mechanical component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under the influence of certain factors. It is one of the primary modes of mechanical component failure—once a part fractures, it not only completely loses its functionality but can also lead to significant economic losses and even cause accidents resulting in injuries or fatalities. Particularly as modern manufacturing systems continue to evolve toward higher power levels and faster rotational speeds, the operating conditions for components have changed dramatically, increasing the likelihood of fracture-related failures. As a result, fracture failure has become a hot topic of research today. The fracture surface formed after a part breaks can accurately capture the dynamic evolution of the failure process. By analyzing the fracture surface, it is possible to identify the primary cause of the fracture, providing valuable insights that help refine designs and enable effective repairs. Based on the cause of failure, fractures can be categorized into types such as brittle fracture and fatigue fracture. Brittle Fracture Before fracturing, the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation; this type of fracture, which develops extremely rapidly, is known as brittle fracture.  Brittle fracture occurs without any prior warning signs, making it a sudden and highly dangerous form of failure. Metal parts may become brittle—and thus prone to sudden fracture— due to improper manufacturing processes, exposure to corrosive media during use, or adverse environmental conditions. For instance, the penetration of hydrogen or hydrides into met al materials can lead to  "hydrogen embrittlement, " while chloride ions infiltrating austenitic stainless steel may cause  "chloride stress corrosion cracking. " Similarly, nitrate ions entering carbon steel can trigger  "nitrate embrittlement, " and steel in contact with alkaline substances might suffer from  "alkali embrittlement. " Additionally, copper components exposed to ammonia can experience  "ammonia-induced embrittlement. " Furthermore, at ambient temperatures between 10°C and 15°C, medium- to low-strength carbon steels are particularly susceptible to  "cold embrittlement " (often caused by elevated phosphorus content in the steel). Meanwhile, aluminum-containing alloys, if not carefully temperature-controlled during heat treatment, can easily overh eat—even with only a slight deviation from the optimal range—leading to severe embrittlement. The hazards posed by brittle fracture in metals are significant, second only to those  associated with fatigue failure. Fatigue Fracture The fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses is known as fatigue failure. In fact, 80% of fractures in mechanical components during use are caused by fatigue. Typically, fatigue failure progresses through three distinct stages: the initiation phase of fatigue cracks; the propagation phase of fatigue cracks; and finally, catastrophic failure—the unstable, rapid growth phase of the fatigue crack. Below, we will analyze the fracture surfaces associated with fatigue failure. A typical fatigue fracture typically exhibits 3 distinct features based on the fracture process. Regions with distinct characteristics: fatigue core zone, fatigue crack propagation Zone and transient zone, as shown in Figure 1.4. Fatigue Core Zone It is the source region of fatigue fracture, visible to the naked eye or under low magnification. A magnifying glass can pinpoint the location of the fatigue core on the fracture surface—it typically does. Appearing in the area with the lowest intensity, highest stress, and closest to the surface Position. But if there are defects inside the material, this fatigue core... It could also occur at the defect site. Scratches left behind during the machining, storage, transportation, and assembly processes are highly likely to become fatigue nuclei, as these marks not only cause stress concentrations but also remain vulnerable to corrosion damage from air and other environmental factors. Figure 1.4: Schematic Diagram of Fatigue Fracture Features (Uniaxial Bending)
1.4.3 General Principles and Requirements for Mechanical Equipment Disassembly Any piece of machine ry is assembled from numerous components. When machinery requires maintenance, it must first be disassembled so that faulty parts can be repaired or replaced. The primary purpose o f dismantling machinery is to facilitate the inspection and repair of its components; in fact, the disassembly process typically accounts for about 20% of the total maintenance wor kload. Therefore, to ensure high-quality repairs, it’s essential to carefully plan ahead and anticipate potential challenges before starting to take apart the equipment. This way,  the dismantling can proceed methodically—following a structured approach that adheres to the following rules and guidelines. Preparations Before Disassembly (1) Selection and Cleanup of the Disassembly Site. Before disassembly, choose an appropriate work area—avoid locations prone to windblown sand or dust. The workspace should be kept free from frequent unauthorized access by unrelated personnel to prevent unnecessary disruptions or accidents. Additionally, ensure that the ground in the work area remains clean, free from dirt, oil, or other contaminants. Prior to entering the disassembly site, all machinery must undergo an external cleaning process to guarantee that the disassembly procedure does not compromise the equipment’s precision. (2) Protective Measures: Before cleaning the exterior of mechanical equipment, electrical devices should be either removed or properly protected to prevent moisture damage. Additionally, parts prone to oxidation and rust should promptly undergo appropriate protective and maintenance measures. (3) Draining the oil before disassembly. Whenever possible, drain the lubricating oil from the machinery while it’s still hot prior to disassembly, ensuring smoother and more efficient removal work. (4) Understand the structure, performance, and operating principles of mechanical equipment. To avoid unnecessary disassembly and ensure the smooth progress of maintenance work, thoroughly assess all aspects of the machinery before dismantling. Familiarize yourself with the structural features of each component, the transmission system, as well as the specific design characteristics and interrelationships of individual parts. Clearly identify their intended functions and how they interact with one another, enabling you to plan the disassembly process logically and select the appropriate tools or equipment for the job. During operation,机电设备 inevitably experience gradual wear, deformation, fracture, corrosion, and other forms of failure in their components. As a result, the equipment's precision,  performance, and productivity decline, potentially leading to malfunctions, accidents, or even complete报废 (scrapping). This underscores the critical need for timely maintenance and  repairs. In restorative maintenance, all measures are aimed at restoring the equipment as quickly and cost-effectively as possible. Effectively eliminate failures to enhance the e quipment's overall utilization rate. Additionally, implementing repair techniques to restore failed components can efficiently achieve this goal. When repairing damage or defects i n mechanical parts, several methods and techniques may be available, but determining the best approach depends on considering the following factors. (1) Consider the compatibility  of the selected repair technique with the part material. When choosing a repair method, the first step should be to determine whether the technique is suitable for the material of  the component being repaired. For instance, manual arc welding is ideal for low-carbon steel, medium-carbon steel, and alloy structural steels—A Case Study Guide for Fault Diagnosi s and Maintenance of Mechanical and Electrical Systems. 38 And stainless steel. Arc surfacing under a flux layer is suitable for low-carbon and medium-carbon steels. Chrome plating  technology works well with carbon structural steels, alloy structural steels, stainless steels, and gray cast iron. Bonded repair methods can firmly join parts made of various met allic and non-metallic materials. Spray coating has a broad applicability—almost any type of metal part, including carbon steel, alloy steel, cast iron components, and the vast maj ority of non-ferrous metal parts, can be coated. However, among metals, only a few non-ferrous materials pose challenges for spraying, such as pure copper; additionally, materials  primarily composed of tungsten or molybdenum are also difficult to coat effectively. (2) Consider the patching layer thicknesses that each repair technique can provide. Since the d egree of wear varies across different parts, the required thickness of the repair layer to compensate for wear will also differ. Therefore, when selecting a repair technique, it’s  important to understand the maximum patching layer thickness achievable by each method.

reference_contexts: ['Before installation, burrs and sharp edges on the parts of the sliding bearing should be removed, and the contact surfaces must be smooth and clean.', 'When installing the bearing housing, the bearing or bushing should be fitted onto the housing and aligned according to the center position of the bushing or shaft sleeve.', 'All bearings on the same transmission shaft must lie on a single axis, with their coaxial error remaining within the specified tolerance range.']
reference: The installation of sliding bearings requires strict adherence to multiple technical requirements. Before installation, all burrs and sharp edges must be removed from bearing components, and all contact surfaces must be smooth and clean. During housing installation, the bearing or bushing must be properly fitted and precisely aligned according to the center position of the bushing or shaft sleeve. All bearings on the same transmission shaft must maintain perfect coaxial alignment within specified tolerance limits. The bearing housing's bottom surface requires proper alignment with machine components, ensuring even, tight contact surfaces and secure fixed connections that prevent any loosening or shifting during operation. Contact quality between bearing and shaft surfaces must be verified using the dye-penetration method to ensure the number of contact points meets specifications. Crucially, during shaft rotation, absolutely no rotation of the bearing bush or shaft sleeve is permitted, ensuring stable operation.
answer: The basic installation requirements for sliding bearings are to remove burrs and sharp edges before installation, align the bearing housing to the center position ensuring all bearings on the same shaft are coaxial, check the contact between the bearing and shaft surface using the dye-penetration method to meet specified contact points, ensure the bearing housing bottom aligns properly with machine components for even and tight contact with secure fixed connections, and prevent the bearing bush or shaft sleeve from rotating when the shaft is rotating.

2. Installation of Integral Sliding Bearings (1) Press-fit the sleeve. When the sleeve dimensions and interference fit are relatively small, a press-fitting method can be used—installing the sleeve by applying pressure with a press or gently tapping it into place using a hardwood block. For larger dimensions and interference fits, or when installing thin-walled sleeves, the thermal expansion method is recommended: cool the sleeve in dry ice or liquid nitrogen before fitting it into the bearing housing. During the press-fitting process, ensure that the mating surfaces are clean and apply a thin layer of lubricant to prevent the sleeve from becoming skewed. (2) Sleeve positioning. After pressing the sleeve into place, its position should be secured using the fastening screws or locating pins as specified in the drawing, to prevent the sleeve from rotating along with the shaft. The method for fixing the sleeve is shown in Figure 2.4. Figure 2.4: Method of Shaft Sleeve Fixation (3) Bore the bushing hole. After the bushing is press-fitted, the interference fit on the outer wall may cause the inner bore to shrink or deform. Therefore, reaming or scraping should be performed to ensure that the contact points between the bushing and the journal meet the specified standards. 3. Diagnosis and Maintenance of Sliding Bearings 1) The contact angle of the plain bearing bush does not meet the requirements. (1) Phenomenon: The contact angle between the bearing bush and the journal does not meet the standard requirements. (2) Cause analysis: Failure to follow the operational guidelines strictly during scraping, careless work practices, and weak foundational skills in the relevant techniques. (3) Harmfulness. If the contact angle between the bearing bush and the journal is too large, it becomes difficult for a lubricating oil film to form, resulting in inadequate lubrication. As a result, bearing wear is accelerated. If the contact angle is too small, it increases the pressure on the bearing, which in turn leads to rapid wear of the bearing as well. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: The contact angle between the bearing bush and the journal should be appropriately sized, typically maintained between 60° and 90°. For high-speed, low-load applications, The bearing contact angle can be set at 60°, while for low-speed, heavy-duty bearings, a contact angle of 90° is recommended. Babbitt metal scraping should be performed only after the equipment has been precisely leveled. The scraping process involves two key areas: first, scraping the contact surface between the babbitt backing (babbitt back) and the bearing housing; and second, scraping the contact area between the babbitt lining and the journal. The scraping and lapping of the bearing shell with the bearing housing should also not be overlooked. Specific requirements are as follows: the contact area between the lower bearing shell and the bearing seat must be at least 50% of the total surface area, while the contact area between the upper bearing shell and the bearing cap should be no less than 40%. Additionally, the contact points between the bearing shells and both the bearing housing and bearing cap should ideally consist of 1 to 2 points per cm². If the contact area is too small or the number of contact points is insufficient, it will cause the bearing bush to... Increased pressure per unit area accelerates the wear of the bearing bushing. When scraping the bearing bushing, all components on the shaft should be fully assembled. Typically, scraping begins with the lower half of the bushing before moving to the upper half. During the scraping process, a thin layer of red lead oil can be applied to the journal, and the journal is gently inserted into the bushing. Then, the shaft is rotated—first in one direction, then in the opposite—to ensure even contact across both halves of the bushing. This allows the bushing and journal to rub against each other. Afterward, the shaft is carefully lifted, and based on the condition of the scraped surface, it’s determined whether the contact angle and contact points meet the specified requirements. If they don’t, further adjustments using additional steps are necessary.

user_input: What causes bearing overheating during equipment trial operation?
reference_contexts: ['Excessive or insufficient lubricating oil inside the bearing, or even complete absence of oil; impure lubricant can also lead to bearing overheating; and improper bearing assembly (such as misalignment, skewing, or lack of clearance).']
reference: Bearing overheating during equipment trial operation can be caused by several factors related to lubrication and assembly. These include having too much or too little lubricating oil inside the bearing, a complete absence of oil, or the presence of impure lubricant. Additionally, improper bearing assembly issues such as misalignment, skewing, or insufficient clearance can also lead to overheating.
answer: Bearing overheating during equipment trial operation is caused by excessive or insufficient lubricating oil, impure lubricant, and improper bearing assembly such as misalignment, skewing, or lack of clearance.

Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance 53 The ABC analysis categoriz es inventory spare parts into 3 classes. (1) Class A Spare Parts. Class A spare parts are a small but critical subset of components, characterized by their high importance, challen ging procurement and manufacturing processes, elevated costs, and extended lead times for stockpiling. Although these parts account for approximately 10% of all spare part types, t hey consume around 80% of the total budget allocated to spare parts. Therefore, Class A items require stringent control measures. Employing inventory theory, carefully determine op timal stock levels and ordering schedules, while maintaining minimal safety stock levels. Additionally, strive to reduce order cycles by increasing the frequency of purchases, ther eby accelerating the turnover of spare parts inventory funds. In warehouse management, ensure meticulous recording of all incoming and outgoing spare parts, conduct thorough statis tical analysis and calculations of inventory levels, and rigorously implement preventive measures to protect components against corrosion and rust. (2) Category B spare parts. Thes e have a wider variety than Category A spare parts, accounting for about 25% of the total product range, but they require less capital investment—typically around 15% of the total  funds allocated to spare parts. Category B spare parts usually maintain a higher safety stock level, though their reserves can be managed more flexibly. Additionally, based on main tenance needs, the ordering cycle can be appropriately extended to reduce the frequency of purchases. (3) Category C spare parts. These account for approximately 65% of all part va rieties but represent only about 5% of the total funds allocated to spare parts. For Category C items, inventory levels can be maintained at a slightly higher level based on mainte nance needs, and order lead times can be extended accordingly. The focus of spare parts management should be placed on managing Class A and Class B spare parts.
1) Verify the fault symptoms or signs Given the complexity and subtlety of hydraulic system failures, it is essential to first verify the specific symptoms or signs of the malfunction. This can be done by asking operators and maintenance personnel about recent changes in the machine’s performance, its maintenance history, any specific actions taken after the initial failure signs appeared, and the components that have already been inspected and adjusted. 2) Identify fault diagnosis parameters Hydraulic system failures are all classified as parameter-based faults, and useful fault information is extracted by measuring relevant parameters. Diagnostic parameters for hydraulic systems include system pressure, system flow rate, component temperature rise, component leakage, system vibration and noise, as well as motor speed. When selecting diagnostic parameters, the following principles should be followed: the parameters must exhibit high sensitivity, ease of measurement, and good reproducibility, while also being capable of capturing as much fault-related information as possible. 3) Analyze and determine the possible location and extent of the fault. Analyze the detected results by referring to the hydraulic system schematic, examining both the structural and system principles to ensure accurate fault diagnosis and minimize misdiagnoses. 4) Develop a rational diagnostic process and diagnostic methods Select instruments and meters for diagnostic use The diagnostic instruments and equipment include photoelectric digital tachometers, thermometers, stopwatches, pressure gauges, hydraulic testers, various types of connectors, specialized tools, and more. The selection principle is as follows: First, choose instruments that do not require any disassembly of system components; second, opt for instruments that need to be connected directly into the system; and finally, use hydraulic measuring devices. In cases where the fault is particularly complex, a hydraulic tester can also be used initially for diagnosis. It’s crucial to note that before analyzing and identifying the exact location and extent of the failure, absolutely avoid any unnecessary disassembly, dismantling, or unauthorized adjustments of hydraulic components. Doing so could inadvertently worsen the problem, introduce new issues, or even complicate the original fault further. reference: Bearing overheating has serious hazardous effects due to the material properties of bearings, which generally have lower strength and hardness than shaft materials. 4) Shaft Heating (1) Phenomenon: The transmission shaft heats up during operation. (2) Cause analysis. On one hand, the oil-seal pad or rubber ring on the shaft is too tight, causing heat generation due to friction during rotation. On the other hand, the clearance between the bearing cap and the shaft varies unevenly around the circumference, leading to shaft abrasion and, consequently, shaft heating. (3) Hazardous Effects. When the shaft's temperature rises, it reduces the shaft's hardness, accelerates wear, and also leads to damage in other components connected to the shaft. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: Replace the spring inside the rubber ring with a looser one, or loosen the bearing cap screws. Also, check whether the clearance between the bearing cap and the shaft complies with the specifications outlined in the equipment’s technical documentation. If it does not meet the requirements, make sure to adjust it carefully.

1.2 Basics of Equipment Maintenance 1.2.1 Maintenance Method The method of equipment maintenance carries the meaning of a maintenance strategy. Modern equipment management emphasizes applying different maintenance approaches to various types of equipment, underscoring that equipment repair should align with the objective principles governing the physical lifecycle of machinery and materials. This approach ensures production continuity while optimizing the efficient use of maintenance resources, ultimately achieving the most cost-effective outcome over the equipment's entire lifespan. Commonly used maintenance methods for electromechanical equipment include the following: Reactive Maintenance Post-failure maintenance, also known as breakdown maintenance, damage repair, or unplanned maintenance, refers to repairs carried out after mechanical and electrical equipment has malfunctioned—essentially, "if it breaks, we fix it." For certain critical equipment, post-failure maintenance should be minimized whenever possible; however, for devices that have minimal impact on production or are backed up by redundant units, opting for post-failure maintenance is often the most cost-effective approach. Preventive Maintenance Maintenance performed before mechanical and electrical equipment fails is called preventive maintenance. Its main benefits include reducing unexpected equipment failures, ensuring continuous production, integrating equipment upkeep and repair tasks into a structured plan—thereby minimizing unplanned disruptions in production—and ultimately improving equipment utilization, lowering maintenance costs, and extending the equipment's natural lifespan. Preventive maintenance is categorized into two basic forms: Regular maintenance Regular maintenance is also known as planned maintenance or time-based preventive maintenance. It involves carrying out preventive maintenance activities at predetermined intervals and follows a cyclical pattern. This type of maintenance is based on the wear patterns of components, with specific guidelines for setting maintenance intervals, defining maintenance categories, outlining maintenance tasks, and estimating the associated workload. However, this approach to maintenance can lead to certain challenges: First, when equipment is still in good technical condition and fully capable of continuing operation, it may undergo major over-maintenance simply because the scheduled interval has arrived—resulting in unnecessary repairs. Second, if a machine’s technical condition has already deteriorated to the point where it can no longer meet production requirements, but the prescribed maintenance interval hasn’t yet been reached, no repair plan will be implemented, leading to under-maintenance. This method is particularly well-suited for process-oriented production equipment or power systems where the wear patterns are well understood, and operations are stable and contin uous—such as large-scale assembly line equipment or key machinery operating on automated production lines. Currently, China primarily implements two main types of equipment mainten ance systems: the Planned Preventive Maintenance System and the Planned Warranty System. (1) Planned Preventive Maintenance System (referred to as Planned Pre-Maintenance). This sy stem involves maintaining, inspecting, and repairing equipment according to its wear patterns, adhering to predetermined maintenance cycles and procedures, to ensure that the equip ment consistently remains in optimal technical condition. Its key features are outlined below. ① Perform daily cleaning, inspection, lubrication, tightening, and adjustments on equ ipment as required to minimize wear and ensure proper operation. ② Conduct regular inspections and adjustments of the equipment's operational status and wear levels according to th e prescribed schedule, ensuring that potential issues are promptly addressed. This allows you to monitor changes in the equipment's technical condition and adequately prepare the n ecessary resources for scheduled maintenance. ③ Conduct preventive maintenance on equipment in a planned and prepared manner. (2) The Planned Maintenance System (also known as the  Maintenance and Repair System) is a equipment maintenance approach that combines routine upkeep with scheduled inspections and repairs. Its key features are outlined below. ① Based  on the equipment's characteristics and condition, different maintenance categories and intervals are specified according to operational hours (such as production output and mileag e).
① Ensure proper installation to prevent the development of additional stress and vibration. For critical components, avoid dents and scratches, as even the smallest damage could become a potential fracture point. ② Care should be taken to protect the equipment's operating environment, preventing erosion from corrosive media and avoiding excessive temperature differences between its various components. ③ To prevent equipment overload, strictly follow the equipment operating procedures. ④ Take timely corrective measures for parts with cracks.
1.4.1 Preparations Before Mechanical Equipment Maintenance Electromechanical equipment occupies a critically important position in the production and operational activities of modern industrial enterprises. To ensure smooth equipment operation and safe production, implementing planned preventive maintenance is an essential component of equipment management and repair practices in industrial companies. This section will cover the detailed process of major equipment overhauls, the determination of equipment repair plans, as well as the technical and material preparations required prior to equipment maintenance. 1. Equipment Major Overhaul Process To ensure the precision and operational performance of mechanical and electrical equipment, preventive scheduled maintenance must be carried out in addition to routine upkeep. Among these preventive measures, major overhauls stand out as a critical task aimed at restoring the equipment's accuracy. Within the category of preventive maintenance, major overhauls—often referred to simply as "overhauls"—represent the most extensive and time-consuming type of repair. An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit. The ultimate goal is to thoroughly eliminate any pre-existing defects and restore the equipment to its specified performance standards. The purpose of precision and performance. The major steps involved in the overhaul of mechanical and electrical equipment typically include: pre-disassembly unit inspection, component removal, component inspection, necessary component disassembly, parts cleaning and examination, component repair and assembly, final assembly, no-load trial operation, load testing, overall machine precision verification, and final acceptance. In practice, these tasks should be carried out according to the overhaul work plan, while also ensuring effective job scheduling, quality control during operations, and thorough completion acceptance. The major overhaul process for mechanical and electrical equipment is typically divided into three stages: pre-repair preparation, the repair process itself, and post-repair acceptance. Pre-repair preparation phase To ensure the repair work proceeds smoothly and accurately, maintenance personnel should carefully listen to operators' requirements for equipment repairs and thoroughly understand the issues affecting the equipment being serviced—such as loss of precision, the extent of wear on major mechanical components, the accuracy of the transmission system, and any visible defects. They should also identify which parts need improvement or modification to meet the equipment’s operational specifications. Additionally, they should review relevant technical documentation, equipment manuals, and previous maintenance records to become familiar with the device’s structural features, transmission system, and original design precision standards. This preparation will enable them to propose comprehensive pre-inspection tasks. Following the pre-inspection, specific repair methods for critical and large components can be determined, allowing for the preparation of specialized tools and precision measuring instruments. Finally, the team must define the post-repair precision testing procedures and establish clear acceptance criteria for trial runs, ensuring all technical preparations are fully in place before proceeding with the complete overhaul of the equipment.

user_input: What are the main components of a rolling bearing and their functions?
reference_contexts: ['The inner ring 1 is mounted on the shaft; the outer ring 2 is fitted into the bearing housing bore; the rolling elements鈥?The rolling element No. 3 is housed between the inner and outer rings; the cage No. 4 evenly spaces the rolling elements.']
reference: A rolling bearing consists of four main components: the inner ring, which is mounted on the shaft; the outer ring, which is fitted into the bearing housing bore; the rolling elements, which are housed between the inner and outer rings to facilitate smooth rotation; and the cage, which evenly spaces the rolling elements to maintain proper alignment and prevent contact between them, ensuring efficient operation and longevity of the bearing.
answer: The main components of a rolling bearing are the inner ring which is mounted on the shaft, the outer ring which is fitted into the bearing housing bore, the rolling elements which are housed between the inner and outer rings, and the cage which evenly spaces the rolling elements.

Rolling bearing: 70°C vs. 40°C (3) The machine tool's feed mechanism should undergo no-load tests at low, medium, and high feed speeds, while the rapid traverse mechanism should be tested under no-load conditions at its maximum rapid-speed setting. (4) During the machine tool's operational test, all mechanisms undergo startup, stopping, braking, automatic motion, gear-shift transitions, and rapid movements. All should be flexible and reliable. (5) All hydraulic, lubrication, and cooling systems must be free of leaks. (6) The pneumatic system and piping must not have any air leaks. (7) The machine tool's safety guards and protective devices must be complete, secure, and function reliably and sensitively. (8) The machine tool's accuracy must be checked both before and after the load test. For machine tools that do not undergo a load test, accuracy verification should be performed after the no-load running test. 2. Precision Inspection of Mechanical Equipment Maintenance After major overhauls of mechanical equipment, acceptance checks are conducted according to established standards, with each type of equipment having its own specific acceptance criteria and inspection methods. Take metal cutting machine tools as an example: the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established various precision testing standards for different types of machine tools, along with general guidelines for machine tool accuracy verification. Similarly, China has developed its own standards that are either equivalent to or closely aligned with international benchmarks. These standards specify the inspection items, criteria, methods, and tolerances for machine tool accuracy—serving as the fundamental basis for conducting precision tests. Currently, machine tool maintenance is carried out based on both geometric and operational precision standards during acceptance procedures. Inspection of Machine Tool Geometric Accuracy Geometric accuracy of machine tools refers to the precision of the components that ultimately affect the machine's operational accuracy. It encompasses individual accuracies of basic structural elements, positional accuracy between various parts, as well as motion accuracy, positioning accuracy, indexing accuracy, and transmission chain accuracy. Typically, geometric accuracy checks are performed while the machine tool is stationary. Before conducting these inspections, it’s essential to first ensure proper installation and leveling. Follow the machine tool’s instruction manual carefully to install the equipment on a suitable foundation and achieve precise leveling. The primary goal of leveling is to guarantee the machine’s static stability, which facilitates accurate measurements during testing—especially those related to the straightness of machine components. Additionally, national standards have standardized methods for inspecting both geometric and operational accuracy of machine tools, providing a reliable reference for conducting geometric accuracy tests. Machine Tool Testing Since the geometric accuracy of machine tools is checked under static conditions, it cannot fully reflect the quality of machine tool maintenance. To determine  whether a machine tool can maintain its original geometric accuracy under operational conditions and load applications, it must be evaluated through various machine tool tests. Th e key components of machine tool maintenance testing include no-load running tests, load tests, and working precision tests. (1) No-load operation test of the machine tool. The pur pose of the no-load operation test is to further verify the correct functioning of each component of the machine tool. Sex, reliability, ease and normality of operation, as well as  whether the temperature rise and noise levels of each moving component are within acceptable limits. The primary focus of the machine tool's no-load running test is to simultaneou sly check the operational status of relevant parts while testing the spindle and feed speeds. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Mechanical and Electrical Equipment Fault Diagnosis and Mai ntenance 35 Before conducting the no-load operation test of the machine tool, ensure that all major overhaul tasks have been completed and that each repair has met the required qua lity standards. Next, fill all oil reservoirs with lubricant and properly grease all lubrication points. It is crucial to note: Only after completing all necessary preparations in  accordance with the safety operating procedures can you proceed with the no-load tests as outlined by the precision inspection standards specific to the machine tool being used. (2 ) Machine Tool Load Testing. The machine tool load test evaluates whether the machine’s main motion system can achieve the maximum torque and power allowed by the design, as well a s checks if all machine components are functioning properly under these conditions, whether there are any positional changes between parts, and if such changes remain within the pe rmissible limits. Additionally, it ensures that vibrations, noise levels, and temperature rise remain within normal operating ranges. The machine tool load test primarily involves  performing a cutting-load test, where tools and cutting parameters are selected according to specified requirements to machine the surface of test specimens made from a particular  material and in a specific size. During the load test, the spindle speed and feed rate are allowed to deviate by no more than 5% compared to the theoretical values. (3) Machine Too l Working Accuracy Test. The purpose of the machine tool working accuracy test is to determine whether the positional accuracy between the machine’s various components during the m achining process meets the precision requirements of the parts being manufactured. Before the test, its geometric accuracy must be rechecked. The machine tool working accuracy test  involves machining the surface of a specified test piece using cutting tools and appropriate cutting parameters, as outlined in the machine tool accuracy testing standards for wor king precision requirements. The geometric accuracy of the machined workpiece surface must fall within the tolerance range specified by the precision standards of the machine tool  used, and the surface roughness value should not exceed the prescribed standard.
General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment

user_input: What are the main categories of rolling bearings based on the direction of load or contact angle?
reference_contexts: ['Radial bearings. Radial contact bearings primarily withstand radial loads. Well, some can handle smaller axial loads; angular contact radial bearings. The bearing can simultaneously handle both radial and axial loads.', 'Thrust bearings. Thrust angular contact bearings primarily handle axial loads. The bearing can also handle smaller radial loads; axial thrust bearings, however, are designed only to withstand axial loads.']
reference: Rolling bearings are categorized into two main types based on the direction of load or nominal contact angle. Radial bearings primarily withstand radial loads, with some types capable of handling smaller axial loads. Angular contact radial bearings can simultaneously handle both radial and axial loads. Thrust bearings primarily handle axial loads, with thrust angular contact bearings also capable of handling smaller radial loads, while axial thrust bearings are designed exclusively for axial loads.
answer: The main categories of rolling bearings based on the direction of load or contact angle are radial bearings and thrust bearings.

user_input: How should rolling bearing types be selected based on load conditions?
reference_contexts: ['If the bearing is subjected to axial loads, thrust bearings are typically selected; if the load is purely axial, For smaller loads, thrust ball bearings are recommended; if the pure axial load is significant, thrust roller bearings should be chosen.', 'When the bearing is subjected to pure radial loads, deep groove ball bearings, cylindrical roller bearings, or needle roller bearings are typically used.', 'If the bearing handles both radial and moderate axial loads simultaneously, deep groove ball bearings, angular contact ball bearings with small contact angles, or tapered roller bearings are suitable options.']
reference: Bearing selection based on load conditions follows specific guidelines: For pure axial loads, thrust bearings are used - thrust ball bearings for smaller loads and thrust roller bearings for significant loads. Pure radial loads typically require deep groove ball bearings, cylindrical roller bearings, or needle roller bearings. When handling both radial and moderate axial loads simultaneously, suitable options include deep groove ball bearings, angular contact ball bearings with small contact angles, or tapered roller bearings. For heavier axial loads, angular contact ball bearings with larger contact angles or tapered roller bearings are ideal. Alternatively, a combined design using both radial and thrust bearings can be employed, where each bearing type specifically handles either radial or axial loads.
answer: Rolling bearing types should be selected based on load conditions by matching bearing characteristics with operating conditions: for pure axial loads, thrust bearings are selected, with thrust ball bearings recommended for smaller loads and thrust roller bearings for significant loads; for pure radial loads, deep groove ball bearings, cylindrical roller bearings, or needle roller bearings are typically used; for combined radial and moderate axial loads, deep groove ball bearings, angular contact ball bearings with small contact angles, or tapered roller bearings are suitable; for heavier axial loads, angular contact ball bearings with larger contact angles or tapered roller bearings are ideal; and for heavy loads or impact loads, roller bearings should be used.

user_input: What factors influence the fit selection for rolling bearings?
reference_contexts: ["The bearing fit refers to the mating between the inner ring and the journal, as well as the outer ring and the housing, influencing the bearing's radial clearance, operational accuracy, and service life.", 'When designing, the type and size of the bearing, as well as the magnitude of the load, should guide the selection of the appropriate fit.', 'For applications with large dimensions, heavy loads, significant vibrations, high rotational speeds, or elevated operating temperatures, a tighter fit is recommended.']
reference: The selection of fit for rolling bearings is influenced by several factors including the bearing's type and size, the magnitude of the load it will bear, and the operational conditions. For applications characterized by large dimensions, heavy loads, significant vibrations, high rotational speeds, or elevated operating temperatures, a tighter fit is recommended to ensure stability and performance. However, an excessively tight fit can impair the bearing's function and complicate assembly and disassembly. Conversely, for components that require frequent removal or where there is movement in the raceways, a looser fit is advisable. Yet, too much looseness can negatively affect rotational accuracy and increase vibration. Thus, the fit must be carefully balanced to optimize bearing performance, accuracy, and service life.
answer: The type and size of the bearing, the magnitude of the load, large dimensions, heavy loads, significant vibrations, high rotational speeds, elevated operating temperatures, components that require frequent removal, and raceways that experience movement influence the fit selection for rolling bearings.

Fit of Rolling Bearings The bearing fit refers to the mating between the inner ring and the journal, as well as the outer ring and the housing, influencing the bearing's radial clearance, operational accuracy, and service life. Rolling bearings are standard components, and the fit between the bearing bore and the shaft follows the hole basis system, while the fit between the outer ring and the bearing housing uses the shaft basis system. Since the tolerance zone for the bearing inner diameter lies below the zero line, whereas in cylindrical tolerance standards, the tolerance zone for the reference hole is above the zero line, the interference fit between the inner ring and the journal is significantly tighter than the corresponding hole-basis fits specified in cylindrical tolerance standards. Figures 2.6 and 2.7 illustrate the fit of rolling bearings and their relationship to deviations in the dimensions of the journal or housing bore relative to the bearing’s reference surfaces (inner ring inner diameter, outer ring outer diameter). When designing, the type and size of the bearing, as well as the magnitude of the load, should guide the selection of the appropriate fit. For applications with large dimensions, heavy loads, significant vibrations, high rotational speeds, or elevated operating temperatures, a tighter fit is recommended. However, excessively tight fits can impair the bearing’s proper function and also make assembly and disassembly more challenging. On the other hand, for components that require frequent removal or where the raceways experience movement, a looser fit should be chosen. However, excessive looseness is detrimental to improving bearing rotational accuracy and reducing vibration. As shown in Figure 2.7, the rotating shaft typically fitted with the inner ring of the bearing is Use interference fits N6, M6, K6, or k5, or transition fits j5 and J6; bearing housing bores that are paired with non-rotating outer rings typically employ transition fits J6 and J7, or clearance fits such as H7 and G7. Figure 2.6: Fit between the outer ring of the rolling bearing and the bearing housing, and between the inner ring of the rolling bearing and the shaft Figure 2.7: Case Studies in Mechanical and Electrical System Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance—Diagnosing Failures in the Fit Between the Bearing Inner Race and Rotating Shaft, as Well as Between the Bearing and Stationary Outer Race, Tutorial 64 2.4.2 Failure Modes of Rolling Bearings
The main factors influencing rolling bearing failure include load conditions, lubrication, assembly practices, environmental factors, and material quality or manufacturing precision. When determining bearing dimensions, it's essential to perform the necessary calculations tailored to the primary failure modes. For rotating rolling bearings under typical operating conditions, both contact fatigue life and static strength analyses are usually required. In contrast, for oscillating or low-speed bearings, only a static strength calculation is sufficient. Meanwhile, high-speed bearings are prone to adhesive wear and scoring caused by heat generation, making these failure modes their main concerns. Therefore, in addition to conducting life calculations, it’s also crucial to verify the bearing’s limiting speed.

user_input: How does the fit system for rolling bearings differ from standard cylindrical tolerance systems?
reference_contexts: ['Rolling bearings are standard components, and the fit between the bearing bore and the shaft follows the hole basis system, while the fit between the outer ring and the bearing housing uses the shaft basis system.', 'Since the tolerance zone for the bearing inner diameter lies below the zero line, whereas in cylindrical tolerance standards, the tolerance zone for the reference hole is above the zero line, the interference fit between the inner ring and the journal is significantly tighter than the corresponding hole-basis fits specified in cylindrical tolerance standards.']
reference: The fit system for rolling bearings differs from standard cylindrical tolerance systems in its basis and tolerance zone placement. For rolling bearings, the fit between the bearing bore (inner ring) and the shaft follows the hole basis system, meaning the shaft is selected to fit the bearing's hole. Conversely, the fit between the outer ring and the housing uses the shaft basis system, where the housing is selected to fit the bearing's outer diameter. Additionally, the tolerance zone for the bearing's inner diameter is positioned below the zero line, unlike standard cylindrical tolerance systems where the reference hole's tolerance zone is above the zero line. This results in interference fits between the inner ring and journal being significantly tighter than those specified in standard hole-basis fits, ensuring a more secure connection suitable for bearing applications.
answer: The fit system for rolling bearings differs from standard cylindrical tolerance systems because the bearing's inner ring fit follows a hole basis system with its tolerance zone lying below the zero line, making interference fits significantly tighter than standard hole-basis fits, while the outer ring fit uses a shaft basis system.

user_input: What are the load distribution characteristics for pure axial and radial loads in rolling bearings?
reference_contexts: ['Pure axial load: Rolling elements are evenly loaded.', 'Radial load: Uneven loading of rolling elements (loaded and unloaded zones).']
reference: Under pure axial load conditions, all rolling elements in the bearing experience uniform loading, meaning the force is distributed equally across each element. In contrast, radial load creates an uneven distribution where only certain rolling elements within the loaded zone bear the force, while those in the unloaded zone experience minimal or no load, resulting in asymmetric stress patterns.
answer: For a pure axial load, the rolling elements are evenly loaded; for a radial load, there is uneven loading of the rolling elements with loaded and unloaded zones.

user_input: What causes pitting failure in rolling bearings and what are its characteristics?
reference_contexts: ['Pitting: Numerous pitting marks appear on the raceways of both the inner and outer rings, as well as on the surfaces of the rolling elements鈥攑rimarily caused by improper loading, incorrect assembly (e.g., excessive interference fit or misalignment of the inner and outer rings), and inadequate lubrication.']
reference: Pitting failure in rolling bearings is characterized by the appearance of multiple small pits or marks on the raceways of the inner and outer rings and on the rolling elements themselves. This failure is mainly caused by three factors: improper loading conditions that exceed design limits, incorrect assembly practices such as excessive interference fits or misalignment between inner and outer rings leading to uneven stress distribution, and inadequate lubrication which results in increased friction and surface degradation.
answer: Pitting failure in rolling bearings is primarily caused by improper loading, incorrect assembly such as excessive interference fit or misalignment, and inadequate lubrication, and it is characterized by numerous pitting marks appearing on the raceways of both the inner and outer rings as well as on the surfaces of the rolling elements.

1. Load Distribution Pure axial load: Rolling elements are evenly loaded. Radial load: Uneven loading of rolling elements (loaded and unloaded zones). 2. Failure Modes of Rolling Bearings Pitting: Numerous pitting marks appear on the raceways of both the inner and outer rings, as well as on the surfaces of the rolling elements—primarily caused by improper loading, incorrect assembly (e.g., excessive interference fit or misalignment of the inner and outer rings), and inadequate lubrication. Plastic Deformation: Uneven plastic deformation pits appear on the rolling elements or raceway surfaces, primarily due to excessive static or impact loads. The main factors influencing rolling bearing failure include load conditions, lubrication, assembly practices, environmental factors, and material quality or manufacturing precision. When determining bearing dimensions, it's essential to perform the necessary calculations tailored to the primary failure modes. For rotating rolling bearings under typical operating conditions, both contact fatigue life and static strength analyses are usually required. In contrast, for oscillating or low-speed bearings, only a static strength calculation is sufficient. Meanwhile, high-speed bearings are prone to adhesive wear and scoring caused by heat generation, making these failure modes their main concerns. Therefore, in addition to conducting life calculations, it’s also crucial to verify the bearing’s limiting speed.

Fit of Rolli ng Bearings The bearing fit refers to the mating between the inner ring and the journal, as well as the outer ring and the housing, influencing the bearing's radial clearance, oper ational accuracy, and service life. Rolling bearings are standard components, and the fit between the bearing bore and the shaft follows the hole basis system, while the fit betwee n the outer ring and the bearing housing uses the shaft basis system. Since the tolerance zone for the bearing inner diameter lies below the zero line, whereas in cylindrical toler ance standards, the tolerance zone for the reference hole is above the zero line, the interference fit between the inner ring and the journal is significantly tighter than the corr esponding hole-basis fits specified in cylindrical tolerance standards. However, excessively tight fits can impair the bearing’s proper function and also make assembly  and disassembly more challenging. The bearing can simultaneously handle both radial and axial loads. (2) Thrust bearings. Thrust angular contact bearings primarily handle axial loads. The bearing can also handle smaller radial loads; axial thrust bearings, however, are designed only to withstand axial loads. 2) Classified by the shape of the rolling element Rolling bearings can be classified into ball bearings and roller bearings. 3) Classified by Whether the Working Shaft Can Be Centered Rolling bearings can be classified into self-aligning bearings and non-self-aligning bearings. 4) Classification Based on Whether Clearance Can Be Adjusted Rolling bearings can be classified into bearings with adjustable clearance and those with non-adjustable clearance. 3. Selection of Rolling Bearing Types Selection principle: Match bearing characteristics with operating conditions. 1) Type Selection (1) Load conditions. If the bearing is subjected to axial loads, thrust bearings are typically selected; if the load is purely axial, For smaller loads, thrust ball bearings are re commended; if the pure axial load is significant, thrust roller bearings should be chosen. When the bearing is subjected to pure radial loads, deep groove ball bearings, cylindrica l roller bearings, or needle roller bearings are typically used. If the bearing handles both radial and moderate axial loads simultaneously, deep groove ball bearings, angular cont act ball bearings with small contact angles, or tapered roller bearings are suitable options. For situations involving heavier axial loads, angular contact ball bearings with large r contact angles or tapered roller bearings are ideal. Alternatively, a combined design—using both radial and thrust bearings—can be employed, with each type of bearing specificall y handling either the radial or axial load. reference_contexts: ['If the bearing is tightly fitted and has a significant interference fit, the bearing must be heated to induce thermal expansion, causing elastic deformation that allows for easy removal.', 'For instance, you can wrap the shaft near the bearing with asbestos cloth and then heat the inner race of the bearing using an acetylene-oxygen flame鈥攖his method enables disassembly while heating continues.', 'However, it鈥檚 crucial to heat slowly, keeping the temperature around 100掳C to prevent damage to the bearing.']
reference: For tightly fitted rolling bearings with significant interference, the heating disassembly method is recommended. This involves heating the bearing to induce thermal expansion and elastic deformation, facilitating removal. Specifically, wrap the shaft near the bearing with asbestos cloth and apply an acetylene-oxygen flame to heat the inner race, allowing disassembly during heating. It is critical to heat slowly and maintain the temperature at approximately 100掳C to avoid damaging the bearing components.
answer: The recommended methods for disassembling tightly fitted rolling bearings are the Heating Disassembly Method, the Tensioner Disassembly Method, press and pull disassembly, and hot disassembly.

Context:  
How to disassemble a rolling bearing? How to assemble it? When designing bearing assemblies, consider the ease of installation and removal to prevent damage to the bearing and other components during these processes. Bearing installation: Small bearings can be gently and evenly tapped into place using a copper hammer to fit the retaining rings; larger bearings should be pressed in with a hydraulic press. Bearings that are large in size and tightly fitted can be heated to expand the bore before assembly. Bearing installation and removal: Specialized tools can be used; when designing the structure, ensure ease of bearing installation and removal. 1. Disassembling Rolling Bearings Disassembling rolling bearings is an essential part of mechanical maintenance. Since rolling bearings are tightly fitted to the shaft, significant force is required to remove them. If the disassembly method is improper, not only may the bearing fail to come off, but if the fit is particularly tight—with a large interference—the process could also damage the bearing and its associated components. Here, we introduce several commonly used methods for removing bearings. (1) Heating Disassembly Method. If the bearing is tightly fitted and has a significant interference fit, the bearing must be heated to induce thermal expansion, causing elastic deformation that allows for easy removal. For instance, you can wrap the shaft near the bearing with asbestos cloth and then heat the inner race of the bearing using an acetylene-oxygen flame—this method enables disassembly while heating continues. However, it’s crucial to heat slowly, keeping the temperature around 100°C to prevent damage to the bearing. (2) If the bearing has a loose fit, you can carefully tap the fitting ring of the bearing with a wooden mallet to remove it. When tapping, make sure to work evenly around the circumference—avoid focusing on just one spot repeatedly. In some cases, a steel hammer may also be used, but in this scenario, always place a wooden block between the hammer and the bearing to ensure that the force is distributed evenly across the bearing, preventing damage. (3) Select a metal material to create a sleeve, ensuring the inner diameter of the sleeve is slightly larger than the journal diameter. During removal, support the sleeve with an appropriate object. If the fit is loose, gently tap the shaft end with a hammer to detach the bearing; if the fit is tight, apply force to the shaft end using a press or jack. Alternatively, if using the sleeve proves inconvenient, you can also substitute it with two clamping plates. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Commonly Used Components 65 (4) Tensioner Disassembly Method. Use a tensioner to remove the shaft.
