Bearing Cleaning (1) Hot Oil Cleaning Method. For bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease, immerse them in hot motor oil heated to 100–200°C. Use pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away any oil contamination with a brush. When heated to 100–200°C, soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease will melt, allowing it to easily flush out of the bearing’s crevices. In some cases, simply shaking the bearing repeatedly in the oil is enough to dislodge the dirt and grime from between the gaps. When cleaning the radial spherical ball bearings of old or imported electric motors, the balls, retainer, and inner ring should be carefully turned horizontally out of the outer ring before being immersed in hot oil. Similarly, when cleaning short cylindrical roller bearings, the rollers, retainer, inner ring, and outer ring must first be separated from one another. When cleaning with hot oil, the oil temperature should not exceed 20°C. If using an open flame for direct heating, be careful to prevent the oil from catching fire. The bearing should be suspended inside the oil pot—immersing it completely at the bottom could cause overheating and reduce its hardness. (2) General Cleaning Method: Place the bearing in kerosene and soak it for 5–10 minutes. While holding the inner ring with one hand, gently rotate the outer ring with the other—this will cause any soft dry grease or rust-preventive paste on the bearing to fall off. Next, transfer the bearing to a container of cleaner kerosene and use a fine, soft-bristled brush to thoroughly clean away oil stains from the raceways and between the rolling elements. Finally, rinse the bearing once more in gasoline before carefully placing it onto a clean piece of paper. When cleaning spherical ball bearings and short cylindrical roller bearings, separate the balls, retainer cage, inner ring, and outer ring for individual cleaning. For bearings already mounted on a shaft, cleaning is typically done by pouring oil directly over them or using an oil gun for targeted spraying. Start with kerosene to remove easily loosened oil deposits, followed by gasoline for tougher residues. If oil stains persist, first apply hot engine oil heated to 100–200°C via pouring or spraying, then finish with gasoline. Always remember not to scrape off hardened oil buildup or rust from the bearing surfaces using sharp tools, as this could damage the smoothness of the rolling elements and raceway grooves. After cleaning, dry the bearing thoroughly with a clean cloth. 3. Inspection of Rolling Bearings For rolling bearings, focus should be placed on inspecting the inner and outer raceways. The entire working surface must be smooth, free from defects such as cracks, micropores, dents, and peeling. Similarly, the surfaces of the rolling elements themselves should be flawless, with no cracks, micropores, or dents. Additionally, the retainer must remain intact, and all rivets should be securely fastened. If clearance is detected between the inner and outer races of the bearing, avoid replacing it immediately—instead, consider adjusting it through preloading to eliminate any increased clearance caused by wear, thereby enhancing its rotational accuracy. 2.4.4 Assembly of Rolling Bearings Rolling bearings consist of an inner ring, outer ring, rolling elements, and a cage—they are the bearing components that enable relative motion between the shaft and the bearing housing through rolling friction. Rolling bearings offer advantages such as low friction coefficients, high efficiency, compact axial dimensions, and ease of assembly and disassembly, making them widely used in various types of machinery and equipment. As standardized components mass-produced by specialized factories, rolling bearings come with predetermined inner diameters, outer diameters, and axial widths at the time of manufacture. Consequently, the inner ring of a rolling bearing serves as the reference hole, while the outer ring acts as the reference shaft. Figure 2.8: Tutorial on Diagnosing and Repairing Electromechanical System Failures in Tensioners – Bearing Disassembly Case 66
Removal Method (1) Striking and Disengaging. Striking involves using the force of a hammer to create relative movement between mating parts, allowing them to separate and achieve disassembly. This is a straightforward method suitable for simpler structures or when dealing with robust, non-critical components. When striking, proceed with caution—improper technique could easily damage the parts. Common tools used for this method include steel hammers, copper hammers, wooden mallets, punches, as well as copper, aluminum, and wooden shims. When removing rolling bearings by striking, always tap symmetrically from both sides; never concentrate the blows on just one side, as this could lead to cracking of the bearing raceway. (2) Press and pull disassembly. Press and pull methods are superior to impact disassembly because they apply force more evenly, allowing precise control over both the magnitude and direction of the force. As a result, these techniques reduce the risk of part misalignment or damage. This method is particularly suitable for dismantling larger components or parts with significant interference fits. Commonly used tools for this process include press benches and pull molds. (3) Hot disassembly. Hot disassembly leverages the thermal expansion properties of metals to separate parts, preventing issues like parts getting stuck or damaged—something that can occur with methods like impact or press disassembly. This technique is commonly used when the interference fit is significant (exceeding 0.1 mm), the components are large in size, or traditional disassembly methods prove impractical. In summary, choose the appropriate removal method based on how the parts fit together. If it’s a transition fit, you can use a tapping method. Remove the part; if it’s a press-fit assembly, you can use either press-off or heat-based disassembly methods. After removal, place the parts on a wooden board or a low surface. Chapter 2: Troubleshooting and Repair of Commonly Used Components 57 On the platform; smaller parts such as screws, nuts, washers, pins, and others can be placed in dedicated boxes. Long, slender components like spindles and lead screws can be hung vertically to prevent bending or deformation. Disassembly of spindle components: The relative positions of parts such as the housing and spindle are ensured using an error-compensation method. To prevent improper disassembly that could compromise assembly accuracy, make sure to mark the circumferential positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and the spindle itself during disassembly. After removal, arrange the bearings and inner/outer washers separately into their respective groups—never mix them up. Additionally, keep the workbench and surrounding area thoroughly clean during disassembly, and immediately immerse removed parts in oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them precisely according to the original markings. 2.1.3 Cleaning, Inspection, and Repair After Shaft Removal
General Principles for Disassembly (1) Based on the structural characteristics of the mechanical equipment, select a logical disassembly sequence. Typically, the process involves dismantling from the overall unit into subassemblies, then breaking down subassemblies into individual components, and finally separating components into their constituent parts—or alternatively, proceeding from accessories to the main unit and from external elements inward. When disassembling particularly complex components, it’s essential to thoroughly study the assembly drawings and carefully analyze the component’s structure as well as the specific roles its parts play within the assembly. Pay special attention to components that require high precision during assembly. This approach helps prevent confusion, ensures an orderly disassembly process, and ultimately facilitates cleaning, inspection, and identification—laying a solid foundation for effective maintenance work. (2) Rational disassembly. During the maintenance and disassembly of mechanical equipment, adhere to the principle of avoiding unnecessary disassembly while ensuring that components requiring removal are indeed taken apart. (3) Use disassembly tools and equipment correctly. After understanding the steps involved in removing mechanical components, it’s crucial to select and properly apply the appropriate disassembly tools. When dismantling, always opt for specialized or suitably matched tools and equipment whenever possible, avoiding random hammering or forceful techniques to prevent damage or deformation of the parts. For instance, when removing shaft sleeves, rolling bearings, gears, pulleys, and similar components, use pullers or hydraulic presses; and for unscrewing studs or nuts, always prefer wrenches that match their dimensions precisely. Precautions During Disassembly: When performing mechanical equipment maintenance, disassembly should also take into account the subsequent assembly tasks. To ensure a smooth process, keep the following points in mind. (1) Ensure thorough verification or marking of disassembled parts. Mechanical equipment often contains numerous precisely matched components and parts, many of which have been specifically selected or balanced for weight—meaning their assembly positions and orientations must not be altered under any circumstances. Therefore, when dismantling, carefully check parts that already bear original markings. If these markings are unclear, misaligned, or missing altogether, re-mark them exactly as they were originally to ensure proper alignment during reassembly, preventing any confusion or errors. (2) Store parts by category. When storing disassembled parts, follow these principles: Parts belonging to the same type or component should be kept together whenever possible; store items according to their size and precision level; non-interchangeable parts must be stored separately in groups; delicate components that are sensitive to dirt or damage should be removed and stored individually; rubber parts should never be stored alongside oil-bearing components; and ensure that easily lost items are carefully accounted for. Parts such as washers and nuts should be strung together with wire or stored in dedicated containers; all types of studs must be fitted with nuts before being placed in storage. Additionally, parts like steel components, aluminum items, rubber pieces, and leather goods should be stored separately in different containers, categorized by their respective material types. (3) Protect the machined surfaces of removed parts. During disassembly, never damage the machined surfaces of the components being taken apart—doing so could complicate repair work and lead to issues such as air, oil, or water leaks, ultimately resulting in reduced performance of the mechanical equipment. 1.4.4 Disassembly Methods for Commonly Used Components The disassembly of commonly used components should follow general disassembly principles, while also considering their specific characteristics and employing appropriate methods tailored to each component in order to achieve the intended purpose. 1. Disassembly of the Spindle Assembly To prevent reduced assembly accuracy due to improper disassembly, mark the relative positions of bearings, washers, tool housings, and spindles around the circumference during removal. After disassembling, group each bearing along with its corresponding inner and outer washers separately and store them in distinct locations—do not mix them up. Ensure that the workbench and surrounding area at the disassembly site remain clean, and immediately place all removed parts into oil to prevent rusting. When reassembling, be sure to reinstall them according to their original marked orientations. Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment

user_input: What are the steps for cleaning bearings using the hot oil method?
reference_contexts: ['Hot Oil Cleaning Method. For bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease, immerse them in hot motor oil heated to 100鈥?00掳C. Use pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away any oil contamination with a brush. When heated to 100鈥?00掳C, soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease will melt, allowing it to easily flush out of the bearing鈥檚 crevices. In some cases, simply shaking the bearing repeatedly in the oil is enough to dislodge the dirt and grime from between the gaps.', 'When cleaning the radial spherical ball bearings of old or imported electric motors, the balls, retainer, and inner ring should be carefully turned horizontally out of the outer ring before being immersed in hot oil. Similarly, when cleaning short cylindrical roller bearings, the rollers, retainer, inner ring, and outer ring must first be separated from one another.', 'When cleaning with hot oil, the oil temperature should not exceed 20掳C. If using an open flame for direct heating, be careful to prevent the oil from catching fire. The bearing should be suspended inside the oil pot鈥攊mmersing it completely at the bottom could cause overheating and reduce its hardness.']
reference: The hot oil cleaning method involves immersing bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease into hot motor oil heated to 100鈥?00掳C. The high temperature causes the hardened substances to melt, allowing them to be flushed out from the bearing's crevices. Use pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away oil contamination with a brush, or in some cases, simply shake the bearing repeatedly in the oil to dislodge dirt and grime. For specific bearing types like radial spherical ball bearings from old or imported electric motors, the balls, retainer, and inner ring must be carefully turned horizontally out of the outer ring before immersion. Similarly, for short cylindrical roller bearings, the rollers, retainer, inner ring, and outer ring should be separated first. Important precautions include ensuring the oil temperature does not exceed 20掳C, avoiding open flames to prevent fire, and suspending the bearing in the oil pot rather than immersing it at the bottom to prevent overheating and hardness reduction.
answer: For bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease, immerse them in hot motor oil heated to 100–200°C, using pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away contamination with a brush; shaking the bearing repeatedly in the oil can also dislodge dirt. For specific bearings like radial spherical ball bearings or short cylindrical roller bearings, separate their components before immersion. The oil temperature should not exceed 20°C, care must be taken to prevent the oil from catching fire if using an open flame, and the bearing should be suspended in the oil pot to avoid overheating.

Context:  
2. Bearing Cleaning (1) Hot Oil Cleaning Method. For bearings hardened by soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease, immerse them in hot motor oil heated to 100–200°C. Use pliers to grip the bearing and gently scrub away any oil contamination with a brush. When heated to 100–200°C, soft dry oil or rust-preventive grease will melt, allowing it to easily flush out of the bearing’s crevices. In some cases, simply shaking the bearing repeatedly in the oil is enough to dislodge the dirt and grime from between the gaps. When cleaning the radial spherical ball bearings of old or imported electric motors, the balls, retainer, and inner ring should be carefully turned horizontally out of the outer ring before being immersed in hot oil. Similarly, when cleaning short cylindrical roller bearings, the rollers, retainer, inner ring, and outer ring must first be separated from one another. When cleaning with hot oil, the oil temperature should not exceed 20°C. If using an open flame for direct heating, be careful to prevent the oil from catching fire. The bearing should be suspended inside the oil pot—immersing it completely at the bottom could cause overheating and reduce its hardness.

user_input: How should rolling bearings be inspected for defects?
reference_contexts: ['For rolling bearings, focus should be placed on inspecting the inner and outer raceways. The entire working surface must be smooth, free from defects such as cracks, micropores, dents, and peeling. Similarly, the surfaces of the rolling elements themselves should be flawless, with no cracks, micropores, or dents. Additionally, the retainer must remain intact, and all rivets should be securely fastened.', 'If clearance is detected between the inner and outer races of the bearing, avoid replacing it immediately鈥攊nstead, consider adjusting it through preloading to eliminate any increased clearance caused by wear, thereby enhancing its rotational accuracy.']
reference: Inspection of rolling bearings should focus on the inner and outer raceways, ensuring the entire working surface is smooth and free from defects such as cracks, micropores, dents, and peeling. The surfaces of the rolling elements must also be flawless, without any cracks, micropores, or dents. Additionally, the retainer should be intact with all rivets securely fastened. If clearance is detected between the inner and outer races, it is advised not to replace the bearing immediately; instead, consider adjusting it through preloading to eliminate increased clearance caused by wear, which enhances rotational accuracy.
answer: Rolling bearings should be inspected for defects through a process of disassembly, cleaning, and inspection, where after cleaning with kerosene and then gasoline, the cleaned components are stored to prevent dust from entering, and during assembly preparation, the surface shapes and dimensional accuracy of the parts are inspected to confirm they meet specifications.

Technical Preparation Before Equipment Maintenance Preparation for equipment maintenance involves two key aspects: technical preparation and production readiness. The technical preparation prior to maintenance is the responsibility of the lead technician, and its main tasks include pre-inspection planning and research, conducting the actual pre-inspection, and preparing comprehensive overhaul technical documentation. Meanwhile, production readiness before the overhaul is managed by personnel responsible for spare parts, materials, and tools, as well as the production planners from the maintenance unit. Their primary responsibilities encompass ordering, manufacturing, inspecting, and storing critical materials, spare parts, and specialized tools, gauges, and testing equipment—along with developing the overall maintenance production schedule. Pre-inspection survey preparation work To gain a comprehensive understanding of the specific condition of equipment degradation, schedule a shutdown inspection before the major overhaul—this is referred to as a pre-inspection. Types of Rolling Bearings 1) By the direction of the load borne by the bearing or according to the nominal contact angle Category (1) Radial bearings. Radial contact bearings primarily withstand radial loads. Well, some can handle smaller axial loads; angular contact radial bearings. The bearing can simultaneously handle both radial and axial loads. (2) Thrust bearings. Thrust angular contact bearings primarily handle axial loads. The bearing can also handle smaller radial loads; axial thrust bearings, however, are designed only to withstand axial loads. 2) Classified by the shape of the rolling element Rolling bearings can be classified into ball bearings and roller bearings. 3) Classified by Whether the Working Shaft Can Be Centered Rolling bearings can be classified into self-aligning bearings and non-self-aligning bearings. 4) Classification Based on Whether Clearance Can Be Adjusted Rolling bearings can be classified into bearings with adjustable clearance and those with non-adjustable clearance. 3. Selection of Rolling Bearing Types Selection principle: Match bearing characteristics with operating conditions. 1) Type Selection (1) Load conditions. If the bearing is subjected to axial loads, thrust bearings are typically selected; if the load is purely axial, For smaller loads, thrust ball bearings are re commended; if the pure axial load is significant, thrust roller bearings should be chosen. When the bearing is subjected to pure radial loads, deep groove ball bearings, cylindrica l roller bearings, or needle roller bearings are typically used. If the bearing handles both radial and moderate axial loads simultaneously, deep groove ball bearings, angular cont act ball bearings with small contact angles, or tapered roller bearings are suitable options. For situations involving heavier axial loads, angular contact ball bearings with large r contact angles or tapered roller bearings are ideal. Alternatively, a combined design—using both radial and thrust bearings—can be employed, with each type of bearing specificall y handling either the radial or axial load. (2) Rotational speed requirements. When high speed and precise rotation are needed, ball bearings should be used as the preferred option . (3) Self-aligning capability requirement: When the shaft is long (with low rigidity) or has multiple support points and requires bearings with self-aligning features, choose self -aligning bearings. (4) Load-carrying and shock-resistant capabilities. Use roller bearings when dealing with heavy loads or impact loads. (5) Space limitations. user_input: What preparations are needed before installing a rolling bearing?
reference_contexts: ['Before installation, prepare the necessary tools and measuring instruments.', 'Carefully inspect the surface dimensions of all parts that will be fitted with the bearing to ensure they meet the requirements specified in the drawings.', 'Then, clean these surfaces thoroughly with gasoline or kerosene, wipe them dry, and apply a thin layer of system lubricant oil (machine oil).']
reference: Before installing a rolling bearing, several preparatory steps must be taken. First, gather all necessary tools and measuring instruments required for the installation. Next, carefully inspect the surface dimensions of all parts that will be fitted with the bearing to ensure they conform to the specifications in the drawings. After inspection, thoroughly clean these surfaces using gasoline or kerosene, then wipe them dry. Finally, apply a thin layer of system lubricant oil, such as machine oil, to the cleaned surfaces to facilitate proper installation and initial lubrication.

Context:  
2.4.5 Clearance in Rolling Bearings and Its Adjustment The clearance in rolling bearings ensures proper operation of the rolling elements, facilitates lubrication, and accommodates thermal expansion. However, the clearance in rolling bearings must not be too large—or too small. If the clearance is excessive, it reduces the number of rolling elements simultaneously bearing the load, increasing the load on each individual element, which in turn shortens the bearing’s lifespan and compromises rotational accuracy, potentially leading to noise and vibration. On the other hand, if the clearance is too tight, it can easily cause overheating and accelerate wear, again negatively impacting the bearing’s longevity. Therefore, adjusting the clearance during bearing installation is an extremely critical task. There are three commonly used methods for adjusting rolling bearing clearance: the shim method, the screw adjustment method, and the combined adjustment method. 2.4.6 Preloading in Rolling Bearing Assembly Preloading refers to applying an axial load to the bearing during installation, inducing a slight pre-deformation between the rolling elements and the inner and outer rings, thereby enabling the bearing to operate with negative clearance. Preloading increases bearing stiffness, enhances rotational accuracy, and extends bearing life. The preload amount should be determined appropriately based on the bearing's load conditions and application requirements. Excessive preload, however, can increase bearing wear and heat generation, ultimately reducing the bearing's service life. Preloading paired angular contact bearings can enhance their operational stiffness. Common methods for controlling preload include adding metal shims, grinding down the raceways, or adjusting the widths of the inner and outer sleeves between the two bearings. 4) Classification Based on Whether Clearance Can Be Adjusted Rolling bearings can be classified into bearings with adjustable clearance and those with non-adjustable clearance.

reference: Gear transmission is a widely used power transmission method that operates through the meshing of gear teeth to transfer motion and power. Key characteristics include its ability to provide an accurate transmission ratio, accommodate a broad spectrum of power and speed levels, achieve high transmission efficiency, maintain a compact structure, and offer a long service life. However, it requires relatively high precision in manufacturing and assembly. Applications are diverse, with several types available: classifications include straight teeth, helical teeth, and herringbone gear drives, as well as cylindrical gears, bevel gears, and rack-and-pinion systems, among others, making it suitable for various mechanical and industrial uses.

The worm gear mechanism, a specific type, has characteristics including a high gear ratio, compact design, self-locking capability, smooth operation, low noise, but relatively low efficiency, higher friction, and significant heat generation, making it suitable for applications like speed reduction and lifting equipment.

2.5.1 Characteristics and Applications of Gear Transmission Gear transmission is one of the most commonly used methods of power transmission, relying on the meshing of gear teeth to transfer motion and power. It is characterized by its ability to ensure an accurate transmission ratio, handle a wide range of power and speed levels, achieve high transmission efficiency, maintain a compact design, and offer long service life—though gear transmissions do require relatively high precision in manufacturing and assembly. There are several types of gear transmissions, which can be classified in different ways into straight teeth, helical teeth, and herringbone gear drives. They can also be categorized into cylindrical gears, bevel gears, and rack-and-pinion gear systems, among others. 2.5.2 Failure Modes of Gear Drives and Preventive Measures
The basic requirements for gear transmission are that the installation position must be correct; the tooth side clearance must meet technical specifications; and the contact spot distribution should be uniform and properly positioned. Gear and shaft assemblies are mostly secured using keys. For gears subjected to axial forces, screws and retaining rings are used to prevent axial movement and ensure proper positioning on the shaft. When transmitting high torque, a transition fit with a larger interference fit is often employed to create a tight, static connection—this typically requires either press-fitting or thermal assembly methods. Here are several common types of errors that occur during the assembly of gears and shafts: 1. Loosening of the cylindrical gear shaft bore (1) Phenomenon: The gear and gear shaft are not tightly fitted together. (2) Cause analysis: The inner bore of the gear was machined incorrectly, resulting in a flared shape. (3) H azardous effects: During operation, lateral oscillation occurs, accelerating wear on both the hole and shaft. Additionally, significant vibration during operation leads to low tran smission efficiency. (4) Prevention and control measures: The internal bore of the gear should be re-machined, and the gear should be replaced if necessary.
2. Gear Runout (1) Phen omenon: The gear centerline does not coincide with the shaft centerline. (2) Cause analysis: Significant assembly dimension errors. (3) Hazardous Effects. When the equipment is run ning, radial runout occurs in the gear transmission. Additionally, the meshing tooth sections experience impacts and noise due to the continuous variation in pitch circle diameter.  If the eccentricity of the centerline exceeds a certain limit, jamming may occur, disrupting the smooth operation of the equipment. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: The gear t ransmission system must be assembled correctly, with all necessary inspections and adjustments performed. Special attention should be paid to ensuring proper alignment of the locat ing keys between the shaft and gears, as well as maintaining appropriate tightness. Any existing issues should be carefully addressed through repairs, and if needed, relevant compo nents should be replaced. Chapter 2: Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of General-Purpose Components
3. Gear Misalignment (1) Phenomenon: The gear becomes skewed when assembled on to the shaft. (2) Cause analysis: Rough and careless assembly; excessive dimensional errors in component machining. (3) Hazardous Effects: When gears are improperly aligned during  assembly on the shaft, end-face runout will occur during equipment operation. This leads to uneven loading between meshing gear pairs, resulting in excessive wear. (4) Prevention a nd Control Measures: Reassembly and adjustment should be performed. If the inspection confirms that the issue is indeed caused by excessive machining errors in the gear shaft bore,  the gear should be replaced. 4. Poor Gear Meshing Performance (1) Phenomenon: The gear was not properly seated against the shaft shoulder during assembly. (2) Cause analysis: The  transmission shaft end is too long; the gear lacks sufficient width during machining; the gear is incorrectly assembled. (3) Harmfulness. During gear assembly, the gears were not p roperly seated against the shaft shoulders, resulting in wide contact between the meshing gears along the axial direction. Meanwhile, the remaining portion of the tooth width exper ienced poor meshing, which further increased the load on those specific teeth. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: The position of the gear on the shaft must be accurately assembl ed according to standard requirements. For components with excessive dimensional deviations, necessary adjustments should be made. 5. Abnormal gear transmission (1) Phenomenon: Abn ormal gear transmission and difficult starting. (2) Cause analysis: The gear retaining key is loose; the gear tooth profile is non-standard or damaged; excessive assembly errors in  the gears; too much oil present.
2.5.5 Assembly and Adjustment of Bevel Gears The assembly of a bevel gear transmission mechanism is essentially similar to that of a cylindrical gear transmission mechanism, with the key difference being that the axes of the two gears intersect at the apex of a cone, forming a specified angle. Typically, the geometric position of the bevel gear axes is determined by the machining accuracy of the housing, while axial positioning relies on the back cone of the bevel gear as a reference. During assembly, the back-cone surfaces must align precisely to ensure proper gear alignment. Depending on whether the contact pattern shifts toward the tooth tip or root, the gear positions should be adjusted and repositioned along the axis accordingly. Axial positioning is usually achieved by shims placed between the bearing housings and the housing itself. Since bevel gears are designed for transmitting motion between perpendicular shafts, the machining of the two vertical bearing housing bores in the housing must strictly adhere to the specified technical requirements. 2.5.6 Assembly and Adjustment of Worm Gear Pair The worm gear mechanism is used to transmit motion and power between two perpendicular shafts, with an intersection angle of 90°. Its key transmission characteristics include: a high gear ratio, a compact design, self-locking capability, smooth operation, and low noise—but it suffers from relatively low transmission efficiency, higher friction, and significant heat generation, which limits the power it can handle, typically up to P ≤ 5 kW. The worm wheel gear ring is usually made from more expensive bronze, resulting in higher manufacturing costs, making this mechanism particularly suitable for applications like speed reduction and lifting equipment. Based on the shape of the worm, worm gear drives can be classified into cylindrical worm drives, globoidal worm drives, and bevel worm drives, with cylindrical worms being the most widely used.

user_input: What are the failure modes of gears?
reference_contexts: ['Gear failure modes include tooth fracture and surface damage failures, such as pitting, wear, and plastic deformation.']
reference: Gear failure modes are categorized into two main types: tooth fracture and surface damage failures. Surface damage failures include pitting, wear, and plastic deformation, which affect the gear's surface integrity and performance.
answer: Gear failure modes include tooth fracture and surface damage failures, such as pitting, wear, and plastic deformation.

Context:  
What are the common failure phenomena of gears? What are the associated hazards? How can these be prevented?  
Working Conditions Power is transmitted through tooth surface contact, with the two tooth surfaces meshing together in a motion that involves both rolling and sliding. The gear surface is subjected to alternating contact compressive stress and friction forces; the tooth root, meanwhile, experiences alternating bending stress. It will experience impact during engagement. Poor installation can lead to improper tooth surface contact. 2. Failure Modes Gear failure modes include tooth fracture and surface damage failures, such as pitting, wear, and plastic deformation. 1) Tooth fracture Classified by failure mechanisms, we have: fatigue fracture—occurs when a cantilever beam is subjected to fluctuating bending stresses or stress concentrations, causing fatigue cracks to propagate from the tensile side at the tooth root until final fracture; overload fracture—resulting from excessively high impact loads or short-term, severe overloading; and wear-induced fracture, where severe tooth wear reduces the gear's static strength, ultimately leading to failure. There are two forms of fracture in terms of morphology: complete fracture and partial fracture. From a design perspective, the gear teeth should undergo calculations to assess their root bending strength. From a manufacturing standpoint, increasing the radius of the fillet at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, and minimizing machining-induced damage on the tooth flank can all help enhance the tooth's resistance to fatigue failure. Additionally, improving the stiffness of the shaft and supports—and ideally eliminating any uneven distribution of loads—can significantly reduce the likelihood of localized tooth fractures. 2) Pitting corrosion
When gears are in operation, prolonged exposure to pulsating cyclic stresses can cause tiny metal flakes to detach, resulting in the formation of shallow pits. Phenomenon: Pitting typically occurs in well-lubricated, closed gear drives. The specific locations are usually near the pitch line, where relative sliding velocities are low, making it difficult to form a lubricant film. In spur gear drives, contact stresses are also relatively high, further increasing the likelihood of pitting. To reduce pitting, the following measures can be taken: From a design perspective, the gear should undergo calculations to ensure adequate tooth surface contact strength. From a manufacturing perspective, In terms of engineering, the tooth surface hardness should be increased, and its roughness reduced; appropriate modification should be employed; lubricants with higher viscosity should be used; and dynamic loads should be minimized.

user_input: What causes tooth fracture in gears and how can it be prevented?
reference_contexts: ["fatigue fracture鈥攐ccurs when a cantilever beam is subjected to fluctuating bending stresses or stress concentrations, causing fatigue cracks to propagate from the tensile side at the tooth root until final fracture; overload fracture鈥攔esulting from excessively high impact loads or short-term, severe overloading; and wear-induced fracture, where severe tooth wear reduces the gear's static strength, ultimately leading to failure.", "From a manufacturing standpoint, increasing the radius of the fillet at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, and minimizing machining-induced damage on the tooth flank can all help enhance the tooth's resistance to fatigue failure. Additionally, improving the stiffness of the shaft and supports鈥攁nd ideally eliminating any uneven distribution of loads鈥攃an significantly reduce the likelihood of localized tooth fractures."]
reference: Tooth fracture in gears can be caused by three primary mechanisms: fatigue fracture, which results from fluctuating bending stresses or stress concentrations leading to crack propagation from the tooth root; overload fracture, due to excessively high impact loads or severe short-term overloading; and wear-induced fracture, where significant tooth wear reduces static strength. Prevention strategies include design calculations for root bending strength, manufacturing improvements such as increasing the fillet radius at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, and minimizing machining damage. Additionally, enhancing the stiffness of shafts and supports, and ensuring even load distribution, can reduce the risk of localized fractures.
answer: Tooth fracture in gears is primarily caused by fatigue fracture from fluctuating bending stresses at the tooth root, overload fracture from high impact or severe short-term overloading, and wear-induced fracture from severe wear reducing static strength. It can be prevented by increasing the fillet radius at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, minimizing machining damage, improving shaft and support stiffness, and eliminating uneven load distribution.

Context:  
Working Conditions Power is transmitted through tooth surface contact, with the two tooth surfaces meshing together in a motion that involves both rolling and sliding. The gear surface is subjected to alternating contact compressive stress and friction forces; the tooth root, meanwhile, experiences alternating bending stress. It will experience impact during engagement. Poor installation can lead to improper tooth surface contact. 2. Failure Modes Gear failure modes include tooth fracture and surface damage failures, such as pitting, wear, and plastic deformation. 1) Tooth fracture Classified by failure mechanisms, we have: fatigue fracture—occurs when a cantilever beam is subjected to fluctuating bending stresses or stress concentrations, causing fatigue cracks to propagate from the tensile side at the tooth root until final fracture; overload fracture—resulting from excessively high impact loads or short-term, severe overloading; and wear-induced fracture, where severe tooth wear reduces the gear's static strength, ultimately leading to failure. There are two forms of fracture in terms of morphology: complete fracture and partial fracture. From a design perspective, the gear teeth should undergo calculations to assess their root bending strength. From a manufacturing standpoint, increasing the radius of the fillet at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, and minimizing machining-induced damage on the tooth flank can all help enhance the tooth's resistance to fatigue failure. Additionally, improving the stiffness of the shaft and supports—and ideally eliminating any uneven distribution of loads—can significantly reduce the likelihood of localized tooth fractures. (3) Hazardous consequences: Gear wear accelerates or causes breakage, leading to malfunction. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: If the gear key becomes loose, it should be securely re-tightened. If the tooth profile exceeds the allowable tolerance or is severely damaged, it should be properly repaired. If the gear assembly is improperly aligned, adjustments must be made.
3. Gear Misalignment (1) Phenomenon: The gear becomes skewed when assembled on to the shaft. (2) Cause analysis: Rough and careless assembly; excessive dimensional errors in component machining. (3) Hazardous Effects: When gears are improperly aligned during  assembly on the shaft, end-face runout will occur during equipment operation. This leads to uneven loading between meshing gear pairs, resulting in excessive wear. (4) Prevention a nd Control Measures: Reassembly and adjustment should be performed. If the inspection confirms that the issue is indeed caused by excessive machining errors in the gear shaft bore,  the gear should be replaced. 4. Poor Gear Meshing Performance (1) Phenomenon: The gear was not properly seated against the shaft shoulder during assembly. (2) Cause analysis: The  transmission shaft end is too long; the gear lacks sufficient width during machining; the gear is incorrectly assembled. (3) Harmfulness. During gear assembly, the gears were not p roperly seated against the shaft shoulders, resulting in wide contact between the meshing gears along the axial direction. Meanwhile, the remaining portion of the tooth width exper ienced poor meshing, which further increased the load on those specific teeth. (4) Prevention and Control Measures: The position of the gear on the shaft must be accurately assembl ed according to standard requirements. For components with excessive dimensional deviations, necessary adjustments should be made. 5. Abnormal gear transmission (1) Phenomenon: Abn ormal gear transmission and difficult starting. (2) Cause analysis: The gear retaining key is loose; the gear tooth profile is non-standard or damaged; excessive assembly errors in  the gears; too much oil present.
3. Gear Inspection After gears have operated for a period of time, tooth profile errors increase due to wear on the tooth surfaces, which ultimately affects their performance. Therefore, it is essential that the gear teeth remain intact, with no signs of extrusion deformation, cracks, or broken teeth. Additionally, wear on the tooth thickness should be kept within limits—not exceeding 0.15 times the module. In production, specialized gear thickness calipers are commonly used to check for deviations in tooth thickness, effectively controlling backlash by measuring the reduction in tooth thickness. Alternatively, a universal involute micrometer can be employed to assess variations in the length of the gear’s normal chord, ensuring precise gear motion accuracy. This method is simple and practical, making it widely adopted in manufacturing processes. Furthermore, the gear’s internal bore, keyways, splines, and threads must all meet standard specifications, with no instances of scoring or damage allowed. 2.5.3 Gear Maintenance and Repair The methods for gear repair are primarily determined based on the gear's failure mode, production technology conditions, and application requirements. For small to medium module gears, if spare parts are readily available, repairs are typically avoided in favor of replacing the gear entirely with a new one. However, when replacing gears, it’s generally recommended to swap them in pairs to ensure optimal meshing performance. If spare parts aren’t sufficient, large gears can be repaired using precision finishing techniques, while smaller gears are replaced altogether. For worn-out large-module gears, dimensional restoration can be achieved through spraying, followed by fine finishing of the tooth surfaces. In cases where large-module gears suffer from broken teeth or cracks, repair methods such as tooth insertion or weld patching are employed.

user_input: What causes pitting in gears and where does it typically occur?
reference_contexts: ['When gears are in operation, prolonged exposure to pulsating cyclic stresses can cause tiny metal flakes to detach, resulting in the formation of shallow pits.', 'Pitting typically occurs in well-lubricated, closed gear drives. The specific locations are usually near the pitch line, where relative sliding velocities are low, making it difficult to form a lubricant film.', 'In spur gear drives, contact stresses are also relatively high, further increasing the likelihood of pitting.']
reference: Pitting in gears is caused by prolonged exposure to pulsating cyclic stresses during operation, which leads to the detachment of tiny metal flakes and the formation of shallow pits. This phenomenon typically occurs in well-lubricated, closed gear drives. The specific locations where pitting appears are usually near the pitch line of the gears. This area is particularly susceptible because relative sliding velocities are low there, making it difficult to form an effective lubricant film. Additionally, in spur gear drives, contact stresses are relatively high in these regions, which further increases the probability of pitting occurring.
answer: Pitting in gears is caused by prolonged exposure to pulsating cyclic stresses and typically occurs in well-lubricated, closed gear drives, specifically near the pitch line where relative sliding velocities are low.

Context:  
When gears are in operation, prolonged exposure to pulsating cyclic stresses can cause tiny metal flakes to detach, resulting in the formation of shallow pits. Phenomenon: Pitting typically occurs in well-lubricated, closed gear drives. The specific locations are usually near the pitch line, where relative sliding velocities are low, making it difficult to form a lubricant film. In spur gear drives, contact stresses are also relatively high, further increasing the likelihood of pitting. To reduce pitting, the following measures can be taken: From a design perspective, the gear should undergo calculations to ensure adequate tooth surface contact strength. From a manufacturing perspective, In terms of engineering, the tooth surface hardness should be increased, and its roughness reduced; appropriate modification should be employed; lubricants with higher viscosity should be used; and dynamic loads should be minimized.
1.3.2 Corrosion of Metal Parts In the field of engineering, metal corrosion leads to enormous economic losses—estimates suggest that globally, steel and equipment scrapped annually due to corrosion account for approximately 30% of the world’s annual steel production. Corrosion is the process by which metals are damaged as a result of interactions with their surrounding environment, typically occurring when metal components undergo chemical or electrochemical reactions under specific environmental conditions. Corrosive damage always begins at the metal’s surface, gradually progressing inward—sometimes rapidly, sometimes more slowly—leading to material loss, degradation of surface quality, and even internal crystal structure damage. This ultimately results in irregularly shaped defects such as pits and spots, severely compromising the component’s integrity and eventually causing it to fail. Metal corrosion is broadly classified into two main categories based on its mechanism and underlying processes: chemical corrosion and electrochemical corrosion. Chemical Corrosion of Metal Parts Chemical corrosion of metals is caused by purely chemical reactions. When the surface material of a metal part interacts chemically with harmful components present in surrounding gases or non-electrolytic liquids, a corrosion layer forms on the metal surface. As this layer continuously flakes off and regenerates, the part gradually deteriorates. The primary harmful substances that react chemically with mechanical components include gases like O₂, H₂S, and SO₂, as well as certain corrosive byproducts found in lubricating oils. Among these, the chemical reaction between iron and oxygen is the most common form of chemical corrosion. Erosion, the process is as follows.
4Fe + 3O₂ → 2Fe₂O₃ 3Fe + 2O₂ → Fe₃O₄ Corrosion products such as Fe₂O₃ or Fe₃O₄ typically form a protective film that coats the metal surface. During friction, Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment 21 After the surface oxide film is worn away, the friction surface quickly reacts with the oxidizing medium, forming a new oxide layer that is subsequently removed during the friction  process. This cyclical process ultimately leads to metal corrosion. A key characteristic of oxidative wear is the presence of uniform, fine grooves aligned along the sliding direc tion on the friction surface, accompanied by reddish-brown flaky Fe₂O₃ or grayish-black filamentous Fe₃O₄ debris. Debris is generated. The primary factors influencing oxidative wea r are the density and integrity of the oxide film, as well as how firmly it adheres to the substrate. If the oxide film is dense, intact, free of pores, and strongly bonded to the  metal substrate, it exhibits excellent wear resistance, resists being worn away easily, and effectively helps prevent corrosion of the metal surface. 2. Electrochemical Corrosion o f Metal Parts Electrochemical corrosion is a complex physical and chemical process of corrosion. It can be defined as the continuous, charge-driven chemical corrosion that occurs w hen two metal electrodes with a potential difference are immersed in an electrolyte solution. This type of corrosion happens when metals come into contact with electrolytic substan ces, and its key distinction from ordinary chemical corrosion lies in the fact that it involves the flow of electric current during the process. The fundamental conditions necessar y for electrochemical corrosion to occur are: ① the presence of two or more objects with differing electrode potentials—or, within a single object, regions exhibiting different ele ctrode potentials—that act as positive and negative electrodes; ② a conductive pathway connecting the electrodes, either through a conductor or direct contact, allowing charges in  the corrosion zone to flow freely; and ③ the simultaneous presence of an electrolyte solution. Common forms of electrochemical corrosion include the following: (1) Uniform corrosio n. When a metal part or component exhibits a uniform corrosion pattern across its surface, it is referred to as uniform corrosion. This type of corrosion can occur in liquids, the  atmosphere, or soil. Among mechanical equipment, the most common form of uniform corrosion is atmospheric corrosion. In industrial areas, the atmosphere often contains higher conce ntrations of corrosive gases such as CO₂, SO₂, H₂S, NO₂, and Cl₂. Additionally, airborne dust particles may carry acidic, alkaline, or saline micro-particles, which, when adhering  to the surface of components, can absorb moisture from the air and form an electrolyte, ultimately leading to corrosion on the part's surface. (2) Pitting corrosion. On most surfac es of metal components, corrosion either doesn’t occur at all or is very mild; however, localized areas develop small corrosion pits that penetrate deeply into the material. This t ype of corrosion is known as pitting corrosion. Because metals used in industry often contain extremely tiny microelectrodes, they are highly susceptible to pitting corrosion when  exposed to aqueous solutions or humid environments. In the case of steel components, when pitting corrosion occurs alongside uniform corrosion, the corrosion spots can easily becom e obscured by the porous structure formed during uniform corrosion, making them difficult to detect and identify. As a result, pitting corrosion is one of the most dangerous forms  of corrosion. (3) Crevice corrosion. In机电 equipment, gaps exist between various connected components—typically ranging from 0.025 to 0.1 mm. When corrosive media enter these gaps a nd remain trapped, localized corrosion can occur precisely at the crevices. For instance, this type of crevice corrosion often happens at flange faces where pipes are connected, as  well as at the riveted joints of metal rivets. (4) Corrosion Fatigue. When metallic components subjected to cyclic stress experience reduced fatigue strength or shortened fatigue  life—and ultimately fail—due to the presence of a corrosive environment, this phenomenon is known as corrosion fatigue or corrosion fatigue fracture. Corrosion fatigue can cause me tal components to fracture even under very low levels of cyclic (pulsating) stress, and often there is no clear fatigue limit. As a result, damage caused by corrosion fatigue tends  to be more severe than that resulting from pure mechanical fatigue alone. To prevent and reduce corrosion failures, as well as minimize their harmful effects on equipment, special  attention must be paid during the manufacturing process to correctly selecting materials for components and thoughtfully designing various structural elements. Additionally, for p arts operating in corrosive environments, advanced anti-corrosion measures such as surface coating technologies, electrochemical protection techniques, and the addition of corrosio n inhibitors should be employed to ensure that these components remain protected—or at least minimally affected—by corrosive agents.
1. Load Distribution Pure axial load: Rolling elements are evenly loaded. Radial load: Uneven loading of rolling elements (loaded and unloaded zones). 2. Failure Modes of Rolling Bearings Pitting: Numerous pitting marks appear on the raceways of both the inner and outer rings, as well as on the surfaces of the rolling elements—primarily caused by improper loading, incorrect assembly (e.g., excessive interference fit or misalignment of the inner and outer rings), and inadequate lubrication. Plastic Deformation: Uneven plastic deformation pits appear on the rolling elements or raceway surfaces, primarily due to excessive static or impact loads. Other forms include abrasive wear, adhesive wear, fracture, rusting, electrochemical corrosion, and abnormal temperature rise, among others.
2.5.1 Characteristics and Applications of Gear Transmission Gear transmission is one of the most commonly used methods of power transmission, relying on the meshing of gear teeth to transfer motion and power. It is characterized by its ability to ensure an accurate transmission ratio, handle a wide range of power and speed levels, achieve high transmission efficiency, maintain a compact design, and offer long service life—though gear transmissions do require relatively high precision in manufacturing and assembly. There are several types of gear transmissions, which can be classified in different ways into straight teeth, helical teeth, and herringbone gear drives. They can also be categorized into cylindrical gears, bevel gears, and rack-and-pinion gear systems, among others. 2.5.2 Failure Modes of Gear Drives and Preventive Measures

user_input: What measures can be taken to reduce pitting in gears?
reference_contexts: ['To reduce pitting, the following measures can be taken: From a design perspective, the gear should undergo calculations to ensure adequate tooth surface contact strength.', 'From a manufacturing perspective, In terms of engineering, the tooth surface hardness should be increased, and its roughness reduced; appropriate modification should be employed; lubricants with higher viscosity should be used; and dynamic loads should be minimized.']
reference: Several measures can be implemented to reduce pitting in gears. From a design perspective, gears should undergo thorough calculations to ensure they have adequate tooth surface contact strength. From manufacturing and engineering perspectives, multiple approaches are effective: increasing the hardness of the tooth surface enhances its resistance to stress; reducing the surface roughness minimizes stress concentrations; employing appropriate modification techniques improves load distribution; using lubricants with higher viscosity helps maintain a protective film under low sliding velocity conditions; and minimizing dynamic loads reduces the cyclic stresses that contribute to pitting formation.
answer: To reduce pitting in gears, measures include ensuring adequate tooth surface contact strength through design calculations, increasing tooth surface hardness, reducing surface roughness, employing appropriate modification, using lubricants with higher viscosity, and minimizing dynamic loads.

Working Conditions Power is transmitted through tooth surface contact, with the two tooth surfaces meshing together in a motion that involves both rolling and sliding. The gear surface is subjected to alternating contact compressive stress and friction forces; the tooth root, meanwhile, experiences alternating bending stress. Poor installation can lead to improper tooth surface contact. 2. Failure Modes Gear failure modes include tooth fracture and surface damage failures, such as pitting, wear, and plastic deformation. 1) Tooth fracture Classified by failure mechanisms, we have: fatigue fracture—occurs when a cantilever beam is subjected to fluctuating bending stresses or stress concentrations, causing fatigue cracks to propagate from the tensile side at the tooth root until final fracture; overload fracture—resulting from excessively high impact loads or short-term, severe overloading; and wear-induced fracture, where severe tooth wear reduces the gear's static strength, ultimately leading to failure. There are two forms of fracture in terms of morphology: complete fracture and partial fracture. From a design perspective, the gear teeth should undergo calculations to assess their root bending strength. From a manufacturing standpoint, increasing the radius of the fillet at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, and minimizing machining-induced damage on the tooth flank can all help enhance the tooth's resistance to fatigue failure. Additionally, improving the stiffness of the shaft and supports—and ideally eliminating any uneven distribution of loads—can significantly reduce the likelihood of localized tooth fractures. 2) Pitting corrosion
